1 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Board of Trustees v. Davis


82-1078


Supreme Court of Ohio


2 Ohio St. 3d 108; 443 N.E.2d 166; 1982 Ohio LEXIS 770; 2 Ohio B. Rep. 658



December 29, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Relators, the Board of Trustees of Springfield Township, are appellants in an appeal presently pending before the Court of Appeals for Summit County in which they seek reversal of a decision by the court of common pleas ordering the Summit County Council to approve a petition seeking annexation of 272.7 acres of land to the city of Akron. The relevant facts which precipitated the instant action have been stipulated.

On June 1, 1979, property owners in an industrial-commercial area of Springfield Township, known as Gilchrist II, who desired their property be annexed to the city of Akron, filed a petition with the Summit County Council. After extensive litigation 1 and a public hearing, the annexation request was denied.


1 The Gilchrist II petition was one of four annexation petitions previously considered by this court in Holcomb v. Bd. of Commrs. (1980), 62 Ohio St. 2d 241 [16 O.O.3d 278].

Subsequently, the Gilchrist II petitioners appealed the decision of the Summit County Council to the court of common pleas in accordance with the provisions of R.C. 307.56 and 2506.01. That court concluded that council's decision denying the annexation was illegal, unreasonable,  [***2] arbitrary and against the manifest weight of reliable and probative evidence and, therefore, remanded the cause with instructions ordering the council to approve the petition and transmit all relevant annexation information to the clerk of the Akron City Council. See R.C. 2506.04. On May 4, 1982, relators appealed the order of the court of common pleas to the court of appeals. Relators, however, failed to request the court of common pleas to stay its judgment pending appeal, pursuant to Civ. R. 62(B). 2 


2 In pertinent part, Civ. R. 62 provides:

"(B) Stay upon appeal. When an appeal is taken the appellant may obtain a stay of execution of a judgment or any proceedings to enforce a judgment by giving an adequate supersedeas bond. The bond may be given at or after the time of filing the notice of appeal. The stay is effective when the supersedeas bond is approved by the court.

"(C) Stay in favor of the government. When an appeal is taken by this state or political subdivision, or administrative agency of either, or by any officer thereof acting in his representative capacity and the operation or enforcement of the judgment is stayed, no bond, obligation or other security shall be required from the appellant."

 [***3] Absent a stay, the annexation information was forwarded to the city clerk who, after waiting sixty days in accordance with the provisions of R.C. 709.04, presented the Gilchrist II petition to the Akron City Council on June 28, 1982, at which time council accepted the annexation under Ordinance No. 415-1982. Pursuant to R.C. 709.10, the ordinance was to become effective July 28, 1982.

On July 9, 1982, nearly two weeks after the passage of the ordinance, relators filed a motion in the court of appeals requesting the issuance of a stay, pursuant to App. R. 7, 3 in an attempt to enjoin the clerk of city council from authenticating, certifying or forwarding, and the county auditor and county clerk from accepting, recording and filing, the annexation documents. After conducting a hearing on the motion, the court of appeals declined to issue the stay on the basis that "* * * there is at this time [July 26, 1982] no act or proceeding which may be stayed pending resolution of this appeal."


3 In pertinent part, App. R. 7 (A) provides:

"Application for a stay of the judgment or order of a trial court pending appeal, or for the determination of the amount of and the approval of a supersedeas bond, must ordinarily be made in the first instance in the trial court. A motion for such relief or for an order suspending, modifying, restoring or granting an injunction during the pendency of an appeal may be made to the court of appeals or to a judge thereof, but, except in cases of injunction pending appeal, the motion shall show that application to the trial court for the relief sought is not practicable, or that the trial court has, by journal entry, denied an application, or failed to afford the relief which the applicant requested. The motion shall also show the reasons for the relief requested and the facts relied upon, and if the facts are subject to dispute the motion shall be supported by affidavits or other sworn statements or copies thereof. * * *"

 [***4] On July 27, 1982, relators initiated this action in mandamus contending that the provisions of R.C. 709.07 operate to deny their right to appeal the judgment of the court of common pleas and, as such, the statute is constitutionally defective. On that same day, we granted relators' request for an alternative writ restraining respondents from taking any action in furtherance of the annexation pending resolution of the subject cause.



DISPOSITION: Writ denied. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator Board of Trustees of Springfield Township (Ohio) initiated an action in mandamus against respondents, the county auditor and others, contending that the provisions of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 709.07 operated to deny their right to appeal the judgment of the court of common pleas and, as such, § 709.07 was constitutionally defective. Relator's request was also granted for an alternative writ restraining respondents regarding the annexation.


OVERVIEW: Relators had sought reversal of a court of common pleas' decision ordering the county council to approve a petition seeking annexation of land acreage to the City of Akron. The annexation was denied, but the order was challenged in the court of appeals and relators failed to request the court of common pleas to stay its judgment pending appeal under Ohio R. Civ. P. 62(B). Absent a stay, the annexation information was forwarded to the city clerk as required under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 709.04, a petition was presented, and the council accepted the annexation under an ordinance. Two weeks after the ordinance passage, a motion for a stay was requested and denied. The mandamus action began. The court denied the writ. Relators wrongly argued that the court of appeals constructed Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 709.07 as the sole avenue by which to preserve their appeal and that the construction denied relators an effective appeal. The court of common pleas properly held that because the city council passed the ordinance and the city officials had fully complied with Ohio Rev. Code ch. 709, there was no act or proceeding that remained to be stayed. Thus, the request for the stay was held moot.


OUTCOME: The court denied the writ of mandamus in favor of respondents.

 

2 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Clermont Environmental Reclamation Co. v. Wiederhold


82-280


Supreme Court of Ohio


2 Ohio St. 3d 44; 442 N.E.2d 1278; 1982 Ohio LEXIS 755; 2 Ohio B. Rep. 587; 13 ELR 20466



December 15, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Clermont County.

Appellees own and operate a hazardous waste disposal facility in Jackson Township, Clermont County. Appellee Clermont Environmental Reclamation Company acquired the site and operated it as a landfill prior to May 8, 1975.

On May 8, 1975, appellants, members of the Jackson Township Board of Trustees, adopted a zoning resolution for the township. Section A, Article IV of that resolution prohibits privately owned and operated landfills in Jackson Township.

In February 1979, appellants advised appellees that their facility violated Section A, Article IV of the zoning ordinance. Appellants ordered appellees to cease the violation. Subsequently, appellees initiated this action to enjoin the application of the zoning resolution to its site.

During the resulting litigation, the General Assembly passed Am. S.B. No. 269, effective October 9, 1980. That legislation amended R.C. Chapter 3734 relative to the transportation and disposal of hazardous wastes. Of particular importance to this case is the enactment of R.C. 3734.05(D)(3) which prohibits the regulation of properly licensed hazardous waste disposal facilities [***2] by political subdivisions of the state.

Appellees filed a motion for summary judgment arguing that as a result of R.C. 3734.05(D)(3) appellants' zoning resolution could not regulate hazardous waste facilities. The appellants argued that R.C. 3734.05(D)(3) is unconstitutional; hence, it cannot serve as a basis for judgment.

The trial court held that R.C. 3734.05(D)(3) was a "general law," that it had uniform operation throughout the state, and that such statute is constitutional and precludes application of the zoning ordinance. The court entered judgment for the appellees. Upon appeal, the court of appeals affirmed.

This cause is now before the court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellee facility initiated an action to enjoin the application of a zoning resolution that prohibited private ownership of hazardous waste facilities. Appellant city sought review of a decision by the Court of Appeals, Clermont County (Ohio) that granted summary judgment in favor of the facility on grounds that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3734.05(D)(3) prohibited the city from passing zoning resolutions to regulate hazardous waste facilities.


OVERVIEW: While the privately owned hazardous waste disposal facility was litigating a new law passed by the city, which prohibited privately owned facilities in that city, the legislature passed an amendment which prohibited the city from regulating such facilities. As a result of the amendment, the facility was granted its motion for summary judgment in the ongoing litigation. The city contended that the amendment to § 3734.05(D)(3) was unconstitutional in that it was a general law that it did not have uniform application and violated Ohio Const. art. II, § 26. The court held that the legislature could limit the application of a statute to a given class even if it resulted in the statute not operating in all geographic areas of the state, as long as the classification was reasonable and the statute operated equally among everyone in the given class. The court found that the legislature intended § 3734.05(D)(3) to have uniform application because it applied to all "political subdivisions" and was a reasonable enforcement of the state's police powers. As such, the amendment was constitutional and took precedence over conflicting state laws.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment in favor of the facility.

 

3 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Thompson v. Industrial Com. of Ohio


No. 81-1500


Supreme Court of Ohio


1 Ohio St. 3d 244; 438 N.E.2d 1167; 1982 Ohio LEXIS 736; 1 Ohio B. Rep. 265



August 18, 1982, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

In 1953 the General Assembly enacted R.C. 4123.412, which created the Disabled Workers' Relief Fund (DWRF). since its inception the DWRF has provided a subsidy to qualifying permanently and totally disabled recipients of workers' compensation. Generally speaking, disabled workers are eligible for a DWRF payment if their combined workers' compensation and Social Security disability benefits amount to less than a statutorily mandated base. R.C. 4123.412. The monthly subsidy received by an eligible worker is calculated by subtracting the sum of workers' compensation and social security from the statutory base (DWRF = Base - [WC + SS]). R.C. 4123.414.

DWRF subsidies were paid from the state's general revenues from 1953 to 1959. In 1959 the General Assembly provided, pursuant to R.C. 4123.411, for an employer payroll assessment to fund the DWRF. In 1975 the statute was amended to increase the payroll assessment. The amendment further provided:

"In the event the amount produced by the assessment is not sufficient to carry out such sections the additional amount necessary shall be provided from the [***2] income produced as a result of investments made pursuant to section 4123.44 of the Revised Code."

The transfer of investment income from the State Insurance Fund (SIF) to the DWRF began in March 1976. To date some $ 100 million has been transferred.

Appellee, C. Russell Thompson, commenced the instant litigation in the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County, in 1977, as a class action brought on behalf of all Ohio employers who are required to contribute to the SIF pursuant to R.C. 4123.29 and 4123.30. His complaint alleged that the transfer of SIF investment income to the DWRF authorized by R.C. 4123.411 was unconstitutional and sought an order prohibiting further transfers, the reimbursement of moneys previously transferred, and other relief. The parties stipulated to the facts and both sides entered motions for summary judgment. The court granted appellant's summary judgment motion whereupon appellee appealed to the Court of Appeals.

The Court of Appeals reversed the trial court and remanded the cause for further proceedings. The Court of Appeals held "that R.C. 4123.411, to the extent that it provides for paying into the DWRF income produced as a result of investing [***3] any portion of the SIF, which income has in turn been paid to the SIF, is in direct contravention of Article II, Section 35, of the Ohio Constitution." This holding was premised on the finding that "[o]nce the income is earned and paid * * * into the SIF, * * * the income becomes a part of the trust fund, and cannot be applied to any purpose other than that permitted by Article II, Section 35, of the Ohio Constitution." The court rejected appellee's alternative contention that DWRF payments violate the proscription against retroactive laws contained in Section 28, Article II of the Ohio Constitution. 

The cause is now before this court upon the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant commission challenged the decision of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which reversed the trial court's summary judgment in favor of the commission in appellee employer's class action regarding contribution to the State Insurance Fund.


OVERVIEW: The employer alleged that the transfer of the fund's investment income to the Disabled Workers' Relief Fund (DWRF) was unconstitutional. The appellate court held that Ohio Rev. Code § 4123.411 was in direct contravention of the state constitution. On review, the court reversed. The court found that the recipients of the DWRF subsidy, namely those permanently and totally disabled employees who had previously been awarded workers' compensation, were clearly members of the appropriate designated group. The court found that an insured had no claim on income earned from his premium payments, and the employer was not entitled to an automatic premium reduction by reason of the fund having made money on his money. The court determined that the employer had not been prejudiced insofar as the transfer of fund income to the DWRF resulted in lower DWRF assessments than he would otherwise have been required to pay. The court also found that the DWRF subsidy received by eligible disabled workers infused Ohio Const. art. II, § 35 with a meaningfulness that was fully consistent with the goals that prompted the initial approval of art. II, § 35.


OUTCOME: The reversal of the summary judgment in favor of the commission in the employer's action regarding contribution to the state insurance fund was reversed.

 

4 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Columbus v. New


No. 81-1389


Supreme Court of Ohio


1 Ohio St. 3d 221; 438 N.E.2d 1155; 1982 Ohio LEXIS 733; 1 Ohio B. Rep. 244



August 11, 1982, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

On August 23, 1980, appellee Chester Jackson was charged by affidavit with falsification in violation of Section 2315.08 of the Columbus City Code. The affidavit stated that "* * * on or about the 22 day of August 1980 [appellee] did knowingly make a false oral unsworn statement, to wit: that his name was Michael Patterson, to a law enforcement officer, to wit: Bryan Sperry * * * who was acting within the scope of his duties, to wit: investigating a stolen check complaint. * * *"

Appellee Ballard Gary New was charged on August 29, 1980, with violation of the same ordinance in that he, "* * * on or about the 19th day of July 1980 did knowingly make a false oral statement to wit: stated that his name was William Lewis Elkins to a law enforcement officer to wit: Off. Susan Lowe * * * who was acting within the scope of her duties to wit: investigating the crime of carrying a concealed weapon involving Ballard New and four companions. * * *"

In both cases, the respective trial court dismissed the charges upon motions by the appellees. Since the issues raised in both cases were the same, the cases were consolidated [***2] for appeal. The judgments were affirmed.

In pertinent part, the Court of Appeals held that "* * * C.C. 2315.08(B) is unconstitutionally overbroad and violative of the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution, as the ordinance does 'provide a strong impetus for the employment of coercive inquisition as a method of criminal investigation.'" In support of this holding, the court reasoned that there was "* * * no language within the ordinance capable of restrictive construction [and] [i]n order for this court to construe C.C. 2315.08(B) in a manner that would allow it to pass constitutional muster would require a complete rewriting of the ordinance."

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city sought review of the judgment of the Franklin County Court of Appeals (Ohio) that upheld the trial court's dismissal of charges against appellee defendants upon ruling that the falsification ordinance under which they were charged, Columbus, Ohio, City Code § 2315.08, was unconstitutionally overbroad and violative of the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments.


OVERVIEW: Two defendants were charged with giving false names to police officers, in violation of § 2315.08, which made it a crime to knowingly make a false, oral or written, sworn or unsworn, statement to a law enforcement officer acting within the scope of his duties. The common pleas court dismissed the charges upon finding the ordinance unconstitutional. The appellate court affirmed and a motion to certify the record was allowed. In affirming, the supreme court agreed that § 2315.08 did not pass constitutional muster under Ohio Const. art. I, § 16, and the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution. The ordinance was void for vagueness because it encouraged arbitrary enforcement and failed to give a person of ordinary intelligence fair notice of what was forbidden. It impermissibly gave police unfettered discretion and there was no language in the ordinance that would permit a restrictive construction to prevent it from being overbroad. Moreover, it impermissibly allowed for the employment of coercive inquisition as a method of criminal investigation in violation of the Fourth Amendment.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the appellate court dismissing defendants' charges upon finding the ordinance unconstitutional was affirmed.

 

5 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Pack v. Cleveland


No. 81-1109


Supreme Court of Ohio


1 Ohio St. 3d 129; 438 N.E.2d 434; 1982 Ohio LEXIS 719; 1 Ohio B. Rep. 166; 35 A.L.R.4th 1223



August 4, 1982, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant motion picture projectionists (projectionists) challenged the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed an order of the court of common pleas that held that the exemption under Ohio Rev. Code § 2907.35(C) of motion picture operators or projectionists from the operation of the obscenity statutes, Ohio Rev. Code §§ 2907.31, 2907.32, was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The court found that as the case involved an interpretation of a statute concerning trafficking of obscene materials, no First Amendment rights of free speech were involved. Because no fundamental right or suspect classification was involved, the test to determine whether Ohio Rev. Code § 2907.35(C) violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment was whether the classification it created bore a rational relation to a legitimate state interest served by the legislation. The fact that an employee projectionist was a union member and assigned to a given theater by way of union hall assignment did not justify the classification contained in § 2907.35(C). The continuance, or maintenance, of the existing contract arrangements between the projectionists' union and the various theaters did not rise to the status of a legitimate state interest. Thus, there was no legitimate state purpose that was served by the classification created in § 2907.35(C), and the court held that the exemption of motion picture projectionists from prosecution under Ohio Rev. Code §§ 2907.31, 2907.32, contained in Ohio Rev. Code § 2907.35(C), violated the Equal Protection Clause.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals affirming the order of the court of common pleas that found the obscenity statute's exemption for motion picture operators or projectionists was unconstitutional.

 

6 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Beckett Ridge Asso. No. I v. Butler County Bd. of Revision


81-892


Supreme Court of Ohio


1 Ohio St. 3d 40; 437 N.E.2d 601; 1982 Ohio LEXIS 699; 1 Ohio B. Rep. 74



July 14, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

Beckett Ridge Association No. I, appellant herein, is an Ohio not-for-profit corporation which owns and is responsible for the maintenance of 15 parcels of real estate designated as "common open space" within the Beckett Ridge planned unit development (PUD) in Butler County. The Beckett Ridge PUD is a large residential-commercial development with at least ten percent of the land space designated as a greenbelt or common open space. Appellant challenged the assessed values of the 15 parcels for the tax year 1977 by filing two complaints with the auditor of Butler County. The Butler County Board of Revision, appellee herein, combined the complaints for consideration and refused to reduce the assessed values.

On appeal, the Board of Tax Appeals reduced the assessed values of the subject parcels. The cause is now before this court on an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Decision reversed and cause remanded. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayer challenged the assessed values of certain of its property for a particular tax year by filing two complaints with the auditor of Butler County. Defendant, the Butler County Board of Revision, combined the complaints for consideration and refused to reduce the assessed values. On appeal, the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio) reduced the assessed values of the subject parcels. The taxpayer appealed.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer was a not-for-profit corporation. The land in question was 15 parcels of real estate designated as "common open space" within a planned unit development (PUD) located within the County. The taxpayer was responsible for maintaining the land. In reversing the decision of the Board of Tax Appeals, the court ruled that the Board erred when it adopted a valuation of the land that was supported only by an appraisal and which ignored the use restrictions, easements, zoning and other factors affecting the then land. The court ruled that under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5713.03 and Ohio Admin Code § 5705-3-07(A), (B), the county auditor was required to consider use restrictions, easements, zoning, and other factors that could reduce the value of the property. The court rejected the taxpayer's claim that taxation of the land constituted double taxation, in violation Ohio Const. art. XII, § 2, because the value of the common open space was already apportioned to the individual residential lots within the PUD.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the Board of Tax Appeals' decision and remanded the cause for further proceedings.

 

7 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Wilcox


81-977


Supreme Court of Ohio


70 Ohio St. 2d 182; 436 N.E.2d 523; 1982 Ohio LEXIS 663; 24 Ohio Op. 3d 284



June 16, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

On July 22, 1979, appellee, Moses J. Wilcox, and an accomplice, Jesse Custom, broke into and ransacked the home of Duane D. Dixon, an acquaintance of Custom. During the course of the burglary Dixon was shot to death. Custom was apprehended within hours of the discovery of the body and a warrant was issued for appellee. He was arrested several months later on an unrelated charge by Warrensville Heights police and then transferred to the Cleveland City Jail. While in jail, appellee made a statement (unchallenged on appeal to this court) regarding the Dixon burglary-homicide. In his statement appellee admitted his involvement in the break-in but implicated Custom as the triggerman.

On January 16, 1980, appellee was indicted for violations of R.C. 2903.01 (aggravated murder) and R.C. 2911.11 (aggravated burglary). On January 30, 1980, the Court of Common Pleas of Cuyahoga County upon motion, referred appellee to the court psychiatric clinic, pursuant to R.C. 2945.371 and 2945.39, for an evaluation to determine whether he was competent to stand trial and whether he was sane when the criminal acts occurred. The examining [***2] psychiatrist found appellee to be borderline retarded, schizophrenic, dyslexic, and to be suffering from organic brain syndrome and so testified at a March 1980 hearing. The court ruled that appellee was incompetent to stand trial and committed him to Lima State Hospital for treatment. In August 1980 appellee was again brought before the court and after a hearing the court determined that he was competent to stand trial.

A jury trial was held commencing August 18, 1980. Appellee entered a plea of not guilty by reason of insanity and at trial introduced psychiatric testimony with respect thereto. The trial court, however, refused to permit additional psychiatric testimony or charge the jury on the question of whether appellee's supposed diminished mental capacity precluded him from forming the specific intent to commit the offenses of aggravated murder and aggravated burglary. The jury rejected appellee's insanity defense and found him guilty on both counts. The court sentenced appellee to concurrent terms of life and 6-25 years for the murder and burglary offenses, respectively.

Appellee appealed to the Court of Appeals, which reversed the trial court in a split decision [***3] and ordered a new trial. The court held that "diminished capacity is a valid defense as tending to negate the elements of specific intent in particular crimes," and further held that the trial court's "refusal to permit testimony [or a special jury instruction] on the defense of diminished capacity constitutes reversible error." Judge (now Justice) Krupansky, dissenting, was satisfied that sufficient evidence of appellee's mental capacity was before the jury and that the requested special instruction was unwarranted.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of the decision of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio) holding that diminished capacity was a valid defense tending to negate elements of specific intent in certain crimes and that refusal to permit testimony regarding diminished capacity in defendant's criminal trial was reversible error.


OVERVIEW: In a trial for aggravated murder and aggravated burglary, defendant entered a plea of not guilty by reason of insanity. Psychiatric testimony regarding the plea was introduced; however, additional testimony regarding whether diminished capacity precluded the requisite specific intent for the offenses was refused. After defendant was sentenced for the offenses, the appellate court reversed, holding that diminished capacity was a valid defense negating specific intent for certain crimes and that the trial court's refusal to allow additional testimony was reversible error. Upon appeal, the court reversed, holding that since the defense of diminished capacity was not recognized in Ohio, defendant was not entitled to introduce psychiatric testimony, unrelated to his insanity defense, to show that defendant lacked specific intent for his offenses.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision holding that diminished capacity was a valid defense to negate defendant's specific intent for aggravated murder and aggravated burglary and that refusal to allow psychiatric testimony regarding defendant's diminished capacity was reversible error, since the diminished capacity defense was not recognized in Ohio.

 

8 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


National Mut. Ins. Co. v. Whitmer


81-1604


Supreme Court of Ohio


70 Ohio St. 2d 149; 435 N.E.2d 1121; 1982 Ohio LEXIS 658; 24 Ohio Op. 3d 248



June 9, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County.

The facts in this case are undisputed. On December 1, 1972, appellant Jack T. Whitmer was operating an automobile owned by his father, appellant Harold E. Whitmer, on a highway within Montgomery County. Vicki L. Butler was a passenger in that vehicle. A series of events, the precise nature of which is immaterial to the issues here considered, resulted in Whitmer's collision with an automobile operated by Connie K. Barnett and in a collision with a third vehicle operated by Scott C. Charlesworth, as a consequence of which Butler suffered extensive personal injuries.

On October 4, 1976, National Mutual Insurance Company (National), the appellee, as the insurer of Barnett, paid Butler (and her parents) the sum of $ 20,500 as compensation for her injuries and obtained a release 1 from the Butlers.


1 Inter alia, the release recited that the payment released any and all claims which the Butlers may have had against any person who might be liable as a result of the injuries which Vicki Butler sustained on December 1, 1972.

On March 21, 1977, National commenced an action for contribution against the Whitmers [***2] in the Court of Common Pleas. Ultimately, the case was heard by a referee of the court upon whose report and recommendation judgment was entered in favor of National. The court found that, as a result of its payment to the Butlers, National was subrogated to Barnett's right of contribution to the extent of the amount it had paid in excess of Butler's injuries as caused by the joint tort of Barnett and Whitmer.The court adopted the finding of its referee that Jack Whitmer was 60 percent responsible for those injuries and, accordingly, awarded judgment in favor of National for $ 12,300, i.e., the amount it had paid in excess of Barnett's proportionate share of her common liability with Whitmer.

Throughout the course of the litigation, the Whitmers objected to the proceeding because recovery on the claim would require an unconstitutional retroactive application of the Ohio Contribution Among Tortfeasors Act. 2 Their contention was predicated upon the fact that National paid the consideration for the release from the Butlers on October 4, 1976, three days following the effective date of the statutes upon which the company's claim for contribution was premised and some 46 months [***3] after the tort had been committed. 3


2 This issue was raised initially in a second amended answer to the complaint and thereafter in both a motion to dismiss the cause and a motion for summary judgment.


3 R.C. 2307.31 and 2307.32 became effective October 1, 1976.

An appeal, taken by the Whitmers, eventuated in an affirmance by the Court of Appeals which certified the record of the case to this court for review and final determination upon a finding that its judgment was in conflict with the determination of the Court of Appeals for Ross County in Acton v. Kroger Company (December 4, 1976), No. 685, unreported.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, an owner and a driver of a car involved in a collision, sought review of a decision of a trial court, which adopted the report and recommendation of its referee in favor of appellee, an insurer of a second driver of another vehicle involved in the collision, in the insurer's action for contribution against appellants. The Court of Appeals for Montgomery County (Ohio) affirmed but certified the record to the court for review.


OVERVIEW: A passenger in the driver's car was injured in the collision. The insurer made a payment to the passenger and her parents for her injuries and obtained a release. The trial court found that the insurer was subrogated to the second driver's right of contribution to the extent of the amount it had paid in excess of the passenger's injuries as caused by the joint tort of the second driver and the driver. Appellants contended that recovery on the claim would require an unconstitutional retroactive application of the Ohio Contribution Among Tortfeasors Act. In affirming the decision, the court held that the award of judgment to the insurer did not require any retroactive application of the Act because, under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 2307.31 and 2307.32, liability for contribution arose only in favor of a joint tortfeasor and then only when that tortfeasor had paid more than his proportionate share of the common liability. Thus, the obligation of appellants to their joint tortfeasor did not arise until the second driver had paid, through the insurer, an amount in excess of her proportionate share to discharge the common liability, which was made after the effective date of the Act.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the court of appeals' decision.

 

9 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Mills-Jennings of Ohio, Inc. v. Department of Liquor Control


81-760


Supreme Court of Ohio


70 Ohio St. 2d 95; 435 N.E.2d 407; 1982 Ohio LEXIS 647; 24 Ohio Op. 3d 181



May 26, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

On October 16, 1979, appellant Mills-Jennings of Ohio, Inc., filed a complaint in the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County seeking a declaratory judgment. The specific relief sought by appellant was a declaration by the court that certain devices, known as "Draw Poker" machines, were not gambling devices per se and that possession of the machines was not a violation of either the laws of Ohio or the regulations of the Liquor Control Commission. The complaint sought a permanent injunction enjoining the Department of Liquor Control, or any of its agents or employees, from seizing or confiscating Draw Poker machines owned by appellant and located in various liquor permit premises throughout Ohio. The complaint also sought to enjoin the Department of Liquor Control from interfering with the business of liquor permit premises based solely on possession of Draw Poker machines unless the machines were being operated in a way in which a monetary payoff or a payoff of any other tangible item of value was being made to the player. Appellant Walter Lazuka, owner of devices known as "TV Draw Poker" machines, was granted leave [***2] to intervene as a new party plaintiff and requested relief similar to that of appellant Mills-Jennings.

The Draw Poker machine in question is an electronic video-game controlled entirely by a computer called a microprocessor. The computer takes the place of a person who would otherwise serve as the dealer in a game of draw poker. In order to activate the machine for play, a player inserts from one to eight quarters into the machine. The player then pushes a button denoted as "draw" and by random selection, five cards appear on the screen. The player has the option of keeping all five cards or any one or more of them. When the player has decided which cards to keep, he then presses the "discard" button, eliminating from the screen the cards the player does not wish to keep. The cards discarded are then replaced with new and different cards and this ends the game. If the player chooses not to discard any cards and wishes to "stand" on the original five cards dealt by the machine, the player simply pushes the "stand" button and this also ends the game.

The purpose of the game is to get the best poker hand possible. When a winning hand appears the player is awarded a free replay or [***3] replays depending on the value of the hand. These replays are called "skill points" and the number of skill points awarded are multiplied by the number of quarters inserted. If a player's winning hand was a "straight" worth five skill points and the player had inserted eight quarters, the player would be awarded 40 skill points. Likewise a player can win up to 400 free replays on one play if the player obtains a "straight flush" after having inserted eight quarters. Once the game has begun the player cannot increase his bid by inserting more quarters.

After an extended trial, the Court of Common Pleas, on July 9, 1980, issued a permanent injunction granting the relief sought by appellants. Upon appeal, the Court of Appeals reversed the judgment of the trial court and "remanded to the trial court for further proceedings consistent with law and our opinion."

The cause in now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment accordingly. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant game owner was granted a permanent injunction enjoining appellee Department of Liquor Control from seizing or confiscating draw poker machines located in various liquor permit premises throughout the state. The trial court had declared that the poker machines were not gambling devices. The Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio) reversed the ruling and the game owner appealed.


OVERVIEW: The court found that pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2915.01(D), poker was a game of chance and pursuant to § 2915.01(F)(3), a gambling device was an apparatus designed for use in connection with a game of chance. Affirming the appellate court ruling, the court held that the draw poker machines were within the statutory definition of gambling devices. The court declined to decide other issues raised by the game owner in the trial court but not ruled upon by the lower courts. The court remanded the case to the trial court for a determination of whether Ohio Admin. Code 4301:1-1-53(B) authorized the liquor control department to confiscate and destroy the draw poker machines seized from liquor permit premises.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court, finding that the draw poker machines were gambling devices per se and remanded the issue of the liquor control department's authority to seize the machines to the trial court.

 

10 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Taylor v. Whitehead


No. 81-1487


Supreme Court of Ohio


70 Ohio St. 2d 37; 434 N.E.2d 732; 1982 Ohio LEXIS 636; 24 Ohio Op. 3d 88



May 5, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Greene County.

The subject property involved in the dispute is approximately four acres of land in Xenia Township, Greene County, owned by William S. and Glenna M. Carl. They purchased the land in April 1977, and subsequently leased it to Express Transport Company for use as a trucking business.

The area was zoned "A-1, Agriculture" at the relevant times when the Carls purchased the land and obtained a building permit for a trucking terminal, and the trucking business commenced operation. In June 1978, to ensure the continued operation of the business, the Carls applied for a change in classification with the Xenia Township Zoning Commission.

On July 5, 1978, the state, on behalf of Francis M. and Sandra J. Taylor, appellants herein, initiated this action by filing a petition against Paul Whitehead, Zoning Inspector, the Carls, the members of the zoning commission and the members of the board of township trustees, appellees herein. The petition sought, inter alia, a writ of mandamus to enforce the existing agricultural classification, a writ of prohibition against acting on the Carls' application for a change in the [***2] zoning classification, and an injunction to prevent the continued operation of the trucking business. In their answer, the Carls contended that the trucking business was exempt as a public utility under R.C. 519.21.

Subsequently, in October 1978, the board of township trustee approved the application for a change in zoning to accommodate the trucking business. The zoning classification was changed to "B-3, Highway Business."

The first issue the trial court considered was whether the trucking business was a public utility, and, thus, exempt from local zoning regulations. Following a hearing, the court determined that Express Transport was a public utility. 1 


1 Although the petition included an allegation that the trucking business constituted a nuisance, the appellants voluntarily dismissed it, without prejudice, prior to a hearing. Thus, it is not an issue in this appeal.

On appeal, the appellants did not challenge this determination. 2 Instead, they argued that neighboring landowners have a property right in the zoning classification subject only to the lawful change in the classification. The court affirmed the trial court and held that local zoning ordinances [***3] are not applicable to public utilities and, thus, no unlawful action had occurred.


2 Appellants did not brief the proposition that the trucking business should not be considered a public utility for purposes of the statutory exemption because, unlike other utilities or railroads, it does not have the power of eminent domain and the service rendered has no relation to the neighboring land. Therefore, it was not considered in this case.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, the State of Ohio on behalf of several residents, sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Greene County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's decision for appellees, a zoning inspector, property owners, and members of the zoning commission and of the board of township trustees, and held that local zoning ordinances were not applicable to public utilities.


OVERVIEW: The property owners leased their land for use as a trucking business when it was zoned for agricultural use. In response to the State's petition seeking to enforce the agricultural classification, the trial court found for appellees and held that the trucking business was a public utility and exempt from zoning regulations. Appellants did not challenge that determination but argued that neighboring landowners had a property right in the zoning classification subject only to the lawful change in the classification. Seeking further review, appellants contended that the use of land by a public utility not possessing the power of eminent domain, in violation of township zoning regulations, was an unconstitutional taking without compensation of neighboring property owners' right of enjoyment. Affirming the judgment, the court held that the zoning classification imposed was irrelevant because public utilities were exempt according to Ohio Rev, Code Ann. § 519.21. Appellants' allegations did not constitute a taking because they did not satisfy the degree of interference or injury required by Ohio law to establish a taking. Diminution of the property value was not itself a taking.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court sustaining the decision of the trial court for appellees.

 

11 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Lilliock


No. 81-817


Supreme Court of Ohio


70 Ohio St. 2d 23; 434 N.E.2d 723; 1982 Ohio LEXIS 634; 24 Ohio Op. 3d 64



March 28, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Licking County.

On February 29, 1980, William R. Lilliock, defendant, appellee herein, was apprehended while driving his 1975 Ford Econoline van on Interstate 70 in Franklin County. Defendant's vehicle matched the description of a van connected with a reported breaking and entering of a truck which occurred earlier at a truck stop in Licking County near Duke's Inn Motel. Defendant voluntarily drove back to the truck stop, and executed a written consent to a search of his vehicle. In addition to various snack food items, office equipment was found in the van and subsequently identified as property stolen from an office located in Duke's Inn. Defendant was charged with breaking and entering (in connection with the snack foods) and receiving stolen property (the office equipment). Following acquittal on the former charge, and conviction on the latter, he was sentenced to two to five years imprisonment.

On August 26, 1980, one day after judgment entry, the state filed an application with the trial court under R.C. 2933.41 for disposition of defendant's van, which had been seized and impounded by the sheriff's department. The [***2] court thereafter declared the van forfeited and ordered ownership of the van transferred to the Licking County Commissioners. 1 


1 Presumably, the van would be available for use by the sheriff's department in undercover work, such a need being stated in the application for disposition of property filed by the Licking County Prosecutor's Office.

Defendant appealed both his conviction and forfeiture to the Court of Appeals, which affirmed the conviction, but vacated the forfeiture in a split decision, finding the van not subject to forfeiture under R.C. 2933.41. The court ordered title restored to defendant.

The cause is now before this court upon the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was convicted of receiving stolen property. Following the conviction, the State filed an application pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2933.41 for disposition of the defendant's van, which had been impounded by the sheriff's department. The Court of Appeals (Ohio) vacated the order of forfeiture finding that the van was not subject to forfeiture under § 2933.41. The State appealed the order.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was apprehended while driving his van, which matched the description of a vehicle connected with a reported breaking and entering of a truck. A subsequent search of defendant's van revealed various snack items and office equipment identified as property stolen from an office near the location where the truck was broken into. Upon review, the court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals. The court found that § 2933.41 required that the property at issue had to be used by the offender in the commission of an offense, and it had to be unlawful for the offender to possess the property. Neither of the requirements was fulfilled by defendant's actions. Defendant received the stolen property when he paid an accomplice for the items. The commission of the offense, in terms of § 2933.41, occurred before the items were placed in defendant's van. As to the second requirement, there was nothing in the nature of the van that would have deemed it unlawful for defendant to possess it. The court found that there was no relation between the loss of defendant's right to possess the van and any legitimate state interest.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the court of appeals was affirmed.

 

12 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Covington v. Lyle


No. 81-575


Supreme Court of Ohio


69 Ohio St. 2d 659; 433 N.E.2d 597; 1982 Ohio LEXIS 625; 23 Ohio Op. 3d 535



March 9, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Miami County.

The village of Covington ("village"), appellant, charged, William E. Lyle, appellee, with unlawfully reporting his auto as stolen in violation of a village ordinance (a misdemeanor). The village, which employs the "statutory form" of government under R.C. Title 7, prosecuted appellee in the Mayor's Court of the village. Appellee entered a plea of not guilty. The mayor, however, found appellee guilty as charged after a trial in which appellee presented a defense and witnesses.

Appellee appealed that decision to the Miami County Municipal Court. The Municipal Court sustained appellee's motion to dismiss. The Court of Appeals affirmed that decision and held that the trial to the mayor, acting as both judge and chief executive officer, violated appellee's constitutional right to due process.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant village appealed from an order of the Court of Appeals of Miami County (Ohio), affirming the order of the Miami County Municipal Court, which granted appellee resident's motion to dismiss. The village challenged the appellate court's determination that the resident's trial and conviction in the village mayor's court for unlawfully reporting his car stolen in violation of a village ordinance, violated the resident's due process rights.


OVERVIEW: The village charged the resident with a misdemeanor. The resident was prosecuted in the village mayor's court. The resident pleaded not guilty. However, the mayor found the resident guilty as charged after he conducted a trial in which the resident was allowed to present his defense and various witnesses. The trial court granted the resident's motion to dismiss. The appellate court affirmed the judgment of the trial court because the resident's right to due process had been violated. The court reversed the judgment of the appellate court because the structure of the statutory form of the village's government did not violate the resident's right to due process of law under the Ohio Constitution or the United States Constitution. Moreover, the village mayor did not have a direct or indirect personal or official substantial pecuniary interest in reaching a determination that was against the resident's interest. The court concluded that the opportunity for review of the legal issues and facts of the particular case enhanced the credibility of the mayor's court system.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the appellate court that affirmed the order of the trial court, which granted the resident's motion to dismiss the village's action against the resident for unlawfully reporting his automobile stolen.

 

13 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Swetland v. Kinney


No. 81-1250


Supreme Court of Ohio


69 Ohio St. 2d 567; 433 N.E.2d 217; 1982 Ohio LEXIS 616; 23 Ohio Op. 3d 479



March 3, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

This is an action in mandamus originating in this court. Relator, David W. Swetland, d.b.a. Park Investment Company, contends Amended Substitute House Bill No. 50 (Am. Sub. H.B. No. 50), enacted pursuant to authorization contained in Section 2a, Article XII of the Ohio Constitution, is unconstitutional and void because it defines "preceding year" in a manner which conflicts with the meaning of that term in Section 2a, Article XII. Relator asserts the General Assembly exceeded the grant of authority contained in Section 2a, Article XII, by enacting Am. Sub. H.B. No. 50, and he therefore requests this court to issue a writ of mandamus directing respondent, Robert R. Kinney, Commissioner of Tax Equalization, to compute the tax reduction factors provided in R.C. 319.301 without reference to Am. Sub. H.B. No. 50.

In November of 1980 the voters of Ohio approved an amendment to the Ohio Constitution which resulted in the addition of Section 2a to Article XII. Section 2a, Article XII, provides in relevant part:

"* * *

"(C) Notwithstanding Section 2 of this article, laws may be passed that provide all of the following:

"(1) Land and improvements [***2] thereon in each taxing district shall be placed into one of two classes solely for the purpose of separately reducing the taxes charged against all land and improvements in each of the two classes as provided in division (C)(2) of this section. The classes shall be:

"(a) Residential and agricultural land and improvements;

"(b) All other land and improvements.

"(2) With respect to each voted tax authorized to be levied by each taxing district, the amount of taxes imposed by such tax against all land and improvements thereon in each class shall be reduced in order that the amount charged for collection against all land and improvements in that class in the current year, exclusive of land and improvements not taxed by the district in both the preceding year and in the current year and those not taxed in that class in the preceding year, equals the amount charged for collection against such land and improvements in the preceding year. * * *"

Pursuant to the authorization contained in this amendment the General Assembly enacted Am. H.B. No. 1238, effective December 19, 1980. Am. H.B. No. 1238 amended R.C. 319.30 and 319.301 to provide that the percentage reduction for real property [***3] taxes calculated according to these sections, commonly referred to as the "tax reduction factor," should henceforth be computed separately for each of the two classes of real estate created by the constitutional amendment.

The procedure for calculating the tax reduction factor in light of the addition of Section 2a to Article XII was further clarified through the enactment of Am. Sub. H.B. No. 50, effective October 12, 1981. Am Sub. H.B. No. 50 states in pertinent part:

"Section 1. (A) * * * for purposes of making the computations under Section 319.301 of the Revised Code for the voted taxes levied for the 1981 tax year only, 'preceding year,' as provided in division (D)(1) of such section, means the year immediately preceding the first reappraisal or any countywide adjustment thereto in which the sums levied against all real property by any voted tax were first reduced by a percentage in order that they would have levied the same number of dollars in that current year, exclusive of any sums levied against improvements added to the tax list since the year preceding that current year, as were charged against the same real property in the year preceding the current year.

 [***4] "(B) For purposes of making such computations:

"(1) 'Tax levied for the first time' means a voted tax levied for the first time, either in the year of or in any year after, the year immediately preceding the first reappraisal or any countywide adjustment thereto in which the sums levied against all real property by any voted tax were first reduced by a percentage in order that they would have levied the same number of dollars in that current year, exclusive of any sums levied against improvements to the tax list since the year preceding that current year, as were charged against the same real property in the year preceding that current year. A voted tax that is a renewal of an existing tax is not a tax levied for the first time.

"(2) 'Preceding year,' with respect to a tax levied for the first time, means the year in which the voted tax was levied." (Emphasis added.)

Relator maintains the above definition of "preceding year" renders Am. Sub. H.B. No. 50 unconstitutional because it defines that term differently than the constitutional amendment it was intended to effectuate. As stated by the relator in his complaint:

"Amended Substitute House Bill No. 50 is unconstitutional [***5] and void in that it defines 'preceding year' as contained in Ohio Revised Code Section 319.301 to be a year other than the actual year preceding 1981 whereas Article XII, Section 2a would require that the year preceding 1981 be 1980."

Therefore, relator urges this court to issue a writ of mandamus compelling respondent to calculate the tax reduction factors pursuant to R.C. 319.301 without regard to Am. Sub. H.B. No. 50.



DISPOSITION: Writ denied. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator, an individual doing business as an investment company, sought a writ of mandamus compelling respondent Commissioner of Tax Equalization to calculate the tax reduction factors pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 319.301 without regard to Amended Substitute House Bill No. 50, which was enacted under authority of Ohio Const. art. XII, § 2a.


OVERVIEW: The challenged bill was an attempt to eradicate the inadequacies of the existing tax reduction system, which unfairly burdened residential and agricultural real property owners. The individual claimed the bill was unconstitutional and void because it defined "preceding year" in a manner conflicting with Ohio Const. art. XII, § 2a. The court denied the individual's request for mandamus relief. The law was presumed constitutional, and the individual failed to show beyond a reasonable or rational doubt that the bill and Ohio Const. art. XII, § 2a were clearly incompatible. In addition, the court concluded that the general assembly's definition of "preceding year" in the bill unquestionably furthered the intent of art. XII, § 2a, which was to ensure equality of treatment of real property owners.


OUTCOME: The court denied the relator a writ of mandamus.

 

14 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Queensgate Inv. Co. v. Liquor Control Com.


No. 81-633


Supreme Court of Ohio


69 Ohio St. 2d 361; 433 N.E.2d 138; 1982 Ohio LEXIS 587; 23 Ohio Op. 3d 337



February 24, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

Queensgate Investment Co., appellant, owns and operates a high-rise motel in downtown Cincinnati, Ohio, and is holder of Liquor Permit D-5A-6, 7137983-0005. The permit covers the entire premises of the motel, including is discotheque located on the top floor called "Lucy's in the Sky."

Appellant wrote and published a monthly newsletter entitled "Skywriting." The August 1978 edition of the newsletter contained two items which advertised drinks at special prices. Specifically, one item referred to "LUCY'S PERPETUAL NOTION - The Drink Exchange." The promotion would permit a customer of the restaurant to obtain a drink in the discotheque "for only 50 ," and then upon returning to the restaurant the next day receive the same price: "[s]avor lunch in the dining room daily and you're rewarded not only with fine food, but you can get two drinks a day for only $ 1.00, 'cause SOMEBODY UP THERE LIKES YOU!'" (Sic. ) The other item advertised a "COY BACON BEING TRADED PARTY" at which drinks would be sold for 79 cents.

The newsletter had been published for approximately one year and was distributed on the permit premises [***2] and was also mailed to members of appellant's club. The mailings occurred on the second Friday of each month.

The Ohio Liquor Control Commission, appellee, alleged that appellant committed three violations of Ohio Adm. Code 4301:1-1-44 1: that appellant "did advertise the retail price of alcholic (sic) beverage in a circular off of permit premises," "did advertise a price advantage for alcoholic beverage in a circular off of permit premises," and "did advertise in a circular off of permit premises." All three violations were alleged to have occurred on August 14, 1978.


1 Ohio Adm. Code 4301:1-1-44 provides, in pertinent part: "4301:1-1-44 Advertising

"No alcoholic beverages shall be advertised in Ohio except in the manner set forth in 4301:1-1-03 and as hereinafter provided.

"(A) As to advertising on the premises, holders of Class C, D, and G permits shall not advertise the price per bottle or drink of any alcoholic beverage, or in any manner refer to price or price advantage except within their premises and in a manner not visible from the outside of said premises.

"(B) Manufacturers and distributors of alcoholic beverages are permitted to advertise their products in Ohio.

"Holders of Class C, D, and G permits shall be authorized to advertise in newspapers of general circulation, radio and television, on bill boards, calendars, in or on public conveyances and in regularly published magazines. Advertising may include the retail price of the original container or packages, but such advertising may not in any manner refer to price advantage.

"Subsequent enactment of law by the 102nd Ohio General Assembly prohibits the advertising of the retail price of beer in any media. See Page 6, Section 4301.211 of the Revised Code of Ohio."

 [***3] On November 29, 1978, a hearing was held before appellee. Appellee found appellant to be in violation of Ohio Adm. Code 4301:1-1-44 and, subsequently, imposed a seven-day suspension of appellant's liquor permit.

Appellant filed an appeal of the suspension order to the Court of Common Pleas of Hamilton County pursuant to R. C. 119.12, asserting that the order was not supported by reliable, probative, and substantial evidence, and was not in accordance with law. The Court of Common Pleas reversed and vacated appellee's order and entered judgment in favor of appellant. Upon appeal to the Court of Appeals, the trial court's judgment was reversed.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant restaurant owner sought review of the decision of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which reversed a common pleas court ruling in its favor and affirmed the decision of the Ohio Liquor Control Commission that the restaurant owner had engaged in prohibited advertising in violation of Ohio Admin. Code 4301:1-1-44 warranting suspension of the restaurant owner's liquor permit for seven days.


OVERVIEW: The restaurant owner operated a night club and restaurant. The restaurant owner had a liquor permit. The restaurant owner circulated flyers advertising drink specials. The commission brought proceedings against the restaurant owner for violating Ohio Admin. Code 4301:1-1-44, which gave the commission control over advertising of alcoholic beverages. The court of common pleas reversed the commission's decision and the court of appeals again reversed, affirming the commission's decision to suspend the restaurant owner's permit for seven days. On appeal, the court affirmed, holding that the commission had been given the authority by the Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4301.03 to adopt regulations governing advertisement of alcoholic beverages. The court also held that the rule did not violate the First Amendment of the United States Constitution. Although protected by the First Amendment, the lawful commercial speech here was legitimately regulated to serve the important governmental interest of discouraging consumption of alcoholic beverages, and the regulation itself was not overly extensive. Thus, the regulation satisfied the test concerning regulation of commercial speech.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the court of appeals, which reversed the common pleas court and reinstated the decision of the commission suspending the restaurant owner's liquor permit for seven days due to the unlawful circulation of the flyers advertising drink specials.

 

15 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Scott


No. 81-136


Supreme Court of Ohio


69 Ohio St. 2d 439; 432 N.E.2d 798; 1982 Ohio LEXIS 598; 23 Ohio Op. 3d 390



February 24, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Greene County.

Randy Scott ("appellant") met an undercover agent at a lounge bar in Fairborn at approximately 9:00 p.m. on September 4, 1979. The agent and appellant had previously discussed drug sales. Appellant told the agent that he could get some "speed" 1 for him. The agent said that he wanted to make a purchase. They traveled together in the agent's car first to another lounge bar in Fairborn and later to appellant's home, 318 Wallace Drive in Fairborn.


1 "Speed" is a vernacular term for amphetamines, which are controlled substances under R.C. Chapter 2925.

Appellant said that he could not quote a price until he saw what his source had available. He entered 308 Wallace Drive and returned to the car to tell the agent that his source had 12 robin eggs of "speed" for $ 2 per tablet. He brought 12 white oblong tablets with blue specks to the car. The agent visually inspected the tablets. Appellant received $ 24 from the agent and took the money to the girl who provided him with the tablets.

Analysis demonstrated that the tablets did not contain a controlled substance.

Both parties stipulated to these facts,  [***2] as clarified by appellant in response to questioning by the court.

After the Greene County grand jury indicted appellant under R.C. 2925.03(A)(1), the Court of Common Pleas accepted appellant's plea of no contest and found him guilty, based upon the stipulated facts and appellant's testimony. The Court of Appeals unanimously affirmed and held that: (a) appellant knowingly offered to sell a controlled substance, and

(b) R.C. 2925.03(A)(1) is clear and not unconstitutionally vague.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Greene County (Ohio), which affirmed defendant's conviction for violating Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2925.03(A)(1) by knowingly offering to sell a controlled substance. Defendant argued that the trial court judgment was erroneous because he did not actually transfer a controlled substance.


OVERVIEW: Defendant told an undercover officer that he could get some "speed" for him. They went to defendant's house, where he sold the officer 12 tablets of what he claimed was speed. The tablets did not contain a controlled substance, but defendant was charged with and pleaded no contest to knowingly offering to sell a controlled substance. The common pleas court accepted defendant's plea and found him guilty based on the facts and his testimony. The appellate court affirmed the conviction and held that § 2925.03(A)(1) was clear and not unconstitutionally vague. On appeal, the court found that the proscribed conduct of § 2925.03(A)(1) was offering to sell a controlled substance, not offering the controlled substance, and that by using the phrase "offer to sell" in the disjunctive with "sell" throughout the statute, the legislature expressly and properly prohibited defendant's conduct as a form of trafficking in drugs. The court concluded that § 2925.03(A)(1) was not unconstitutionally vague because all the Due Process Clause required was that the law give sufficient warning that men might conduct themselves so as to avoid that which was forbidden.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for offering to sell a controlled substance.

 

16 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Johnson's Island, Inc. v. Board of Township Trustees


81-95


Supreme Court of Ohio


69 Ohio St. 2d 241; 431 N.E.2d 672; 1982 Ohio LEXIS 563; 23 Ohio Op. 3d 243



February 17, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Ottawa County.

This is an appeal from the affirmance of a summary judgment granted to the appellees, Board of Township Trustees of Danbury Township, and its individual members. Johnson's Island, Inc., appellant, brought this declaratory judgment action in the Court of Common Pleas of Ottawa County, seeking a determination that the Zoning Resolution of Danbury Township was unconstitutional as applied to appellant's property.

The facts giving rise to the action, and to this appeal, are that Johnson's Island is a relatively small 275-acre island in Lake Erie lying in Sandusky Bay within Danbury Township, Ottawa County, connected to the mainland by a causeway. In 1956, the appellant purchased the entire island with the exception of a Confederate Soldiers' Cemetery owned by the United States Veterans Administration, the property being acquired for the purpose of subdividing and selling building lots.

Located upon Johnson's Island was a limestone quarry which had been actively mined a number of years prior to the appellant's purchase, but at the time was inactive. The appellant recorded and obtained approval of a subdivision [***2] plan for the sale of lots, principally located around the perimeter of the island, for the construction of summer homes. In addition to this sales activity, it appears that the appellant, sometime after the purchase, also began certain activities in the quarry such as draining the quarry of water, blasting and removing loose limestone for building a marina, and removing some of the stone for building a causeway to the mainland.

In 1975, a comprehensive zoning plan was adopted by Danbury Township in which the entire island was zoned residential (multi-family residential district [R-3]). Prior to the adoption of the zoning plan, the island was developed with approximately 75 improved home sites, which lots had been sold by Johnson's Island, Inc.

In 1977, the homeowners' association, Johnson's Island Club, Inc., and one of its members, sought and obtained an injunction in the Court of Common Pleas of Ottawa County, case No. 19567, to prevent Johnson's Island, Inc., from conducting any quarry operations in the limestone quarry. In their complaint the plaintiffs alleged, inter alia, that the ongoing quarrying operation violated the permitted use classification of plaintiffs'  [***3] property under the zoning resolution, in that "quarrying" was a use permitted only in a heavy manufacturing district (M-2).

With respect to the potential zoning issues in this initial controversy, Johnson's Island elected to rely on the fact that it had established a "nonconforming use" by virtue of quarrying the property prior to the adoption of the zoning resolution, and even thereafter. Johnson's Island did not challenge the constitutionality of the township zoning regulation as applied to its quarry site.

The trial court, in its findings of fact and conclusions of law, rejected defendants' argument, holding that Johnson's Island had failed to establish a nonconforming use in existence at the time of the enactment of the Danbury zoning resolution in 1975. On July 7, 1977, the trial court issued an injunction to prevent further quarrying. The Court of Appeals affirmed, and this court overruled a motion to certify the record.

On August 4, 1978, the appellant filed a complaint in the instant matter seeking a declaratory judgment, framing the prayer in two issues: (1) that the residential classification is unconstitutional as applied to appellant's land, and (2) that the parcel [***4] which consisted of some 75.6 acres of appellant's property falls properly within an M-2 heavy manufacturing classification. The purpose of the desired zoning change was to enable the appellant to conduct a limestone quarrying operation on the island.

In answer to the complaint for declaratory judgment, the appellees filed a motion for summary judgment, contending that the appellant and other quarrying contractors were defendants in the prior case, No. 19567, in the Court of Common Pleas of Ottawa County, and that the judgment in such action was res judicata to the issues presented in this declaratory judgment action. The trial court agreed, and granted summary judgment for the appellees. The Court of Appeals affirmed.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant landowner sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Ottawa County (Ohio), which affirmed a summary judgment granted to appellee board of trustees in the landowner's action for a determination that a zoning resolution was unconstitutional as applied to the landowner's property.


OVERVIEW: The landowner filed a complaint for a declaratory judgment that a residential zoning classification was unconstitutional as applied to its land, and that the parcel, which was the site of a former quarry, fell properly within the heavy manufacturing classification. The landowner sought to conduct a limestone quarrying operation. The board of trustees filed a motion for summary judgment on the ground that the landowner was a defendant in a prior zoning action against the quarry operators. The trial court granted the motion and held that the prior action was res judicata. The appellate court affirmed. On further review, the court affirmed the appellate court's judgment and rejected the landowner's claim that res judicata did not apply. The landowner argued that it could not have raised the constitutional issue in the prior action because at that time, the landowner had not exhausted administrative remedies. The court found otherwise and held that, because the landowner was in a defensive position in the prior action, exhaustion was not required and that the landowner's action was barred by the doctrine of res judicata.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment.

 

17 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Puente


81-221


Supreme Court of Ohio


69 Ohio St. 2d 136; 431 N.E.2d 987; 1982 Ohio LEXIS 550; 23 Ohio Op. 3d 178



February 10, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Ashtabula County.

In October 1979, the Grand Jury of Ashtabula County indicted appellee, Dennis Puente, for two counts of attempted murder. Prior to trial, appellee challenged the manner in which the array of grand and petit jurors was selected. 1 Appellee asserted that, in choosing the array of jurors, a jury commissioner had not followed the procedures set forth in R.C. 2313.01 et seq. 2 The trial court overruled appellee's motion. Subsequently, a jury found appellee guilty of one count and not guilty of the other.


1 No hearing was held on appellee's challenge to the jury array. Appellee's motion was based upon a similar motion and hearing held in State v. Aldridge, case No. 10241, Court of Common Pleas of Ashtabula County. The motions were heard by the same judge.

Appellant did not challenge the propriety of this trial procedure until oral argument before this court. Accordingly, for purposes of this decision, we will assume that the procedure used was proper and that the evidence adduced at the hearing in State v. Aldridge, supra, is equally applicable to this case.


2 Testimony revealed that one of the two jury commissioners for Ashtabula County followed the commands of R.C. 2313.01 et seq. 

 [***2] Upon appeal, the Court of Appeals for Ashtabula County reversed appellee's conviction. Relying upon State v. Davis (1978), 60 Ohio App. 2d 355, the court held that appellee had been prejudiced by a failure to have his jury selected in the method prescribed by law.

At the hearing held to determine what method the jury commissioners used to formulate the array of grand and petit jurors, 3 it was established that one jury commissioner did not follow the mandates of R.C. 2313.01 et seq. 


3 See fn. 1, supra. 

The evidence showed that the jury commissioner would receive the poll list from the board of elections. 4 Then, when requested by the court for a certain number of jurors, the commissioner would contact leading citizens, familiar with the various precincts in the county, to determine which residents of the county's precincts would be competent jurors. 5 Having determined which residents would be competent jurors, the commissioner would place a proportionate number of names from each precinct in the jury wheel. The commissioner, in developing the list of people whose names would be placed in the jury wheel, automatically exempted people entitled to statutory [***3] exemptions, such as doctors, dentists, lawyers and students studying outside the county. Lastly, the commissioner kept no record of his proceedings.


4 The poll list consists of all registered voters in the county from the preceding year. R.C. 2313.06.


5 The poll lists are divided by precinct.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Ashtabula County (Ohio), which reversed defendant's conviction for one count of attempted murder on the grounds that defendant was prejudiced by a failure to have his jury selected in the method prescribed by law.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of attempted murder. The court of appeals reversed the conviction, holding that the jury commissioner did not follow the mandates of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2313.01, et seq., in selecting the array of petit jurors because he automatically exempted people entitled to statutory exemptions, such as doctors, dentists, lawyers, and students studying outside the county. The court of appeals held that while Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2313.12 authorized commissioners of juries to exempt those who were statutorily entitled to exemption, a commissioner could do so only upon the request of the persons so entitled.The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals, holding that there was nothing in the record that showed defendant was either prejudiced by the jury commissioner's failure to follow the requirements of § 2313.01, et seq., or that the jurors who indicted and convicted defendant were not qualified jurors.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals, which had reversed defendant's conviction for attempted murder.

 

18 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Bonkowsky v. Bonkowsky


81-270


Supreme Court of Ohio


69 Ohio St. 2d 152; 431 N.E.2d 998; 1982 Ohio LEXIS 553; 23 Ohio Op. 3d 188



February 10, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

This matter brings into issue the viability of Ohio's existing principle of interspousal tort immunity. The facts giving rise to this question are not controverted. Appellant, Hanna L. Bonkowsky, and appellee, Otto R. Bonkowsky, are wife and husband, respectively. While on an automobile trip in the state of Vermont, appellee was driving and appellant was a passenger in the car when an accident occurred, and appellant was injured. Appellant filed an action in the Court of Common Pleas of Cuyahoga County against appellee, claiming negligence on the part of the latter. The parties stipulated to the existence of automobile liability insurance, and that the policy did not expressly bar such an action. The appellee moved for summary judgment, contending that interspousal immunity barred the claim despite the fact that the law of the state of Vermont would allow such an action. The Court of Common Pleas granted such motion, and the Court of Appeals affirmed upon the basis of Ohio's previously pronounced position on interspousal immunity.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance [***2] of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:
