PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant wife sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals, Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's summary judgment for appellee husband in the wife's action claiming that she was injured in an automobile accident due to the husband's negligence.


OVERVIEW: The parties stipulated to the existence of automobile liability insurance and that the policy did not expressly bar the wife's action. The husband contended that interspousal immunity barred the wife's claim. The wife argued that the principle of interspousal immunity should not be followed because there was liability insurance under which her claims could be satisfied and the reasons supportive of the principle were no longer viable. On appeal, the court adhered to its previously pronounced position in favor of interspousal immunity because the doctrine reasonably related to the legitimate state interest of fostering marital harmony and preventing fraud and collusion. The court's recent precedent reviewing the viability of such policies should be given a great deal of weight.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment.

 

19 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Downing v. Cook


81-535


Supreme Court of Ohio


69 Ohio St. 2d 149; 431 N.E.2d 995; 1982 Ohio LEXIS 552; 23 Ohio Op. 3d 186



February 10, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

Plaintiff-appellant, Mariann H. Downing, brought suit in the Court of Common Pleas seeking an order declaring Section 905.04(H)(1) of the Codified Ordinances of the city of Berea * unconstitutional and restraining the Berea Chief of Police, defendant-appellee John Cook, from enforcing it.


* Section 905.04(H) of the Codified Ordinances of the city of Berea provides, in part:

"No person shall * * *

"(1) Own, keep or harbor more than three (3) dogs, excepting puppies under three (3) months old, in or on the premises of any dwelling unit within the City, unless the zoning lot upon which dogs are kept have a minimum area of 4,000 square feet for each dog kept on such zoning lot regardless of the number of persons keeping or harboring dogs on such lot."

Violation of Section 905.04(H)(1) is a minor misdemeanor and constitutes a nuisance subject to abatement in the manner provided by the Revised Code or Chapter 949 of the Berea Codified Ordinances. Section 905.04(I).

By stipulation the case was submitted to the trial court on the basis of the pleadings, appellant's motion for summary judgment, the trial briefs [***2] and certain evidentiary material proffered by the appellant. Among that material is an affidavit executed by the appellant which asserts that she is co-owner of an 80 foot by 101 foot parcel of property located in the city of Berea upon which she resides; that she owns two Irish Setters and a mixed-breed dog which she keeps on the premises; that she displays one of her Irish Setters at dog show competitions; and that she desires to breed one of her Irish Setters and keep a puppy for show purposes.

Appellant also submitted the affidavit of Donald J. Kwiatkowski, who is president of an organization known as Purebred Dog Breeders and Fanciers Association Inc. of Northern Ohio, and is a member of the American Kennel Club, Cuyahoga County Animal Control Advisory Board, and the Ohio Dog Owners Association. His affidavit stated that both the Ohio Dog Owners Association and the Purebred Dog Breeders and Fanciers Association objected to Section 905.04(H)(1). In the opinion of Kwiatkowski, the ordinance constitutes an impermissible interference with the rights of property owners and will not solve problems of barking dogs, free-roaming dogs, or dog bites. The plaintiff also submitted [***3] a photograph of a well-groomed Irish Setter and a copy of the deed to her property.

The Court of Common Pleas granted judgment for the defendant, holding that " § 905.04(H)(1) is a valid ordinance and enforceable by the police authority of the City of Berea."

The Court of Appeals affirmed.

The cause is before this court pursuant to allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio) that affirmed a trial court decision in favor of appellee police chief and held that Berea, Ohio, Ordinance § 905.04(H)(1), which prohibited the ownership of more than three dogs, was a valid ordinance and enforceable by the police chief.


OVERVIEW: The appellate court affirmed a trial court decision in favor of the police chief and held that Berea, Ohio, Ordinance § 905.04(H)(1), which prohibited the ownership of more than three dogs, was a valid ordinance and enforceable by the police chief. Appellant sought review, and the court affirmed. The court found that her evidence, largely consisting of opinions, was conclusory in nature or irrelevant, and did not rebut the presumption that the ordinance was valid. Furthermore, although the ordinance could limit appellant in the enjoyment and use of her property, she failed to demonstrate that it was not reasonably adapted to the legitimate purpose of avoiding the problems associated with a concentration of dogs in a small area in a residential environment.


OUTCOME: The decision of the appellate court affirming a trial court judgment in favor of the police chief and finding the subject ordinance valid was affirmed.

 

20 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


University Heights v. O'Leary


No. 80-1716


Supreme Court of Ohio


68 Ohio St. 2d 130; 429 N.E.2d 148; 1981 Ohio LEXIS 633; 22 Ohio Op. 3d 372



December 16, 1981, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County. Defendant-appellee, James W. O'Leary, is a private investigator. On the evening of June 14, 1979, appellee's assignment was to keep a subject's car under surveillance. At approximately 10:00 p.m. that evening appellee's car was parked in a May Company parking lot in the city of University Heights. Also in the parking lot was a van, upon which several police officers converged to arrest the occupants for the illegal sale of fireworks. After the arrest, officers of the University Heights Police Department came over to appellee's car in which appellee's co-worker, Gerald Wright, was sitting to investigate his presence in the parking lot after store hours. During the course of the police questioning of Wright, an empty gun holster was observed on the floor of the automobile. Wright was searched and a search was begun of the car. Some cartridges were found in the car's glove compartment. Appellee returned while the police were searching the interior of the car. Pursuant to police request, appellee opened the trunk of the car which contained several encased, unloaded weapons. As a result of the discovery of these weapons,  [***2] appellee was charged with violating Sections 626.04(a) and 626.09(a) of the Codified Ordinances of the city of University Heights, which proscribe the possession and carrying of a firearm in a vehicle in the city of University Heights unless the person has a "Restricted Weapons Owner's Identification Card." Prior to trial appellee filed the following: (1) a motion to suppress the evidence seized during the search of the car and (2) a motion to dismiss the charges on the ground that Sections 626.04(a) and 626.09(a) were facially unconstitutional. An initial hearing on the charges was held on August 17, 1979, in the Shaker Heights Municipal Court. The case was continued because neither the appellee, the prosecutor, nor the court could obtain the correct copies of the applicable ordinance. A subsequent hearing was held on August 21, 1979. The court overruled appellee's first motion, finding the search and seizure constitutional. 1 the court, however, granted appellee's second motion, finding Sections 626.04(a) and 626.09(a) unconstitutional because they were overbroad, vague and unenforceable.


1 Appellee failed to challenge this ruling by cross-appeal in the Court of Appeals, so the issue of the constitutionality of the search and seizure is not now before this court.

 [***3] The Court of Appeals affirmed, finding Sections 626.04(a) and 626.09(a) overbroad, vague, unenforceable and violative of due process because they penalized innocent conduct. The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city challenged an order of the Court of Appeals (Ohio), which affirmed a lower court's finding in favor of appellee private investigator that University Heights, OH, Codified Ordinances of the City of University Heights §§ 626.04(a) and 626.09(a), of which appellee was charged in violation, were unconstitutional because they were overbroad, vague, and unenforceable.


OVERVIEW: Appellee private investigator was assigned to keep a subject's car under surveillance. Police converged on the parking lot where appellee was sitting in his car to arrest other occupants for the illegal sale of fireworks. Police approached appellee and saw an empty gun holster. Upon a search of the car, police found weapons and ammunition. Appellee was charged with violation of University Heights, OH, Codified Ordinances of the City of University Heights §§ 626.04(a) and 626.09(a), which proscribed the possession and carrying of a firearm in a vehicle in the city unless the person was registered. The trial court found the ordinances to be unconstitutional because they were overbroad, vague, and unenforceable. An intermediate court affirmed. On appeal, the court reversed, holding that §§ 626.04(a) and 626.09(a) were constitutional and not violative of due process.


OUTCOME: The court reversed, holding that it was not violative of due process for appellant city to require a non-resident, who did not possess a firearm owner's identification card from his own municipality, to acquire a restricted weapons owner's identification card before bringing a firearm into the city unless he fits into the exceptions of the ordinance and that the ordinance was not otherwise unconstitutional.

 

21 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Anderson v. Jacobs


No. 80-1688


Supreme Courts of Ohio


68 Ohio St. 2d 67; 428 N.E.2d 419; 1981 Ohio LEXIS 621; 22 Ohio Op. 3d 268



November 18, 1981, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Huron County.

On January 18, 1978, appellee, Susan M. Anderson, an unmarried woman, gave birth to a child. In July 1978, appellee filed a complaint, pursuant to R. C. 3111.01, 1 in the Juvenile Court Division of the Court of Common Pleas of Huron County, alleging that appellant, James A. Jacobs, was the father of her child.


1 R. C. 3111.01 states:

"When an unmarried women, who has been delivered of, or is pregnant with, a child, makes a complaint in writing under oath, before a judge of a county court or in juvenile court, charging a person with being the father of the child, the judge shall issue his warrant, directed to any sheriff, police officer, or constable commanding him to pursue and arrest the accused person in any county, and to bring him forthwith before the judge to answer the complaint."

The Huron County Welfare Department (HCWD) required the identification of the putative father and the commencement of paternity proceedings in order for appellee [***2] to remain eligible to receive full Aid to Families with Dependent Children (ADC) benefits. 2 Appellee was also required to assign her interest "in and to any and all support payments" to HCWD pursuant to R. C. 5107.07. 3 Throughout these preceedings appellee has been represented by the Huron County Prosecutor's Office, which, by contractual agreement, handles contested paternity cases for HCWD. 4 


2 ADC is a federally funded program authorized under Title IV of the Social Security Act (Section 601, Title 42, U. S. Code). Participating states are required to secure the cooperation of ADC recipients to establish paternity and secure support for a child born out of wedlock. Section 654(4), Title 42, U. S. Code. See, also, 45 CFR Section 232.12.

 Ohio Adm. Code 5101:1-3-10(A)(1)(c) requires ADC recipients to cooperate "* * * [i]n establishing the paternity of a child born out of wedlock for whom aid is claimed." See, also, Ohio Department of Public Welfare, Public Assistance Manual (ODPAM), Section 314.12. Moreover, "[f]ailure to cooperate in the securing of support * * * renders the caretaker * * * [mother] ineligible for assistance." Id. at Section 314.12(3).


3 R. C. 5107.07 states in relevant part:

"The acceptance of aid under sections 5107.02 to 5107.15 of the Revised Code constitutes an assignment to the department of public welfare of any rights an individual receiving aid has to support from any other person. The rights to support assigned to the department constitute an obligation of the person who is responsible for providing the support to the state for the amount of aid payments to the recipient or recipients whose needs are included in determining the amount of aid received. * * * Support obligations owed to children shall be distributed in accordance with laws and rules applicable to the federal child support program * * *."



4 See ODPAM Section 8404.5 ("[c]ounty prosecuting attorneys are responsible for representing [sic] a complainant in paternity proceedings * * *").

 [***3] Appellant denied that he was the child's father. He was unemployed when the instant paternity action was before the trial court, prompting appellant's counsel 5 to file an affidavit of indigency on behalf of appellant. Appellant moved the trial court to order blood grouping tests, pursuant to R. C. 3111.16, 6 and in the same motion requested, based on his claim of indigency, that the court require the county to pay initially for the blood grouping tests, which customarily must be prepaid, and then assess the sums expended as costs to be borne by the unsuccessful party as authorized by R. C. 3111.16.


5 Appellant's counsel is associated with Advocates for Basic Legal Equality, Inc., a legal aid organization.


6 R. C. 3111.16 states in relevant part:

"Whenever it is relevant * * * the trial court, on motion of the defendant, shall order that the complainant, her child, and the defendant submit to one or more blood-grouping tests to determine whether, by the use of such tests, the defendant can be determined not to be the father of the child. The tests shall be made by qualified physicians or other qualified persons, not to exceed three, selected by the court, and under such restrictions and directions as the court or judge deems proper. * * * The court shall determine how and by whom the costs of the tests shall be paid."


 [***4] The trial court denied appellant's motion, finding "no precedent for the Court to pay for blood tests in this jurisdiction." After trial to the court, appellant was adjudged to be the father of appellee's child. The court ordered appellant to make weekly support payments and to pay $ 810 for birth and medical expenses. The order also imposed poundage to be applied to support arrearages due the HCWD.

Appellant appealed to the Court of Appeals, assigning as error the trial court's refusal to grant his "Motion for Blood Test at Public Expense." The Court of Appeals affirmed the trial court in a split decision with the majority taking the view that "because the paternity action * * * is a strictly civil proceeding, the defendant has no right to a blood grouping test at public expense." Judge Potter, dissenting, opined that "where a defendant in a paternity action establishes that he is indigent, the court can order the county to initially pay the cost of defendant's blood test and then tax the cost of this blood test as part of the costs of the paternity proceeding."

The Court of Appeals finding its judgment to be in conflict with the determination of the Court of Appeals for Geauga [***5] County in Pulford v.. Ashba (January 29, 1979), C.A. No. 773, unreported, 7 certified the report of the case to this court for review and final determination.


7 The Court of Appeals in Pulford relied on Walker v.. Stokes (1975), 45 Ohio App. 2d 275, which held on equal protection grounds that it is mandatory that the trial court tax as costs the expense of a blood test requested by appropriate motion by an indigent in a bastardy action.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant putative father sought review of a decision from the Court of Appeals for Huron County (Ohio), which affirmed a trial court's judgment for appellee mother and adjudged the putative father to be the father of the mother's child and ruled that the putative father had no right to a blood grouping test at public expense.


OVERVIEW: A mother filed a paternity proceeding against the putative father and he was adjudged the father of the child and was ordered to make weekly support payments and to pay for birth and medical expenses. The putative father contended that the trial court's refusal to authorize blood grouping tests without prepayment violated his right to due process and denied him a meaningful opportunity to be heard. The court reversed the appellate court's judgment for the mother and remanded the case to the trial court with directions to order a blood grouping test to be paid by the county. Under the Eldridge test, the court found that the private interests were substantial since the putative father had a pecuniary interest in avoiding substantial support obligations, and at issue was the creation of a parent-child relationship. The court ruled that access to blood grouping tests for indigent defendants would help insure the correctness of paternity decisions. Also, the State had a legitimate interest in a child born out of wedlock who was receiving public assistance. As such, the denial of blood grouping tests violated the putative father's due process guarantee under U.S. Const. amend. XIV.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's judgment and remanded the case to the trial court with an order to grant the putative father's request for blood grouping tests to determine if he was the actual father of the mother's child.

 

22 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Beatty v. Akron City Hospital


No. 80-1194


Supreme Court of Ohio


67 Ohio St. 2d 483; 424 N.E.2d 586; 1981 Ohio LEXIS 603; 21 Ohio Op. 3d 302



August 12, 1981, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County.

This cause presents for review and determination by this court the question of whether R. C. 2711.21(C), a section of the Ohio Medical Malpractice Act, is constitutional.

The facts, in brief, giving rise to this appeal are that on March 14, 1978, the appellants, Sandra and Edward Beatty, filed an amended complaint against the appellees, Dr. Richard C. Walker and Akron City Hospital, alleging that appellees had performed a tubal ligation on Sandra Beatty without her consent. The appellees answered and the matter was set for arbitration hearing pursuant to R. C. 2711.21. The arbitration panel consisted of three lawyers, one appointed by each party, and one by the court. After a hearing, the arbitrators determined that appellants had knowingly and voluntarily consented to the tubular ligation procedure and, accordingly, the arbitrators entered a finding in favor of the appellees.

Seeking a trial de novo, appellants filed a second amended complaint on January 22, 1979, wherein they demanded a jury trial. The appellees, pursuant to R. C. 2711.21(C), moved that the finding of the arbitrators be placed into evidence [***2] at trial. The appellants opposed the motion, asserting that R. C. 2711.21 was unconstitutional. The trial court overruled appellants' contention and directed that the arbitrators' decision be admitted in evidence.

On October 25, 1979, the trial commenced and, over appellants' objection, the arbitrators' finding was received into evidence. The jury rendered verdicts for the appellees.

The appellants appealed to the Court of Appeals. In that appeal, the appellants contended that: (1) R. C. 2711.21 violates the appellants' right to a civil jury trial as guaranteed by the Seventh Amendment to the United States Constitution and Section 5, Article I of the Ohio Constitution; and (2) R. C. 2711.21 violates the constitutional guarantees of equal protection by treating medical claims in a judicially different manner (than other tort claims), there being no state interest sufficiently compelling to justify such different treatment.

The Court of Appeals held that the challenged section is constitutional and affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

This cause is now before the court pursuant to allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff patient brought a medical malpractice action against defendants, doctor and hospital. The matter was set for arbitration pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2711.21, and the arbitrators found for the doctor and hospital. The patient sought a trial de novo. The trial court rendered judgment for the doctor and hospital based on a jury verdict. The Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio) affirmed the judgment. The patient sought review.


OVERVIEW: The patient claimed that she was given a tubal ligation without her consent. During the jury trial, the findings of the arbitration panel were admitted into evidence pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2711.21(C). On appeal, the patient argued that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2711.21 violated her right to a civil jury trial as guaranteed by the Seventh Amendment to the United States Constitution and Ohio Const. art. I, § 5. The patient also argued that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2711.21 violated the constitutional guarantees of equal protection by treating medical claims in a judicially different matter than other tort claims. The court held that § 2711.21 did not violate the patient's right to a civil jury trial because it was unlikely that a properly instructed jury would accord more weight to the findings of the arbitration panel than was appropriate. The court also held that because the state had a compelling reason to justify sending medical malpractice claims to arbitration, § 2711.21 did not violate the patient's right to equal protection under the law.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment from the appellate court, which affirmed the trial court's judgment in favor of the doctor and hospital in the patient's medical malpractice action.

 

23 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Spikes


No. 80-1552


Supreme Court of Ohio


67 Ohio St. 2d 405; 423 N.E.2d 1122; 1981 Ohio LEXIS 597; 21 Ohio Op. 3d 254



July 29, 1981, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL and CROSS-APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lake County.

On October 1, 1979, three males approached Fredrick Veshinfsky while he was at the Painesville recreation park. One of these males tapped on Veshinfsky's car. One approached him from behind and choked him until he lost consciousness. Veshinfsky testified that, after he regained consciousness, he found his wallet outside his pants and that $ 110 and his glasses were missing. He saw a white car going up a nearby hill. Veshinfsky noticed the male who had tapped on his car looking back at him from inside the white car. Veshinfsky pursued this car and pulled in front of it. Veshinfsky left his car, and appellee James Spikes left the white car. Veshinfsky testified that appellee then struck him several times in the nose and face.

After reporting the incident to the Lake County sheriff's department, Veshinfsky went to Lake County Memorial Hospital. Several hours later, he was transferred to Richmond Heights General Hospital. Veshinfsky testified that he suffered a broken nose as well as having blood in his urine, trouble with his kidneys and back pains for two weeks.

Appellee was indicted [***2] on two counts: aggravated robbery, R. C. 2911.01, and felonious assault, R. C. 2903.11. Before trial, appellee moved the Court of Common Pleas to compel discovery of the felony and misdemeanor records of all witnesses for the purpose of impeachment at trial. The trial court ordered the prosecutor to furnish appellee with the felony and misdemeanor record of appellee and any felony records of the state's witnesses. The court observed that Crim. R. 16 does not require that the prosecutor supply a criminal defendant with the criminal record of his or her own witnesses. 1 


1 Crim. R. 16 provides, in pertinent part:

"(B) Disclosure of evidence by the prosecuting attorney.

"(1) Information subject to disclosure.

"* * *

"(b) Defendant's prior record. Upon motion of the defendant the court shall order the prosecuting attorney to furnish defendant a copy of defendant's prior criminal record, which is available to or within the possession, custody or control of the state.

"* * *

"(e) Witness names and addresses; record. Upon motion of the defendant, the court shall order the prosecuting attorney to furnish to the defendant a written list of the names and addresses of all witnesses whom the prosecuting attorney intends to call at trial, together with any record of prior felony convictions of any such witness, which record is within the knowledge of the prosecuting attorney. * * *."

 [***3] Appellee was tried to a jury. At trial, the prosecutor, over appellee's objections, cross-examined a defense witness regarding a misdemeanor conviction. Appellee later attempted to cross-examine Veshinfsky as to whether he had a misdemeanor record. The trial court sustained the prosecutor's objection. Defense counsel made an offer of proof on the record that he had received "information from a law enforcement official" that Veshinfsky did have a misdemeanor record. Defense counsel admitted, however, that he did not have an official report or court record substantiating his belief.

The trial court admitted in evidence, over defense objection, records from both of the hospitals at which Veshinfsky received treatment. Each hospital provided a sworn certification, as required by R. C. 2317.422. 2 


2 R. C. 2317.422 provides:

"Notwithstanding sections 2317.40 and 2317.41 of the Revised Code, the records, copies, or photographs thereof, of a hospital, and homes required to be licensed pursuant to section 3721.01 of the Revised Code, may, in lieu of the testimony in open court of their custodian, person who made them, or person under whose supervision they were made, be qualified as authentic evidence if any such person endorses thereon his verified certification identifying such records, giving the mode and time of their preparation, and stating that they were prepared in the usual course of the business of the institution. Such records, copies, or photographs may not be qualified by certification as provided in this section unless the party intending to offer them delivers a copy of the same, or of the relevant portions thereof, to the attorney of record for each adverse party not less than five days before trial. Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the right of any party to call the custodian, person who made such records, or person under whose supervision they were made, as a witness."

 [***4] At the conclusion of the trial, the jury returned from deliberations and requested that the court read to them "the conditions needed for aggravated robbery." The court complied and repeated the definition of serious physical harm. The jury later found appellee guilty of aggravated robbery, R. C. 2911.01, under count one of the indictment. The jury also found appellee guilty of assault, R. C. 2903.13, a lesser-included offense under count two of the indictment, felonious assault, R. C. 2903.11. The trial court issued concurrent sentences of 4 to 25 years at the Ohio State Reformatory on count one and 60 days in the Lake County jail on count two. Appellee also received a fine of $ 500, which the trial court suspended. The Court of Appeals reversed and remanded the cause for further proceedings. That court held that State v.. Tims (1967), 9 Ohio St. 2d 136, and appellee's constitutional right to confront the witnesses against him require that the examining physician testify prior to the admission in evidence of hospital records.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion and cross-motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment accordingly [***5] .


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state challenged an order of the Court of Appeals (Ohio), which reversed appellee's conviction, by a jury of aggravated robbery in violation of Ohio Rev. Code § 2911.01 and assault in violation of Ohio Rev. Code § 2903.13.


OVERVIEW: A jury convicted appellee of aggravated robbery in violation of Ohio Rev. Code § 2911.01 and assault in violation of Ohio Rev. Code § 2903.13. The intermediate court reversed appellee's conviction, finding that appellee's constitutional right to confront the witnesses against him required that an examining physician testify prior to the admission into evidence of hospital records. On appeal, the court reversed in part and affirmed in part, holding that the hospital records were admissible pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code § 2317.422. The court also held that appellee had no constitutional right to discovery of the misdemeanor conviction records of all prosecution witnesses.


OUTCOME: The court reversed in part and affirmed in part, holding that the hospital records were admissible evidence and that appellee had no constitutional right to discovery of the misdemeanor conviction records of all prosecution witnesses.

 

24 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Johns v. State


No. 80-1450


Supreme Court of Ohio


67 Ohio St. 2d 325; 423 N.E.2d 863; 1981 Ohio LEXIS 584; 21 Ohio Op. 3d 204



July 22, 1981, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

This civil case had its genesis in the Court of Common Pleas of Cuyahoga County upon the conviction, sentence, and subsequent six and one-half year incarceration of Frank L. Johns, appellee herein, for the crime of selling marijuana on November 30, 1964. After exhausting his state remedies, Johns filed an original action in habeas corpus in the federal District Court. He claimed that his privately-retained, personally-selected lawyer had afforded him inadequate representation of counsel in the sole particular of his claim of alibi.

The District Court dismissed the petition, finding adequate representation, in that such private counsel had telephoned Johns' place of employment and was assured that Johns' employment records were not conclusive either way on the question of whether Johns was at work at the time of the alleged crime. Thus, counsel had no essential duty to subpoena the records.

Upon appeal, the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals reversed, declaring that it was the duty of private counsel to subpoena all the employment records because they might have created a reasonable doubt. Holding that the petitioner [***2] was deprived of his constitutional right to the effective assistance of counsel, the federal Court of Appeals remanded the case to the state courts "with instructions to grant the writ unless the time cards can be located to permit a fair re-trial." Johns v.. Perini (C.A. 6, 1972), 462 F. 2d 1308, at 1315. The federal Court of Appeals observed that "[t]he seriousness of the omission is emphasized by the fact that the employer routinely destroys time cards after five years." Id.

The Ohio authorities were unable to prosecute Johns and he was released.

Through counsel, Johns unsuccessfully attempted to persuade the General Assembly to enact a moral claim Bill, but ultimately was successful in the passage of Am. sub. S. B. No. 221, which provides, in part, as follows:

"Section 41. Notwithstanding the provisions of Chapter 2743 of the Revised Code, Mr. Frank Johns, 12705 Craven Avenue, Cleveland, Ohio, 44105, is hereby authorized to file a claim for damages in the Court of Claims for unlawful incarceration and for lost wages, legal expenses and general damages resulting from his alleged unlawful incarceration. The Court of Claims, after all the evidence in support [***3] of this claim has been heard, shall determine: 1) whether the preponderance of the evidence offered supports a finding that Mr. Johns has been unlawfully incarcerated by the State of Ohio, and if this is so, 2) the dollar amount of damages to be awarded as compensation. Funds shall be available from the balance in the reparations Rotary Fund to pay any award for damages made to Mr. Johns by the Court of Claims. Such claim for damages must be filed prior to July 1, 1979, after which date the authority to file such claim shall expire."

Johns filed a complaint in the Court of Claims subsequent to the enactment of this Bill, and the Court of Claims entered a summary judgment against him. This judgment was reversed by the Court of Appeals for Franklin County, which observed:

"Whether the decision of the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals in effect held the judgment of conviction void or voidable, or whether such judgment is res judicata for purposes of the issues raised herein, will not be discussed at this time in that it is not necessary to do so. The Court of Claims, and this court, must consider the rights of this particular claimant in light of the special legislation enacted [***4] which creates his cause of action.

"The legislation dealt with here is very clear as to the duty of the Court of Claims. The court must, according to the wording of the bill, first hear all of the evidence in support of the claim, and it then must determine 'whether the preponderance of the evidence offered supports a finding that Mr. Johns had been unlawfully incarcerated by the State of Ohio.'

"Further, if the court so finds upon all of the evidence adduced that Mr. Johns was unlawfully incarcerated, then the court must determine dollar amount damages to be awarded as compensation. Here, the Court of Claims decided this cause upon summary judgment, and did not permit plaintiff to submit any evidence upon the issue of unlawful incarceration. How then can it be said that the legislative mandate to hear all of the evidence and determine by the preponderance of the evidence whether Mr. Johns had been unlawfully incarcerated has been carried out? We must hold that the reasonable intent of the legislative enactment was for the Court of Claims to entertain and review the evidence on the issue of the unlawful incarceration, and to make its determination as to whether justice had [***5] been done in the trial of the cause of Mr. Johns. * * *"

Upon rehearing in the Court of Claims, counsel for Johns did not adduce evidence as to whether Johns had been unlawfully incarcerated by the state of Ohio, and objected to all evidence except that which went to the issue of damages. This time the Court of Claims entered judgment in favor of the state of Ohio because it had no evidence to review on the first issue in the legislative mandate. Johns through counsel had claimed that the judgment in habeas corpus entered by the federal Court of Appeals was res judicata upon that issue.

Upon appeal of this second Court of Claims' judgment, the Court of Appeals, composed of a different panel, departed from "the law of the case" 1 which it had spelled out in the first review, and based its judgment on the sole proposition that the federal Court of Appeals judgment in habeas corpus was res judicata upon the issue of "unlawful incarceration by the State of Ohio." This time the Court of Appeals reversed and remanded the case with instructions to the Court of Claims to hear only evidence as to Johns' damages.


1 See Bane v.. Wick (1856), 6 Ohio St. 13; and the cases collected in 5 Ohio Jurisprudence 3d 307, Appellate Review, Section 648; 5 American Jurisprudence 2d, Appeal and Error, Sections 744-759.

 [***6] This cause is now before this court upon the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellee was convicted, sentenced, and incarcerated for selling marijuana. He was released early pursuant to a writ of habeas corpus. He then filed an action in the court of claims, seeking damages against appellant State of Ohio for unlawful incarceration. The State appealed from a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which reversed the court of claims' remand decision in favor of the State.


OVERVIEW: Appellee was released from prison, after serving a portion of his sentence for selling marijuana, on the basis of his habeas corpus petition, which alleged that he was without effective assistance of counsel on his alibi claim. Appellee subsequently filed a damages action against the State in the court of claims, pursuant to specially enacted legislation authorizing him to do so. On remand from the court of appeals, the court of claims entered a judgment in favor of the State due to appellee's failure to adduce any evidence that his incarceration was unlawful. The court of appeals, however, departed from "the law of the case" and reversed the judgment in favor of the State. On appeal, the court reversed the court of appeals' decision. The legislative enactment at issue did not presume appellee's entitlement to a key to the public treasury. Rather, it required the court of claims to independently determine that appellee's incarceration was unlawful before awarding him any damages. The decision in the habeas corpus action was not res judicata on the issue. Accordingly, appellee's failure to present evidence on the issue precluded a judgment in his favor.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the court of appeals' judgment reversing the court of claims' remand decision in favor of the State.

 

25 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Duerk v. Donahey


No. 81-377


Supreme Court of Ohio


67 Ohio St. 2d 216; 423 N.E.2d 429; 1981 Ohio LEXIS 568; 21 Ohio Op. 3d 135



July 15, 1981, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

Relator, James A. Duerk, is the Director of the Department of Economic and Community Development of the state of Ohio. Pursuant to R. C. Chapter 166, he obtained approval to grant a loan from state funds and a loan guarantee to the Tamarkin Company in the amount of $ 6,900.000. In accordance with R. C. 166.08, relator submitted a certificate to respondent, Gertrude W. Donahey, Treasurer of the state of Ohio, indicating that the loan and loan guarantee had been approved and requested that she issue the bonds necessary to secure the moneys needed. Respondent refused to issue the bonds due to her belief that certain provisions of R. C. Chapter 166 were in violation of the Ohio Constitution.

Relator then brought this action in mandamus seeking an order compelling respondent to issue the bonds pursuant to R. C. Chapter 166. By way of affirmative defense, respondent asserts that R. C. Chapter 166 violates Section 13, Article VIII of the Ohio Constitution.



DISPOSITION: Writ allowed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator Director of the Department of Economic and Community Development of the State of Ohio filed an action in mandamus that sought an order that would compel respondent Treasurer of the State of Ohio to issue bonds pursuant to Ohio Revised Code Chapter 166.


OVERVIEW: Pursuant to Chapter 166, the Director obtained approval to grant a loan from state funds and a loan guarantee to a particular company. In accordance with Ohio Rev. Code § 166.08, the Director submitted a certificate to the Treasurer, which indicated that the loan and the loan guarantee had been approved and requested that she issue the bonds necessary to secure the moneys needed. The Treasurer refused to issue the bonds due to her belief that certain provisions of Ohio Revised Code Chapter 166 were in violation of the Ohio Constitution. The court granted the writ and held that the Treasurer was under a clear legal duty to issue the bonds as requested. The court found that Chapter 166 contemplated the use of moneys in the Liquor Control fund prior to a determination of "excess" under Ohio Rev. Code § 4301.12. The court held that it would appear that bonds that were authorized under Ohio Revised Code Chapter 166 were obligations that were to be deducted before determining the "excess" payable to the state treasury under Ohio Rev. Code § 4301.12. Moreover, the court held that the Treasurer failed to meet her burden with regard to proving the unconstitutionality of the law.


OUTCOME: The court granted the writ and ordered the Treasurer to issue the bonds that the Director requested.

 

26 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Office of Consumers' Counsel v. Public Utilities Com.


Nos. 80-1480, 80-1528, 80-1547


Supreme Court of Ohio


67 Ohio St. 2d 153; 423 N.E.2d 820; 1981 Ohio LEXIS 563; 21 Ohio Op. 3d 96



July 15, 1981, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio.

These three cases are appeals taken from an order of appellee, Public Utilities Commission of Ohio (hereinafter "commission"), granting intervening appellee, the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company (hereinafter "CEI"), a rate increase of approximately $ 69.6 million. The commission order further provided for the amortization over a ten-year period of CEI's substantial investment in four terminated nuclear power plants. 1 


1 Davis-Besse Units 2 and 3 and Erie Units 1 and 2 are the cancelled facilities at issue.

The commission's order dealt with two cases that had been consolidated. Case No. 79-537-EL-AIR involved CEI's application to increase rates. Case No. 79-744-EL-CMR concerned a complaint and appeal taken by CEI from a 1979 rate setting ordinance passed by the city of Cleveland.

Inasmuch as these three appeals primarily concern issues relating to the nuclear power plant cancellations, we shall briefly reprise the history of these now terminated facilities. In 1967, CEI joined with four other electric companies to form the Central Area Power Coordination Group (CAPCO). 2 The CAPCO companies [***2] sought to achieve economies of scale and greater service reliability by jointly planning, constructing, and operating electrical generating facilities. In 1973, the CAPCO group committed itself to build the four nuclear plants at issue herein based on forecasts that predicted a substantially increased demand for electricity by the CAPCO companies' customers during the 1970's and 1980's. These forecasts subsequently had to be revised downward when increasing energy costs spurred conservation efforts and significantly softened the demand for electricity. Moreover, the 1979 accident at Three Mile Island prompted the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to issue stringent and costly new standards for nuclear power plants, requiring major design changes in the Babcock and Wilcox units that CAPCO planned to construct and operate. After much study and redesign the CAPCO companies decided to terminate the four units on January 23, 1980. When the decision to cancel the plants was announced, CAPCO had already invested considerable sums in the projects. Preliminary expenses included expenditures for engineering, siting, environmental, geological, and seismic studies, and for obtaining state and [***3] federal licenses. Moreover, to comply with detailed regulatory requirements and complete all the necessary documents, certain plant components had to be purchased at a fairly early stage in the planning process. CEI's share of the total CAPCO investments in the four cancelled plants amounted to approximately $ 56,400,000 as of the date of termination.


2 In addition to CEI the CAPCO group consists of Toledo Edison, Ohio Edison, and two Pennsylvania utilities, Duquesne Light Co. and Pennsylvania Power Co.

The instant CEI rate case was pending before the commission when the plant terminations were announced. 3 The commission had accepted CEI's application for a rate increase as of September 17, 1979, and had established calendar year 1979 as the test year and June 30, 1979, as the date certain. The commission staff conducted an investigation and issued its initial report in March 1980. This report did not make reference to the terminated nuclear plants because CEI did not officially inform the commission of the plant cancellations until February 1980. The commission staff, at appellants' request, then conducted a supplemental investigation to consider the effect of the [***4] terminated plant expenditures on CEI's rate application. The staff completed its investigation of the cancelled nuclear facilities and filed revised schedules in mid-April. The staff recommended that the investment in the four nuclear plants should be amortized over a ten-year period as CEI had requested.


3 The rates established by the commission order in the instant ratemaking case have recently been superseded by new rates set by order on May 4, 1981 in case No. 80-376-EL-AIR.

Public hearings on the rate increase application began on April 2, 1980, and continued for 32 days. Staff witnesses appeared and testified at the hearings in regard to the cancelled nuclear plants and other matters contained in the application. Appellants were represented at, and participated fully in, these public hearings.

The commission issued its order on July 10, 1980. Appellants timely filed for a rehearing which the commission denied as to the issues raised in the present appeal.

These causes are now before this court upon appeals as of right.



DISPOSITION: Order reversed in part and affirmed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In consolidated actions, appellants, the Office of Consumers' Counsel, a senior citizens coalition, and a city, sought review of an order from appellee Public Utilities Commission of Ohio, which granted intervening appellee electric company a rate increase. The Commission's order further provided for the amortization over a 10-year period of the electric company's substantial investment in four terminated nuclear power plants.


OVERVIEW: In its order, the Commission allowed a certain amount to be included in the rate base for construction work in progress (CWIP) pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 4909.15(A)(1) and 4909.15(E). The court found no merit in the constitutional challenge to the CWIP provisions because the Commission's discretion was sufficiently circumscribed by the specific eligibility criteria enumerated in the statutes. However, the court determined that the Commission exceeded its statutory authority when it approved amortization of the electric company's investment in four terminated nuclear power plants. The court found that the Commission's action was not consistent with the statutorily mandated ratemaking formula contained in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4909.15. The court concluded that the extraordinary loss sustained by the electric company in connection with the terminated nuclear plants could not be transformed into an ordinary operating expense pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4909.15(A)(4) by Commission fiat. Nor did the court find statutory authorization for such action in the gross annual revenue determination under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4909.15(D)(2)(b).


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the Commission in part regarding the Commission's permitting an amount to be included in the rate base for CWIP. The order of the Commission was reversed in part, and the case was remanded to the Commission for a redetermination of the electric company's allowable operating expenses, excluding therefrom the expenditures attributable to the cancelled nuclear facilities.

 

27 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Kanter Corp. v. Stringer


No. 80-1122


Supreme Court of Ohio


67 Ohio St. 2d 8; 424 N.E.2d 282; 1981 Ohio LEXIS 544; 21 Ohio Op. 3d 5



July 1, 1981, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

This dispute arose when Lawrence W. Sirk, claimant, was injured during the course of his employment with the Kanter Corporation on January 8, 1974. Claimant, a minor at the time of his injury, was injured when his left forearm became entangled in a rotating salt truck auger which he was cleaning. Claimant filed a claim for workers' compensation which was allowed.

Subsequently, claimant filed a motion pursuant to R. C. 4123.89 with the Bureau of Workers' Compensation requesting the Industrial Commission to allow him an additional award of 100 percent of the maximum award established by law. Claimant based his motion upon the allegation that his injury was a direct result of his employment, in violation of (former) R. C. 4109.12(D) and (U). The commission granted claimant's motion.

Having no right of appeal from the commission's order, the appellee employer initiated this action in the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County by filing a complaint for a writ of mandamus against the appellants, Anthony Stringer, Administrator of the Bureau of Workers' Compensation, and the members of the Industrial Commission. Appellee [***2] requested a writ of mandamus vacating the order awarding the additional 100 percent, and directing the commission to conduct a further hearing to determine a just additional award not less than 15 percent nor more than 50 percent of the maximum award established by law. To support its position, appellee argued that, to the extent it requires an additional award in excess of 50 percent, R. C. 4123.89 conflicts with Section 35, Article II of the Ohio Constitution. 

The Court of Common Pleas held R. C. 4123.89 unconstitutional to the extent that it mandates an additional award in excess of the maximum amount authorized by Section 35, Article II of the Ohio Constitution. Accordingly, the court issued a writ of mandamus ordering the commission to vacate its order and hold a supplementary hearing to determine a just additional award, to be not less than 15 percent nor more than 50 percent of the maximum award authorized.

On appeal and cross-appeal, the Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas.

This cause is before the court pursuant to an allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, administrator of the Ohio Bureau of Workers' Compensation and members of the Ohio Industrial Commission, sought review of the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which granted appellee employer's requested writ of mandamus against the administrator and commission after the commission permitted a claimant an additional award of 100 percent of the maximum award allowed by law under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4123.89.


OVERVIEW: The industrial commission found that claimant's injury was caused by employment which was prohibited by (former) Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4109.12(D) and (U). The industrial commission allowed the claimant an additional award of 100 percent of the maximum award established by law. The trial and the appellate courts ruled that § 4123.89 conflicted with Ohio Const. art. II, § 35 because it mandated an additional award in excess of 50 percent. The court rejected the administrator and commission's contention that there was no conflict between Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4123.89 and Ohio Const. art. II, § 35 and that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4123.89 was not enacted to provide for specific safety requirements. The court reasoned that the commission's contention ignored both the legislative history of § 4123.89 and the limitations placed upon the Ohio General Assembly by Ohio Const. art. II, § 35. The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment and held that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4123.89 established specific safety requirements within the meaning and limitations of Ohio Const. art. II, § 35.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment, which issued the employer's requested writ of mandamus.

 

28 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Unger


No. 80-1297


Supreme Court of Ohio


67 Ohio St. 2d 65; 423 N.E.2d 1078; 1981 Ohio LEXIS 550; 21 Ohio Op. 3d 41



July 1, 1981, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Miami County.

On the afternoon of January 21, 1979, defendant, Jerry Unger, appellant herein, was drinking beer with Rex A. Hopkins at Miller's Bar in Arcanum, Ohio. The victim, Dennis Weaver, arrived at the bar and asked defendant for a ride to Minster, Ohio. Defendant agreed to transport Weaver to Minster and asked Hopkins to accompany them on the trip.

As this trio was driving along, defendant and Hopkins decided, for an inexplicable reason, to kill Weaver. Towards this end, defendant drove to a rustic area along the Stillwater River. There, while defendant repeatedly stabbed the decedent, Hopkins beat him with a tire iron. In an attempt to conceal the body, both men dragged the victim to an outhouse and placed him therein. Hopkins also removed Weaver's wallet.

On the return trip to Arcanum, Unger and Hopkins stopped at a gasoline service station in Pitsburg, Ohio, where they informed one Alvin Bird of the murder which they had just committed. Bird notified a Darke County deputy sheriff of this incident.

In the early morning hours of January 22, 1979, the Darke County deputy sheriff, accompanied by Bird and a Miami [***2] County deputy sheriff, searched the aforementioned site of the murder, where they discovered the mutilated body of the victim.

Shortly thereafter, sheriff's deputies from Darke and Miami Counties arrested the defendant at his residence in Darke County, gave him his Miranda warnings and transported him to the Miami County Jail. During a subsequent interrogation by detectives from the Miami County Sheriff's Department, at which defendant was, again, apprised of his Miranda rights, defendant made a full confession pertaining to his participation in Weaver's murder.

Defendant was indicted for aggravated murder, in violation of R. C. 2903.01(A), and, on arraignment, entered a plea of not guilty and not guilty by reason of insanity. Accordingly, the trial court, on March 14, 1979, referred Unger to the Dayton Area Forensic Psychiatry Services, pursuant to R. C. 2945.39, for a psychological examination and determination of his mental condition at the time of Weaver's murder. Defendant was informed by the trial court, simultaneous to this referral, that not only was he entitled to an independent psychiatric evaluation, but also, that he had the option to secure the independent [***3] examination at public expense.

On April 11, 1979, five days before his scheduled trial, defendant requested and received a continuance from the trial court, until May 14, 1979, for the reason that another psychiatrist had purportedly agreed to examine him, apparently at the defendant's or his family's expense. This examination never took place, allegedly because the psychiatrist would not perform the examination.

In the interim, Dayton Area Forensic Psychiatry Services issued a report which concluded that defendant, at the time of the murder, was capable of distinguishing right from wrong and that he "engaged in a series of purposive actions which required control and some degree of planning."

On May 9, 1979, five days before the rescheduled trial, defendant requested another continuance for the reason that he needed more time to secure a private, independent psychiatric evaluation. After a hearing, the trial court overruled defendant's motion for this second continuance and the case proceeded to trial. Defendant was convicted af aggravated murder.

The Court of Appeals affirmed this conviction.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion for [***4] leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged the decision of the Court of Appeals for Miami County (Ohio), which affirmed his conviction for aggravated murder.


OVERVIEW: Defendant stabbed the victim to death in a rural area after the victim went to the bar where defendant was drinking and sought a ride. Defendant was convicted of aggravated murder. The appellate court affirmed the conviction. Defendant sought review, contending that the trial court abused its discretion in refusing to grant a second continuance; that his confession should have been be suppressed because the police violated Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2935.14; and that his automobile was unconstitutionally seized. On appeal the court affirmed, holding that defendant was informed, well in advance of any trial date, of his prerogative to have an additional psychiatric examination, so that he was not prejudiced by the denial of a late continuance when he failed to act earlier. In addition, even if § 2935.14 was violated by defendant's transportation to another county before being allowed to speak to an attorney, the exclusionary rule was not violated because the statutory violation did not rise to a constitutional level. Finally, the impoundment of defendant's vehicle was reasonable and consistent with the tests mandated by controlling constitutional precedent.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for aggravated murder.

 

29 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Slatter


No. 80-852


Supreme Court of Ohio


66 Ohio St. 2d 452; 423 N.E.2d 100; 1981 Ohio LEXIS 532; 20 Ohio Op. 3d 383



June 24, 1981, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Athens County.

On October 28, 1978, Jauffre T. Slatter, appellee, was observed by two police officers to be holding an open container of an alcoholic beverage while standing on the west side of North Court Street in Athens, Ohio. The officers approached appellee and, since he was standing with a large group of people who were engaging in a "Halloween celebration," asked him to accompany them across the street. While escorting appellee across the street, one of the officers placed his hand on appellee's arm. Upon reaching the east side of North Court Street, the officers asked appellee for identification and, when appellee could not produce any, appellee was placed under arrest for a violation of an Athens city ordinance that prohibits the possession of open containers of alcohol on the public street, a minor misdemeanor. 1 Appellee was then taken to a police cruiser for transportation to police headquarters, but before he could be placed in the cruiser one of the arresting officers was attacked from behind by an unknown assailant. When the second officer went to the defense of his partner, appellee fled the scene. Appellee was later [***2] arrested and indicted for a violation of R. C. 2921.34, escape. 2 


1 The "open container" prohibition is set forth in Section 93.04 of the Code of Ordinances of Athens, Ohio, as follows: "No person shall have in his possession an open bottle, * * * containing any liquor, * * * in any other public place." Section 11.01 of the Code of Ordinances of Athens states: "Each act or omission which is prohibited or declared unlawful in this Code of Ordinances is a minor misdemeanor, and in case no penalty of fine or imprisonment is otherwise provided, the offender, upon conviction, shall be fined not more than $ 100.00 for each such offense."


2 R. C. 2921.34 reads, in part: "(A) No person, knowing he is under detention or being reckless in that regard, shall purposely break or attempt to break such detention, or purposely fail to return to detention, either following temporary leave granted for a specific purpose or limited period, or at the time required when serving a sentence in intermittent confinement."

Appellee filed a pre-trial motion to suppress at trial any evidence concerning the initial arrest for the "open container" violation, asserting that his arrest occurred on the [***3] west side of North Court Street and that such arrest was prohibited by R. C. 2935.26(A). The state of Ohio, appellant, argued that the arrest had occurred on the east side of North Court Street, after appellee had been unable to produce identification, and, thus, was proper under R. C. 2935.26(A)(2). Alternatively, appellant argued that R. C. 2935.26 was unconstitutional as being in conflict with Crim. R. 4.1(A) and (C). At the hearing on the motion, the trial court found R. C. 2935.26 not to be unconstitutionally in conflict with Crim. R. 4.1. The trial court also found:

"1.) The arrest of the defendant occurred on the West [sic] side of N. Court Street in front of the Junction Bar.

"2.) The arrest of the defendant was in violation of O.R.C. 2935.26 and therefore unlawful.

"3.) Evidence of the arrest and all surrounding or related activity is ORDERED suppressed."

Upon appeal of the constitutionality of R. C. 2935.26, the Court of Appeals for Athens County held that the statute created a substantive right of "non-arrest except where § 2935.26(A)(1)(2)(3)(4) apply. * * * This statute acts to preclude arrest and is a guarantee of personal freedom given by the legislature [***4] where no such right existed before." Thus, the statute was held to be not in conflict with a rule of procedure promulgated by this court. The judgment of the trial court was affirmed.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State challenged the decision of the Court of Appeals (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's decision to suppress evidence of defendant's arrest upon a violation of Ohio Rev. Code § 2935.26 regarding authorization to arrest for the commission of a minor misdemeanor. The trial court held that § 2935.26 created a substantive right of non-arrest with limited exceptions. Defendant had been arrested for an open intoxicants charge.


OVERVIEW: The State contended that § 2935.26 conflicted with Ohio R. Crim. P. 3, 4, and 4.1 and was in violation of Ohio Const. art. IV, § 5(B). The court disagreed and affirmed the decision of the appellate court, holding that § 2935.26 created a substantive right of freedom from arrest for one accused of the commission of a minor misdemeanor unless one of the statutory exemptions existed. The court agreed with the appellate court that the statute acted to preclude arrest and was a guarantee of personal freedom given by the legislature where no such right existed before. The right of non-arrest for a minor misdemeanor was created, defined, and regulated by the statute. The statute further was not to pertain to the method of enforcing that right as Ohio R. Crim. P. 4.1 did. The court found that the statute and the rule were complimentary, not in conflict.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the appellate court, which upheld the validity of the statute pertaining to arrests for the commission of a minor misdemeanor and with regard to defendant's arrest for open intoxicants despite the State's appeal of that decision.

 

30 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Johnston v. Taulbee


No. 80-1437


Supreme Court of Ohio


66 Ohio St. 2d 417; 423 N.E.2d 80; 1981 Ohio LEXIS 526; 20 Ohio Op. 3d 361



June 17, 1981, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hocking County.

In June 1979, Edwin C. Johnston, Judge of the Juvenile Division of the Court of Common Pleas of Hocking County (hereinafter appellee), submitted to the Board of County Commissioners of Hocking County (hereinafter appellants) a written request for an appropriation of funds for the 1980 fiscal year of $ 87,550, which included a personal service schedule for salaries of $ 71,000 and a departmental budget of $ 16,550.

The parties met twice in late December of 1979 to discuss appellee's appropriation request, the only significant change being a compromised reduction of the personal service schedule from $ 71,000 to $ 68,700.

Pursuant to R. C. 2101.11, appellants, on January 2, 1980, advertised that, on January 3, a public hearing would be held to consider the written request submitted by appellee for the 1980 fiscal year.

After the hearing, appellants appropriated to the appellee for the operation of the Juvenile Court for 1980 the sum of $ 65,250, which included $ 53,050 for the personal service schedule and $ 12,200 for the departmental budget.

Dissatisfied with the allocation, appellee timely initiated [***2] an original action in mandamus in the Court of Appeals, praying that appellants be ordered to appropriate all the funds requested.

After an evidentiary hearing, the Court of Appeals granted appellee's request for the issuance of a writ of mandamus and ordered appellants to appropriate to the appellee $ 85,200, which consisted of $ 68,700 for the personal service schedule and $ 16,500 for the departmental budget.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant board of county commissioners challenged the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Hocking County (Ohio), which granted the request of appellee judge of a juvenile court for the issuance of a writ of mandamus and ordered the board to appropriate the funds requested by the judge for the juvenile court's budget.


OVERVIEW: The judge submitted a written request for an appropriation of funds for a fiscal year. The request included a personal service schedule for salaries and a departmental budget. The board met with the judge twice to discuss the appropriation request. The only significant change made to the request was a slight reduction of the personal service schedule. The board advertised that a public hearing would be held to consider the judge's request. After the hearing, the board appropriated much less than the amount in the judge's request. The judge initiated an original action in mandamus in the appellate court, praying that the board be ordered to appropriate all the funds requested. The appellate court granted the request for the issuance of a writ of mandamus and ordered the board to appropriate to the judge the requested funds. The board appealed. The court affirmed, holding that the board was required to appropriate the funds requested by the judge. The court reasoned that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2151.10, which gave the board discretion to appropriate funds to the juvenile court, was an unconstitutional legislative encroachment and impeded the judiciary in the administration of justice.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment granting the judge's request for the issuance of a writ of mandamus and ordering the board to appropriate the funds requested.

 

31 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


In re Furnishings & Equipment for Judge, Courtroom & Personnel for Courtroom Two


No. 80-1032


Supreme Court of Ohio


66 Ohio St. 2d 427; 423 N.E.2d 86; 1981 Ohio LEXIS 527; 20 Ohio Op. 3d 367



June 17, 1981, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Wood County.

On November 30, 1979, appellant, Judge Donald D. Simmons of the Court of Common Pleas of Wood County, entered a "Journal Entry and Order" directing appellees, the Board of County Commissioners and the Auditor of Wood County, to purchase, without competitive bidding, certain furnishings and equipment that appellant had ordered from David A. Sanders, Inc., for use in connection with Courtroom Two of the Wood County Courthouse. In this ex parte order, appellant found that a real and present emergency existed because construction was soon to be completed on Courtroom Two and there was no suitable or available equipment and furnishings for the courtroom, jury room, judge's chambers, and that the need and cost of these items had not been budgeted with the cost of the construction and renovation project.

On December 21, 1979, Judge Simmons entered a second order in response to a letter he had received that day from the board of county commissioners, in which they indicated they would not comply with the court's order of November 30. In the second order, appellant ordered appellees to appear in court on January [***2] 7, 1980, for a hearing to determine whether appellees would comply with the order of November 30 and to show cause why the commissioners should not be punished for their apparent contempt of court.

On December 31, 1979, appellees filed a notice of appeal from the November 30 judgment entry and order, and a motion for a stay of enforcement of judgment pending appeal without a supersedeas bond. Appellees, on the same day, also filed a writ of prohibition to prohibit the proposed January 7 proceedings. The Court of Appeals dismissed the complaint for a writ of prohibition 1 and granted a stay of enforcement of the November 30 order pending appeal without supersedeas bond.


1 Although appellees did not cross appeal the issue, we point out that the Court of Appeals acted correctly in dismissing appellee's complaint in prohibition. A common pleas court has jurisdiction to enforce its order against a board of county commissioners by proceedings in contempt. State, ex rel. Bd. of County Commrs., v.. Juvenile Division (1978), 54 Ohio St. 2d 113.

In a split decision, the Court of Appeals reversed the trial court. The majority found that Judge Simmons did not have the [***3] authority to issue the ex parte order of November 30 ordering appellees to purchase the furnishings and equipment for Courtroom Two without competitive bidding. The court determined that the remedy the judge should have sought to compel such purchases was a writ of mandamus.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Appeal dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant judge of the trial court entered an order directing appellees, the Board of County Commissioners and the Auditor of Wood County, to purchase, without competitive bidding, certain furnishings and equipment that the judge had ordered for use in the courthouse. The judge then issued an order for a hearing. Appellees appealed. The Court of Appeals for Wood County (Ohio) reversed the trial court. The judge appealed.


OVERVIEW: The judge had issued a second order for appellees to appear in court for a hearing to determine whether they would comply with the original order and to show cause why they should not have been punished for their apparent contempt of court. The appellate court found that the judge did not have the authority to issue the ex parte order ordering appellees to purchase the furnishings and equipment for the courthouse without competitive bidding. The appellate court determined that the remedy the judge should have sought to compel such purchases was a writ of mandamus. The court disagreed and held that when a board of county commissioners refused to appropriate funds or provide quarters and equipment reasonably requested by the court, a judge may seek to enforce his order by way of mandamus or by proceedings in contempt. When the judge undertook to enforce his order by proceedings in contempt, instead of by way of mandamus, the board's remedy was by way of appeal from a finding of contempt. Until there was a hearing in the contempt proceedings, there was no final appealable order.


OUTCOME: The appeal was dismissed.

 

32 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Meshel v. Keip


No. 81-153


Supreme Court of Ohio


66 Ohio St. 2d 379; 423 N.E.2d 60; 1981 Ohio LEXIS 523; 20 Ohio Op. 3d 338



June 10, 1981, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

Am. Sub. H. B. No. 204, which became effective on July 30, 1979, and terminates on June 30, 1981, sets forth the appropriations for fiscal year 1980 (July 1, 1979 to June 30, 1980) and fiscal year 1981 (July 1, 1980 to June 30, 1981). The Act made a number of appropriations to the Ohio Rail Transportation Authority (ORTA), including three general revenue fund appropriations, these being (1) account number 401, which consists of $ 500,000 for line acquisition ($ 250,000 each year), (2) account number 402, which consists of $ 200,000 for line maintenance ($ 100,000 for each fiscal year), and (3) account number 403, which consists of $ 1,677,812 for the high speed rail program ($ 1,127,812 for fiscal year 1980, $ 550,000 for fiscal year 1981).

On June 30, 1980, the Controlling Board approved a request to transfer $ 932,704 from ORTA's appropriation for fiscal year 1980 to ORTA's account number 403 for fiscal year 1981. The $ 932,704 consisted of unspent funds appropriated to accounts numbers 401, 402 and 403, as well as to two other accounts. This action prevented the amounts appropriated from lapsing pursuant to R. C. 131.33, which states, in part:

"Except [***2] as provided in this section, appropriations made to a specific fiscal year shall only be expended to pay liabilities incurred within that fiscal year. * * *"

In the late summer and early fall of 1980, ORTA solicited responses from engineering firms regarding the building of a test track to be located in northeastern Ohio. Eighteen firms formed four teams which presented their proposals to a select committee of legislators, ORTA board members, and staff. The committee recommended that a team consisting of Dalton, Dalton, Newport, Inc., as prime consultant, in association with Japan Railway Technical Services, DeLeuw and Poly-Tech, Inc., be selected as the consultant and awarded a contract.

On January 7, 1981, the ORTA board, by resolution, awarded a contract to the Dalton team for approximately $ 1,200,000. On January 16, 1981, an ORTA employee hand-delivered an application for encumbrancy, accompanied by two copies of the contract, to the Office of Budget and Management for processing.

On January 26, 1981, pursuant to the request of William D. Keip, the Director of the Office of Budget and Management, the Controlling Board met in special session and transferred the appropriations [***3] of numerous state agencies for fiscal year 1981 into fiscal year 1980. Among the sums so transferred was $ 1,288,245 from ORTA's account number 403. This sum was then considered to have lapsed under R. C. 131.33, and the applied-for certification could not be given.

On January 30, 1981, Harry Meshel, a taxpayer of the state of Ohio and a member of the General Assembly, filed an action in this court seeking a writ of mandamus compelling Keip to certify the availability and adequacy of funds sufficient for the contract with the Dalton team. On March 5, 1981, Meshel amended the complaint to include William W. Wilkins, the Director of Administrative Services, as a party.



DISPOSITION: Writ allowed in part and denied in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator, a member of the General Assembly, sought a writ of mandamus compelling respondent state officials to certify the availability of funding for a contract for a rail transportation project.


OVERVIEW: Funding was not certified for a contract because the Controlling Board had transferred rail transportation appropriations to a prior fiscal year, thereby causing them to lapse. A member of the General Assembly contended that the transfer was unlawful because legislative authority had been unconstitutionally delegated to the Board. The court held that the Board had effectively deappropriated funds without express legislative authority and granted the writ in part. Because Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 127.17 restricted the Board's actions to those required to carry out legislative intent, appropriations for a current year could not be eliminated by transfer to a prior year. However, appropriations that had been carried forward from a prior year could be transferred back to the year of appropriation without violating the General Assembly's purposes. Legislative authority was not unconstitutionally delegated to the Board because § 127.17 imposed restrictions on its ability to transfer funds. Neither the Board nor its actions violated Ohio Const. art. II, §§ 4, 27 because Board membership was not a public office forbidden to legislators.


OUTCOME: The court allowed the writ in part and denied it in part.

 

33 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Schomaeker v. First Nat'l Bank


No. 80-885


Supreme Court of Ohio


66 Ohio St. 2d 304; 421 N.E.2d 530; 1981 Ohio LEXIS 514; 20 Ohio Op. 3d 285



June 3, 1981, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Putnam County.

Defendant-appellant, First National Bank of Ottawa, operates a bank in the village of Ottawa, Ohio, on property zoned B-2, central business district, designated pursuant to Ottawa Zoning Ordinance No. 944.

In order to provide expanded employee and customer parking, the bank negotiated an option to purchase Inlot No. 19, a parcel separated from the bank's property only by an alley. Inlot No. 19 is located in an area zoned R-1, residential.

The bank applied for a variance to permit use of Inlot No. 19 as a parking lot. The village clerk authorized the use by issuing a certificate of occupancy. The bank thereupon bought and acquired title to Inlot No. 19.

Thereafter, plaintiff-appellee, Eileen D. Schomaeker, a contiguous property owner in the R-1 residential area, filed an injuction action against the bank in case No. 77-104 in the Court of Common Pleas of Putnam County challenging the certificate of occupancy granted the bank for Inlot No. 19. The court enjoined the bank from developing a parking lot on Inlot No. 19 until it could obtain a valid variance from the village of Ottawa Planning Commission. Pursuant [***2] to this court order, the bank applied to the planning commission for a use variance. After a public hearing attended by a number of interested citizens including plaintiff, the planning commission granted the use variance sought by the bank, making it subject to specific conditions involving landscaping, lighting and fencing.

Plaintiff then instituted the present action in the Court of Common Pleas, seeking a declaratory judgment holding the use variance granted by the planning commission void. The court declared that the planning commission fully complied with the applicable zoning provisions in granting the use variance in question.

Plaintiff then appealed this judgment to the Court of Appeals which, by a split decision, reversed the trial court. It held that the grant of a use variance, in effect, constituted rezoning as a matter of law. Such legislative action, the court decided, exceeded the authority of the planning commission to grant variances as provided by Section 402.3 of the zoning ordinance. To authorize a use not permitted by the zoning ordinance would require legislative action by the village council.

This cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance [***3] of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant landowner filed a declaratory judgment action seeking to declare void a use variance appellee planning commission granted to appellee bank. The Court of Appeals for Putnam County (Ohio) reversed the trial court in holding that the commission exceeded its authority under Ottawa, Oh., Zoning Ordinance § 402.3 in granting the use variance because such grant constituted rezoning. The commission and bank appealed.


OVERVIEW: The bank applied for a use variance to use certain property as a parking lot. The landowner filed a suit against the bank to challenge the certificate of occupancy granted to it, and the trial court enjoined the bank from developing the lot until it obtained a valid variance from the commission.
