The landowner then filed a declaratory judgment action against the bank and commission. The court held (1) the commission effectively granted a use variance under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 713.11, which allowed the city to delegate to the commission the power to grant variances; (2) the granting of the use variance was not rezoning, or an impermissible delegation of legislative power, but an exercise of administrative or quasi-judicial power and not inconsistent with Ottawa, Oh., Zoning Ordinance § 402.3; (3) the landowner failed to exhaust administrative remedies under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2506.01 in not appealing the granting of the use variance; and (4) the suit was barred by res judicata because the trial court's determination that the grant of a use variance, when the specified conditions existed, would allow the bank to construct the lot, barred relitigation of such issue.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment for the landowner.

 

34 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Saunders v. Clark County Zoning Dep't


No. 80-756


Supreme Court of Ohio


66 Ohio St. 2d 259; 421 N.E.2d 152; 1981 Ohio LEXIS 506; 20 Ohio Op. 3d 244



May 27, 1981, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Clark County.

Rev. William E. Saunders, Jr., and Horizon House, plaintiffs-appellees, filed a complaint in the Court of Common Pleas of Clark County seeking declaratory and injunctive relief against defendants, the Clark County Zoning Department, appellant herein, John Houser, the zoning inspector, and others. The issue raised was whether the foster care facility operated by plaintiffs for adjudicated delinquent boys was "a family" for zoning purposes, and therefore was legally located within an area zoned "R-1 suburban residence district."

On September 4, 1978, plaintiff Saunders, an ordained minister of the Church of the Nazarene, obtained approval from the Ohio Youth Commission to use his residence at 2805 Fowler Road, Enon, Ohio, in Clark County, as a foster care facility for the treatment and rehabilitation of ten youths. Plaintiff, and his wife and five children, lived at this residence together with as many as nine foster children placed by the youth commission at various times. Plaintiff's home on Fowler Road was in area zoned "R-1 suburban residence district." From January 1978 to October 1978, the Saunders had operated [***2] a foster care facility at a farm in Cable, Ohio, in conjunction with the Fowler Road residence.

In October 1978, plaintiff's group home, Horizon House, was incorporated as a non-profit corporation. Plaintiff and his wife also had been approved as foster parents by the Ohio Department of Public Welfare. A few persons were hired to assist plaintiff and his wife to care for their foster children.

Plaintiff's Fowler Road residence is a large two-story split level house containing seven bedrooms, four bathrooms, a living room, a dining room and a kitchen.

John Houser, the zoning inspector, testified that on October 20, 1978, he sent a letter to plaintiff to "cease and desist" operation of the foster home. Following administrative and legal skirmishing between plaintiff and the zoning officials, Houser notified plaintiff by letter dated May 31, 1979, that he was operating a "boarding house" at his Fowler Road residence in an R-1 district in violation of the Clark County Zoning Resolution. The inspector's letter also stated that if plaintiff wished to continue that operation he was required to apply for rezoning into an R-4 district.

Plaintiffs, on June 8, 1979, filed the instant [***3] complaint for declaratory and injunctive relief to enable them to continue operation of the Horizon House foster care home on Fowler Road.

The trial court rendered judgment finding Horizon House to be a "boarding house"; that continued operation in an area zoned "R-1 suburban residence district" violated the Clark County Zoning Resolution; and that its permitted use was for an R-4 district. Plaintiffs were denied the relief requested, and final judgment was rendered in favor of defendants.

On appeal, the Court of Appeals reversed, holding that "[a] group of two or more children living together with foster parents as a single housekeeping unit constitutes a 'family' and is a permissible R-1 use under the express language of * * * [Subarticle] 4.18 of the zoning resolution of Clark County."

This cause in now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, the county zoning department, the zoning inspector, and others, sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Clark County (Ohio) that reversed a judgment and found in favor of appellees, a foster home and its operator.


OVERVIEW: The foster home and its operator filed a complaint seeking declaratory and injunctive relief against appellants. The issue was whether the foster care facility for adjudicated delinquent boys was "a family" for zoning purposes, and therefore was legally located within an area zoned R-1 suburban residence district. After close examination of the relevant provisions of the zoning resolution and giving due deference to the applicable principles of law, the court held that the foster home fit the definition of "family" under Clark County, Ohio, Zoning Resolution 4.18. Therefore, the foster home and its operator were entitled to a declaratory judgment authorizing the use of the foster home for the described purpose of a foster home.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment from the appellate court in favor of the foster home and its operator finding that the foster home was legally located with an area zoned R-1 suburban residence district.

 

35 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Burch v. Perini


No. 80-1339


Supreme Court of Ohio


66 Ohio St. 2d 174; 420 N.E.2d 1001; 1981 Ohio LEXIS 491; 20 Ohio Op. 3d 189



May 20, 1981, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN HABEAS CORPUS.

David W. Burch, petitioner herein, was charged by the Summit County Grand Jury in a 19-count indictment for his participation in an international narcotics smuggling and distribution operation. After a trial, at which he was represented by counsel, a jury found petitioner guilty of engaging in organized crime, of four counts of conspiracy and of permitting drug abuse, in violation of R. C. 2923.04, 2923.01 and 2925.13, respectively. The Court of Common Pleas sentenced petitioner to five to twenty-five years imprisonment for engaging in organized crime and to three to fifteen years for one count of conspiracy, the sentences to run consecutively. Additionally, the court imposed a ten to twenty year sentence of imprisonment for the remaining three counts of conspiracy. Finally, a six month jail sentence was imposed for the drug abuse offense.

Pursuant to a journal entry of the Court of Common Pleas, petitioner was committed to the Marion Correctional Institution, of which respondent herein is superintendent.

The Court of Appeals affirmed petitioner's convictions for engaging in organized crime and permitting drug abuse, and reversed the convictions for [***2] the conspiracy offenses. In so doing, the Court of Appeals ruled that the conspiracy offenses merged with the conviction for engaging in organized crime, a violation of R. C. 2923.04.

Petitioner then prosecuted an appeal to this court (case No. 80-113), which reversed and remanded his case to the Court of Appeals for resolution of the issues in light of our decision in State v.. Young (1980), 62 Ohio St. 2d 370, certiorari denied    U.S.   , 66 L. Ed. 2d 137, a case which held the organized crime statute unconstitutional. 

Petitioner then brought this action seeking a writ of habeas corpus in this court. Petitioner contends, in essence, that both the trial and appellate courts abused their discretion in not granting his motion for bail pending the remand of his case from this court.



DISPOSITION: Writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner filed an application for a writ of habeas corpus. He asserted that both the trial court and the court of appeals had abused their discretion in not granting his motion for bail pending the remand of his case to the court of appeals. He argued that he was entitled to release on the grounds that he had already served his sentence on the only offense that had not been reversed on appeal.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner had been imprisoned after being convicted of engaging in organized crime, four counts of conspiracy, and permitting drug abuse. The court of appeals reversed petitioner's convictions on the conspiracy counts on the grounds that they merged with the conviction for engaging in organized crime. On further appeal, the court reversed and remanded the case to the court of appeals for resolution in light of its decision holding the organized crime statute unconstitutional. Petitioner argued that, because he had served the sentence for the drug abuse offense, he should be released. The court stated that, when it remanded a cause to the court of appeals for resolution in light of a recent ruling, the remand was not a final determination of the case. Rather, the judgment would only be final when disposed of by the court of appeals. The court also noted that the court of appeals might want to closely examine its ruling on the conspiracy counts and that the remand would not necessarily result in petitioner's release. The court concluded that the courts below had not abused their discretion in denying bail to assure petitioner's appearance at the further proceedings.


OUTCOME: The court denied petitioner's application for a writ of habeas corpus.

 

36 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Townsend v. Dollison


No. 80-1258


Supreme Court of Ohio


66 Ohio St. 2d 225; 421 N.E.2d 146; 1981 Ohio LEXIS 500; 20 Ohio Op. 3d 220



May 20, 1981, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Summit County.

Pursuant to R. C. 4507.40, the driver's license of Michael Townsend, appellant herein, was suspended on December 26, 1978, for his accumulation of 12 points within a two-year period.

The facts of this case, as stipulated by the parties, show that, from 1974 to November 1976, appellant lived at 337 Brown Street in Akron, Ohio. Since that time, appellant has lived in various other places in the Akron area. Appellant renewed his license on September 10, 1977. The last known address of the appellant appears on the records of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles as 337 Brown Street.

The bureau twice sent notice of the license suspension by certified mail to appellant at 337 Brown Street. The notice of suspension was unclaimed.

Appellant continued driving through the period of suspension until October 29, 1979, when he was stopped by Akron police and charged with driving an unsafe vehicle. He was also charged with driving on a suspended license.

On or about January 9, 1980, appellant filed a license petition in Akron Municipal Court asserting that the suspension order was ineffective since he had not received actual notice [***2] of the suspension. That court denied the petition, in effect determining that the Bureau of Motor Vehicles had complied with the notice requirement of R. C. 4507.40(K) by sending the suspension notice to appellant at 337 Brown Street.

The Court of Appeals affirmed the trial court and, finding its judgment to be in conflict with the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County in Fell v.. Bur. of Motor Vehicles (1972), 30 Ohio App. 2d 151, certified the record of the case to this court for review and final determination.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant driver sought review of an order of the Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio), which affirmed a municipal court's denial of the driver's petition that asserted that the driver's license suspension order was ineffective because he had not received actual notice of the suspension. The denial was based on the fact that respondent Bureau of Motor Vehicles had complied with the notice requirements of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4507.40(K).


OVERVIEW: The driver claimed that the notice provision in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4507.40(K) had to be interpreted to require actual notice or he would be denied due process of law. On review the court found no error. The court noted that the constitutionality of a notice mechanism was dependent upon the likelihood of its ultimate success in notifying an interested party of a pending action. A method for providing notice had to be reasonably calculated, under all the circumstances, to apprise interested parties of the pendency of the action and afford them an opportunity to present their objections. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4507.40(K) required that notice by the registrar be sent to the last known address of the licensee. However, the licensee had the obligation to supply his last known address. A letter mailed to an incorrect address supplied by the driver constituted neglect on his part. If the address was in error because of the driver's fault, he could not later be heard to complain that he did not get notice at his last known address.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals.

 

37 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Board of Education v. Board of Education


No. 80-1134


Supreme Court of Ohio


66 Ohio St. 2d 152; 420 N.E.2d 990; 1981 Ohio LEXIS 488; 20 Ohio Op. 3d 165



May 13, 1981, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

In January 1977, appellant, Board of Education of the Marion City School District, requested the transfer to its district of certain parcels of land previously annexed to the city from three adjacent school districts, Pleasant, River Valley, and Elgin locals. The boards of education of these districts are designated appellees herein. R. C. 3311.06 requires the approval of appellee Ohio State Board of Education (state board) of any such transfer. 1 Accordingly, application for this transfer was made to the state board which, at the request of appellees, appointed a referee to conduct hearings on the matter pursuant to R. C. Chapter 119. After the adjudication hearing, the referee recommended approval of some parcels for transfer, and disapproval of others. Objections to the referee's report and recommendations were filed and thereafter, on March 12, 1979, the state board disapproved the transfer of any of the requested territory.


1 R. C. 3311.06 provides in pertinent part:

"* * * When the territory * * * [newly] annexed to a city or village comprises part but not all of the territory of a school district, the said territory becomes part of the said city school district * * * only upon approval by the state board of education."

 [***2] Appellant timely filed an appeal pursuant to R. C. 119.12 in the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County, asserting that no reliable, probative or substantial evidence supported the state board's denial of the transfer of territory. The court determined that there was "some reliable, probative and substantial evidence in support of the Board's order and it was issued in accordance with law," and thereupon ordered the appeal dismissed.

Upon appeal, the Court of Appeals ordered "that the judgment of the Common Pleas Court of Franklin County is modified to show [a] lack of jurisdiction in accordance with this decision and, as modified, is affirmed." The Court of Appeals held that the disapproval of the requested transfer was a legislative act of the State Board of Education and, as such, was not appealable to the common pleas court.

This cause in now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city school board challenged a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which modified the common pleas court's affirmance of an order of the state board of education denying the city school board's request for transfer of certain properties belonging to appellee local school boards into the city school board's district. The court of appeals found that the common pleas court lacked jurisdiction to hear the appeal.


OVERVIEW: The city school board sought review of the court of appeals' determination that the courts lacked jurisdiction to rule on a decision made by the state board of education. The court affirmed the judgment, finding that the act of the state board of education disapproving the transfer of land from one school district to another was a quasi-legislative act not subject to review by the courts. As a legislative act, it was not appealable pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 119.12, which allowed appeal of certain administrative decisions to the common pleas court.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals that found that the court of common pleas had no jurisdiction to rule on the city school board's appeal from the state board of education's denial of its request to transfer properties into its district.

 

38 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Office of Consumers' Counsel v. Public Utilities Com.


No. 80-747


Supreme Court of Ohio


66 Ohio St. 2d 162; 420 N.E.2d 993; 1981 Ohio LEXIS 490; 20 Ohio Op. 3d 171



May 13, 1981, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Public Utilities Commission.

On December 29, 1978, intervening appellee, Ohio Edison Company (company), filed with appellee Public Utilities Commission of Ohio (commission), notices of intent to file applications for rate increases. In the notices of intent, the company requested that the 12 months ending September 30, 1979, be established as the test period and that March 31, 1979, serve as the date certain. The commission, by entries dated January 30, 1979, approved the requested test period and date certain.

The company filed the applications 1 with the commission on April 2, 1979, which were accepted on May 23, 1979. On July 12, 1979, the commission granted appellant, Office of Consumers' Counsel (appellant), leave to intervene in the proceedings.


1 The company filed two applications with the commission. One application, 78-1567-EL-AIR, involved a rate increase for the company's urban customers. The other, 78-1568-EL-AIR, involved a rate increase for the company's rural customers. The cases were heard as one before the commission, and have been so treated by the parties to this appeal.

Subsequently, the commission's staff conducted an [***2] investigation on the company's applications and filed a written report with the commission on the investigation. Appellant timely filed objections to the staff's report.

Public hearings were commenced on November 7, 1979, and concluded on December 17, 1979. On January 30, 1980, the commission issued its opinion and order, from which this appeal is prosecuted. The portion of the order relevant to this appeal permitted the inclusion of approximately $ 125.5 million in the company's rate base as an allowance for construction work in progress (CWIP). The greatest portion of this amount represented a CWIP allowance for the construction of a coal-fired generating plant, Bruce Mansfield Unit No. 3, the third of three coal-fired generating plants which have been constructed by a consortium of power companies including Ohio Edison.

Appellant timely filed an application for rehearing which was denied in part and granted in part by the commission. The commission denied that portion of appellant's application for rehearing relating to the allowance of CWIP.

This cause is now before the court as an appeal of right.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant consumer advocate sought review of a decision by appellee Public Utilities Commission of Ohio, which authorized a rate increase sought by a public utility company that included an allowance for construction work in progress. The advocate argued that the Commission improperly applied Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4909.15(A)(1) and improperly applied the Commission's own requirements.


OVERVIEW: The Commission determined that one of the facilities being built by the company was 75 percent complete based upon a physical inspection, an elapsed time test, and a dollars obligated test. Under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4909.15(A)(1), the Commission determined that the company was entitled to an allowance for the construction work in progress. On appeal, the court concluded that § 4909.15(A)(1) did not require the Commission to determine the percentage of completion based upon a physical examination only. The court found that § 4909.15(A)(1) permitted the Commission to make an allowance based upon the extent to which a particular construction project was complete on a pro rata basis with other portions of an entire facility. The court determined that the Commission did not have rigid criteria for determining when an allowance for construction work in progress became effective. There was no requirement that the Commission only authorize an allowance for construction work in progress after a facility became operational.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the Commission's decision.

 

39 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Brown v. Cleveland


No. 80-789


Supreme Court of Ohio


66 Ohio St. 2d 93; 420 N.E.2d 103; 1981 Ohio LEXIS 479; 20 Ohio Op. 3d 88



April 29, 1981, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

Appellant, David L. Brown, owns an 8,040 square foot lot located on the northeast corner of East 117th Street and St. Clair Avenue in the city of Cleveland. Although this property is situated in an area which is zoned for local retail use and, therefore, an area where the operation of the gasoline service station is a prohibited use, appellant legally operates a gasoline service station thereon as a valid pre-existing, non-conforming use. 1 


1 Section 359.01 of the Cleveland Zoning Code provides:

"Existing Nonconforming Buildings and Uses.

"(a) Except as provided in Section 347.06 and Chapter 351, a use of building or land lawfully existing on the effective date of this Zoning Code or of any amendment or supplement thereto, or for which a permit has been lawfully issued, may be continued even though such use does not conform to the provisions of this Zoning Code for the use district in which it is located, but no enlargement or expansion shall be permitted except as a variance under the terms of Chapter 329, and no substitution or other change in such nonconforming use to other than a conforming use shall be permitted except by special permit from the Board of Zoning Appeals. Such special permit may be issued only if the Board finds after public hearing that such substitution or other change is no more harmful or objectionable than the previous nonconforming use in floor or other space occupied, in volume of trade or production, in kind of goods sold or produced, in daily hours or other period of use, in the type or number of persons to occupy or to be attracted to the premises or in any other characteristic of the new use as compared with the previous use.

"(b) The enactment of this Zoning Code shall not in any way affect the legality of previous orders requiring the discontinuance of nonconforming uses nor extend the time limit already established when existing nonconforming uses shall be discontinued. (Ord. No. 845-62. Passed April 27, 1964. Effective April 27, 1964.)"

 [***2] Appellant, having decided to diversify and expand his business, applied for a permit which would enable him to convert part of this gasoline service station into a grocery store, a permitted use, and to operate this structure in the dual capacity of a gasoline service station and a grocery store. The commissioner of buildings refused to issue the permit.

Contrary to the denial of a permit, appellant made the appropriate structural alterations to the gasoline service station and did, in fact, begin to operate the building as both a gasoline service station and a grocery store.

Appellant unsuccessfully sought a variance from the board of zoning appeals. In refusing to grant the requested variance, the board of zoning appeals found, inter alia, 2 that appellant's dual use of the property was in violation of the accessory off-street parking requirements of what is now Section 349.04 3 of the Cleveland Zoning Code.


2 The board of zoning appeals also found that the gasoline service station-grocery store combination violated Sections 343.13 and 355.03 of the Cleveland Zoning Code.

Section 343.13, in part, provides:

"Service stations are a permitted use in a General Retail Business District provided that:

"(a) The lot shall have an area of not less than 12,000 square feet and at least one street frontage of not less than 100 feet."

Section 355.03 provides:

"No yard, open space or lot area provided for any building or group of buildings for the purposes of complying with the requirements of this Zoning Code shall be reduced or again considered as the yard, open space or lot area required for any other building or additional construction on the same lot or on another lot. (Ord. No. 2204-A-48. Passed December 19, 1949. Effective January 29, 1950.)"


3 Section 349.04(f) requires at least one parking space for each 100 square feet of gross floor area for gasoline service stations and one parking space for each 500 square feet of gross floor area for food stores and supermarkets having less than 2,000 square feet of gross floor area. Pursuant to these provisions, the city zoning engineer testified before the board of zoning appeals that appellant was required to furnish seven to eight parking spaces.

 [***3] Pursuant to R. C. Chapter 2506, appellant prosecuted an administrative appeal to the Court of Common Pleas of Cuyahoga County and filed with the court a complete transcript, including all the testimony, exhibits, maps and photographs which had already been presented at the prior hearing of the board of zoning appeals. The judge, apparently attempting to avoid a rote repetition of the testimony which had been elicited at the hearing of the board of zoning appeals, granted appellant's motion to introduce additional evidence but restricted this additional evidence to evidence which, with reasonable diligence, could not have been discovered and produced at the previous hearing. At the conclusion of the proceedings in the trial court, the judge affirmed the board of zoning appeals' refusal to grant the variance.

Appellant then initiated an appeal to the Court of Appeals, which affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant gas station owner challenged a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed the judgment from the trial court that appellee city, through appellee board of zoning appeals, did not improperly restrict the owner's ability to place a grocery store with his gas station.


OVERVIEW: The owner wanted to add a grocery store to his gas station. The commissioner of buildings, the board of zoning appeals, the trial court, and the court of appeals each found that the grocery store's new venture required additional parking, which the owner failed to prove he could safely accommodate. On review, the owner argued that: (1) his property was immune from governmental regulation because he was adding a permitted use to a non-conforming use; (2) the trial court committed reversible error by suppressing allegedly relevant, probative evidence; and (3) he was unconstitutionally denied equal protection of the law because the city permitted similarly-situated property owners to operate gasoline service stations and grocery stores at one site. The court held that: (1) the non-conforming use was not immune from compliance with the parking requirements of Cleveland, Ohio, Zoning Code § 349.04(f), so the new use would not be immune either; (2) the owner experienced no prejudice from the exclusion of the evidence; and (3) the city had a legitimate reason for requiring the restrictions and the owner's evidence was insufficient to show any equal protection violation.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision to deny the owner the right to add the additional use to his property.

 

40 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Reed


No. 80-757


Supreme Court of Ohio


65 Ohio St. 2d 117; 418 N.E.2d 1359; 1981 Ohio LEXIS 457; 19 Ohio Op. 3d 311



March 31, 1981, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL and CROSS-APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

On July 15, 1978, Charles Burdsall, a police officer for the city of Cincinnati, was shot and killed after he stopped a vehicle and approached it to investigate an alleged attempted robbery. David Mellon, a civilian riding with the police officer in an auxiliary capacity, was also wounded in the incident.

On July 21, 1978, the Hamilton County Grand Jury indicted Wayne Reed, charging him with three counts of aggravated murder in violation of R. C. 2903.01, attempted murder in violation of R. C. 2903.02, escape in violation of R. C. 2921.34, and aggravated robbery in violation of R. C. 2911.01. The first count of aggravated murder charged that Reed had caused Burdsall's death while escaping; the second count charged that he had caused the death of Burdsall while fleeing immediately after attempting to commit an aggravated robbery; and the third count charged that he had purposely caused the death of Burdsall with prior calculation and design. On July 22, 1978, Reed was arrested in Cleveland.

The case was tried to a jury beginning on October 16, 1978. At trial, David Hamler, a Cincinnati police officer,  [***2] testified that at approximately midnight on July 14, 1978, while off duty, he drove to a King Kwik store to make a purchase. As he drove into the parking lot at the side of the store, he noticed a late 1960's Chevrolet parked in the lot with a man seated behind the steering wheel. The officer then parked his car in the front lot, exited his vehicle and approached the front door of the store. He then noticed a man, whom he identified as Wayne Reed, at a pay phone next to the front window of the store. He testified that Reed was holding the telephone receiver and was acting as if he was talking into it, but that he was, in fact, peering into the store at a clerk who was counting money. Hamler stated that Reed was not actually talking on the phone because the mouthpiece was away from his mouth and he was talking too quietly to be heard. He testified that there was no indication that Reed was carrying a gun.

Hamler went into the store, identified himself to the clerk, and asked the clerk to call the police department because he believed a robbery was in progress. The clerk made the call and Hamler spoke to a police officer. Shortly thereafter Officer Robert Plum arrived in a [***3] marked police car. As Plum arrived, Reed hung up the phone, walked around the corner of the building, and got into the Chevrolet which immediately drove off.

Officer Burdsall then pulled up in a marked police car, and after a brief conversation with Hamler, drove off in pursuit of the Chevrolet.

David Mellon testified that he and Burdsall pursued the Chevrolet out of the lot and stopped it; that he and Burdsall got out of the police car with Burdsall having drawn his gun; that they walked up to the Chevrolet and Burdsall ordered the occupants out of the car; and that the driver then got out of the car, turned around, and proceeded to shoot three times at Burdsall and twice at Mellon. Mellon identified the driver as Wayne Reed.

The only evidence offered by the prosecution of prior calculation and design, excepting evidence regarding the shooting itself, was a statement Reed made to a person who had been in an auto body repair class with him approximately a month before Burdsall's death that "if a cop got in his way [during a robbery] he would blow him away."

During the course of the trial the prosecution called Barbara Brown, Reed's fiancee, as a witness. After the court [***4] refused to declare her a hostile witness, the prosecutor questioned her regarding conversations she had with Reed following the shooting. When her answers conflicted with those made to a police officer shortly after the shooting, the prosecutor moved the court to allow him to use the statements to refresh her recollection on the ground that he had been surprised by the conflicting testimony. The court permitted the prosecutor to read the statements to Brown who then had an opportunity to explain them.

On November 1, 1978, the jury found Reed guilty as charged on all counts of the indictment. On January 18, 1979, the court sentenced Reed to death on each of the three counts of aggravated murder which were to be served concurrently, to seven to twenty-five years each for the felonies of attempted murder and aggravated robbery to be served consecutively with each other and the death sentences, and to two to five years for the escape to be served consecutively with the other sentences.

On appeal to the Court of Appeals, Reed argued (1) that the death sentences should be commuted to life sentences because the Ohio death penalty had been held unconstitutional; (2) that the trial court [***5] had erred in allowing Officer Hamler to state that he believed a robbery was occurring; (3) that the court had erred in allowing the prosecutor to read Barbara Brown's prior statements into the record; (4) that the trial court had erred in allowing the conviction of defendant on the three counts of aggravated murder; (5) that the guilty verdicts were contrary to the manifest weight of the evidence; and (6) that the trial court erred in imposing consecutive sentences on the felonies underlying the two aggravated murder convictions based on those felonies.

The Court of Appeals reduced the death sentences to life imprisonment and reversed the imposition of sentences on all three aggravated murder convictions, remanding the case to the trial court with instructions to choose one aggravated murder offense upon which sentencing should be ordered. The court affirmed the trial court in all other respects.

Defendant appealed to this court, reasserting the assignments which the Court of Appeals held to be without merit. The state cross-appealed the reversal and remand of the imposition of the sentences on the three counts of aggravated murder.

The cause is now before this court pursuant [***6] to the allowance of a motion and cross-motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, who was convicted of three counts of aggravated murder under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2903.01, attempted murder under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2903.02, escape under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2921.34, and aggravated robbery under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2911.01, appealed the decision of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which reduced his death sentences to life imprisonment and remanded for resentencing. The State cross-appealed.


OVERVIEW: Defendant killed a police officer who pursued and stopped him after he peered in the window of a store. On appeal, the court considered whether there was evidence of prior calculation and design, an element of aggravated murder. The court held that general statements that defendant made a month earlier were insufficient to show prior calculation and design. The court also held that the act of peering into a store window at a clerk counting money did not constitute an attempt to commit a theft offense, which was an essential element of aggravated robbery, without a showing of a purpose to deprive the store owner of property. The court also found that the officer did not have control over defendant, so the evidence may have shown the misdemeanor of resisting arrest, but not the felony of escape. The court noted that the evidence clearly supported a finding of murder and that murder was a lesser-included offense of aggravated murder. The court exercised its authority under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.79(D) and Ohio R. Crim. P. 33(A)(4) to modify the verdict to convict defendant of murder.


OUTCOME: The court reversed defendant's convictions for aggravated robbery and escape, reduced the conviction of three counts of aggravated murder to one count of murder, and affirmed the conviction for attempted murder. The court modified the judgment of the Court of Appeals and remanded the cause to the trial court.

 

41 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Byrd v. Board of Elections


No. 80-1249


Supreme Court of Ohio


65 Ohio St. 2d 40; 417 N.E.2d 1375; 1981 Ohio LEXIS 442; 19 Ohio Op. 3d 230



March 18, 1981, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County.

This is an appeal by Clint L. Byrd, appellant herein, from the denial of his complaint in quo warranto and mandamus by the Court of Appeals.

The facts, in essence, giving rise to this appeal, are as follows:

In the general election conducted on November 6, 1979, Byrd and William C. Wetzel were candidates, together with six others, for the Norton City School District Board of Education -- two members to be elected. The election results showed, in part, that Jean L. Behr received 1,671 votes, Wetzel received 1,397 votes, and Byrd received 1,259 votes. Since only two candidates were to be elected, the board of elections declared Behr and Wetzel the winners, and, on November 20, 1979, issued certificates of election.

On December 19, 1979, Byrd went to the board of elections to file his financial report and while there decided to review the computer print-out of the election results. Byrd became concerned about the accuracy of the print-out results in that he had only received eight votes in his own precinct, which he felt was incorrect. Upon contacting the deputy director of the board of elections, the ballots in [***2] Byrd's home precinct were examined and it was determined that there had indeed been an error in tallying the votes, occasioned by an improper code number being key-punched into the board of elections computer.

Upon an informal hand count of the votes in the precinct in question, the vote totals were as follows: Behr, 1,604, Byrd, 1,411, and Wetzel, 1,371.

Byrd thereafter brought a complaint in the Court of Appeals seeking, upon the basis of the total votes as determined by the hand count, a writ of mandamus to compel the board of elections to withdraw the certificate of election issued to Wetzel and issue such certificate to Byrd, and further, by an action in quo warranto, challenging Wetzel's right to hold office. The court denied the complaint.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant candidate challenged a decision of the Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio), which denied his complaint for mandamus seeking to compel appellee board of elections to withdraw the certificate of election issued to the declared winner and issue such a certificate to the candidate and in quo warranto challenging the declared winner's right to hold office.


OVERVIEW: The candidate was one of several candidates for two positions on the board of education. The election results showed that two other persons received more votes than the candidate and the board of elections declared them the winners. Thereafter, it was discovered that there had been an error in the tallying of the votes in the candidate's home precinct and, pursuant to an informal tally, the candidate had more votes than the declared winner. He brought a complaint seeking a writ of mandamus to compel the board of elections to withdraw the certification of election issued to the declared winner and issue a certificate to the candidate. He further challenged the declared winner's right to hold office. The lower court denied the relief requested and the court affirmed. It found that subsequent to the election, the candidate could have either sought a recount or filed an election contest had he reviewed the election results within 15 days after they were declared, rather than six weeks later. By his failure to act within the prescribed statutory periods provided by law, the court concluded that he forfeited his right to relief.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the lower court, which denied defendant's request for an order to compel the board of elections to declare him the winner and his action in quo warranto challenging the declared winner's right to hold office.

 

42 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Blue Cross of Northeast Ohio v. Ratchford


No. 80-243


Supreme Court of Ohio


64 Ohio St. 2d 256; 416 N.E.2d 614; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 874; 18 Ohio Op. 3d 450



December 30, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

By letter dated September 15, 1978, Blue Cross of Northeast Ohio (hereinafter "Blue Cross") filed a request with the Department of Insurance for a rate increase for its non-group subscriber contracts. Hearings on the increase were conducted for eight days in October and November of 1978, pursuant to R. C. 1739.051(D).

The hearing officer, finding that Blue Cross had failed to demonstrate a total good faith effort to contain costs, determined that the proposed rate increase was only partially lawful, fair and reasonable. As a result, he recommended that the proposal be reduced by 20 percent. On December 1, 1978, the Superintendent of Insurance issued an order in accordance with the hearing officer's report.

Blue Cross appealed the order to the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County. On February 21, 1979, the court granted Blue Cross' motion for final judgment apparently based on the decision of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County in Blue Cross of Northwest Ohio v.. Jump (January 25, 1979, Case No. 78AP-450), unreported. In that case, the Court of Appeals had held that if any good faith effort [***2] was shown, the entire requested rate increase had to be granted.

On December 18, 1979, the Court of Appeals affirmed the Court of Common Pleas on the basis of that earlier decision.

The cause is now before this court upon the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant superintendent of insurance sought review of the decision from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which affirmed a decision granting final judgment to appellee insurer in its action to overturn a decision of a hearing officer that granted the insurer only a partial rate increase.


OVERVIEW: The insurer filed for a rate increase, and a hearing officer granted a partial increase on the basis that proposed increase was only partially lawful, fair, and reasonable in that the insurer had not provided a good faith effort to establish the entire increase. The insurer sought judicial review of the decision, and the trial court granted judgment in favor of the insurer. The appellate court affirmed the decision, and the superintendent challenged the judgment. On appeal, the court reversed and held that an all or nothing increase was not required. The superintendent had the authority pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1739.051 to grant partial rate increases based on a finding of partial good faith, which did not involve an unlawful delegation of authority. The statute provided sufficient guidance and standards, and judicial review was available in a meaningful way. The evidence showed that the insurer did not meet the required good faith effort standard in all areas. The superintendent's determination did not apply new standards in violation of the insurer's due process rights and was not arbitrary.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment in favor of the insurer that reversed a determination by the superintendent that provided that the insurer was only entitled to a partial rate increase.

 

43 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


McCruter v. Board of Review


No. 80-303


Supreme Court of Ohio


64 Ohio St. 2d 277; 415 N.E.2d 259; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 878; 18 Ohio Op. 3d 463



December 30, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Richland County.

Mable McCruter, appellee herein, was discharged by her employer, White-Westinghouse Corporation, and filed a claim for unemployment compensation benefits. The claim was disallowed by the Administrator of the Ohio Bureau of Employment Services. Upon reconsideration, the administrator affirmed his earlier decision.

The appellee timely appealed that decision, and a hearing was held before a referee of the Board of Review. The referee affirmed the administrator's decision. According to a certificate of mailing signed by Kathy Watson, the referee's decision was mailed to the appellee on April 13, 1978.

On May 2, 1978, the appellee filed an application to institute further appeal from the decision of the referee with the Board of Review. The Board of Review held a hearing to determine whether the appellee's application was timely filed. At that hearing the appellee testified that she called the Bureau of Employment Services on April 27, 1978, to inquire about the status of her case. It was not until the next day, April 28, 1978, that she received a copy of the referee's decision. There was no evidence, other than [***2] the certificate of mailing, as to when the referee's decision was mailed.

The Board of Review dismissed the appellee's application to institute further appeal. It found that the application was filed more than 14 days after the decision was mailed, contrary to the requirement of R. C. 4141.28(L).

That decision was appealed to the Court of Common Pleas of Richland County. The Court of Common Pleas affirmed the decision of the Board of Review.

The Court of Appeals reversed. In reversing, the court held that the certificate of mailing is not dispositive of claims relating to the adequacy of notice to the appellee.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff discharged employee filed an action against defendant Board of Review, seeking a review of the Board's decision dismissing as untimely the employee's appeal of the Board's prior decision which affirmed a denial of unemployment compensation benefits to the employee by the Administrator of the Ohio Bureau of Employment Services. The Court of Appeals (Ohio) reversed a lower court's judgment affirming the dismissal. The Board appealed.


OVERVIEW: The discharged employee had filed a claim for unemployment compensation benefits. The claim was disallowed by the Administrator. The employee appealed. The Board affirmed the Administrator's decision. The Board's decision was mailed to the employee. More than 14 days after the notice of the Board's decision was mailed, the employee sought further review of the Board's decision. The employee alleged that she did not receive the notice until more than 14 days after the notice was mailed. The Board dismissed the appeal as untimely under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4141.28(L). The lower court affirmed the Board. The court of appeals reversed. The court reversed the court of appeals' decision. The court found that § 4141.28(L) required an application of appeal to be filed within 14 days after the Board's decision was mailed, regardless of when it was received. Thus, the employee's failure to file within the time limits of § 4141.28(L) deprived the Board of jurisdiction to hear the appeal.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the court of appeals' decision for the discharged employee.

 

44 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Nagle v. Olin


No. 80-301


Supreme Court of Ohio


64 Ohio St. 2d 341; 415 N.E.2d 279; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 891; 18 Ohio Op. 3d 503



December 30, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Knox County.

On November 6, 1978, a verified complaint was filed against James Olin in the Court of Common Pleas, Juvenile Division by Martin Nagle, the Attendance Officer of the Richland County Public Schools. The complaint alleged that James Olin was in violation of the Ohio compulsory education law ( R. C. 3321.38) in that he failed to send his child, Jennifer Olin, a child of compulsory school age, to a school which conforms to minimum standards prescribed by the State Board of Education. Olin entered a plea of not guilty.

Following trial, Olin was found guilty. The Court of Appeals affirmed.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Knox County (Ohio), which confirmed a decision finding him guilty of a violation of the state compulsory education law for failing to send his daughter to a school that conformed to minimum standards prescribed by the state board of education.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was found guilty of failing to send his child to a state-approved school. He appealed and the appellate court affirmed the decision of the trial court. He appealed again, arguing that his prosecution was discriminatory, in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution. The court held that defendant failed to prove that the fact that he held nonconforming religious beliefs in any way motivated the State to charge him. Defendant contended that the State had to permit him to send his child to an Amish school as an incident of his right to freely exercise his religion and his right to direct the upbringing and education of his child. The court observed that certain aspects of the board's minimum standards came into direct conflict with defendant's religious beliefs and interfered with the free exercise of his religion. The court held that, until the board adopted minimum standards which went no further than necessary to assure the State's legitimate interests in the education of children in private elementary schools, the balance was weighted in favor of a First Amendment claim to religious freedom.


OUTCOME: The court reversed defendant's conviction for failing to send his daughter to a state-approved school.

 

45 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Holmes v. Union Gospel Press


No. 80-481


Supreme Court of Ohio


64 Ohio St. 2d 187; 414 N.E.2d 415; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 863; 18 Ohio Op. 3d 405



December 23, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Medina County.

Appellant, James H. Holmes, was separated from his employment with appellee, Union Gospel Press, on February 17, 1978. Appellant filed a claim for unemployment compensation benefits with the Ohio Bureau of Employment Services.

On March 29, 1978, a "determination of application for benefit rights" was mailed by the bureau to appellant informing him that his claim for benefits was disallowed because Union Gospel had not elected to be covered by the Ohio unemployment insurance laws. Appellant requested reconsideration, and it is undisputed that on April 14, 1978, the administrator of the bureau mailed his decision on reconsideration to appellant's last known post office address. It appears from the record that appellant did not receive the decision in the mail but learned of it after contacting the unemployment office.

On May 3, 1978, appellant filed a notice of appeal with the Unemployment Compensation Board of Review. The board of review, after a hearing, determined that the filing was untimely under R. C. 4141.28(H) and that the board therefore lacked jurisdiction to hear the appeal. The board's decision was affirmed [***2] by the Court of Common Pleas of Medina County.

The Court of Appeals affirmed the trial court and, finding its judgment to be in conflict with decisions of the Courts of Appeals for Richland and Hamilton Counties, certified the record of the case to this court for review and final determination.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant employee sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Medina County (Ohio) that found that the employee's notice of appeal from the denial of his claim for unemployment benefits was untimely.


OVERVIEW: The employee filed a claim for unemployment compensation and his claim for benefits was disallowed because appellee, the employer, had not elected to be covered by the state unemployment insurance laws. The employee requested reconsideration and the administrator of the state bureau of employment services mailed his decision to the employee at the employee's last known post office address. The employee never received the decision and learned of the decision denying his claim when he contacted the unemployment office. The employee filed a notice of appeal and the board of review found the filing to be untimely. The trial court and appellate court affirmed the board of review's decision and the matter was certified to the court. The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment and held that the notice requirement of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4141.28(H) was reasonably calculated to apprise the appellant of the decision and to afford him an opportunity to appeal. Thus, the notice requirement was not unconstitutional on its face.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment that determined that the employee's appeal was untimely.

 

46 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Pachay


No. 80-393


Supreme Court of Ohio


64 Ohio St. 2d 218; 416 N.E.2d 589; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 868; 18 Ohio Op. 3d 427



December 23, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lake County.

On November 1, 1978, the appellee, James M. Pachay, was arrested on a warrant issued by the Juvenile Division of the Court of Common Pleas of Lake County charging him with non-support in violation of R. C. 2919.21, a misdemeanor of the first degree. The appellee appeared for arraignment, entered a plea of not guilty and was released on bond. On March 14, 1979, 134 days after his arrest, the appellee moved for a dismissal under the provisions of R. C. 2945.71 et seq. The appellant, state of Ohio, conceded that the appellee was not brought to trial within the time limits of R. C. 2945.71, but contested the motion to dismiss on the sole ground that R. C. 2945.71, 2945.72 and 2945.73 are invalid as an unconstitutional legislative usurpation of the judicial power. The trial court granted the motion to dismiss and ordered the appellee discharged.

The state appealed to the Court of Appeals which affirmed the trial court.

The cause is now before this court upon the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Lake County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's grant of defendant's motion to dismiss on the grounds defendant was not brought to trial within the time limits of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.71. On appeal, the State claimed § 2945.71 was an unconstitutional legislative usurpation of the judicial power.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with non-support, entered a plea of not guilty, and was released on bond. After 134 days had passed since his arrest, defendant filed a motion to dismiss for failure to bring him to trial within the time limits of § 2945.71. The court affirmed the judgment. The right of an accused to a speedy trial was recognized by the constitutions of Ohio and the United States. The court noted that throughout the long history of litigation that involved the application of the speedy trial statutes, it had repeatedly announced that the trial courts were to strictly enforce the legislative mandates evident in the speedy trial statutes. Strict enforcement of the speedy trial statutes was grounded in the conclusion that they implemented the constitutional guarantee of a public speedy trial. The court chose to enforce the mandate of the present speedy trial statutes in the belief that § 2945.71 represented a rational effort to enforce the constitutional guarantee of a speedy trial.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the court of appeals was affirmed.

 

47 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Kettering v. Hollen


No. 80-60


Supreme Court of Ohio


64 Ohio St. 2d 232; 416 N.E.2d 598; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 870; 18 Ohio Op. 3d 435



December 23, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County.

Michael H. Willcox is an officer of the Kettering Police Department. At approximately 3:00 a.m. on September 23, 1978, Willcox, while on duty in his marked patrol car, was proceeding northbound on South Smithville Road in Kettering. He observed a pickup truck in his rear view mirror, overtaking him at a high rate of speed. The officer pulled into a center leftturn lane, allowing the pickup to go past him. Willcox estimated its speed to be in excess of 50 miles per hour at that time, more than 15 miles per hour over the posted speed limit. As the officer gave chase, he observed the truck weaving across three lanes of the five-lane roadway, and once even hitting the curb. At one point during the chase, the drive of the truck fell over to his right, disappearing from the officer's view for "a second or two," then reappearing as he sat back up. Willcox then determined to stop the pickup, and turned on the cruiser emergency lights.

As the vehicles came to an intersection, the pickup slowed very rapidly and made a left turn, running a traffic light in the process. Willcox followed, and turned on the cruiser's [***2] siren. The chase continued for three more blocks, at which point the truck suddenly came to a stop in the middle of the westbound lane on Watervliet Avenue at its intersection with Mondail Avenue. This intersection is within the corporate limits of Dayton. The record does not disclose where the vehicles entered Dayton.

As the officer walked toward the pickup, the defendant, Jeffrey L. Hollen, got out of the truck and staggered for a moment before catching ahold of the side of the truck. The defendant was unable to produce his driver's license, and failed the field sobriety tests administered to him by the officer. Willcox took the defendant into custody, and charged him with one count of failure to drive in a single lane, and one count of operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol. At a trial to the bench in the Kettering Municipal Court, the defendant was convicted and sentenced on both counts.

The Court of Appeals reversed the convictions, holding the extraterritorial warrantless arrest of the defendant in Dayton by a Kettering police officer to be illegal, and the evidence obtained by such an arrest inadmissible.

The cause is now before this court [***3] upon the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The prosecution sought review of the decision of the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County (Ohio), which reversed defendant's conviction and found the extraterritorial warrantless arrest of defendant in Dayton by a Kettering police officer to be illegal, and the evidence obtained by such an arrest inadmissible.


OVERVIEW: The Kettering police officer noticed defendant speeding and driving erratically. He attempted to stop defendant and a chase ensued. The chase ended in Dayton and defendant failed the field sobriety tests. Defendant was convicted of failure to drive in a single lane and operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol. The court reversed the decision of the appellate court and found that the record was insufficient as to the factual of issue of whether the arresting process commenced while the Kettering police officer and defendant were still in Kettering. Therefore, the court assumed that defendant's arrest in Dayton was not authorized. However, the court determined that the fruits of defendant's arrest, based on probable cause but unauthorized, were not suppressible solely because of the fact of the arrest in Dayton by a Kettering police officer. The court reasoned that defendant was not immune from prosecution merely because of the fact that his arrest was unlawful or unauthorized. The court found that the issue was whether inadmissible evidence was used to convict defendant and that defendant's conviction was not the result of the use of inadmissible evidence.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision of the appellate court that had reversed defendant's conviction.

 

48 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Stromberg v. Bd. of Edn.


No. 80-126


Supreme Court of Ohio


64 Ohio St. 2d 98; 413 N.E.2d 1184; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 841; 18 Ohio Op. 3d 343



December 17, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

The instant cause arose from a complaint filed in the Court of Common Pleas by Sidney Stromberg, appellant herein, as a taxpayer and resident of the village of Bratenahl, challenging the dissolution and merger on July 1, 1970, of the Bratenahl School District with the Cleveland School District and the constitutionality of R. C. 3311.29, and praying for injunctive relief with respect to the order of merger and the transfer of property and funds. The transfer of the property, assets and management of Bratenahl School District has been completed.

The dissolution of the Bratenahl School District and its merger on July 1, 1970, has had an extensive and protracted history of litigation in this court and in the federal courts. The controversy involved the efforts of the Bratenahl School District to preserve its independent identity despite its failure to maintain a school system consisting of grades one through twelve, inclusive, as required by R. C. 3311.29.

In State, ex rel. Bd. of Edn., v.. State Bd. of Edn. (1978), 53 Ohio St. 2d 173, certiorari denied, 439 U.S. 865, the Bratenahl board of education challenged [***2] the state's final order of dissolution. In upholding the validity of the order, the majority opinion concluded, at page 178, "that the Bratenahl Local School District was properly dissolved on July 1, 1970, by the state board." Seeking to stop this dissolution, the board of education then filed a complaint in prohibition and mandamus in the Court of Appeals for Franklin County. Citing the above decision of this court, the Court of Appeals dismissed the complaint sua sponte, by finding that the first Bratenahl case was res judicata. This judgment was affirmed by this court in State, ex rel. Bd. of Edn., v.. State Bd. of Edn. (1979), 58 Ohio St. 2d 189.

Expressing the issues in terms of denials of equal protection and due process under the Constitution of the United States, the Bratenahl board of education, joined by individual taxpayers and students, then asserted the same issues in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio. The District Court dismissed the action. The Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit agreed with the District Court that the Ohio litigation fully and completely disposed of all claims, and affirmed the dismissal.  [***3] Wilt v.. State Bd. of Edn. (C.A. 6, 1979), 608 F. 2d 1126.

The status of the Bratenahl Local School District was before this court again in Wiss v.. Bd. of Elections, 61 Ohio St. 2d 298, decided March 12, 1980. While this case involved the eligibility of a resident and elector of the village of Bratenahl to be a candidate for the Cuyahoga County Board of Education, the initial question raised was whether the Bratenahl Local School District had been dissolved. This court stated, at page 299, as follows: "A review of these cases shows that the status of the Bratenahl School District has been established and the same was dissolved on July 1, 1970, and the issue is res judicata." Further, on page 300, it was noted that "[i]n Wilt v.. Bd. of Edn., supra, the federal circuit court also found this issue to be res judicata." The candidate argued that the Bratenahl controversy was still alive because the constitutionality of R. C. 3311.29 was under attack in the instant case, then pending in the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County. This court stated that this rationale for qualifying the Bratenahl issue as viable is tenuous at best, and that an allegation [***4] of unconstitutionality of a statute in a case pending in a lower court is not justification for overturning a determination twice made by this court.

The appellees herein, State Board of Education and Cleveland Board of Education, filed motions to dismiss based upon the earlier decisions of this court that the judgment in the action between the State Board of Education and the Bratenahl board of education was res judicata as to appellant's complaint. The trial court dismissed appellant's complaint and the Court of Appeals affirmed.

The cause is now before this court upon the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayer sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's dismissal of his action based on res judicata. The taxpayer brought an action against appellee state and city boards of education challenging the dissolution and merger of a local school district with that of the city, challenging the constitutionality of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3311.29, and seeking an injunction.


OVERVIEW: In a previous action involving the local board of education, the state's final order of dissolution was upheld. Thereafter several parties brought actions seeking to challenge the dissolution. All of the actions were dismissed on the grounds of res judicata. The taxpayer was also challenging the dissolution. The taxpayer argued that as a taxpayer he had a private right, independent of the local board of education, to relitigate the same public issue determined against the local school board. Upon review, the Court determined that this could be true where cause of action were not the same or where the taxpayer had a different private right not shared in common with the public. However, the judgment against the local school board with binding and conclusive as res judicata on all residents, citizens, and taxpayers with respect to matters adjudicated which were of general and public interest.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment.

 

49 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Harris v. Fuerst


No. 80-1014


Supreme Court of Ohio


64 Ohio St. 2d 130; 413 N.E.2d 826; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 846; 18 Ohio Op. 3d 363



December 17, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

On January 14, 1980, counsel for relator, Rose Harris, went to the office of Gerald E. Fuerst, Clerk of the Court of Common Pleas of Cuyahoga County, respondent herein, with the intention of filing a complaint in divorce. Pursuant to R. C. 2701.09 and Rules 7 and 14 of the Court of Common Pleas of Cuyahoga County, fees are to be paid in conjunction with the necessary publication in the local daily law journals concerning relator's divorce complaint. Neither relator, an indigent, nor her attorneys, would tender the prepayment of those fees. Further, relator neither applied for nor received, a judicial waiver, available to all, of the fees based on her indigency.

She filed an action in United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio (Rose Harris v.. James A. Rhodes et al., case No. C79-1082), seeking declaratory and injunctive relief which, inter alia, would declare unconstitutional the requirement of paying the applicable publication fees when the divorce complaint is filed by an indigent person. That action was dismissed by the federal court and an appeal is presently pending in United States Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals.

 [***2] Relator also filed this original action in mandamus requesting that a writ issue directing respondent to accept relator's complaint without the payment of the publication fees.

The cause is now before this court upon relator's motion for summary judgment, and upon respondent's motion to dismiss the complaint.



DISPOSITION: Cause dismissed.

 

50 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Saurman


No. 80-201


Supreme Court of Ohio


64 Ohio St. 2d 137; 413 N.E.2d 1197; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 849; 18 Ohio Op. 3d 367



December 17, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Geauga County.

These cases were initiated by the state of Ohio, appellant herein, which filed separate complaints in Chardon Municipal Court, charging the appellees, Kirt S. Saurman and Terrence W. Zimmerlin, with violations of R. C. 1533.161 R. C. 1533.161 prohibits, in part, the throwing or casting of the "rays of a spotlight or other artificial light from any vehicle into any field, woodland, or forest for the purpose of locating a wild animal." The complaints alleged that, on November 26, 1978, while in Geauga County, the appellees cast the rays of a spotlight from a motor vehicle into a woodland for the purpose of locating deer.

Before trial the appellees filed motions to dismiss, asserting that the portion of R. C. 1533.161, under which they were charged, is unconstitutional. There was no evidence taken by the trial court, nor were any stipulations of fact entered into by the parties. However, the trial court did have before it the materials constituting the legislative history of the statute in question, including the Legislative Service Commission summaries of Am. Sub. S.B. No. 71 (1969) and Am. H.B. No. 959 (1972), and [***2] both the House and Senate Agriculture and Natural Resources Reports to Am. Sub. H.B. No. 1316 (1976).

The Chardon Municipal Court granted the motions to dismiss and held that R. C. 1533.161 violated the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution because it does not bear a rational relationship to the valid state interest in the protection of wildlife or the restriction of hunting.

The cases were consolidated for appeal in the Court of Appeals for Geauga County, which affirmed the trial court.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State of Ohio challenged a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Geauga County (Ohio), which affirmed a judgment of the trial court, which grated defendants' motions to dismiss the State's action, alleging a violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1533.161.


OVERVIEW: The State filed a complaint alleging that, in violation of § 1533.161, defendants cast the rays of a spotlight from a motor vehicle into a woodland for the purpose of locating deer. The trial court granted defendants' motions to dismiss and held that the statute violated the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution because it did not bear a rational relationship to the valid State interest in the protection of wildlife or the restriction of hunting. The appellate court affirmed the judgment. On appeal, the court reversed the judgment of the appellate court. The court found that there was a reasonable basis for the general assembly to determine that the elimination of all spotlighting of wild game from vehicles would be in the best interests and furtherance of the protection of the wild animals of the State, and that it was within the province of the general assembly to enact laws for the protection of wild game. The court held that as a result, § 1533.161 was rationally related to the protection of game and there was a rational relationship between the statute and public health, safety, and welfare.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the appellate court.

 

51 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Dupler v. Mansfield Journal Co.


No. 80-196


Supreme Court of Ohio


64 Ohio St. 2d 116; 413 N.E.2d 1187; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 844; 18 Ohio Op. 3d 354; 6 Media L. Rep. 2362



December 17, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Tuscarawas County.

This cause arose as a libel action by plaintiff-appellant, Jerry L. Dupler, against defendant-appellee, Mansfield Journal Co., Inc., on the basis of an editorial appearing in the April 9, 1975, edition of The Times-Reporter, a newspaper owned by the appellee and published in New Philadelphia, Ohio. The article, written by appellee's editor, Harry Yockey, criticized the county prosecutor's decision not to prosecute Dupler for his alleged misconduct, as a private investigator, in recovering stolen property for a client. 1 At that time, appellant was a city councilman in Dover, Ohio, and a candidate for mayor of that community.


1 The full text of the April 9, 1975, editorial reads as follows:

"The Tuscarawas County prosecutor's reaction to the seizure of a stolen stereo set and several other items at a New Philadelphia apartment by Jerry Dupler, Dover councilman and a private eye, is somewhat surprising.

"Prosecutor Ron Collins indicated there would not be any prosecution because of 'a lack of criminal intent.'

"Private investigators, under Ohio law, must inform authorities 12 hours in advance of participation in a case. The prosecutor revealed he had been contacted about a search warrant the night Dupler, acting in behalf of Brad Dinolfo, made the seizure. However, the prosecutor said he didn't think police had 'sufficient justification' for a warrant.

"The prosecutor's office, we are certain, prosecutes numerous cases wherein 'criminal intent' is not evident. J. C. Shew, an assistant prosecutor, added that their office isn't concerned that Dupler, employed by Cloverleaf Security, had not informed police of his intentions. Nor is the prosecutor's office concerned over the fact that Dupler did not have a search warrant.

"It seems to us that Dupler, if he is qualified as a licensed private investigator, ignored Ohio law twice -- by not giving authorities the proper notification and then by making a seizure without a search warrant.

"It is proper to ask, in view of the circumstances, what the intent was behind Dupler's actions. It also is proper to ask if the prosecutor's office is politically motivated in its unconcern.

"If Jerry Dupler is going to continue his work as a private eye the prosecutor's office should at least make certain he refrains in the future from ignoring Ohio statutes."

 [***2] The record indicates that appellant notified Dover and New Philadelphia police on March 25, 1975, of his involvement in the case and his intent to recover a stolen stereo from a local apartment. Police declined to assist Dupler because they lacked a search warrant. Dupler and his client evidently received the consent of a man at the apartment to conduct a search, although it was never determined whether this individual actually was a resident of the premises. Dupler and his client recovered the stereo and other property which they turned over to police at the scene.

Articles appearing in the April 4 and April 8, 1975, editions of The Times-Reporter described the reactions of the New Philadelphia police chief and the local prosecutor's office to Dupler's unorthodox tactics in this matter, and the prosecutor's decision not to charge Dupler with violating state law in his method of intervention. Yockey's subsequent editorial criticized this decision not to prosecute. Appellant's defamation suit ensued.

Prior to trial, defendant filed a motion for summary judgment which was overruled. At trial, plaintiff presented evidence that defendant failed to comply with R. C. 2739.13 [***3] and 2739.14, in printing an editorial retraction submitted by plaintiff in August 1975. At the close of plaintiff's case-in-chief and at the close of all evidence, defendant moved for a directed verdict in his favor, on the basis that plaintiff had not met his burden of proving that the allegedly libelous comments were made with actual malice. Both such motions were effectively overruled. The jury returned a verdict for plaintiff in the amount of $ 149,000.

The Court of Appeals subsequently reversed and entered judgment for defendant. It found that the trial court erred in not granting defendant's motions for summary judgment and directed verdict, because there was no evidence presented that Yockey knew, at the time of publication, that his comments were false or, in fact, entertained serious doubts as to their truth. The appellate court also found that R. C. 2739.13 and 2739.14, the so-called "retraction statutes," were unconstitutional as infringing upon defendant's First Amendment rights.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff public official appealed the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Tuscarawas County (Ohio), reversing the trial court's denial of defendant newspaper's motions for summary judgment and for directed verdict in the official's libel action and finding Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 2739.13 and 2739.14, the "retraction statutes," unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The newspaper printed an editorial alleging that the official, a private investigator, city councilman, and mayoral candidate, had ignored Ohio law by failing to inform police that he was going to seize certain property and seizing the property without a warrant. The official had, in fact, notified police, and there had allegedly been consent for the search. The court held that, under the "actual malice" standard, the official failed to show that the newspaper acted with reckless disregard of the falsity of the publication. The editor relied on prior articles, and it was insufficient for the official to show that the editor's interpretation was false without showing the editor's awareness of the high probability of falsity. The editor had no reason to doubt the accuracy of statutory interpretations and drew one of several permissible legal conclusions from sketchy facts. The trial court committed prejudicial error by admitting evidence of the newspaper's failure to retract in conformance with Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 2739.13 and 2739.14. Sections 2739.13 and 2739.14 were irrelevant to the issue of malice, and the appellate court erred in determining their constitutionality.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment finding that the newspaper was entitled to summary judgment, but reversed the finding that the "retraction statutes" were unconstitutional.

 

52 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Felske v. Daugherty


No. 79-1678


Supreme Court of Ohio


64 Ohio St. 2d 89; 413 N.E.2d 809; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 840; 18 Ohio Op. 3d 313



December 10, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

On April 8, 1969, appellee, Fred W. Felske (claimant), suffered an injury to his back during the course of his employment with the city of Columbus, Health Department. Felske's claim for medical expenses relative to his injury was allowed and paid by the Bureau of Workers' Compensation.

During the next six years, claimant neither applied for nor received compensation pursuant to R. C. 4123.56, 4123.57 or 4123.58, even though it is stipulated that he had several periods of temporary total disability during this time relative to the injury, for which the claimant requested and was paid sick-leave benefits by his employer in an amount equal to the wages he would have received had he worked.
