On April 18, 1977, claimant filed with appellant Industrial Commission an application for determination of the percentage of permanent partial disability. A subsequent commission order refused this application on the basis that, in the absence of payment of compensation, the commission lacked jurisdiction under R. C. 4123.52 to consider this claim after six years from the date of injury. The order was affirmed by the Court of Common [***2] Pleas.

The Court of Appeals, however, found the construction of R. C. 4123.52 adopted by the commission to be unconstitutional, as applied to the instant situation, in that it denied appellee equal protection of the law. In order to avoid an unconstitutional application, that court "liberally construed" this statute so as to equate "payment of compensation for total disability" with the payment of sick-leave benefits in an amount equal to wages. The Court of Appeals, therefore, reversed the lower court's judgment and remanded the cause for a determination of whether claimant sustained sufficient periods of temporary total disability as a result of his injury, for which he was paid sick-leave benefits, in order to invoke the continuing jurisdiction of the commission for "ten years from the date of the last payment of compensation."

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant Workers Compensation Commission challenged an order of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which found the Commission's construction of Ohio Rev. Code § 4123.52 to be unconstitutional as applied to appellee worker, reversing the trial court's judgment. It remanded for a determination of whether the worker had sufficient periods of temporary total disability from his injury to invoke the Commission's continuing jurisdiction.


OVERVIEW: The worker was allowed medical expenses for a work injury. During the next six years, he did not apply for compensation although he had several periods of temporary total disability from the injury, for which his employer paid him sick-leave benefits. The worker applied for permanent partial disability but the commission found it lacked jurisdiction. The court held that the Commission properly determined that it lacked jurisdiction to consider the application after six years from the date of injury. However, this construction of Ohio Rev. Code § 4123.52, as applied to the worker, violated equal protection because it classified workers on the basis of whether they received disability compensation within six years of the injury. A worker who was paid compensation could apply for modification any time within 10 years after the last payment. A worker who was only reimbursed for medical expenses was foreclosed from seeking additional compensation six years after his injury. It was arbitrary to determine a worker's entitlement to invoke the Commission's continuing jurisdiction on the basis of whether he received remuneration for that disability from his employer or from the Commission.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment, as modified, and remanded the cause to the Commission for consideration of the worker's application for determination of the percentage of permanent partial disability.

 

53 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Smart v. McKinley


No. 80-1423


Supreme Court of Ohio


64 Ohio St. 2d 5; 412 N.E.2d 393; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 827; 18 Ohio Op. 3d 128



October 29, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS and PROHIBITION.

On July 25, 1980, the Governor of Ohio signed into law Am. Sub. S. B. No. 13 which, inter alia, created a new judicial seat on the Fifth District Court of Appeals ("new seat"). On July 31, Judge David D. Dowd, Jr., resigned his position as a Fifth District Court of Appeals judge ("unexpired seat"). At the November 4 general election, a candidate will be elected to fill the new seat, as well as a candidate to fill the term of the unexpired seat.

On August 6, Irene Smart filed her petitions with the Stark County Board of Elections for the new seat. On the same day, Donald R. Ramsayer filed his petitions as an independent candidate for the unexpired seat. On August 13, the board of elections approved and certified Smart and four other candidates for the new seat, but rejected Ramsayer's petitions. The justification for the rejection of Ramsayer's petitions was R. C. 3513.31, which provides the procedure for filling the vacancy for the unexpired seat. That section permits committees of political parties to select candidates to run in the general election to fill the unexpired term of the person who has resigned.

Subsequently, Ramsayer [***2] filed suit in United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio, Eastern Division, seeking an order that he be placed on the ballot for the unexpired seat. (Ramsayer v.. Celebrezze, Jr. [case No. C-2-80-732].) On September 9, Smart withdrew her candidacy for the new seat, which the board of elections unanimously voted to accept on September 12. On September 22, District Court Judge Robert M. Duncan issued his decision in the case of Ramsayer v.. Celebrezze, Jr. (unreported). Judge Duncan held R. C. 3513.31 unconstitutional to the extent that it excluded Ramsayer from running for the unexpired seat as an independent candidate. Accordingly, Ramsayer's name was ordered to be placed on the ballot for the unexpired seat. On September 23, the board of elections certified Ramsayer as a candidate for the unexpired seat.

On September 25, Smart, a Democrat, filed petitions of candidacy as an independent for the unexpired seat. On the same day, several electors brought an action in the Court of Common Pleas of Stark County seeking injunctive relief to keep Smart off the ballot. On September 26, the board of elections voted unanimously to place Smart on [***3] the ballot for the unexpired seat. On October 9, Judge Gary McKinley, respondent herein, visiting judge on the Court of Common Pleas of Stark County, issued a permanent restraining order enjoining the Secretary of State and the board of elections from printing the name of Smart on the ballot for the unexpired seat.

On October 9, Smart and the board of elections filed this original action seeking, in effect, an order to place Smart on the ballot for the unexpired seat. On October 15, relators' motion to suspend the injunction pending disposition of this action was sustained.

Respondent has filed motions to dismiss and for summary judgment.



DISPOSITION: Writ allowed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, a candidate and a board of elections, filed an action in mandamus against respondent, a Stark County Common Pleas Court judge, seeking an order that the candidate be placed on the ballot for an unexpired seat. The judge filed a motion for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: Candidates were to be elected to fill a new seat and an unexpired seat. Petitioner sought the new seat, and an independent candidate sought the unexpired seat. The board rejected the independent candidate, and he filed a separate action and was eventually placed on the ballot. Petitioner later withdrew her candidacy and sought candidacy as an independent for the unexpired seat. The judge enjoined the board from printing petitioner's name, claiming that she did not timely file. However, in the case brought by the independent candidate, the federal district court had held that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3515.31, insofar as it forbade the placing of independents on the ballot, was unconstitutional. The judge held that at the least the 65-day limitation contained in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3513.30, the statute regarding candidate withdrawal, had to be used. The court prohibited the injunction. The period of limitation was not clear. The office holder vacated the unexpired office 40 days before the election. Thus, the 65-day period did not apply. The problem of the applicable and pertinent time limitations for the filing of an independent candidacy was to be determined by the general assembly.


OUTCOME: The court issued a writ prohibiting the common court pleas judge from enjoining the placing of the candidate's name on the ballot.

 

54 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Peebles v. Clement


No. 79-886


Supreme Court of Ohio


63 Ohio St. 2d 314; 408 N.E.2d 689; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 823; 17 Ohio Op. 3d 203



July 31, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Greene County.

On January 11, 1977, Robert and Bonnie Peebles filed a complaint against Betty Ann Clement, her daughter Kimberly, and defendants' bank, alleging that Betty was indebted to them in excess of $ 4,000, as a result of her failure to account for funds collected while she was employed by them as resident manager of the Bonnie Villa Apartments in Fairborn, Ohio.

In conjunction with the complaint, Robert Peebles filed an affidavit of attachment and an attachment bond of $ 8,000 with the Clerk of Courts of Greene County. In the affidavit, Peebles stated that he believed that Betty Ann Clement was about to remove her property out of the court's jurisdiction with intent to defraud the plaintiffs, that she was about to convert the property into money, and that she had concealed, assigned, removed, or disposed of property or was about to do so in order to defraud the plaintiffs.

On January 12, 1977, orders of attachment were issued attaching various bank accounts, an automobile, household goods, and other personal effects of Betty and Kimberly Clement.

On February 25, 1977, Betty Ann Clement filed an answer and counterclaim,  [***2] and on April 29, 1977, the Peebles filed an amended complaint increasing their demand to $ 15,164.45.

On January 9, 1978, Betty Ann Clement moved the court to dismiss the order of attachment arguing, in part, that Ohio's attachment procedure is unconstitutional. The Court of Common Pleas granted the motion, finding that the Ohio Attachment Before Judgment Statutes are unconstitutional, and as a consequence the court ordered that the attachment be dissolved.

The Court of Appeals affirmed the decision but limited its application to the facts in the case before it. It determined that the statutes could conceivably be used in a constitutional manner and should be allowed to stand so they could be so used.

The cause is now before this court upon the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, as modified.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant creditor sought review from the Court of Appeals for Greene County (Ohio), which affirmed an order granting appellee debtor's motion to dismiss a prejudgment order of attachment, finding that the Ohio Attachment Before Judgment Statutes, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2715.01 et seq., were unconstitutional as applied to the facts of this case.


OVERVIEW: Creditor filed an action to collect an alleged debt and obtained an attachment of debtor's property before judgment pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2715.01 et seq. The trial court granted debtor's motion to dismiss the order of attachment because the statute violated debtor's due process rights. The appellate court affirmed but limited its holding to the facts of this case. Creditor sought further review and the court affirmed, holding that prejudgment attachment statutes must at a minimum: (1) require plaintiff to furnish an appropriate bond or other security to compensate a defendant in the event of wrongful seizure; (2) require that an affidavit be filed alleging personal knowledge of specific facts forming a basis for prejudgment seizure; (3) require that a judicial officer pass upon the sufficiency of the facts alleged in the affidavit; (4) provide for dissolution of the seizure upon the posting of a bond by defendant; and (5) provide an immediate right of hearing to the defendant in which plaintiff must prove that the seizure was warranted. Because Ohio's procedure failed to provide for adequate and timely judicial supervision, it was unconstitutional in all cases.


OUTCOME: The court modified the judgment of the Court of Appeals is insofar as it limited its ruling to the facts in the case at bar and, as modified, affirmed the judgment finding Ohio's prejudgment attachment procedure to be unconstitutional.

 

55 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Carroll v. Washington Township Zoning Com.


No. 79-873


Supreme Court of Ohio


63 Ohio St. 2d 249; 408 N.E.2d 191; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 816; 17 Ohio Op. 3d 161



July 30, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Richland County.

Plaintiffs-appellants, Mr. and Mrs. Charles T. Carroll, served as foster parents for five or six children from Richland County Childrens Services prior to 1976. Aware of the Ohio Youth Commission's (OYC) need for foster homes, they sought and received approval to act as foster parents for adolescents placed with them by OYC.

In March 1976, appellants purchased a 13-room house in Washington Township for use as a foster home. The house is situated in an area zoned for agricultural and single-family residential use. In order to accommodate the foster children, as well as their own children, the Carrolls made certain structural modifications, including the installation of a fire-alarm system and septic tank, the remodeling of a kitchen and bathroom, and the conversion of the third floor into a dormitory facility.

During their first year as foster parents for OYC, the Carrolls had an average of seven foster children living with them at any one time. The youths stayed at the Carroll home for periods ranging from six months to one year; consequently, a total of 17 foster children lived with the Carrolls during that [***2] year, all of them within the ages of 15 to 17.

The facts show that the Carrolls enter into a separate contract for each child placed in their home by the OYC, and that each child remains a ward of OYC. The Carrolls are given an initial allowance of $ 100 per child, and are paid $ 11.50 per child per day by OYC. In addition, OYC pays for all medical and dental care for the foster children, and reimburses appellants for the operation of their automobile. The Carrolls testified that they supplement these allowances with money of their own in order to give their foster children what they consider to be a satisfactory living environment.

In December 1976, the zoning board determined that appellants' use of their property did not comply with township zoning resolutions. Appellants sought, but were denied, both a use variance and a rezoning of their property.

Appellants then instituted this action in the Court of Common Pleas seeking a declaratory judgment that they were in compliance with the township zoning resolutions or, in the alternative, that the zoning resolutions, as applied to them, were confiscatory and in violation of their right to due process. The trial court found [***3] for defendants-appellees, and granted defendants' counterclaim for an injunction. The Court of Appeals affirmed.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an action commenced by plaintiffs, owners of a house used as a foster home, against defendant Zoning Commission of Washington Township, Ohio, seeking a declaratory judgment that they were in compliance with the Township zoning resolutions, or that the resolutions, as applied to them, were confiscatory, the Court of Appeals (Ohio) affirmed a trial court's judgment for the Commission. The owners appealed.


OVERVIEW: The owners had purchased a 13-room house in the Township for use as a foster home. The house was situated in an area zoned for single-family residential use. The owners made certain structural modifications to the house in order to accommodate the foster children. The owners had an average of seven foster children living with them at any one time. The Township zoning board determined that the owners' use of their property did not comply with the zoning resolution. The owners were denied both a use variance and a rezoning of their property. The trial court enjoined the owners from using the house as a foster home. The court of appeals affirmed. The court, in turn, affirmed the court of appeals' judgment. The court found that the court of appeals did not err in finding that the foster home did not qualify as "one family residential dwelling unit" which the Township zoning resolution required. The court stated that a comprehensive township zoning plan which excluded a foster home from an area zoned for residential use was not per se unconstitutional, and that such a zoning plan was not unreasonable.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the court of appeals' judgment affirming the trial court's judgment for the Zoning Commission.

 

56 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Garcia v. Siffrin Residential Ass'n


No. 79-409


Supreme Court of Ohio


63 Ohio St. 2d 259; 407 N.E.2d 1369; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 817; 17 Ohio Op. 3d 167



July 30, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Stark County.

The appellee herein, Siffrin Residential Association (Siffrin), is an Ohio non-profit corporation formed to promote the development of a residential, rather than an institutional, type of living environment for certain mentally retarded persons of Stark County, pursuant to the provisions of R. C. 5123.18, which provides for the licensing, inspection and operation of "residential facilities." 1 


1 Ohio for a number of years has by law provided for the licensing of facilities for the care of mentally retarded persons. Such licensure provision was contained in R. C. 5123.18. In 1977, the General Assembly enacted a new R. C. 5123.18 which became effective on October 31, 1977. The new section was included within Am. Sub. S. B. No. 71.

The portions of R. C. 5123.18 as enacted which are germane to this discussion are as follows:

"(A) As used in this section and section 5123.19 of the Revised Code:

"(1) 'Residential facility' means a home or facility in which a person with a developmental disability resides, except a home subject to Chapter 3721 of the Revised Code or the home of a relative or legal guardian in which a person with a developmental disability resides.

"(2) 'Developmental disability' means a disability that originated before the attainment of eighteen years of age and can be expected to continue indefinitely, constitutes a substantial handicap to the person's ability to function normally in society, and is attributable to mental retardation, cerebral palsy, epilepsy, autism, or any other condition found to be closely related to mental retardation because such condition results in similar impairment of general intellectual functioning or adaptive behavior or requires similar treatment and services.

"(3) 'Family home' means a residential facility that provides room and board, personal care, habilitation services, and supervision in a family setting for not more than eight persons with developmental disabilities.

"(4) 'Group home' means a residential facility that provides room and board, personal care, habilitation services, and supervision in a family setting for at least nine but not more than sixteen persons with developmental disabilities.

"(B) Every person desiring to operate a residential facility shall apply for licensure of the facility to the chief of the division of mental retardation and developmental disabilities.

"* * *

"(D) Any person may operate a licensed family home as a permitted use in any residential district or zone, including any single-family residential district or zone, of any political subdivision. Family homes may be required to comply with area, height, yard, and architectural compatibility requirements that are uniformly imposed upon all single-family residences within the district or zone.

"(E) Any person may operate a licensed group home as a permitted use in any multiple-family residential district or zone of any political subdivision, except that a political subdivision that has enacted a zoning ordinance or resolution establishing planned unit development districts may exclude group homes from such districts, and a political subdivision that has enacted a zoning ordinance or resolution may regulate group homes in multiple-family residential districts or zones as a conditionally permitted use or special exception, in either case, under reasonable and specific standards and conditions set out in the zoning ordinance or resolution to:

"(1) Require the architectural design and site layout of the home and the location, nature, and height of any walls, screens, and fences to be compatible with adjoining land uses and the residential character of the neighborhood;

"(2) Require compliance with yard, parking, and sign regulation;

"(3) Limit excessive concentration of homes.

"(F) This section does not prohibit a political subdivision from applying to residential facilities nondiscriminatory regulations requiring compliance with health, fire, and safety regulations and building standards and regulations.

"(G) Divisions (D) and (E) of this section are not applicable to municipal corporations that had in effect on June 15, 1977, an ordinance specifically permitting in residential zones licensed residential facilities by means of permitted uses, conditional uses, or special exception, so long as such ordinance remains in effect without any substantive modification."

 [***2] In November 1977, Siffrin purchased a residence at 1532 Yale Avenue, N.W., Canton, for the proposed use as a "residential facility" to house eight or fewer "developmentally disabled" female adults. This site is in an area zoned R-2 within Chapter 1137 of the Canton City Ordinances, which zoning classification restricts the sites to one and two-family dwellings. 2 


2 The sections of Chapter 1137 of the Canton city zoning ordinance which are pertinent to this discussion are as follows:

"1137.02 Permitted Uses

"Principal permitted uses are as follows:

"(a) Any use permitted in the R-1 District.

"(b) Two-family dwellings."

Within the zoning ordinances of Canton we find the following definitions:

"1123.24 Dwelling.

"'Dwelling' means any building or portion thereof, which is designed for or used for residential purposes; including one and two-family and multi-family, but not including a tent, tourist cabin, trailer, trailer coach, hotels, motels, boarding houses or lodging houses."

"1123.25 Dwelling unit.

"'Dwelling unit' means a group of rooms arranged, maintained or designed to be occupied by a single-family (see definition of family), and consists of a complete bathroom, complete kitchen or kitchenette; and facilities for living, sleeping and eating. All of the facilities are to be located in contiguous rooms and used exclusively by such family and by any authorized persons occupying such dwelling unit with the family."

"1123.27 Dwelling, Two-family.

"'Two-family dwelling' means a building designed for or used exclusively for residence purposes by two families living independently of each other."

"1123.30 Family.

"'Family' means one or more persons occupying a dwelling unit and living as a single housekeeping unit, whether or not related to each other by birth or marriage, as distinguished from a group occupying a boarding house, lodging house, motel, hotel, fraternity or sorority house."

 [***3] Appellants, Alex J. and Mary L. Garcia, are owners of a residence located adjacent to the proposed facility, in which residence they have lived for approximately 25 years.

In March 1978, Siffrin made application to the Ohio Department of Mental Health and Mental Retardation, pursuant to R. C. 5123.18, for licensure of the home. The department, pursuant to law, issued a notice to the Canton Planning Commission, Canton Board of Zoning Appeals and the Clerk of Canton City Council, prior to the publication of the required legal notice. Letters of objection to the proposed location were filed by Mr. Garcia and another neighbor. Subsequently, a petition was signed by some 50 residents in the neighborhood, objecting to the location of this facility.

The Canton Zoning Department also filed a letter of objection, stating that the proposed use was neither a permitted use nor a conditional use in a R-2 district, and that the home as proposed could only qualify as a "boarding house" or "rooming house," a conditional use in a R-4 residential district.

The Department of Mental Health and Mental Retardation reviewed the objections, including that of the city of Canton, and determined that [***4] zoning restrictions imposed by the odinance were superseded by the effect of R. C. 5123.81 and, more specifically, subsection (D) thereof, which, in pertinent part, states as follows:

"Any person may operate a licensed family home as a permitted use in any residential district or zone, including any single-family residential district or zone, of any political subdivision."

This present cause was thereafter instituted on April 21, 1978, by the filing of the complaint by the Garcias, in the Court of Common Pleas of Stark County (case No. 78-450), seeking to enjoin Siffrin from establishing a "family home" at 1532 Yale Avenue, and requesting that R. C. 5123.18(D) be declared unconstitutional. Appellants also requested that Drs. Moritz and Cannon of the Department of Mental Health and Mental Retardation be enjoined from licensing the home.

The city of Canton filed a complaint against the same defendants, also seeking to enjoin the licensing and establishment of this "family home," and to have R. C. 5123.18(D) declared unconstitutional.

Appellee, Ohio Legal Rights Service, moved and was granted leave to intervene as a party-defendant in case No. 78-450. The cases were consolidated [***5] and after a hearing, a preliminary injunction was granted to the plaintiffs enjoining the director from issuing a license for this operation.

Upon trial of this matter, evidence was adduced showing that Siffrin is a corporate entity controlled by a board of directors; that the corporation has at least one other "residential facility" in operation; and that the overall operations of this proposed facility, as well as the currently operating facility, are under the control of a director. The staff that was to be brought into this proposed operation, in addition to the director, would be a married couple who would reside on the premises, two other women working full-time, and other special purpose training staff as needed to carry out the "habilitation services" and "personal care" as provided by statute and regulations. "Habilitation," as defined in R. C. 5123.68(G), "means the process by which the staff of the institution assists the resident to acquire and maintain those life skills which enable him to cope more effectively with the demands of his own person and of his environment and to raise the level of his physical, mental, social, and vocational efficiency. Habilitation includes [***6] but is not limited to programs of formal, structured education and training * * *."

The director and an admissions committee screen the applicants for the home, and individual month-to-month contracts are entered into with either the individual, member of the family or guardian, or the state of Ohio if the person was institutionalized. The amount charged for the services to be given the individual varies with the physical or educational needs or requirements of the individual. The clients are persons with one or more "developmental disabilities"; all are characterized by deficiencies in adaptive behavior, in socialization, and in life skills, and some have both neurological and organic disabilities or damage.

The budget for this facitlity would be approximately $ 61,000 "broken down * * * [into] direct care, indirect staff cost for secretarial, administrative, administrative non-personnel cost, telephone, travel, things of this nature, food, mortgage, utilities, depreciation, insurance, things like this." There is a rather complex funding of residents, including federal and state funds for room and board reimbursement.

Thereafter, on August 18, 1978, Judge DeHoff, of the Court [***7] of Common Pleas of Stark County, issued his findings of fact and conclusions of law. Among the findings of fact of the trial court are the following:

"20. Under the definitions contained in Chapter 1123 of the Canton City Ordinance, "family" means one or more persons occupying a dwelling unit and living as a single housekeeping unit, whether or not related to each other by birth or marriage, and who do not pay consideration for living there and who do not have an "operator" running the dwelling.

"21. Ohio Revised Code Section 5123.18 defines "family home" as a residential facility that provides room and board, personal care, habilitation services, and supervision in a family setting for not more than eight persons with developmental disabilities.

"22. Ohio Revised Code Section 5123.18(B) provides that persons desiring to operate a family home residential facility must apply for a license. [Emphasis sic.]

"23. The proposed Siffrin Residential Association for the Developmentally Disabled of Stark county "family home" will house up to eight female adults, two full-time houseparents and a part-time relief staff employed by the Siffrin Association for the Develpmentally [***8] Disabled of Stark County and will be administered by a full-time director.

"24. The proposed Siffrin Residential Association for the Develpmentally Disabled of Stark County "family home" will operate when at full capacity, on a budget of $ 65,000 per year.

"* * *

"26. Location of the proposed "family home" at 1532 Yale Avenue N. W., Canton, Stark County, Ohio, immediately adjacent to the residence of Alex J. Garcia and Mary Garcia, will cause a diminution of the Garcias' property value.

"27. Location of a group home housing eight mentally retarded adult men at 150 South Rose Avenue, Akron, Ohio, resulted in a thirty-five (35) percent tax valuation reduction to the immediate neighboring property owned by Charles Zindle and Charlotte Zindle."

The conclusions of law of the trial court included the following:

"2. The defendant's, Siffrin Residential Association for the Developmentally Disabled of Stark County, proposed use of the premises located at 1532 Yale Avenue N. W., Canton, Stark county, Ohio, as a "family home" is not a "family" within the meaning of Canton's Zoning Ordinances, effective February 14, 1977, and is not a permitted or conditional use in an R-2 zone.

"3.  [***9] Amended Substitute Senate Bill No. 71, subsections (D) and (E), Ohio Revised Code Section 5123.18(D), (E), are not "general" laws of the State of Ohio within the meaning of Article XVIII, Section 3, of the Ohio Constitution.

"4. Canton's Zoning Ordinances are enacted pursuant to the constitutional grant of powers of local self-government, Article XVIII, Section 3; are not subject to the "conflict" provision of Article XVIII, Section 3 of the Ohio Constitution; and are not superseded by Amended Substitute Senate Bill No. 71, subsections (D) and (E), Ohio Revised Code Section 5123.18(D), (E).

"5. Amended Substitute Senate Bill No. 71, subsections (D), (E) and (G), Ohio Revised Code Section 5123.18(D), (E), (G) are not uniform in their operation throughout the State of Ohio and are void as special laws prohibited by Article II, Section 26 of the Ohio Constitution.

"6. Amended Substitute Senate Bill No. 71, subsections (D) and (E), Ohio Revised Code Section 5123.18(D), (E), are unconstitutional and in violation of the due process clauses of Article I of the Ohio Constitution and the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution in that they are arbitrary and capricious."

 [***10] Judgment was accordingly entered for the Garcias and the city of Canton. Siffrin, Drs. Moritz and Cannon, and the Ohio Legal Rights Service thereafter appealed the decision of the Court of Common Pleas to the Court of Appeals. The members of that court rendered their opinion and judgment on March 1979, reversing the judgment of the trial court.

The Court of Appeals found that the Siffrin operation would be in compliance with the Canton ordinance, in that the facility and its residents could be considered a "family" under the ordinance because they would be "occupying a dwelling unit and living as a single housekeeping unit." Further, the court found that the trial court erred in finding that the establishment of the Siffrin home will occasion a diminution in the value of the Garcias' adjacent property.

The Court of Appeals further found that R. C. 5123.18(D) and (E) are general laws of the state of Ohio within the meaning of Section 3, Article XVIII of the Ohio Constitution.

Further, the Court of Appeals held that the Canton zoning ordinance, being an exercise of the police power pursuant to Section 3, Article XVIII of the Ohio Constitution, is subject to the conflict provision [***11] of that section, and held that R. C. 5123.18 was not a "special" law, even though under subdivision (G) it excludes certain cities from the zoning overriding features of (D) and (E), and that such statute did have a uniform operation throughout the state, and was therefore not contrary to Section 26, Article II of the Ohio Constitution.

1. "The Siffrin Residential Association's proposed use of the residence at 1532 Yale Ave. N.W., Canton, Ohio, as a "family home," defined in O.R.C. Section 5123.18(A)(3), is not a "family" use as defined in the Canton city ordinance and consequently is not a permitted use in an R-2 zoned district."

2. " Ohio Revised Code Sections 5123.18(D) and (E) are not "general laws" of the state of Ohio withing the meaning of Article XVIII, Section 3 of the Ohio Constitution."

3. "Canton's zoning ordinances are enacted pursuant to the constitutional grant of powers of local self-government, Article XVIII, Section 3; are not subject to the "conflict" provision of Article XVIII, Section 3; and are not superseded by Ohio Revised Code Sections 5123.18(D) and (E)."

4. " Ohio Revised Code Sections 5123.18(D), (E) and (G) are void as special laws prohibited by Article [***12] II, Section 26 of the Ohio Constitution."

5. " Ohio Revised Code Sections 5123.18(D) and (E) are unconstitutional and in violation of the due process clauses of Article I of the Ohio Constitution and the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution."

6. " Ohio Revised Code Sections 5123.18(D) and (E) create an arbitrary and discriminatory classification of persons and are unconstitutional under Article I of the Ohio Constitution and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution."

7. "Appellants Garcias are entitled to injunctive relief to prevent operation of the Siffrin Residential Association's "family home" at 1532 Yale Avenue, N.W., Canton, Ohio pursuant to Ohio Revised Code Section 713.3."

8. "Application of the city of Canton's zoning ordinance to prohibit the proposed use of the Siffrin Residential Association's "family home" in an R-2 district is a constitutional exercise of the city's police powers."

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, neighbors and a city, appealed a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Stark County (Ohio) that reversed a trial court's decision and ruled that defendant property owner's proposed use of a residence as a facility and home for several developmentally disabled adults was not contrary to Canton, Ohio, Zoning Ordinance ch. 1137.02 (ordinance) and that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5123.18, which permitted such a use, was constitutional.


OVERVIEW: The property owner (owner) purchased a home in an area that was restricted to one- and two-family dwellings under the ordinance and sought to operate a group home for several developmentally disabled adults. The neighbors and the city opposed the use, arguing that it did not conform to the ordinance and that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5123.18, which permitted the operation of such a facility in any zone, was unconstitutional. The trial court rendered judgment for the city and neighbors. The appellate court reversed, finding that the facility fell within the ordinance and that § 5123.18 was constitutional. On appeal, the court ruled that the ordinance was constitutional and that, because the persons housed in the home would require individual and particularized care, it was clear that the home was not intended to create a family atmosphere within the meaning of "family use" as used in the ordinance. The court then declared § 5123.18 unconstitutional. The court ruled that the statute impermissibly restricted the city's police power and impermissibly classified cities in its attempt to create a deadline by which no ordinance could be enacted to restrict the creation of such homes.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment. The state statute, which permitted use such as the property owner's proposed use in any zone or district, was unconstitutional. The zoning ordinance was a valid exercise of the city's police power and was substantially related to governmental interests. The property owner's proposed use was not a "family use" within the meaning of the ordinance.

 

57 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Cities Service Oil Co. v. Orteca


No. 79-1451


Supreme Court of Ohio


63 Ohio St. 2d 295; 409 N.E.2d 1018; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 820; 17 Ohio Op. 3d 189



July 30, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

Cities Service Oil Company, appellee herein, applied to Joseph Orteca, Building Commissioner of the city of Warrensville Heights ("city"), for a building permit. Appellee seeks to tear down the existing automotive service station on its property in that city, located at the southwest corner of Northfield Road and Clarkwood Parkway, and to replace it with a self-service gasoline station and Quik-Mart facility. The city planning commission unanimously voted to refuse the permit, a decision which was affirmed by city council on September 21, 1976.

In 1976, the General Assembly enacted R. C. 3741.141 1 permitting the operation of self-service automotive stations within the state. The statute became effective on January 1, 1977. On November 3, 1976, the Warrensville Heights city council passed ordinance No. 1976-150 forbidding self-service gasoline stations in the city. In February of 1977, appellee filed a second application for a building permit, accompanied by a set of plans approved by the state, as required by the building commissioner's regulations. Orteca neither approved nor refused this second application,  [***2] but informed appellee by telephone that no permit would be issued since the city planning commission and council had rejected the first application.


1 R. C. 3741.141 provides: "Franchised dealers shall be allowed the option as to whether they wish to offer full-service, self-service on one island, or complete self-service in the conduct of their business."

Appellee's parcel of land is in an area zoned Class U-3, apartment house use. The city had issued a special use permit to Flo-An, Inc., in 1963, for the parcel in question. There was a transfer of ownership of the parcel to appellee soon thereafter and, on April 14, 1964, the city issued a building permit to appellee to allow the construction of the present service station facilities.

On December 5, 1977, appellee brought an action in mandamus in the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County seeking to require Orteca to issue a building permit to appellee. On July 20, 1978, the Court of Appeals issued an order granting a limited writ of mandamus directing Orteca and the city to process appellee's building permit according to a procedure outlined by the court. 2 Pursuant to that order, hearings were held before the city [***3] planning commission and council regarding appellee's application. Subsequently, appellee was informed that a new special use permit would be required and was also notified of non-compliance of appellee's plans with city ordinances. Council's granting of the special use permit was conditioned on appellee's compliance with certain enumerated areas. 3 Appellee objected to several of the conditions. By letter of October 19, 1978, Orteca informed appellee that the building permit application had been denied.


2 The Court of Appeals found the following procedure to be mandated by city ordinances:

"1. Commissioner Orteca has a clear legal duty to refer relator's second application to the planning commission;

"2. the planning commission has a clear legal duty to consider the application and make a recommendation concerning it to council;

"3. the council has the duty to consider the planning commission's recommendation;

"4. Council's duty then is to forward their approval or disapproval to commissioner Orteca; and

"5. Commissioner Orteca has the duty to take final action by granting or denying the building permit."

The court also ordered "* * * that each decision made during the processing of this application be reduced to writing and include each and every reason for that decision; all objections omitted will be deemed waived."


3  These conditions included:

"1. That there be solely one building structure erected.

"2. The automobile service station be limited to those service items as shown in the Codified Ordinances of the City of Warrensville Heights, Section 1141.05(a)(4) (no multiple use).

"3. The building plans shall comply with Ohio Department of Highway Regulations governing ingress and egress at gasoline service stations.

"4. The tanks providing for self-storing petroleum products shall not provide for the storage in excess of 24,000 gallons in the aggregate and no more than 10,000 per tank.

"5. That the building plans shall comply with side yard and rear yard requirements of the City of Warrensville Heights.

"6. That the proposed service station structure shall be in compliance with all of the regulations of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Warrensville Heights.

"7. That the plans provide for separate toilet facilities for the members of each sex.

"8. That the proposed service station shall not be operated as a self-service station."

 [***4] On December 13, 1978, appellee filed a "Motion for Supplemental Order" in the Court of Appeals. On September 6, 1979, the Court of Appeals issued a writ of mandamus ordering Orteca to issue the requested building permit to appellee. Further, that court found city ordinance No. 1976-150 unconstitutional and void ab initio.

The cause is now before this court on an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio) issued an order granting a limited writ of mandamus directing appellants, commissioner and city, to process appellee company's building permit. The company's application was denied. The appellate court then issued a writ of mandamus ordering the commissioner to issue the permit. The appellate court also found Warrensville Heights, Ohio, Ordinance No. 1976-150 unconstitutional and void ab initio.


OVERVIEW: The company sought a building permit to tear down an existing automotive service station on its property and to erect a self-service station and grocery store. The company's parcel of land was zoned for apartment house use. The previous owner had received a special use permit from the city. The city refused the company's first two permit requests. In response to the appellate court's limited writ, a hearing was held and the company was informed that a new special use permit would be required and that its plans were not in compliance with Ordinance No. 1976-150. On review, the court held that (1) the writ of mandamus was not available to control the discretion of public officials, and that the appellate court erred in ordering the city and commissioner to perform the discretionary act of issuing a building permit for a use not permitted by the applicable zoning ordinance, (2) the appellate court erred in estopping the city and commissioner from asserting the personal nature of a special use permit, and (3) where Ordinance No. 1976-150 was in conflict with Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3741.141, the ordinance was void and unenforceable.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's judgment insofar as the company had not established a clear legal right to a building permit. The court held that the city could validly require the company to procure a new special use permit as a condition precedent to issuance of a building permit.

 

58 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


County Comm'rs Asso. v. Public Utilities Com.


No. 79-1461


Supreme Court of Ohio


63 Ohio St. 2d 243; 407 N.E.2d 534; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 815; 17 Ohio Op. 3d 150



July 23, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Public Utilities Commission.

On July 8, 1976, the Public Utilities Commission issued an opinion and order in case No. 74-761-TP-AIR which approved, among other things, the substitution by the Ohio Bell Telephone Company (Ohio Bell) of measured rate local business service for flat rate service.

On April 17, 1978, a complaint was filed requesting reclassification of elementary and secondary schools as residential. On May 15, 1978, Ohio Bell and the complainants entered into a stipulation, agreement, and recommendation wherein the schools agreed to dismiss their complaint and Ohio Bell agreed to modify the measured rate service as it applied to them by placing a ceiling on the amount they could be charged under the measured rate system in recognition of their unique needs. On May 25, 1978, the commission found the stipulation, agreement, and recommendation to be reasonable and approved a tariff giving the schools this special treatment.

Subsequently, numerous complaints were filed regarding the adequacy and sufficiency of the classification system used by Ohio Bell to determine which customers received measured rate service, including one filed June 8, 1978,  [***2] by the County Commissioners' Association of Ohio, appellants herein, on behalf of the association and the state's county governments (case No. 78-940-TP-CSS). Due to the large number of complaints filed, the commission, on its own motion, on December 14, 1978, initiated an investigation into the classification system (case No. 78-1487-TP-COI).

Numerous parties intervened, including the appellants. After taking testimony, in February 1979, the commission ordered, on July 18, 1979, that the investigation be dismissed and no new classifications be created. Because the special treatment of schools was the product of an approved stipulation, the commission further ordered that the situation be reviewed in a separately docketed proceeding. A number of parties, including appellants, did not argue that the schools should not be given special treatment, but rather that the counties should receive the same treatment as the schools. The commission refused to make such an order.

A hearing had been held on appellants' complaint on August 1, 1978, prior to the initiation of the commission's investigative case. The notice regarding the investigative case stated as follows:

"ORDERED, That [***3] upon written request of the parties of record in any other case seeking reclassification under Ohio Bell's existing tariff, notice be taken of the portions of the transcript in said cases shown to be relevant to the subject matter of the instant investigation, and the same be adopted into this proceeding."

At the hearing in the investigative case the County Commissioners' Association requested that the record from this complaint case be adopted into the investigative case. It was noted that Ohio Bell requested that the record from the investigative case be adopted into the record of all pending complaint proceedings. The hearing examiner granted the association's request. In the complaint case, the commission administratively noticed the record of the investigative case.

On November 28, 1979, the commission entered its findings and order in the complaint case, which incorporated the conclusion of the investigative case and ordered that the matter be dismissed without altering the classification as urged by the appellants.

Appellants appealed both decisions to this court, arguing that the differentiation between schools and county governments is contrary to statute and in violation [***4] of the guarantees of equal protection and due process of law contained in the Ohio and United States Constitutions. In addition, appellants argue that the disposition of their complaint (case No. 78-940-TP-CSS) is invalid because (1) the length of time taken to decide the case was unreasonably long, (2) the order did not contain sufficient findings of fact, and (3) it was the result of administratively noticing the record of the investigative case.

The cause is now before this court as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Orders affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant association of county commissioners sought review of a decision by appellee Public Utilities Commission (Ohio), which refused the association's request that the Commission grant counties the same special telephone rate ceiling that it previously had approved for elementary and secondary schools. The association contended that the rate differentiation was contrary to statute and that it violated equal protection and due process.


OVERVIEW: After the Commission approved a tariff giving elementary and secondary schools a special rate ceiling for telephone rates, the association requested the same treatment for county governments. The Commission denied the request and found that the facts before the Commission formed a reasonable basis for distinguishing between counties and schools. In its ruling, the court found that the schools were given special treatment because of their unique status, their unique needs, their inability to pass on costs, and their financial plight. Although there were similarities between the counties and the schools, the differences justified the differential in treatment on both statutory and constitutional grounds. Both the counties and the schools had financial problems, but the counties could handle those problems better without experiencing a drop in essential services, so the schools' need for special treatment was unique. Because of that uniqueness, the court held that the Commission's refusal to order the same rate treatment for the counties was not unlawful, unreasonable, or unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the Commission's decision.

 

59 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Flynt


No. 79-556


Supreme Court of Ohio


63 Ohio St. 2d 132; 407 N.E.2d 15; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 798; 17 Ohio Op. 3d 81



July 16, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

On July 14, 1976, complaints were issued against defendants-appellants, Larry C. Flynt, Jimmy R. Flynt and Althea Leasure Flynt, for allegedly pandering obscenity in violation of R. C. 2907.32(A)(2), complicity in violation of R. C. 2923.03(A)(2) and personal accountability for organizational conduct in violation of R. C. 2901.24(A)(1). The complaints alleged that the defendants, as officers, agents or employees of Hustler magazine, caused, or permitted, the exhibition or dissemination of materials known to be obscene, to wit, the July and August, 1976, issues of Hustler magazine.

The defendants moved to dismiss the complaints on the basis that they were discriminately prosecuted, in contravention of the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. The trial court granted an evidentiary hearing on the motion, whereupon the following facts were elicited, primarily from Bruce A. Taylor, the assistant law director for the city of Cleveland. Taylor had been in charge of the city's obscenity prosecution when these complaints were issued.

It was testified that since April of 1973 the city of Cleveland had initiated [***2] between 500 and 550 obscenity prosecutions. The materials selected for prosecution were largely determined in accordance with instructions given by Taylor to police officers, although the officers were given considerable latitude to exercise their own discretion. The instructions provided that applicable Supreme Court decisions proscribed the sale of "obscenity which is hard-core." "Hard-core" was understood to encompass "actually instead of simulated acts of sex." The officers were further instructed to seize the "most explicit of the material available." Enforcement therefore concentrated on "adult book-stores and theaters." There was also testimony that certain materials which may not have contained "actual sexual contact" were, nevertheless, seized and prosecuted. It was conceded by Taylor, that "[w]e had never prosecuted a magazine like Hustler."

Further testimony revealed that the police department received complaints about the July 1976 issue of Hustler, and, in particular, a cartoon depicting sexual activity between prominent political figures and the Statue of Liberty. An investigation ensued, whereupon a copy of the issue was brought to Taylor, who subsequently decided [***3] to initiate action against the magazine.

Taylor asserted that Hustler was prosecuted as a test case. Other magazines of a similar nature had been under investigation for eight months without being prosecuted. He conceded that such an extended investigation was unusual. When questioned why he did not prosecute these magazines, Taylor stated that he was "waiting for this case." When he was asked whether further prosecutions would follow, should he receive a favorable decision in this case, Taylor responded, "I don't know. That decision I can't make alone either" but "[i]t's being discussed."

On the basis of this testimony and the testimony of a Cleveland police officer working obscenity cases, the trial judge determined that the defendants were prosecuted discriminatorily, in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment, and dismissed the complaints. The Court of Appeals reversed, holding that the defendants failed to sustain their burden of proof.

The cause is now before this court upon the allowance of appellants' motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants sought review of the decision of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which reversed the decision of the trial court that the case should be dismissed for discriminatory prosecution in the State's action against defendants for pandering obscenity, pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code § 2907.32(A)(2), complicity in violation of § 2923.03(A)(2), and personal accountability for organizational conduct, pursuant to § 2901.24(A)(1).


OVERVIEW: The city issued complaints against defendants for pandering obscenity in violation of Ohio Rev. Code § 2907.32(A)(2), complicity in violation of § 2923.03(A)(2), and personal accountability for organizational conduct in violation of § 2901.24(A)(1). After a hearing, the trial court determined that the State was prosecuting defendants discriminatorily and dismissed the complaints. On the State's appeal, the appellate court reversed the decision of the trial court. On the defendant's appeal, the court affirmed the decision of the appellate court. The court determined that test cases did not necessarily violated the Equal Protection Clause of the United States Constitution, that the elements of proving discriminatory prosecution required a showing of differential treatment and of invidious or bad faith prosecution based on impermissible considerations, that defendant's had a heavy burden in establishing the prima facie case, and that defendants failed to meet the burden of proving an invidious or bad faith motivation.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the appellate court, which reversed the decision of the trial court. The court found that defendants had not met the burden of proving intentional or purposeful discrimination in selective prosecution.

 

60 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Cleveland v. Public Utilities Com.


Nos. 79-1158, 79-1173


Supreme Court of Ohio


63 Ohio St. 2d 62; 406 N.E.2d 1370; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 773; 17 Ohio Op. 3d 37



July 9, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Public Utilities Commission.

These appeals are from a May 2, 1979, order of appellee, Public Utilities Commission of Ohio, granting Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company (CEI), intervening appellee, an increase of approximately $ 60.5 million in certain of its rates and charges for electric service.

After accepting CEI's application for a rate increase, the commission established the calendar year 1978 as the test year and June 30, 1978, as the date certain. The commission staff conducted an investigation of the application and issued its findings on January 12, 1979. Thereafter, public hearings encompassing 34 days were held before the commission. Represented at these hearings were, inter alia, appellant in case No. 79-1158, the city of Cleveland (city), and appellants in case No. 79-1173, the Senior Citizens Coalition et al. (Senior Citizens).

Following appellee's May 2, 1979, order, timely applications for rehearing were filed by appellants. The commission granted a rehearing on two issues not relevant to these appeals, but denied rehearing on all other grounds.

These causes are now before this court upon appeals as of right.



DISPOSITION:  [***2] Judgment accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, a city and senior citizens, sought judicial review of an order of appellee Public Utility Commission (Ohio), which granted a rate increase to intervenor electric company.


OVERVIEW: The city and the senior citizens opposed the electric company's application to raise utility rates. The Commission granted the electric company's increase, including a nuclear plant, attorney's fees, declining block rates, a construction work in progress (CWIP), charitable contributions, and advertising costs. The city and the senior citizens sought judicial review. The court affirmed the Commission's decision except in so far as institutional and promotional advertising and charitable contributions were included in the electric company's rate increase. The finding that the nuclear plant was used and useful was not against the weight of the evidence or unsupported by the record. Likewise, the Commission exercised sound judgment in including attorney's fees in the rate increase. As to the CWIP, the Commission properly granted an allowance in accord with constitutional guidelines respecting its authority. Nevertheless, the court reversed the Commission's decision to the extent that it included promotional and institutional advertising costs, which primarily benefitted the electric company, and charitable contributions, which were an unnecessary expense.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed that part of the Commission's order granting a rate increase to the electric company, which included a nuclear plant, attorney's fees, declining block rates, and a construction work in progress. The court reversed the Commission's grant of a rate increase to the extent that it included charitable contributions and advertising costs.

 

61 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Rarick v. Board of County Comm'rs


Nos. 79-798, 79-799


Supreme Court of Ohio


63 Ohio St. 2d 34; 406 N.E.2d 1101; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 767; 17 Ohio Op. 3d 21



July 2, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Geauga County.

Richard L. Rarick was appointed Building Service Superintendent of Geauga County in 1963. His wife, Erma M. Rarick, was appointed Assistant Building Service Superintendent in 1965.

In a letter dated January 5, 1977, the Board of Geauga County Commissioners notified the Department of Administrative Services that they were designating a number of positions, including the ones occupied by the Raricks, as unclassified pursuant to R. C. 124.11(A)(9). The department approved of the designations. It is unclear whether these positions had been considered at one time to be in the classified service. It does not appear that the Raricks were ever appointed on the basis of the results of competitive examinations.

In July 1977, the Raricks were terminated from their employment. No reason for the terminations was given; the procedures required in R. C. Chapter 124 to terminate employees in the classified service were not used.

The Raricks appealed their terminations to the State Personnel Board of Review, and hearing was held on August 19, 1977. At the hearing it was established (1) that the superintendent made recommendations [***2] regarding the hiring and firing of employees, which the county commissioners always followed; (2) that he purchased supplies on blanket purchase orders; (3) that he had contracted snow removal duties to himself and others subject to approval by the commissioners; (4) that the Raricks owned their own cleaning equipment which they acquired from a monthly allowance given them by the commissioners; (5) that, in addition to doing maintenance work themselves, the Raricks supervised others in such work; and (6) that the assistant filled the superintendent's position during his absence.

The hearing examiner determined that these duties placed the Raricks in both a fiduciary and administrative relationship with the county commissioners and, as a consequence, he recommended that their appeals be dismissed because the board does not have jurisdiction over appeals of removals from positions in the unclassified service. The board disaffirmed the report and ordered that the Raricks be reinstated.

The commissioners appealed to the Court of Common Pleas of Geauga County which held that the Raricks' assigned and actual duties placed them in an administrative and fiduciary relationship with the [***3] commissioners. Consequently, the court held that the order of the board was not supported by reliable, probative and substantial evidence and that the board lacked subject matter jurisdiction over the appeal.

On separate appeal by the Raricks, the Court of Appeals reversed in each case, finding that, although the positions held by the Raricks are positions of trust, they did not involve the special confidence and trust necessary to place their positions in a fiduciary or administrative relationship with the appointing authority.

The causes are now before this court upon allowances of motions to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgments reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant board of county commissioners challenged an order from the Court of Appeals for Geauga County (Ohio), which reversed the trial court decision that had found appellee employees' assigned and actual duties placed them in an administrative and fiduciary relationship with the commissioners.


OVERVIEW: The employees were appointed as the county's assistant and building service superintendents. The county commissioners were designated as unclassified and, later, terminated. The employees appealed to the State Personnel Board of Review, which ordered reinstatement. The commissioners appealed to the trial court, which held that the employees' assigned and actual duties placed them in an administrative and fiduciary relationship with the commissioners and that the Board lacked subject matter jurisdiction over the appeal. The appellate court reversed. The commissioners appealed, arguing that, because the employees were designated as unclassified, the Board did not have jurisdiction over appeals from the terminations. The court disagreed, holding that: (1) the Board had jurisdiction over the appeal from the employees who were in the classified service, regardless of how they have been designated by their appointing authority; (2) the employees were directly responsible to the commissioners; and (3) purchasing supplies and supervising building staff were within the employees' duties, which placed the positions in an administrative and fiduciary relationship with the commissioners.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the appellate court, which reversed the trial court decision that had found the employees' assigned and actual duties placed them in an administrative and fiduciary relationship with the commissioners.

 

62 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Buckley v. Cincinnati


No. 79-1421


Supreme Court of Ohio


63 Ohio St. 2d 42; 406 N.E.2d 1106; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 769; 17 Ohio Op. 3d 26



July 2, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

Plaintiffs-appellants, police officers and firefighters employed by the city of Cincinnati, instituted actions in the Court of Common Pleas challenging Cincinnati Ordinance No. 258-1977, which was enacted June 29, 1977. Appellants' motion to consolidate the actions was granted by the trial court. Appellants contended, inter alia, that the ordinance, which seeks to regulate the residency of city employees, contravened certain provisions of the Ohio Constitution, and that its enactment exceeded the power conferred upon city council by the Cincinnati Charter.

The court subsequently granted appellants' motion for summary judgment, holding that the ordinance had a retroactive effect upon those city employees who were employed prior to the date of its passage. The court, however, rejected appellants' claim that enactment of the ordinance was an ultra vires act of the city council, holding that the Cincinnati Charter did not forbid the enactment of a valid residency ordinance.

On appeal and cross-appeal, the Court of Appeals affirmed that portion of the trial court's judgment which upheld the council's power to [***2] enact a valid residency ordinance, but reversed that portion which declared the subject ordinance to be unconstitutional. 

The cause is now before this court upon allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, police officers and firefighters employed by the city of Cincinnati, filed actions challenging Cincinnati, Ohio, Ordinance No. 258-1977. The Court of Appeals for Hamilton County affirmed that portion of the trial court's judgment which upheld the power of defendants, the city of Cincinnati and others, to enact a valid residency ordinance, but reversed that portion which declared the ordinance unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The ordinance purported to amend Cincinnati, Ohio, Admin. Code art. XVII, § 1, which imposed a residency requirement on city employees. Plaintiffs contended that the ordinance had a retroactive effect upon their constitutional right to travel. The court disagreed because there was no constitutional right to be employed by a municipality while living elsewhere. Prior to enactment of the ordinance, city employees were permitted to reside where they wished within the county, but the court found that this "right" was not vested such that its subsequent impairment violated Ohio Const. art. II, § 28. The court further found that the ordinance was drafted to avoid the problem of retroactivity where it did not require current employees divest themselves of property or to change their residence, but simply provided that if an employee desired to change his residence, he had to move into, or remain within, the city. Thus, the court concluded that the ordinance regulated future conduct and was prospective in operation. The court found that the Cincinnati charter allowed the council to pass laws relating to municipal service so long as they did not conflict with provisions of state law.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the court of appeals.

 

63 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Zoller v. Talbert


No. 79-1613


Supreme Court of Ohio


62 Ohio St. 2d 329; 405 N.E.2d 724; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 752; 16 Ohio Op. 3d 391



June 18, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Seneca County.

Appellant, Thomas M. Zoller, law director of the city of Tiffin, filed a complaint in mandamus in the Court of Appeals, alleging that appellee, Bonford R. Talbert, Jr., judge of the Tiffin Municipal Court, had, in an indeterminate number of cases, disregarded the mandatory sentencing provisions applicable to those convicted of a violation of R. C. 4511.19 (driving while intoxicated or drugged). By way of relief, appellant sought to compel appellee to impose a 30-day suspension of driving privileges on all defendants convicted under R. C. 4511.19 or parallel ordinances, as mandated by R. C. 4507.16(B), and to forward to the Bureau of Motor Vehicles the abstract of such proceedings, as required by R. C. 4507.40(B). The Court of Appeals sua sponte dismissed the complaint, concluding that appellant had no standing to maintain the action.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, a city's director of law, sought review of an order of the Court of Appeals for Seneca County (Ohio), which dismissed the director's original complaint for mandamus seeking to compel appellee judge to impose a 30-day suspension of driving privileges on all defendants convicted of driving while intoxicated or drugged.


OVERVIEW: The trial court concluded sua sponte that the director had no standing to maintain the action. On appeal, the court held that (1) the director had standing by virtue of his obligation under City of Tiffin, Ohio, Charter § 6.02(C) because he was the prosecutor for the city and in his official capacity had a beneficial interest in the subject matter of which he complained different from and transcending that of the citizenry generally; (2) if there were errors made by the judge in sentencing, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.67(A) provided a plain and adequate remedy at law to correct those errors; and (3) mandamus would not lie because the director had an adequate remedy at law.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

 

64 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Leis v. Outcalt


No. 79-1231


Supreme Court of Ohio


62 Ohio St. 2d 331; 405 N.E.2d 725; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 753; 16 Ohio Op. 3d 392



June 18, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

This cause arises from an action in mandamus filed by relator, Simon L. Leis, Jr., the Prosecuting Attorney for Hamilton County, to compel respondent, Judge Peter Outcalt of the Court of Common Pleas of Hamilton County, to impose sentence on Barbara Beasley, a.k.a. Barbara Christian (hereinafter "defendant"), in conformity with R. C. 2929.11. 1 


1 R. C. 2929.11(B) provides:

"Terms of imprisonment for a felony shall be imposed as follows:

"* * *

"(2) For a felony of the second degree the minimum term shall be two, three, four, or five years and the maximum term shall be fifteen years."

The Grand Jury of Hamilton County indicted the defendant on two counts of felonious assault with a deadly weapon, a felony of the second degree. On November 30, 1978, the defendant's cause came before respondent for disposition, at which time the defendant entered a plea of no contest to each count of the indictment. After accepting the defendant's plea, respondent found the defendant guilty as charged and, over the objections of relator made in the judge's chambers, sentenced the defendant to pay a $ 500 fine for each count [***2] of the indictment. No sentence of imprisonment was imposed.

On December 6, 1978, relator instituted the instant action in mandamus in the Court of Appeals. On that date the defendant paid the outstanding fines and costs assessed by the trial court. Thereafter, on August 15, 1979, the Court of Appeals issued a writ of mandamus ordering respondent to impose the sentence of imprisonment mandated by R. C. 2929.11. On August 21, 1979, respondent set aside the defendant's sentence and resentenced the defendant to two concurrent terms of imprisonment of not less than two years and fined the defendant $ 500 for each count of the indictment. 2 


2 Relator indicates to this court that an appeal from this order is now pending in the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

The cause is now before this court as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant trial judge challenged an order of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which issued writ of mandamus compelling him to sentence a defendant in conformity with Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2929.11. The action in mandamus was filed by relator, the prosecuting attorney, after the judge refused to impose sentence under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2929.11 for a felony conviction.


OVERVIEW: Defendant entered a plea of no contest to two counts of felonious assault with a deadly weapon, a second-degree felony. The judge accepted the plea, found her guilty, and sentenced her to pay a fine for each count. The prosecutor made objections to the sentence. Thereafter, defendant paid the fines and costs. Upon the prosecutor's request, the court of appeals issued a writ of mandamus ordering the judge to impose a mandatory sentence under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2929.11. Consequently, defendant was resentenced to prison terms and fined in the same amount. On appeal, the court reversed, holding that the writ of mandamus should have been denied because the prosecutor had a plain and adequate remedy at law under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.67(A).


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals.

 

65 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Young


Nos. 79-728, 79-1124


Supreme Court of Ohio


62 Ohio St. 2d 370; 406 N.E.2d 499; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 760; 16 Ohio Op. 3d 416



June 18, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Courts of Appeals for Hamilton and Cuyahoga Counties.

Two cases have been consolidated herein. In the one cause (case No. 79-728), defendant-appellee, Carolyn N. Young, was indicted with 23 other individuals for violating R. C. 2923.04, this state's organized crime statute. Following her indictment, appellee moved to dismiss the charge on the basis that R. C. 2923.04 was unconstitutional. The motion was denied by the Court of Common Pleas of Hamilton County. Appellee then entered a plea of no contest to the charge of engaging in organized crime. She was found guilty. The Court of Appeals for Hamilton County held R. C. 2923.04(A)(1), (2), (3) and (5) to be unconstitutional and reversed the conviction and discharged appellee.

In the second cause (case No. 79-1124), defendant-appellees, George L. Forbes, Ceasar Moss, James H. Boyd, Carlton Rush, Curtis J. Watkins, Carl Bayer, David E. Cohen, Raymond Bona, Eugene L. Hazen, Thomas Layer, Ernie Mills, and Virgil Shively, were indicted for engaging in organized crime in violation of R. C. 2923.04(A)(1), (2), (3) and/or (5). Upon appellees' motion, and pursuant to a hearing, the Court of Common [***2] Pleas of Cuyahoga County declared the statute unconstitutional and dismissed the indictments against appellees. Upon appeal, this determination was affirmed by the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

The judgments of these two appellate courts were found to be in conflict with the unreported decisions of the Court of Appeals for Summit County in State v.. Byars (December 21, 1977, No. 8543) and the Court of Appeals for Fairfield County in State v.. Houlihan (November 1, 1978, No. 11 CA 78), and the records of these causes were certified to this court for review and final determination.

Subsequent to certification of both cases, the state of Ohio (hereinafter appellant) moved this court for an order consolidating the two cases, and, on September 12, 1979, the motion was allowed.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed in case No. 79-728.

Judgment affirmed in case No. 79-1124.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state of Ohio challenged the decisions of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton and Cuyahoga Counties (Ohio) which had determined that Ohio Rev. Code § 2923.04, an organized crime statute, was unconstitutionally vague pursuant to the Due Process Clause and dismissed indictments against several individuals. The court consolidated the actions for consideration upon appeal.


OVERVIEW: Several individuals were indicted pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code § 2923.04, an organized crime statute that made it illegal to facilitate any services to a crime syndicate, defined therein as five or more persons engaged in certain broadly described activities. The indictments in two separate actions were either dismissed at trial or upon appeal, when both courts found § 2923.04 unconstitutional for vagueness under the Due Process Clause of U.S. Const. amend. XIV because the statute lacked ascertainable standards of guilt. On further appeal, the court found that § 2923.04 did not expressly limit the scienter requirement to illegal activities and could be used to wrongfully punish lawful conduct. The court found that § 2923.04 did not specify with clarity the prohibited conduct so that a reasonable person would be given fair notice of its violation, and that the definitions of the statute's terms were imprecise. The court noted that the legislature's language gave much discretion to prosecutors who could use § 2923.04 to turn minor offenses into first degree felonies. The court held that the statute was unconstitutional for vagueness.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgments of the courts of appeals, which had found for the individuals indicted under the organized crime statute and held that the statute was unconstitutional for vagueness because it did not give adequate notice of the prohibited conduct to reasonable individuals. The court rejected appellant state's suggestion that the word "illegal" could be read into the statute's scienter requirement.

 

66 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Gerzeny v. Richfield Township


No. 79-1494


Supreme Court of Ohio


62 Ohio St. 2d 339; 405 N.E.2d 1034; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 755; 16 Ohio Op. 3d 396



June 18, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County.

Kalman Gerzeny, appellee herein, owns approximately 28 acres of land in Richfield Township which has at all relevant times been located in an "R-1, Rural Residential" zoning district.

It is undisputed that appellee has significantly improved the appearance of his property since first acquiring it in 1967. From a near swamp appellee has developed his property into a private park or playground, suitable for picnicking and other recreational activities. Appellee has constructed a manmade lake suitable for swimming and fishing, a shelter pavilion, and a large "barn." Appellee has used his property in the past for family reunions and other family activities. Since 1973, appellee has authorized several organizational groups to use his property for meetings or picnics on a cost-free basis. Appellee has at no time resided on the property.

In November 1977, appellee filed with the township zoning inspector an "Application for Zoning Certificate" to use his property as a "privately owned park with related facilities." Such a certificate has always been required by the zoning resolution in connection with use of R-1 property [***2] for a private park.
