The inspector refused to grant the certificate on the grounds that the proposed use required a conditional use permit which could only be issued by the Richfield Township Board of Zoning Appeals (hereinafter "board").

Appellee appealed to the board. Following a public hearing, the board refused appellee a conditional zoning certificate.

Thereafter Gerzeny appealed the board's denial to the Court of Common Pleas pursuant to R. C. Chapter 2506. The court affirmed the denial of the conditional use permit. The Court of Appeals reversed and remanded the cause for further proceedings.

The cause is before this court upon allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant property owner sought review of a decision from the Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio), which reversed the trial courts affirmance of a decision by appellee zoning board to deny the property owner's request for a conditional use permit to operate a recreational park.


OVERVIEW: The property owner had a 28-acre tract, which he had improved as a recreational park. It was located in a residentially zoned area. He sought a conditional use permit, but the zoning board denied his request because Richfield Township, Ohio, Zoning Resolution § 402-(2)(B) required a 100-acre minimum. The trial court affirmed that decision but the intermediate court reversed, on the ground that the inclusion of a minimum acreage requirement for the issuance of a conditional use permit for private parks deprived the property owner of equal protection because no minimum acreage was requisite to issuance of a permit for governmentally owned parks. On appeal, the court reversed because use of public parks or recreational grounds in a residential area for the common benefit of all the people of a zoning district was not commensurate with the use of lands by a private corporation for its exclusive profit in a manner forbidden by the zoning regulations. The court noted that if a zoning board was authorized to issue special permits for a named use it could not issue a permit if a specific requirement of the zoning ordinance would be violated thereby.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the intermediate court, which had reversed the decision of the trial court that had affirmed the decision of the zoning board to deny the property owner's request for a conditional use permit.

 

67 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Union Oil Co. v. Worthington


No. 79-868


Supreme Court of Ohio


62 Ohio St. 2d 263; 405 N.E.2d 277; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 734; 16 Ohio Op. 3d 315



June 4, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

The appellant herein, Union Oil Company of California, owns an approximate one acre parcel of real property situated in the city of Worthington. The Union Oil property is zoned to permit single-family residential use. In December 1976, Union Oil filed an action, pursuant to R. C. Chapter 2721, in which it sought a judgment declaring the existing zoning ordinance unconstitutional as applied to its property, declaring that Union Oil had a clear legal right to use its property for commercial purposes, enjoining the city of Worthington from interfering on the basis of zoning with the construction of a gasoline service station or car wash on the property, and ordering "such further relief as the court deems just and proper."

On August 28, 1978, following trial to the court without a jury, the court entered judgment finding the existing zoning of the Union Oil property to be unconstitutional, and ordering that the "property in question should be, and it hereby is, rezoned to C-3 * * *."

The Court of Appeals sustained the court's determination that the zoning ordinance was unconstitutional as applied to Union Oil's property,  [***2] neither party having assigned that finding as error. The court held that the trial court had erred, however, in ordering the property rezoned to a new and different use classification, reversed the decision in part, and remanded the cause to the trial court.

The cause is before this court upon allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant property owner sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which sustained the trial court's determination that the zoning ordinance covering the owner's property was unconstitutional but found that the trial court erred in ordering the property re-zoned to a new and different use classification.


OVERVIEW: The property was zoned residential. The owner wanted to build an gas station or car wash. The owner sought a judgment declaring the existing zoning ordinance unconstitutional as applied to its property, declaring that the owner had a clear legal right to use its property for commercial purposes, and enjoining appellee city from interfering on the basis of zoning with the construction of a gas station or car wash. The Court had to decide what nature of relief, a trial court could properly order in connection with a determination of unconstitutionality of a zoning ordinance in a declaratory judgment action. The trial court should have given notice to the zoning authority that, within a reasonable time, it could re-zone the property. Further notice should have been given that, if the property was not rezoned with in the time period, the trial court would authorize the property owner to proceed with the proposed use if, on the basis of the evidence before it, the trial court found the proposed use to be reasonable. Only if necessary was the court to conduct further proceedings to determine whether the new zoning restrictions could constitutionally proscribe the owner's proposed use.


OUTCOME: The Court affirmed the appellate court's judgment.

 

68 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Dorian v. Euclid Board of Education


No. 79-446


Supreme Court of Ohio


62 Ohio St. 2d 182; 404 N.E.2d 155; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 716; 16 Ohio Op. 3d 208



May 14, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

Nancy Dorian was employed as a school psychologist by the Euclid Board of Education on June 21, 1965. She continued to be employed in that capacity through the 1973-74 school year and she had received a continuing contract pursuant to R. C. 3319.11 on April 12, 1971.

Dorian was certified as both a high school French teacher and a school psychologist pursuant to R. C. 3319.22. Her certification as a French teacher expired in August 1968.

In March 1974, Dr. Spartoco DiBiasio, the Superintendent of the Euclid School District, recommended to the Euclid Board of Education that it reduce the number of school psychologists from three to two because of declining enrollment and a lack of funds. The lack of funds was due, at least in part, to the decline in enrollment, state funding being predicated on school population. DiBiasio further recommended the transfer of Dorian, the school psychologist with the least seniority, to the position of French teacher.

Pursuant to the superintendent's recommendation, the board reduced funding for school psychologist positions to account for two rather than three psychologists and reclassified [***2] Dorian as a French teacher. Dorian was informed of the change orally and in a written letter dated April 2, 1974, which was in response to a letter she had written asserting a grievance. The April 2nd letter, written by Robert Wightman, assistant superintendent of the district, notified Dorian that the board believed that she was able to teach French and that she should proceed to renew her certificate to teach that subject. The letter indicated that personnel adjustments had been made necessary by decreased enrollment and class size policy.

In response to Dorian's grievance, the board reaffirmed the reduction in school psychologists on July 15, 1974. By letter dated August 21, 1974, Dorian refused to accept the French teaching assignment and withdrew her grievance.

Dorian brought an action in the Court of Common Pleas of Cuyahoga County alleging a breach of contract and asking for reinstatement with full pay at the salary level of a school psychologist. The court concluded that because the board had not followed the procedures required under R. C. 3319.16, for terminating a teacher on a continuing contract, the board had breached its contract with Dorian. The court ordered [***3] that she be reinstated with full back pay.

The Court of Appeals affirmed, finding that the trial court could have reasonably concluded from the evidence that the act of not paying Dorian was a termination rather than a suspension. The court determined that failure to follow the procedure enumerated in R. C. 3319.16 constituted a breach of contract if the action of the board was a termination of a continuing contract.

The cause is now before this court upon the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant board of education sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed a ruling in favor of appellee teacher in her breach of contract claim.


OVERVIEW: Due to declining enrollment and lack of funds, the teacher was suspended as a school psychologist and reclassified as a French teacher. She refused to accept the assignment and filed a claim alleging a breach of contract. The lower appellate court affirmed a judgment in favor of the teacher. On further appeal, the court reversed. The court stated that the suspension was reasonable due to the decreased enrollment and was procedurally valid under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3319.17. The court stated that the suspension procedure under § 3319.17, which permitted the board to make reasonable reductions and provided for preference to teachers on continuing contract, was not unconstitutional. The court ruled that the procedure did not deprive the teachers of a protected property interest since no fundamental right was involved and no stigma was attached to the discharge.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the lower appellate court, which affirmed a judgment in favor of the teacher in her breach of contract claim against the board of education.

 

69 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Meeks v. Papadopulos


Nos. 79-1294, 79-1299, 79-1308


Supreme Court of Ohio


62 Ohio St. 2d 187; 404 N.E.2d 159; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 717; 16 Ohio Op. 3d 212; 92 Lab. Cas. (CCH) P55,308



May 14, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by and APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Stark County.

APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

Plaintiffs-appellants in case Nos. 79-1294 and 79-1308 are current or former full-time deputy sheriffs of Stark County who initiated actions in the Court of Common Pleas of Stark County to obtain overtime compensation under R. C. 4111.03 of the Ohio Minimum Fair Wage Standards Act. 1 Upon the filing of the complaints, defendants-appellees filed motions to dismiss on the grounds that they were exempt from the operation of R. C. 4111.03 by virtue of 4111.01(E)(7). The trial court in each case sustained appellees' motion. Appeals were instituted to the Court of Appeals for Stark County and, upon motion, the actions were consolidated. In affirming the trial court, the Court of Appeals found the payment of overtime to police and fire protection personnel inconsistent with "governmental and political facts of life" and with the "demands of the service of police protection and fire protection," concluding by virtue of R. C. 4111.01(E)(7) that police and fire protection personnel were exempt from the overtime compensation provisions of R. C. 4111.03.  [***2]


1 R. C. 4111.03(A), as pertinent here, stated:

"An employer shall pay an employee for overtime at a wage rate of one and one-half times the employee's wage rate for hours worked in excess of forty hours in one work week, in the manner and methods provided in and subject to the exemptions of section 7 and section 13 of the 'Federal Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938,' 52 Stat. 1060, 29 U.S.C. 207, 213, as amended except that employers not covered by said act on January 1, 1973, shall not be required to pay the rate required by this section until July 1, 1974.

"Any employee employed in agriculture shall not be covered by the overtime provisions of this section."

Plaintiffs-appellees in case No. 79-1299 filed a class action against defendants-appellants, the Hamilton County Sheriff et al., seeking compensatory damages for work performed in excess of 40 hours a week. Appellees' suit was premised upon the contention that they were entitled, under the provisions of R. C. 4111.03, to one and one-half times their wage rate for hours worked in excess of 40 in one work week. In response to appellants' motion to dismiss the complaint, the trial court ruled that it was the intent [***3] of the General Assembly under R. C. 4111.01(E)(7) to exempt members of police or fire protection agencies from the Ohio Minimum Fair Wage Standards Act and granted the motion to dismiss. The Court of Appeals for Hamilton County reversed, finding the language of R. C. 4111.01(E)(7) to be "plain and unambiguous," and excluding "only members of a police or fire protection agency employed on a part time or seasonal basis by a political subdivision of this state * * *."

The Court of Appeals for Stark County, finding its judgment in case No. 79-1294 to be in conflict with the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County in case No. 79-1299, certified the record of the cause to this court pursuant to Section 3(B)(4) of Article IV of the Constitution of Ohio. Case No. 79-1299 is before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record, as is case No. 79-1308.

These cases have been consolidated by this court for purposes of review and final determination.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed in case Nos. 79-1294 and 79-1308. Judgment reversed in case No. 79-1299.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff deputies brought actions in two different counties seeking overtime wages. The actions resulted in conflicting appellate decisions on the proper application of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4111.03 to law enforcement and fire personnel from the Court of Appeals for Stark County (Ohio) and the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio). The conflict was certified for review and the cases were consolidated.


OVERVIEW: The deputies contended that they were entitled to overtime wages pursuant to § 4111.03. One appellate court agreed, while the second determined that the deputies were not covered by the statute. The court found that the statute was ambiguous and applied principles of statutory construction. It ruled that members of police and fire agencies who worked for employers as defined in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4111.01(D) were not entitled to overtime compensation. Such a construction avoided any conflict with other existing laws on compensation and work hours. Also, nothing in the court's construction violated either the due process or the equal protection clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment. The deputies had not asserted any property interest protected by due process. Also, there was no violation of equal protection because there was a rational basis for treating police and fire protection personnel differently under the overtime statute.


OUTCOME: The judgment finding that the overtime statute did not apply to police and fire protection personnel was affirmed. The judgment finding that police and fire protection personnel were entitled to overtime payments was reversed.

 

70 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Moss v. Dep't of Natural Resources


No. 79-433


Supreme Court of Ohio


62 Ohio St. 2d 138; 404 N.E.2d 742; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 706; 16 Ohio Op. 3d 161



May 7, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

The two causes presented in this appeal were consolidated by the Court of Appeals to resolve identical issues of law. Each cause was initially brought in the Court of Claims.

In the Moss case, plaintiff-appellants, Lenore and Abraham Moss, allege that Mrs. Moss fractured her ankle stepping into a hole at West Branch State Park, Ravenna, Ohio. Plaintiffs further allege that the hole was caused by the combined negligence of the state and other private parties. Plaintiffs also assert that they made certain purchases at the park, i.e., gasoline (for plaintiffs' boat) and refreshments.

In the O'Neal case, plaintiff-appellant, Bobbie O'Neal, as administratrix of the estate of Diedre O'Neal, sues in wrongful death for the drowning of the decedent at Punderson State Park, Geauga County. Plaintiff alleges that the decedent's death was caused by the negligence of the defendants, various departments of the state and Edward Skipper, manager of the area. As in the Moss case, plaintiff O'Neal asserts an expenditure by the aggrieved party at the state facility, to wit, the rental of a canoe.

The Court of [***2] Claims dismissed the claims against the state for failure to state a claim for relief because the state was immune from liability pursuant to R. C. 1533.181. Since only non-state parties remained, the court reasoned that it lacked jurisdiction as to them, and accordingly dismissed both cases in their entirety. The Court of Appeals affirmed.

The cause is now before this court upon allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The two causes presented in the appeal were consolidated by the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio) to resolve identical issues of law. Appellants, an administratrix and a couple, sought review of two decisions that affirmed two decisions of the trial court that dismissed the a administratrix and couple's wrongful death and negligence claims, respectively, against appellee Ohio Department of Natural Resources.


OVERVIEW: In one case, the administratrix filed a wrongful death action for the drowning of the decedent at a state park. In the other case, the couple filed a negligence action when the wife broke her leg at another state park. Both parties indicated that they made purchases at the state park. The trial court dismissed the claims. The appellate court affirmed. The administratrix and the couple appealed. On appeal, the court affirmed. The court held that the state-owned lands were premises within Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 1533.18 and 1533.181, which granted the owner, the lessor, or the occupier of the premises immunity from suit by a recreational user. The court found that the parties who did not pay a fee, but made other purchases, such as the decedent and the wife, were recreational users. The court held that the decedent and the wife's purchases did not qualify as a fee. The court opined that the recreational immunity did not deny equal protection. The court noted that there was a reasonable relationship to a legitimate state interest in encouraging the owners of premises suitable for recreational pursuits to open their land to public use without worrying about liability.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision that the Department was not liable for the wrongful death of the decedent or for the injury to the wife.

 

71 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Cleveland v. Calandra


No. 79-1242


Supreme Court of Ohio


62 Ohio St. 2d 121; 403 N.E.2d 989; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 702; 16 Ohio Op. 3d 143



April 30, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

On September 23, 1978, Jacqueline Blevins was arrested and charged with soliciting in violation of city of Cleveland Ordinance No. 619.09. Section 619.09(b)(1) requires that, upon conviction of a first offense, "[a]t least 10 days' imprisonment and a fine of $ 200.00 are mandatory * * *."

Blevins' case was assigned to Judge Salvatore R. Calandra (hereinafter appellee) of the Cleveland Municipal Court.

Blevins entered a plea of not guilty and filed a motion to dismiss. The city of Cleveland (hereinafter appellant) filed a memorandum in opposition to Blevins' motion and demanded that the mandatory ten-days' imprisonment be imposed upon conviction. Thereafter, appellee held the mandatory sentence provision, subsection (b)(1), to be unconstitutional as constituting cruel and unusual punishment. Thereupon, Blevins withdrew her plea of not guilty and entered a plea of no contest.

On November 22, 1979, Blevins was found guilty of violating Section 619.09 as a first offender, and, upon consideration of the probation report, was sentenced to one-year's probation, 60 days and costs, the days and costs suspended. Appellee [***2] thereby failed to impose the mandatory ten-days' imprisonment.

Appellant then filed a complaint in mandamus in the Court of Appeals, seeking a writ ordering appellee to impose the mandatory ten-days' imprisonment.

On August 2, 1979, the Court of Appeals dismissed the complaint, declaring that appellant had an adequate remedy at law and that failure to sentence according to law that was declared unconstitutional was a discretionary matter and not a legal duty and, therefore, not within the scope of mandamus.

The cause is now before this court on appeal as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The City appealed an order of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which dismissed its complaint for a writ of mandamus ordering respondent trial judge to impose a mandatory 10-day sentence upon defendant after her conviction for solicitation in violation of Cleveland, Ohio, Ordinance § 619.09. The City argued that it did not have an adequate remedy at law.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with solicitation in violation of § 619.09. She pled not guilty and moved to dismiss; the City opposed the motion and demanded that the mandatory 10-day imprisonment be imposed upon conviction under § 619.09(b)(1). The trial court held that § 619.09(b)(1) was unconstitutional as cruel and unusual punishment. Defendant withdrew her plea of not guilty and pled no contest. She was convicted as a first offender and sentenced to probation. The City sought a writ of mandamus compelling the trial judge to impose sentence. The appellate court dismissed on the ground that the City had an adequate remedy at law. On appeal, the court looked to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.67(A), which provided that a prosecutor could appeal, with leave, any decision of a trial court in a criminal case except the final verdict. The court thus held that the City had an adequate remedy at law through discretionary appeal and failed to pursue it; until leave to appeal was sought and denied, mandamus was not an available remedy. Also, the trial judge's failure to impose sentence was not a breach of a legal duty because he did not ignore the mandatory provision but found it unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order denying the City's request for a writ of mandamus.

 

72 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Holloway v. Brown


No. 79-383


Supreme Court of Ohio


62 Ohio St. 2d 65; 403 N.E.2d 191; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 689; 16 Ohio Op. 3d 47; 15 A.L.R.4th 1153



April 9, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

The Greater Cincinnati Junior Chamber of Commerce (the "Jaycees") is an organization with the stated purpose of promoting civic welfare and of educating its members in civic duty and responsibility and in leadership. In order to finance these activities, the Jaycees solicit contributions.

Due to financial difficulties, the Jaycees entered into a contract with R. E. Holloway, who, as Holloway Productions (hereinafter "Holloway"), was to provide and promote a children's variety show to be held in the Cincinnati area on December 16, 1974, guaranteeing the Jaycees a minimum profit.

On October 24, 1974, the Cincinnati Charitable Solicitations Commission denied Holloway's application for licenses as a professional promoter and solicitor.

The denial was based on the failure of Holloway to be registered and bonded pursuant to R. C. Chapter 1716, and on the fact that the cost of solicitation in Holloway's contract with the Jaycees exceeded limits placed on such costs in the city's charitable solicitations ordinance, Chapter 821 of the Cincinnati Municipal Code (hereinafter "ordinance"). The commission also cited [***2] previous violations of the ordinance by Holloway. The commission further found that Holloway had failed to use the proper trustee bank account in handling the proceeds of a circus it had promoted earlier that year in Cincinnati.

Holloway did not pursue its right of appeal to the city manager provided for in the ordinance, but elected to join with the Jaycees and file an action in the Court of Common Pleas of Hamilton County against the Attorney General, the city of Cincinnati, and the members of the commission, seeking a declaratory judgment and an injunction declaring the ordinance unconstitutional and void.

The Attorney General filed a counterclaim, not relevant to the instant action, which has been separated from this case and is still pending in the Court of Common Pleas.

After hearing testimony and receiving briefs, the trial court, in a letter to counsel dated September 7, 1977, found the ordinance to be unconstitutional due to the vagueness of the definition of charitable organization, and the discriminatory effect of the ordinance against professional promoters. The court further declared that the ordinance set forth no guidelines for its administration. On October [***3] 4, 1977, the court journalized its entry and made permanent the injunction sought by the plaintiffs.

Upon appeal by defendants, the Court of Appeals reversed, finding that the ordinance, with the exception of its use of character and reputation as criteria for granting registration and licenses, is a constitutionally valid use of the city's police power.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, a production company and a civic organization, sought review of an order from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio) which reversed a lower court order and entered judgment in favor of appellee attorney general, holding that a city's charitable solicitation ordinance was a constitutionally valid use of the city's police power.


OVERVIEW: The civic organization hired the production company to provide and promote a children's variety show. The Cincinnati Charitable Solicitations Commission (commission) denied the production company's application for licensure as a professional promoter. The denial was based primarily on the fact that the cost of the solicitation in the production company's contract with the civic organization exceeded the city's charitable solicitations ordinance. Appellants brought a declaratory judgment action seeking a determination that the ordinance was unconstitutional. The trial court entered judgment in favor of appellants but the appellate court reversed the decision and held that the ordinance was a proper exercise of the city's police power. On further appeal, the court affirmed. The court held that the ordinance did not violate any provisions of the Unites States or Ohio Constitutions by legislatively distinguishing between charitable solicitations performed by a non-affiliated solicitor in the community or those performed by parties affiliated with the charity. The court further held that use of the word "charitable" in the ordinance was not unconstitutionally vague.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order determining that the city's charitable solicitations ordinance was a proper exercise of the city's police power.

 

73 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Swetland v. Kinney


No. 79-1402


Supreme Court of Ohio


62 Ohio St. 2d 23; 402 N.E.2d 542; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 682; 16 Ohio Op. 3d 14



April 2, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

In this original action, relator, David W. Swetland, d.b.a. Park Investment Co., seeks a writ of mandamus directing respondents, Commissioner of Tax Equalization and Auditor of Cuyahoga County, "to rescind and withdraw any and all guidelines, forms and applications prepared and circulated by them which in any way whatsoever give or tend to give legal effect to R. C. 323.152(B) and to instruct all of their subordinates responsible for real property tax assessment, levy and collection in the State of Ohio that R. C. 323.152(B) is constitutionally invalid."

 R. C. 323.152(B) was enacted by the 113th Ohio General Assembly as a part of Am. Sub. H. B. No. 204. It provides, in relevant part, that:

"Real property taxes on a homestead shall be reduced for each year for which the owner obtains a certificate of reduction from the county auditor under section 323.154 of the Revised Code. The amount of the reduction shall equal one-fourth of the amount by which the taxes charged and payable on the homestead are reduced for such year under division (B) of section 319.301 of the Revised Code."

Because R. C. 319.301(B) specifically speaks in terms of authorizing a [***2] ten-percent "reduction" in taxes on all real property in this state, the effect of R. C. 323.152(B) is to provide a further "reduction" in real estate taxes of two and one-half percent for "homesteads," as that term is defined in R. C. 323.151(A). 1 The provisions of R. C. 323.152(B) are effective for the 1979 tax year and thereafter. 2 


1 R. C. 323.151(A) provides that:

"(A) 'Homestead' means a dwelling or a unit in a multiple-unit dwelling or condominium owned and occupied as a home by an individual whose domicile is in this state and who has not acquired ownership from a person, other than his spouse, related by consanguinity or affinity for the purpose of qualifying for the real property tax reduction provided in section 323.152 of the Revised Code. The homestead shall include so much of the land surrounding it, not exceeding one acre, as is reasonably necessary for the use of the dwelling or unit as a home. An owner includes a vendee in possession under a purchase agreement or a land contract, a mortgagor, one or more joint tenants with right of survivorship, and tenants in common. The commissioner of tax equalization shall adopt rules for the uniform classification and valuation of real property or portions of real property as homesteads."


2 R. C. 323.152(B) was to have been effective for tax year 1980 and thereafter. However, S. B. No. 260, enacted July 30, 1979, made this section effective for the 1979 tax year. Subsequently, Sub. H. B. No. 830 was enacted. It eliminated the previous requirement that residential real property owners file an application in order to be eligible for the tax reduction in 1979.

 [***3] On October 23, 1979, this court sustained relator's motion for an alternative writ, and ordered respondents to show cause why the writ should not be allowed. By the same entry, the court ordered that arguments be expedited.

The cause is before the court on the pleadings and briefs of the parties, respondent commissioner's memorandum in response to the show cause order, respondents' motions to dismiss, and relator's motion for judgment on the pleadings.



DISPOSITION: Writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an original action, relator, an individual doing business as an investment corporation, sought a writ of mandamus directing respondents, a commissioner of tax equalization and a county auditor, to rescind and withdraw any guidelines prepared by them that gave legal effect to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 323.152(B) and to instruct all of their relevant subordinates that § 323.152(B) was constitutionally invalid.


OVERVIEW: The relator argued that Ohio Const. art. XII, § 2 required a tax rate that was uniform for all real property in the state of Ohio, other than specifically set forth in that section and Ohio Const. art. II, § 36. The relator argued that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 323.152(B), which provided for a real estate tax reduction of two and one-half percent for homesteads, was unconstitutional insofar as it violated this fundamental principle. The court held that § 323.152(B), which rolled back or partially exempted real property taxes on "homesteads" as defined within § 323.151(A), was not in violation of Ohio Const. art. XII, § 2. The court concluded that Ohio Rev. Code § 323.152(B) was a valid exercise of the General Assembly's taxing power, and contravened neither Ohio Const. art. XII, § 2 nor Ohio Const. art. I. Because the relator had not proved the existence of a clear legal duty on the part of the respondents, the relator's motion for judgment on the pleadings was overruled, and the writ of mandamus was denied.


OUTCOME: The court denied the writ of mandamus sought by the relator.

 

74 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Barker v. State


No. 79-436


Supreme Court of Ohio


62 Ohio St. 2d 35; 402 N.E.2d 550; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 683; 16 Ohio Op. 3d 22



April 2, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Portage County.

This cause arises from the dismissal of a complaint for expungement filed on June 19, 1978, by appellee, Albert Darrell Barker, in the Court of Common Pleas of Portage County.

In his complaint, appellee averred that he was convicted on January 20 and April 10, 1956, for armed robbery in two counties in West Virginia. The complaint indicated that the offenses for which he was convicted occurred at the same general location and time span. It stated further that on July 20, 1960, appellee was discharged from parole by the West Virginia authorities, whereafter he apparently began his residence in Ohio. 1 


1 The record, which is not fully developed because the action was dismissed in its preliminary stages, fails to establish either the date when appellee commenced his residence in this state, or the duration of that residency. Appellee has averred in his complaint for expungement that at the time this action was filed, he was a resident of Portage County, Ohio. We note further that appellee's assertion before this court that his residency commenced after he was discharged from parole in 1960, has not been challenged by appellants. Furthermore, appellants' motion to dismiss this cause in the trial court concedes that "[t]he only connections the plaintiff has to * * * Ohio, is his residence in Streetsboro, Ohio." Accordingly, we conclude for purposes of deciding the questions of law presented that appellee has established a bona fide residence in Ohio. The extent to which appellee would have to establish this fact and other matters concerning his entitlement to expungement, as a prerequisite to the exercise of the Court of Common Pleas' discretion under R. C. 2953.31 et seq., is not before us and is not affected by this appeal.

 [***2] Appellee's expungement complaint, filed under the provisions of R. C. 2953.31 et seq., requested "* * * all official records pertaining to * * * [his] conviction * * * [be] expunged and sealed and all index references thereto be deleted." On June 23, 1978, appellants herein, the state of Ohio and the Portage County prosecutor, filed a motion to dismiss appellee's complaint, arguing, inter alia, that the Courts of Common Pleas in Ohio were without jurisdiction over the subject matter of the cause, in that such courts do not have "the power to expunge convictions in West Virginia." At a hearing held on appellants' motion, appellee contended that the pertinent statutory provisions empowered the Court of Common Pleas of Portage County to assume jurisdiction, as appellee was a resident of that county. Appellee argued further that such court possessed a "greater interest" in this cause than in any other, and also had "the right to seal the records as they relate to Ohio." The trial court, upon determining that the statutory provisions of R. C. 2953.31 et seq. relating to convictions in another jurisdiction conferred no jurisdiction upon it to order officials in West Virginia [***3] to expunge appellee's record of conviction, sustained appellants' motion to dismiss.

Upon appeal, the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas was reversed. The majority in the Court of Appeals reasoned that the provisions of R. C. 2953.31 et seq. authorized the expungement of a record of conviction occurring in a jurisdiction other than in Ohio. Therefore, notwithstanding the inability of Ohio courts to order extraterritorial authorities to physically expunge such records of conviction located without this state, Ohio sentencing courts have jurisdiction to "expunge convictions from other states as they apply to their use in Ohio."

This cause is before the court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state challenged the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Portage County (Ohio), which reversed the trial court's dismissal of defendant's action to expunge all records pertaining to his West Virginia convictions.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of armed robbery in two counties in West Virginia. After he moved to Ohio, he filed an action under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2953.31 et seq. to have his conviction records expunged. The trial court dismissed the action, holding that it was without jurisdiction to expunge convictions in West Virginia. The appellate court reversed. On appeal, the court affirmed. The court held that because U.S. Const. art. IV, § 1 did not place an obligation upon state courts to accord full faith and credit to extra-territorial state criminal judgments, the trial court had jurisdiction to expunge records pertaining to defendant's West Virginia convictions. The court held that no evidence was presented showing the West Virginia's interests were paramount to Ohio's interests in providing remedial relief to qualified offenders in order to facilitate their prompt transition into meaningful and productive roles.


OUTCOME: The judgment was affirmed because the trial court had jurisdiction to expunge records pertaining to appellee's West Virginia convictions under Ohio statute because the United States constitution did not obligate Ohio to accord full faith and credit to West Virginia's criminal judgments.

 

75 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Northern Ohio Patrolmen's Benevolent Ass'n v. Parma


No. 79-369


Supreme Court of Ohio


61 Ohio St. 2d 375; 402 N.E.2d 519; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 676; 15 Ohio Op. 3d 450



March 26, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

On October 4, 1976, the city of Parma passed ordinance No. 83-73, which provides that all city employees who are members of reserve components of the armed forces are entitled to 31 days of leave of absence each calendar year for field training or active duty. Further, the ordinance provides that "[i]f a city employee's military pay or compensation during such period of leave of absence is less than his city pay would have been for such period, he shall be paid by the city the difference in money between the city pay and his military pay for such period."

On April 15, 1977, appellees, Northern Ohio Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and five members of the Parma Police Department, filed an action against the city, its mayor and its council president (appellants herein), and the state Attorney General, seeking declaratory relief and money damages.

This action challenged the validity of the Parma ordinance and the authority of the city, a non-chartered municipality, to adopt such an ordinance which is alleged to be at variance with R. C. 5923.05.

Appellees, under the purview of R. C. 5923.05, allege that they are [***2] entitled to a leave of absence from their respective duties without loss of pay for such time as they are in the military service on field training or active duty for periods not to exceed 31 days in any calendar year. In essence, appellees maintain that, by virtue of R. C. 5923.05, which permits municipal employees a military leave of absence without loss of pay, they are entitled to their full salaries during such leave, notwithstanding the ordinance, which provides that the city should pay only the difference between the city pay and the military pay for such periods.

On May 4, 1977, the city responded by filing a motion to dismiss appellees' complaint, alleging that the statute and ordinance are not in conflict and, alternatively, that the city has the authority to adopt conflicting legislation under its Home Rule power, Section 3 of Article XVIII of the Ohio Constitution. 

Appellees filed an answer brief in opposition to the motion to dismiss, and the city filed a reply brief. On August 1, 1977, the trial court held that the ordinance "is not unconstitutional, nor is it in conflict with Ohio Revised Code Section 5923.05."

On August 11, 1977, appellees timely filed [***3] a notice of appeal in the Court of Appeals. On February 8, 1979, the appellate court reversed the decision of the trial court and remanded this matter to that court for disposition of appellees' money damages claim, which was never ruled on by the trial court.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, a city, the city's mayor, and the city council president, sought certification of the record of a decision by the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which reversed a decision of the trial court and held that Parma, Ohio, Ordinance 83-73 (Oct. 4, 1976) was unconstitutional. At issue was the validity of the ordinance, which was alleged to be at variance with Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5923.05.


OVERVIEW: Appellees, a patrolmen's benevolent association and police officers, challenged the ordinance, which provided that city employees who were members of the armed forces reserves were entitled to 31 days of leave, but that an employee would only be paid its city salary to the extent that a shortfall existed between the employee's military and city pay. Section 5923.05 provided for the same amount of leave but without any loss of pay. The court held that the ordinance was constitutional. The statute and the ordinance were directly in conflict and not capable of a reasonable construction that would harmonize the two. Municipal power was derived from the Ohio Constitution and not from a charter. The city, a non-chartered municipality, had authority, pursuant to its Home Rule powers, to enact an ordinance that conflicted with the general laws of Ohio when the ordinance was limited to a matter of substantive local self-government. The ability to determine the salaries to be paid to city employees was a fundamental exercise of substantive local self-government power.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals and found that the ordinance was constitutional and valid.

 

76 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Wiss v. Cuyahoga County Bd. of Elections


No. 79-1476


Supreme Court of Ohio


61 Ohio St. 2d 298; 401 N.E.2d 445; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 657; 15 Ohio Op. 3d 357



March 12, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

On November 2, 1979, R. Garin Wiss, appellee herein, initiated an original action in mandamus in the Court of Appeals, seeking an order requiring the Cuyahoga County Board of Elections to restore his name to the ballot as a candidate for the Cuyahoga County Board of Education at the November 6, 1979, general election. The board had determined that the appellee's nominating petition was invalid and had removed his name from the ballot for the reason that, as a resident of the village of Bratenahl, appellee would be ineligible to serve as a member of the county board of education if elected.

On November 5, 1979, the Court of Appeals granted the writ of mandamus and ordered the board of elections to place appellee's name on the ballot as a candidate for the Cuyahoga County Board of Education at the November 6, 1979, election. The board of elections was further ordered to count the votes cast for such office, but to withhold certification of the results until the status of the Bratenahl Local School District had been adjudicated.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed [***2] .


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, a county board of elections, sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which granted a writ of mandamus to appellee candidate and ordered the board of elections to place his name on a ballot for the board of education.


OVERVIEW: The employee claimed that he was a qualified elector of the village. The board of elections, sua sponte, reviewed the petition papers and found them wanting due to his residence outside the territorial area of the office to which he sought election. In a prior case, the court had court concluded that the school district of the candidate's village was dissolved and merged with a city district. The employee argued that because the court's statement was not in a syllabus, the language was of no effect. He insisted that the controversy was alive because the constitutionality of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3311.29, the statute empowering the state board to dissolve the school district, was under attack in a pending case. The court reversed the grant of the writ. The determination that the school district was dissolved was a sine qua non underpinning to the court's syllabus in the prior case. An allegation of unconstitutionality of a statute in a case pending in a lower court was not justification for overturning a the court's prior determination. Because the village school district was dissolved and its territory merged, the employee was ineligible to serve on the board of education.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals and denied the writ of mandamus.

 

77 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Blue Cross of Northwest Ohio v. Jump


No. 79-440


Supreme Court of Ohio


61 Ohio St. 2d 246; 400 N.E.2d 892; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 646; 15 Ohio Op. 3d 257



February 20, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

On October 14, 1977, Blue Cross of Northwest Ohio (hereinafter "Blue Cross") 1 filed with the Department of Insurance a request for an average rate increase of 35.9 percent for its non-group subscribers, effective March 1, 1978. On November 29 and 30, and December 1 and 2, 1977, the department held public hearings on the merits of this request, as authorized by R. C. 1739.051(D). Similar hearings were held in February 1977, which resulted in a rate increase for Blue Cross, effective April 30, 1977. At the close of the November-December hearings, the hearing officer concluded that Blue Cross was not in complete compliance with R. C. 1739.01(M) and Department of Insurance Rule 3901-1-28 (Ohio Adm. Code 3901-1-28), and recommended that the average rate increase be limited to 25 percent. Pursuant to his authority under R. C. 1739.051(D) to disapprove Blue Cross' rate request if, inter alia, Blue Cross failed to "show by reliable, probative, and substantial evidence * * * [that it was] exerting a good faith effort to control costs," the Superintendent of Insurance, by final order dated January 6, 1978, rejected the [***2] hearing officer's recommendation and denied the entire proposed rate increase.


1 A Blue Cross plan is a hospital service association and thus regulated under R.C. Chapter 1739, and not under R.C. Title 39 as are commercial insurance companies.

As provided for in R. C. 1739.051(D), Blue Cross appealed this order to the Court of Common Pleas. The court found Blue Cross to be in substantial compliance with the relevant provisions of R. C. Chapter 1739 and Rule 3901-1-28 "since it * * * demonstrated by reliable, probative, and substantial evidence that it has made [inter alia] a good faith effort to control costs * * * charged to it by member health care facilities, including hospitals." Therefore, pursuant to R. C. 119.12, the Court of Common Pleas vacated the superintendent's order, and ordered an average 30 percent increase in Blue Cross' non-group rates.

On appeal, the Court of Appeals sustained the trial court's finding, but adjusted the approved rate increase upward to an average 35.9 percent (i.e., Blue Cross' entire request). Alternatively, the Court of Appeals ruled that the discretion given the superintendent by the statute and rule was unconstitutional. 

 [***3] This cause is now before the court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: On allowance of motion to certify the record, appellant, Ohio Superintendent of Insurance, sought review of the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio) that sustained the trial court's approval of appellee insurance company's rate increase but adjusted it upward to grant entire increase as originally requested by appellee.


OVERVIEW: Appellant, Ohio Superintendent of Insurance, maintained that appellee insurer's proposed rate increase should have been disapproved for failure to comply with requirements of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1739.01(M). Appellee used education and persuasion to control hospital costs. The court concluded that those efforts were not enough to satisfy statutory requirements. The statute also required use of financial incentives and disincentives. In fact, the court reasoned that appellee's compliance with § 1739.01(M) depended primarily on use of financial incentives and disincentives. Appellee argued that § 17393.01(M) was an unlawful delegation of legislative authority. The court disagreed because the legislature provided as much guidance as was practical.


OUTCOME: Judgment was reversed; appellee's rate was allowed based on an erroneous construction of state law. Appellee did not use financial incentives and disincentives to control costs. Consequently, appellee did not satisfy statutory requirements that required a combination of education, persuasion, and incentives.

 

78 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Lancaster Colony Corp. v. Lindley


No. 79-689


Supreme Court of Ohio


61 Ohio St. 2d 268; 400 N.E.2d 905; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 649; 15 Ohio Op. 3d 270



February 20, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

On January 31, 1972, the Lancaster Colony Corporation and its five subsidiaries, appellants herein, filed a declaration of estimated corporation franchise tax for the 1972 report year and remitted $ 66,368.22 to the Treasurer of State. On or about March 27, 1972, appellants filed requests for extension of time for filing their corporation franchise tax and, at the same time, remitted an additional $ 66,335.21 to the Treasurer.

On or about May 30, 1972, appellants filed a combined corporation franchise tax report for the 1972 report year and computed their franchise tax on the "net income" rather than the "net worth" method, since the net income method resulted in a greater tax liability, as required by the 1971 amendment to R.C. 5733.05.

Appellants applied for and received a refund of $ 4,116.47, plus interest, because their estimated payments were greater than their reported liability.

On April 30, 1975, the Tax Commissioner, appellee herein, assessed appellants an additional $ 9,349.57, including penalty and interest, for their franchise tax for the 1972 report year. On May 29, 1975, pursuant to R.C. 5733.11, appellants paid [***2] the assessment and contemporaneously filed an application for review and correction.

Before the Tax Commissioner issued a final determination on appellants' application, this court held, in Lakengren v.. Kosydar (1975), 44 Ohio St. 2d 199, that the 1971 amendment to R.C. 5733.05, which requires a corporation to calculate its franchise tax by the "net income" method rather than the "net worth" method if it results in a greater tax liability, is unconstitutional as applied to a corporation whose accounting year ended prior to the effective date of the statute. 

Based on the Lakengren decision, appellants, on February 6, 1976, filed an amended application for review and correction, requesting the commissioner to reduce their combined 1972 franchise tax liability by $ 104,201.73, the difference between the amount they had paid under the "net income" method, including the $ 9,349.57 assessment, and the amount they alleged they should have paid according to the "net worth" method, plus interest. On the same date, pursuant to R.C. 5733.12, they filed an application for a refund of $ 104,201.73.

On April 5, 1977, the commissioner issued a certificate of final determination [***3] regarding the application for review and correction. The commissioner, relying upon Lakengren, determined that appellants' franchise tax should have been calculated on the "net worth" basis. Accordingly, he allowed a refund of the $ 9,349.57 assessment of April 30, 1975, and promptly issued a certificate of final determination regarding the application for refund of $ 9,349.57. However, the commissioner also determined, on April 5, 1977, that he lacked jurisdiction to consider the application for refund for the remaining $ 94,852.16, remitted to the Treasurer in 1972, because it was not filed within three years of the payment.

Pursuant to R.C. 5717.02, appellants timely appealed both orders to the Board of Tax Appeals. The board determined that, when an application for review and correction is filed, pursuant to R.C. 5733.11, only the assessment itself may be challenged in that proceeding and, thus, that the commissioner properly determined that he lacked jurisdiction to consider a refund of the $ 94,852.16 since the application was not filed within three years of payment. The final orders of the commissioner were affirmed.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal [***4] as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellee tax commissioner assessed appellants, a corporation and its five subsidiaries (taxpayers), a penalty for their franchise tax. The taxpayers filed an application for review and correction. The tax commissioner held that he lacked jurisdiction to consider the application because it was not filed within three years of the payment. The Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio) confirmed that decision. The taxpayers appealed.


OVERVIEW: In challenging the tax commissioner's refusal to issue them a refund on the ground that the refund application was untimely, the taxpayers asserted that because the tax commissioner recognized an overpayment of the April 30, 1975, assessment for the 1972 report year, he had a mandatory duty to refund the entire overpayment of the franchise tax for the 1972 report year, pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5733.11, regardless of the date of payment. On appeal, the court affirmed. The court held that the tax commissioner did not have a mandatory duty to issue a refund of the entire overpayment, pursuant to § 5733.11. According to the court, the mandates as to the amount and procedure of a refund were determined pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5733.12. The court further held that the three year time period ran separately from each remittance, and thus, because the 1972 remittances were made more than three years prior to the application for a refund, the refund application was not timely. The court emphasized that the three-year limitation of § 5733.12 began to run anew against each illegal and erroneous payment.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision.

 

79 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Daniels


No. 79-299


Supreme Court of Ohio


61 Ohio St. 2d 220; 400 N.E.2d 399; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 641; 15 Ohio Op. 3d 232



February 13, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Summit County.

The appellant, Laura Daniels, was indicted on two counts of endangering children in violation of R. C. 2919.22(A) and one count of involuntary manslaughter in violation of R. C. 2903.04. These charges stemmed from appellant's alleged delinquent care of her twin sons. Evidence indicated that the two boys were malnourished from birth, causing the death of one of the twins. The other twin survived but was severely undernourished and suffered from multiple bodily lesions. Testimony also established that the appellant was a chronic alcoholic.

Prior to trial, appellant moved to dismiss the charges under R. C. 2919.22(A), contending that this statutory section was unconstitutional. The trial court overruled this motion, and the cause proceeded to trial, where a jury found the appellant guilty of all three counts charged in the indictment. Upon appeal, the Court of Appeals affirmed the appellant's convictions. Finding its judgment to be in conflict with the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Lake County in State v.. Bruno (No. 5-195, April 18, 1977), unreported, the court certified the record of the case to [***2] this court for review and final determination.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was convicted of endangering children, in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2919.22(A), and of involuntary manslaughter, in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2903.04. The Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio), affirmed the convictions. Finding its judgment to be in conflict with a judgment in a prior case, the intermediate appellate court certified the record of the case for further review and final determination.


OVERVIEW: Prior to trial, defendant filed a motion to dismiss the child endangerment charges filed against her under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2919.22(A), claiming that § 2919.22(A) was unconstitutional. The trial court overruled the motion. Defendant was convicted of endangering children and of involuntary manslaughter. On appeal, the intermediate appellate court affirmed the judgment, but because its decision conflicted with its judgment in a prior case, the intermediate appellate court certified the record of the case for further review and final determination. On review, the court affirmed, finding that defendant made no claim that her actual conduct toward her children could not be regulated under § 2919.22(A), and that her overbreadth challenge was invalid. According to the court, defendant did not fall within the overbreadth exception to the standing requirements because the freedom of personal choice in matters of marriage and family life was not protected by the First Amendment's rights of association. In addition, the court noted that § 2919.22(A) did not regulate expression or the right of assembly in any respect, but governed conduct that endangered children.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

80 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Lenart v. Lindley


Nos. 79-291, 79-292, 79-295


Supreme Court of Ohio


61 Ohio St. 2d 110; 399 N.E.2d 1222; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 622; 15 Ohio Op. 3d 152



January 30, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Board of Tax Appeals.

These appeals arise from a consolidated decision of the Board of Tax Appeals (BTA) wherein the board reversed sales tax assessments levied by appellant herein, the Tax Commissioner, against appellees, Kay Lenart, William M. Caserta, and Glenn R. Tidrick. The appeals were heard before this court on the same day and, because they involve common issues of fact and law, are consolidated for disposition.

In cases Nos. 79-291 and 79-292, Lenart and Caserta were informed by notice of tax assessment that they were personally liable, under the authority R. C. 5739.33, for unpaid sales taxes, penalties, and delinquency charges. This liability allegedly resulted from the failure of American Airmotive, Inc. (Airmotive), the corporation with which appellees were associated, to remit sales taxes to the state of Ohio. Subsequent to a hearing on these assessments, appellant concluded that Caserta was subject to liability for unpaid sales taxes during the period from March 12, 1970 6, July 6, 1973. CAserta had held the position of Vice-President for Airmotive from March of 1970 until his resignation from that office in July or August of 1973. Appellant's [***2] entry noted further that Lenart's liability also arose under the provisions of R. C. 5739.33, and involved unpaid sales taxes occurring from March 12, 1970, to October 26, 1972, and from May 20, 1973, to July 15, 1973. The record demonstrates that Lenart served as the Secretary-Treasurer of Airmotive in 1970 and 1971, and then as Secretary of the corporation from 1971 until July of 1973.

Appellees filed substantially identical notices of appeal with the BTA, challenging the determination of appellant and specifying, inter alia, that they were not personally liable for the sales tax assessments because all corporate "sales tax return filings and payments were current" prior to their resignations as corporate officers. When appellees' causes came before the BTA for disposition, appellant objected to the admission of evidence relative to whether appellees' responsibilities as corporate officers placed them within the purview of R. C. 5739.33, contending that appellees' failure to raise that issue in their notices of appeal, as required by R. C. 5717.02, rendered the BTA without jurisdiction to consider it. Citing Abex v.. Kosydar (1973), 35 Ohio St. 2d 13, 298 N.E. 2d [***3] 584, the BTA overruled appellant's objection. The BTA reversed appellant's orders, finding that appellees' corporate responsibilities were insufficient to render them personally liable for the assessments in question.

In case No. 79-295, appellant issued three sales tax assessments against appellee, Glenn Tidrick, wherein Tidrick was held personally liable, pursuant to R. C. 5739.33, for unremitted sales taxes, penalties, and delinquencies owed by Airmotive and occurring between October 26, 1972, and December 5, 1974. Subsequent to a hearing held before appellant, Tidrick's liability was upheld on the basis of his involvement as a corporate employee and officer.

The record demonstrates that Tidrick was initially employed by Airmotive in May of 1972 as an accountant. In November he was appointed Treasurer of the corporation, an office which he held until April of 1973. On July 19, 1974, he was appointed Vice-President and Treasurer of Airmotive and was elected to the corporation's Board of Directors. On December 5, 1974, Tidrick resigned his offices with the corporation, but remained as an employee. In March of 1975, the corporation went into receivership.

Tidrick appealed [***4] to the BTA from appellant's orders, alleging that appellant erred in finding him liable for the corporation's unpaid sales taxes because he at no time had the control of, supervision over, or responsibility for, filing sales tax returns or making the payments, within the meaning of R. C. 5739.33 or Weiss v.. Porterfield (1971), 27 Ohio St. 2d 117, 271 N.E. 2d 792. The BTA found that Tidrick did not come within R. C. 5739.33 and reversed the assessments levied by appellant.

These causes are now before this court upon appeals as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Decision reversed and causes remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant Ohio Tax Commissioner appealed a consolidated decision of the Board of Tax Appeals (BTA) (Ohio), which reversed sales tax assessments levied by the Commissioner, against appellees, three officers of a corporation, as responsible parties for the payment of corporate sales taxes under Ohio Rev. Code § 5739.33. The Commissioner challenged the jurisdiction of the BTA to absolve the officers from tax liability.


OVERVIEW: Three officers were informed by two separate tax assessments notices that they were personally liable for unpaid corporate sales taxes, penalties, and delinquency charges. When the first cause came before the BTA for disposition, the Commissioner objected to the admission of evidence relative to whether the officers' responsibilities placed them within the purview of § 5739.33, contending that their failure to raise that issue in their notice of appeal, as required by Ohio Rev. Code § 5717.02, rendered the BTA without jurisdiction to consider it. In the second action, the Commission contended that one of the officers, the corporate treasurer, had direct responsibility for filing the taxes. The BTA overruled the Commissioner's objections and assessments, finding that each of the officers' responsibilities were insufficient to render them personally liable. On appeal, the court reversed both rulings because the BTA's decision was predicated upon a finding that was not presented in the notice of appeal, the treasurer admitted that he was aware of the corporation's statutory duty to remit all sales tax proceeds, and that he signed the checks when payments was remitted to the state.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the BTA's decision and remanded the cause for further proceedings relative to the unaddressed propositions of error specifically set forth in the notices of appeal to the BTA.

 

81 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Salzl v. Gibson Greeting Cards, Inc.


No. 79-516


Supreme Court of Ohio


61 Ohio St. 2d 35; 399 N.E.2d 76; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 605; 15 Ohio Op. 3d 49



January 9, 1980, decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

Claimant-appellee, Henry Salzl (hereinafter claimant), began working as a paper cutter for Gibson Greeting Cards, Inc. (hereinafter Gibson), in October 1958. He worked for Gibson for a period of nearly 18 years until he was forced to retire at the age of 65 because of the company's mandatory retirement policy.

Prior to 1970, Gibson offered its employees a profit sharing plan which was financed through company contributions, although the employee was permitted to augment the plan with his or her voluntary contributions. The claimant never made any voluntary contributions. In 1970, Gibson adopted a pension plan which was also funded by the employer. The terms of the pension plan called for mandatory retirement at age 65, and the plan took effect January 1, 1970. The employees of Gibson were given notice of the contents of the plan through publication and distribution of a pension plan handbook. This was the only notice they had since the company unilaterally adopted the plan, and the employees had no voice in the decision. The funds in the profit sharing plan were used to finance a portion of the pension plan when [***2] the latter became effective.

After the pension plan became effective, the employees had the option of resigning their position and withdrawing their profit sharing funds, or allowing the funds that were in the profit sharing plan to be transferred to the pension fund. The claimant chose to allow his profit sharing funds to become incorporated into the pension plan. In 1970, claimant's balance of funds in the profit sharing plan was $ 5,731.07. When he terminated his employment with Gibson, the fund had appreciated to $ 7,600. Instead of receiving a lump sum payment, claimant chose to receive a monthly pension of $ 187.95.

If it had not been for Gibson's mandatory retirement policy, claimant would have continued his employment. His request to continue working was denied. After leaving Gibson, claimant actively sought employment elsewhere. He was unsuccessful. He then applied for unemployment compensation benefits. Such benefits were initially denied by the administrator and were again denied on reconsideration. On July 15, 1976, a hearing was held before a referee, and he ruled that claimant had not quit his job without just cause in connection with his work, under R.  [***3] C. 4141.29(D)(a), and therefore was entitled to benefits. Upon further appeal, the Board of Review (appellant herein), following a hearing, determined that claimant was discharged for just cause in connection with his work and suspended his benefit rights. This decision was summarily affirmed by the Court of Common Pleas of Hamilton County. The Court of Appeals reversed and held that the claimant was entitled to unemployment benefits.

The Court of Appeals, finding its judgment to be in conflict with the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Summit County in May Co. v.. Bd. of Review (1975), 49 Ohio App. 2d 21, certified the record of the case to this court for review and final determination.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), construing Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4141.29(D)(2)(a), reversed decisions of appellant Bureau of Employment Services and the common pleas court finding appellee claimant, whose employer forced him to retire at age 65, ineligible for unemployment benefits. The court of appeals certified the record for review and final determination because its judgment conflicted with that of another court of appeals.


OVERVIEW: The court of appeals held, contrary to the Bureau and the common pleas court, that the claimant was entitled to unemployment benefits after being forced to leave his employment because of his employer's mandatory retirement policy. Upon certification for review and final determination, the court upheld the court of appeals' decision, finding it consistent with the Unemployment Compensation Act's intent. The court found a rational basis for distinguishing between an employee who leaves work pursuant to a pension and retirement plan that was negotiated by his union and accepted as part of his contract and an employee, such as the claimant, who is forced to leave his employment because of a unilaterally enacted pension program calling for mandatory retirement at age 65. The distinction provided the basis for the court's holding that the claimant was entitled to employment benefits, pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code § 4141.29(D)(2)(a), because he was discharged without cause.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the court of appeals' judgment reversing the Board of Review's and the common pleas court's decisions finding the claimant ineligible for unemployment benefits.

 

82 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Smith v. Haney


No. 78-1551


Supreme Court of Ohio


61 Ohio St. 2d 46; 398 N.E.2d 797; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 607; 15 Ohio Op. 3d 56



January 9, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lucas County.

This cause originated as an administrative licensing proceeding before the Division of Wildlife, Ohio Department of Natural Resources. That division, in accordance with R. C. 1533.342 established a "limited entry" program for regulating the issuance of commercial fishing licenses on Lake Erie and elsewhere within Ohio. Under this program the number of commercial fishermen was limited to control the size of the annual fish harvest.

This licensing system was instituted by the promulgation of Section 1501:31-3-03 of the Ohio Administrative Code, which, as it stood in 1977, governed the proceedings in this cause. Subsection (A) of Ohio Adm. Code 1501:31-3-03, as a grandfather provision for this program, provided that those entities possessing a commercial fishing license in 1975 would be issued licenses in 1976 and thereafter if certain requirements were followed. 1 The issuance of new licenses was governed by subsection (B) of that regulation, which is the center of controversy in this cause.


1 Ohio Adm. Code 1501:31-3-03(A) at the time this cause arose in 1977 provided, in its pertinent part, as follows:

"Except as provided in Division (B) of this rule, only those persons holding commercial fishing licenses in 1975, except trotline licenses, will be licensed to fish in 1976 and thereafter, provided they have made proper application and paid the required fees by March first of each year, and have complied with the necessary provisions in Chapters 1531 and 1533 of the Revised Code and division of wildlife orders in previous fishing seasons."

 [***2] Appellees, Gerald Smith and Carl H. Smith, Jr., the applicants herein, fell within the grandfather provisions of this program and submitted a renewal application to the Division of Wildlife for a commercial fishing license for the year 1977. The applicants, however, failed to comply with Ohio Adm. Code 1501:31-3-03 (A) and thus lost their continued licensing status under the grandfather clause. The applicants were thereafter treated as new license seekers and were placed at the top of a waiting list for such licenses. No new licenses were granted in 1977.

The applicants challenged the adjudicative hearing that resulted in the denial of their application in the Court of Common Pleas of Lucas County, pursuant to R. C. 119.12. That court affirmed the adjudicative order of the Division of Wildlife in all respects. Upon appeal, the Court of Appeals upheld that portion of the administrative decision which denied the applicants their preferential licensing status under Ohio Adm. Code 1501:31-3-03 (A). This determination is not now before this court. However, the Court of Appeals also held that Ohio Adm. Code 1501:31-3-03 (B) was impermissibly vague because it failed to establish [***3] specific procedures for granting or denying licenses to new commercial fishing applicants. Based upon this conclusion, the court further determined that the decision to deny the application in this cause was arbitrary and capricious. The court went on to order the issuance of a new 1977 license to the applicants.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant Ohio Department of Natural Resources Division of Wildlife challenged the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Lucas County (Ohio), which held that Ohio Admin. Code § 1501:31-3-03(B) was impermissibly vague. The appellate court reversed the trial court's finding that an application filed by appellee commercial fishing license applicants was properly denied. The appellate court ordered the issuance of the license to the applicants.


OVERVIEW: The appellate court ruled that Ohio Adm. Code § 1501:31-3-03(B) failed to establish specific procedures for granting or denying licenses. The applicants alleged that the regulation gave unfettered discretion to the chief of the wildlife division in granting the licenses. On appeal, the court held that § 1501:31-3-03(B) was valid because of extensive guidelines set forth in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1533.342. The court found that the regulation when read in conjunction with § 1533.342 revealed a legislative scheme adequate to safeguard against administrative capriciousness. Further, the court indicated that the applicants did not raise the issue regarding the limit on the number of new licenses issued, and therefore the Division of Wildlife was not required to demonstrate its compliance with the factors contained in § 1533.342. The court concluded that Ohio Adm. Code § 1501:31-3-03(B) was not impermissibly vague. The court determined that the Division of Wildlife's denial of a new license was not arbitrary under § 1533.342.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's order that a commercial fishing license be issued to the applicants.

 

83 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Heller v. Miller


No. 79-161


Supreme Court of Ohio


61 Ohio St. 2d 6; 399 N.E.2d 66; 1980 Ohio LEXIS 601; 15 Ohio Op. 3d 3



January 2, 1980, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

Earl and Karen Heller, relators herein, are the natural parents of Johnny Steven Heller, born January 15, 1976. Shortly after Johnny's birth, the Hancock County Children's Services Board filed a complaint in the Court of Common Pleas of Hancock County, Juvenile Division, seeking permanent custody of the child because he allegedly lacked proper care and support due to the physical condition of both the mother and father. Pursuant to R. C. 215.352 and 120.33, the court determined that the Hellers were indigent and appointed counsel to represent them. On October 23, 1978, the court issued an order which permanently terminated Earl and Karen Heller's parental rights to Johnny.

On November 16, 1978, relators filed a notice of appeal in the trial court. This appeal is still pending before the Court of Appeals. On December 24, 1978, relators filed a motion seeking appointment of counsel and a transcript of the proceedings at public expense in the trial court and, on December 26, 1978, they filed a similar motion in the Court of Appeals.

Respondent Judge Allan H. Davis of the trial court overruled the motion on December 26, 1978, finding that the court lacked [***2] jurisdiction over the proceedings because the case was before the Court of Appeals. Respondents Judges Edgar J. Miller and J. Thomas Guernsey of the Court of Appeals overruled the motion for want of authority.

On April 5, 1979, relators filed an amended complaint in mandamus asking this court to issue a writ compelling respondent judges to appoint counsel and cause a transcript of the proceedings in the trial court to issue at public expense.



DISPOSITION: Writ allowed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner parents sought a writ of mandamus to compel respondent judges to appoint counsel and cause a transcript of the proceedings in the trial court to issue at public expense.


OVERVIEW: Parents sought a writ of mandamus to compel appointment of counsel and a transcript at public expense of their parental termination proceedings. The writ of mandamus issued. The court held that the refusal to supply a transcript and to provide counsel constituted a trespass on the rights of similarly situated citizens in violation of the due process and equal protection clauses of the United States and Ohio Constitutions. The court found that there was no plain and adequate remedy at law available to parents in the case at bar. The court also found that the parents could not effectively appeal without a transcript and counsel. The court further found that if the parents continued pro se without benefit of a transcript, any appeal wold have been ineffectively presented. The court determined that the stipulated facts showed that the parents were indigent. The court ruled that neither the exclusion of frivolous appeals nor the desire to settle the child's fate quickly could justify depriving the indigent parents of the right to appeal when appellate review, as of right, was available to other parents in cases involving the involuntary, permanent termination of parental rights.


OUTCOME: The court issued the writ of mandamus.

 

84 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Price


No. 79-338


Supreme Court of Ohio


60 Ohio St. 2d 136; 398 N.E.2d 772; 1979 Ohio LEXIS 514; 14 Ohio Op. 3d 379



December 19, 1979, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Muskingum County.

After meeting at a laundromat in Zanesville on the evening of July 18, 1977, complainant, Christa G., age 13, and two female friends, both age 14, appellant, Gary D. Price, age 23, and a male friend of his decided to go for a ride. The group purchased a six-pack of beer, traveled to a trailer where each consumed certain amounts of beer, and then left to purchase additional quantities of beer. Next, the group picked up a second male friend of appellant and proceeded to Mount Sterling, where all went for a swim in a pond.
