While in the pond, appellant asked Christa if she wanted to engage in sexual intercourse. Upon her refusal, appellant threatened to drown her if she did not take a walk with him. Christa then returned to the car with one of her female friends. Shortly thereafter, appellant returned to the car, pulled Christa from the back seat to an area nearby behind some bushes, forced her to the ground, removed her pants, and raped her. At this point, both Christa's female friends ran to assist her. The group then returned to Zanesville where the three females were released. Christa went home and told her family [***2] of the incident. The family went immediately to the sheriff's office.

Appellant was indicted for the offenses of rape, pursuant to R. C. 2907.02, and kidnapping, pursuant to R. C. 2905.01; and was separately indicted for the offense of corruption of a minor, pursuant to R. C. 2907.04. 1 Upon trial to a jury, appellant was convicted of both rape and kidnapping, with the jury finding further that the complainant was not released unharmed in a safe place. The remaining charge was dismissed. Thereupon, the trial court imposed identical concurrent sentences of from six to twenty-five years. On appeal, the Court of Appeals affirmed both the rape and kidnapping convictions.


1 These cases were consolidated pursuant to a motion of the prosecutor, and tried to a jury beginning February 28, 1978.

This cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals (Ohio), which affirmed his rape and kidnapping convictions.


OVERVIEW: Defendant challenged the intermediate appellate court judgment that affirmed his rape and kidnapping convictions. Defendant argued that the trial court erred in admitting the hearsay testimony of the victim's friend as a spontaneous exclamation. On appeal, the court determined that the testimony was properly admitted because it concerned events immediately following the alleged rape and consisted of the victim's statement to her friend that defendant had just raped her. Defendant also contended that he could not be convicted of both rape and kidnapping on the basis of identical evidence because the crimes were not committed separately. The court determined that the rape and kidnapping were neither committed separately nor with separate animus. The force by which defendant removed the victim from the car to engage in sexual conduct was indistinguishable from the force by which he used to restrain the victim of her liberty as required under the kidnapping statute. The court concluded that since the restraint of movement of the victim was merely incidental to the separate underlying crime of rape, there was no separate animus sufficient to sustain the kidnapping conviction.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's rape conviction, but it reversed his conviction for kidnapping.

 

85 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


General Electric Co. v. De Courcy


No. 79-21


Supreme Court of Ohio


60 Ohio St. 2d 68; 397 N.E.2d 397; 1979 Ohio LEXIS 500; 14 Ohio Op. 3d 270



November 28, 1979, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

The instant cause arises from a judgment of the Court of Appeals affirming a trial court determination that appellant, General Electric Company, is not entitled to recover interest on real estate taxes illegally or erroneously collected from it, and invested for a period of time by appellees, the Hamilton County auditor and treasurer.

The facts are undisputed. For calendar years 1969, and 1971 through 1973, appellant was assessed and paid taxes on its real property located in Hamilton County on the erroneous basis of 1969 instead of 1962 year reproduction costs. During the tax years involved herein, the tax valuation of most other real estate in Hamilton County was based on 1962 reproduction costs. This distinction resulted in substantially and disproportionately higher real estate taxes to appellant than to other taxpayers.

After receiving adverse rulings on its administrative complaints, General Electric appealed to the Court of Appeals, alleging the discriminatory effect of appellees' method of valuation of General Electric's real property. That court found violations of both the Equal Protection Clause and Section [***2] 2, Article XII, of the Ohio Constitution, requiring taxation to be uniform. On remand, the board of revision recomputed the tax years involved and ordered a refund to appellant of $ 648,876.80, which amount represented those taxes illegally or erroneously collected. Appellant demanded interest which the county had collected from investment of the erroneously collected taxes, or interest at the prevailing legal rate, but the county refused to pay. Appellant then instituted this action in the Court of Common Pleas for recovery of the demanded interest. It is noted that all parties agreed by stipulation to the amounts of assessments, investments and the interest involved.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayer sought review of a judgment entered in the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio) affirming a trial court determination that the taxpayer was not entitled to recover interest on real estate taxes illegally or erroneously collected from it, and invested for a period of time by appellees, the county auditor and treasurer.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer was assessed taxes on an erroneous basis. The error resulted in higher real estate taxes to the taxpayer than to other taxpayers. The board of revision recomputed the tax years involved and ordered a refund to the taxpayer. The taxpayer demanded interest, which the county had collected from investment of the erroneously collected taxes, or interest at the prevailing legal rate, but the county refused to pay. The taxpayer instituted an action for recover of the demanded interest. The trial and appellate courts determined that the taxpayer was not entitled to recover interest. The court stated that the refund of taxes was in accordance with Ohio Rev. Code § 5715.22, which made no provision for the payment of interest, but merely for the remittance of those real property taxes paid by the taxpayer in excess of the amount due. In the absence of statutory authority, the tax collector, in his role as trustee of public funds, could not disburse any such funds beyond the bounds of his statutorily created trust. The taxpayer was not entitled to interest because the recovery of interest was not allowed by statute and there were no constitutional violations.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment denying the taxpayer's right to interest.

 

86 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Lorain v. Tomasic


No. 78-1216


Supreme Court of Ohio


59 Ohio St. 2d 1; 391 N.E.2d 726; 1979 Ohio LEXIS 466; 13 Ohio Op. 3d 1



July 3, 1979, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lorain County.

Appellant, Paul Tomasic, is a bingo operator for a bingo game conducted at the Lorain Catholic High School in Lorain, Ohio, on behalf of the Lorain Catholic High School Booster Club. The game is fully licensed by the state of Ohio, pursuant to R. C. 2915.08, and is operated for a charitable organization as defined in R. C. 2915.01(H).

On January 30, 1978, appellant was arrested for paying out approximately $1,700 in prize money in violation of Ordinance 719.03(a) of the Lorain Codified Ordinances which prohibits the paying out of more than $1,200 in prizes during any single bingo session. He plead "not guilty" and, on February 10, 1978, filed a motion to dismiss the complaint on the ground that the ordinance unconstitutionally conflicted with R. C. 2915.09(B)(5). The statute prohibits a payout of more than $3,500 during any bingo session conducted by a charitable organization.

On March 23, 1978, the trial court found the ordinance to be unconstitutional and granted the appellant's motion to dismiss.

On August 2, 1978, in a split decision, the Court of Appeals reversed, holding there was no restriction upon a charitable [***2] organization in R. C. 2915.09(B)(5) to "pay out less than $3,500 during a bingo session."

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant bingo operator was convicted of paying out $ 1,700 in prize money in violation of Lorain, OH, Ordinances, § 719.03(a) that prohibited the paying out of more than $ 1,200 in prizes during a bingo session. Defendant sought review of the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Lorain County (Ohio) reversing a trial court's decision to grant defendant's motion to dismiss based on its finding that the ordinance was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Lorain, OH, Ordinances, § 719.03(a), which prohibited the paying out of more than $ 1,200 in prizes during a bingo session, was in conflict with Ohio Rev. Code § 2915.09(B)(5), which provided that a charitable organization could not pay out more than $ 3,500 during any bingo session. Defendant paid out $ 1,700 in a single bingo session. The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals, holding that there was no restriction under Ohio Rev. Code § 2915.09(B)(5) on a charitable organization to pay out less than $ 3,500 during a single session. The court noted that in determining whether an ordinance was in conflict, the test was whether the ordinance permitted that which the statute forbade and prohibited and vice versa. The court reasoned that allowing ordinances to be enacted throughout the state reducing maximum pay outs would destroy a uniform application of the state statutory scheme and create a potential for emasculating a charitable organization's ability to conduct a lawful bingo operation. Such a construction of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2915.09(B)(5) would have rendered its language meaningless. Thus, the ordinance was unconstitutionally in conflict with state law.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the court of appeals' judgment, which had found no constitutional conflict between an ordinance and state law and which had reversed the trial court's grant of defendant's motion to dismiss.

 

87 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Gardner


No. 78-919


Supreme Court of Ohio


59 Ohio St. 2d 14; 391 N.E.2d 337; 1979 Ohio LEXIS 468; 13 Ohio Op. 3d 8



July 3, 1979, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

As a result of events occurring on July 8, 1976, appellants, Ralph Gardner and Angel Ogletree, were each indicted on two counts of kidnapping (a violation of R. C. 2905.01), the victims being Donna Fenrick and William Coar, and one count of felonious assault (a violation of R. C. 2903.11), the victim being William Coar. Additionally, appellant Ogletree was indicted for the rape of Donna L. Fenrick (a violation of R. C. 2907.02). 1 


1 An indictment against a co-defendant, Sara McGowan, was severed prior to trial, and a juvenile participant was charged with deliquency.

A jury trial commenced in the Court of Common Pleas of Cuyahoga County on October 5, 1976. The testimony presented therein tended to show that on July 8, 1976, the appellants, Sara McGowan, and a juvenile were driving around Cleveland in McGowan's car, looking for Ogletree's girlfriend They picked up Coar at his residence and then went to the apartment of a Carroll Dicks, where they found Ms. Fenrick. According to Coar and Fenrick, they were forced, at gunpoint, to leave Ms. Dicks' apartment with appellants and the others. Coar testified that Gardner [***2] struck him with his gun as they were leaving. After riding around in two groups using both McGowan's and Fenrick's cars, they all resumed their excursion in McGowan's car, during which time Ogletree allegedly forced Fenrick to submit to oral sex in the back seat of the moving auto. Fenrick testified that she committed the act only because Gardner and the juvenile were pointing guns at her. Soon thereafter police apprehended and arrested the occupants of the car on suspicion that gunshots had been fired therefrom. A .38 caliber revolver was found in Gardner's pants pocket, and a .32 caliber gun was found under a blanket on the rear floor of the auto. At the scene of the arrest, Fenrick told the police that she and Coar had been kidnapped.

The jury found Gardner guilty on all counts charged and found Ogletree guilty on both counts of kidnapping, the lesser included offense of aggravated assault, and rape. Both appellants were thereafter sentenced according to law. The Court of Appeals subsequently affirmed the convictions.

This cause is now before this court pursuant to allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants challenged the decision of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which convicted one defendant of kidnapping in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2905.01 and felonious assault in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2903.11 and convicted the other defendant of kidnapping, the lesser-included offense of aggravated assault, and rape in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2907.02.


OVERVIEW: Defendants asserted that the operation of Ohio's rape shield law under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2907.02(D) unconstitutionally infringed upon their Sixth Amendment right to confrontation of witnesses and their right to a fair trial under the Due Process Clause. On appeal, the court affirmed their convictions. The court determined that the evidence that the complainant had a reputation as a prostitute was not sufficiently probative of consent to outweigh the State's legitimate interests in excluding the testimony. Likewise, the defense attempts to impeach the credibility of the complainant by the reputation evidence and evidence of a specific solicitation were correctly prohibited by the trial court. Also, the admission of collateral evidence was correctly admitted under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.59. The evidence showed that handguns were used, that the victims were required to commit the same act, and that this occurred in the same residence from which the complainant was allegedly abducted the next day. Being so closely related in nature, time, and place to the offense charged, the evidence was relevant as tending to prove an intent to commit forcible rape.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendants' convictions for kidnapping, assault, and rape.

 

88 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Herrick v. Lindley


Nos. 78-1020, 78-1047


Supreme Court of Ohio


59 Ohio St. 2d 22; 391 N.E.2d 729; 1979 Ohio LEXIS 469; 13 Ohio Op. 3d 13



July 3, 1979, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

On January 22, 1974, by amended complaint, plaintiffs-appellees instituted a class action in the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County. The action was commenced on behalf of a plaintiff class comprised of an estimated 40,000 participants in either the Public Employees Retirement System (PERS) or the State Teachers Retirement System (STRS), who retired prior to October 16, 1972. On that date, R. C. 145.56 and 3307.71 were amended so as to subject PERS and STRS retirement benefits to the state income tax levied by R. C. 5747.02.

Appellees sought a declaratory judgment that the amendments to these sections, as applied to the plaintiff class, violated the provisions of Section 28, Article II of the Constitution of Ohio. Appellees further demanded that an injunction issue restraining collection of the tax upon retirement benefits received by the plaintiff class, and that taxes previously paid on such benefits be refunded.

Appellant Tax Commissioner filed a motion to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction over the subject matter, lack of jurisdiction over the person, and for failure to state a claim. The trial court granted [***2] appellant's motion and dismissed the complaint. On appeal, the Court of Appeals reversed the order of the trial court and remanded the cause for further proceedings. This court affirmed the decision of the Court of Appeals in Herrick v. Kosydar (1975), 44 Ohio St. 2d 128.

Upon remand, the trial court declared the amendments to R. C. 145.56 and 3307.71 unconstitutional to the extent that they were found to operate retrospectively. In addition, the court enjoined the levy and collection of the state income tax upon retirement benefits vesting prior to October 16, 1972, and ordered appellant to compute the amount of taxes wrongfully collected in the past.

The Court of Appeals, with one judge dissenting, affirmed those parts of the lower court's judgment which struck down the amendments to the statutes and enjoined the levy and collection of the state income tax upon retirement benefits received by the plaintiff class. However, the court reversed that portion of the judgment which ordered appellant to compute the amount of taxes theretofore collected.

The causes are now before this court pursuant to the allowance of defendant's motion to certify the record in No. 78-1020,  [***3] and of plaintiffs' motion to certify the record in No. 78-1047.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Cross-appeals were taken from a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which affirmed the lower court's judgment that found amendments to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 145.56, 3307.71 invalid and enjoined the levy and collection of the state income tax upon plaintiff retirees' benefits, while reversing a portion of the judgment that ordered defendant tax commissioner to compute the amount of taxes theretofore collected.


OVERVIEW: The retirees contended that they had a vested right to receive their retirement benefits exempt from the state income tax. Prior to the date of the challenged amendments, the retirees' benefits were by statute exempted from all state taxes. The court held, however, that a tax upon income realized after the effective date of the amendments was not retrospective in nature.Moreover, the vesting provisions of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 145.561, 3307.711 prohibited only a reduction in the rate of payment, not the imposition of a tax.Accordingly, the court concluded that the imposition of the state income tax upon retirement benefits that were vested prior to the effective date of the amendments did not impair a vested right of the retirees, nor did it constitute a retroactive tax.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment that had found the challenged amendments to be invalid.

 

89 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Sammons


No. 78-1431


Supreme Court of Ohio


58 Ohio St. 2d 460; 391 N.E.2d 713; 1979 Ohio LEXIS 459; 12 Ohio Op. 3d 384



June 27, 1979, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

Leland Sammons, appellant herein, was charged in the Hamilton County Municipal Court with three violations of R. C. 2919.22(A), endangering children. At his trial, it was adduced that on August 9, 1977, appellant's wife "disciplined" three of their sons, aged nine, ten and eleven, by applying heated scissors to their backsides. Appellant was asleep in the same room at the time, but apparently was awakened by the noises of the second child being harmed.

According to the children's testimony, appellant asked his wife what was burning, and when he discovered what she was doing, he told her to stop, but then began laughing. Appellant's wife then branded the third child while appellant looked on, taking no action to restrain her.

Appellant and his wife did nothing to care for the burns until the children complained of pain several days later. At that time, an unspecified ointment was applied to the burns.

Only after the boys had run away from home and had been found by police were their burns treated by a physician. One of the examining physicians testified that each of the boys had sustained "moderately severe"  [***2] burns which had penetrated all three layers of the skin. The other physician testified that, in his opinion, the burns required immediate medical attention for the risk of infection was substantial.

A jury found appellant guilty as charged and judgment was entered upon the verdicts. Appellant appealed the judgment, contending, inter alia, that R. C. 2919.22(A) is unconstitutionally vague and overbroad. The Court of Appeals rejected his contention and affirmed the judgment.

The Court of Appeals finding its judgment to be in conflict with the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Lake County in State v. Bruno (No. 5-265, April 18, 1977), unreported, certified the record of the case to this court for review and final determination.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged the decision of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which affirmed a lower decision that convicted him of three violations of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2919.22(A), endangering children.


OVERVIEW: The trial court convicted defendant of three violations of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2919.22(A), endangering children, after he watched his wife brand their children and did nothing to intervene. The court of appeals affirmed. On appeal, defendant claimed that § 2919.22(A) was void for vagueness and overbreadth under the Due Process Clause of U.S. Const. amend. XIV. The court affirmed the conviction, holding that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2919.22 provided, in part, that no person, being the parent of a child under eighteen, was to create a substantial risk to the health or safety of such child by violating a duty of care, protection, or support. To have stood by and done nothing to prevent the torturous branding of one's children, and then continue to stand by and do nothing to see that the wounds inflicted were properly medically treated, met no standard, however abysmally low. Whatever the color of the collar, a generally acceptable standard of societal attention to the needs and care of offspring was not difficult of either determination or application.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for three violations of endangering children.

 

90 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Cross


No. 78-1539


Supreme Court of Ohio


58 Ohio St. 2d 482; 391 N.E.2d 319; 1979 Ohio LEXIS 462; 12 Ohio Op. 3d 396



June 27, 1979, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Belmont County.

On November 1, 1977, appellant, Richard E. Cross, was arrested on a charge of aggravated arson and detained in the Belmont County jail where he remained in lieu of bond while awaiting trial. On December 23, 1977, he left the jail without authorization. Appellant made his escape through a hole in a fire door that had been made by two other prisoners. Appellant's reasons for leaving the jail were that "[i]t was so cold in there, you couldn't stand it," "[i]t was colder in there than it was outside," "[t]hey did not have no heat," the jail "hardly had any water," and because "I didn't have no lawyer; didn't know anything about my case." Generally it can be said that the appellant felt that his health, safety and legal interests were being neglected by prison officials.

The appellant fled to Mexico but returned to California and turned himself in to authorities on January 13, 1978. Appellant waived extradition and was returned to the Belmont County Jail. He was charged with violating R. C. 2921.34. 1 


1 R. C. 2921.34 reads:

"(A) No person, knowing he is under detention or being reckless in that regard, shall purposely break or attempt to break such detention, or purposely fail to return to detention, either following temporary leave granted for a specific purpose or limited period, or at the time required when serving a sentence in intermittent confinement.

"(B) Irregularity in bringing about or maintaining detention, or lack of jurisdiction of the committing or detaining authority, is not a defense to a charge under this section if the detention is pursuant to judicial order or in a detention facility. In the case of any other detention, irregularity or lack of jurisdiction is an affirmative defense only if either of the following occurs:

"(1) The escape involved no substantial risk of harm to the person or property of another.

"(2) The detaining authority knew or should have known there was no legal basis or authority for the detention.

"(C) Whoever violates this section is guilty of escape, a felony of the fourth degree. Sentence of confinement imposed for escape shall be served consecutively to any other sentence of confinement imposed on such offender."

 [***2] On June 6 and 7, 1978, a jury trial was held on the escape charge, and appellant's counsel attempted to introduce and proffer certain grand jury reports and other evidence of alleged inhumane conditions at the Belmont County jail as a basis for asserting the affirmative defense of "necessity" or "duress." 2 


2 The terms "necessity" and "duress" are distinct, yet are often used interchangeably and are often indistinguishable. They share in common the fact that they provide an excuse, justification or affirmative defense to a criminal charge. Running throughout their meanings is the theme that imminent, immediate danger or threat of danger prevents the actor from exercising his own will, and that there is no alternate path to take. Therefore, the actor is forced to choose between the lesser of two evils.

As evidence of the interchangeability, the defense has been variously termed as: coercion, Syck v. State (1973), 130 Ga. App. 50, 202 S. E. 2d 464; State v. St. Clair (Mo. 1953), 262 S. W. 2d 25; compulsion, Pittman v. Commonwealth (Ky. 1974), 512 S. W. 2d 488; State v. Sherian (1951), 234 N. C. 30, 65 S. E. 2d 331; Browning v. State (1943), 31 Ala. App. 137, 13 So. 2d 54; duress, State v. Procter (1977), 51 Ohio App. 2d 151; People v. Luther (1975), 394 Mich. 619, 232 N. W. 2d 184; People v. Harmon (1975), 394 Mich. 625, 232 N. W. 2d 187; or as necessity, People v. Lovercamp (1974), 43 Cal. App. 3d 823, 118 Cal. Rptr. 110; State v. Reese (Iowa, 1978), 24 Crim. L. Rep. 2331.

The appellant utilizes the term "necessity" because he relies on Lovercamp, supra. The appellee refers to "duress" because that is the defense that has generally been recognized in Ohio. See State v. Sappienza (1911), 84 Ohio St. 63, and State v. Procter, supra. For purposes of this review, we treat duress and necessity as the same defense.

 [***3] The trial court, however, excluded such evidence as immaterial and refused to charge the jury upon the affirmative defense of necessity as a defense to escape. 3 A unanimous jury verdict of guilty was returned, and the defendant was sentenced to not less than eighteen months and not more than five years imprisonment.


3 The defendant's proposed jury charge was as follows:

"1. the defendant was faced with a specific threat of death, forcible sexual attack, substantial bodily injury, or substantial health impairment in the immediate future;

"2. there was no time for complaint to the authorities or there existed a history of futile complaints or complete inaction which make any result from such complaints illusory;

"3. there was no time or opportunity to resort to the courts;

"4. there was no evidence of force or violence used toward prison personnel or other 'innocent' persons in the escape, and;

"5. the defendant reported to the authorities when he attained a position of safety from the immediate threat, then the defendant will have raised the affirmative defense of necessity."

This charge was much the same as that given in Lovercamp, supra, except that the defendant added the phrase, "or substantial health impairment" to paragraph No. 1. As discussed infra, we fail to see the relevance of this addition to the instant appellant, but if an escapee is going to assert a health impairment claim, then he must satisfy the six minimum conditions set out in State v. Worley (1975), 265 S. C. 551, 554, 220 S. E. 2d 242, before the defense of necessity or duress is available to him.

 [***4] Upon appeal to the Court of Appeals, the judgment of the trial court was affirmed on the grounds that Ohio "does not recognize any affirmative defense to a charge of breaking jail if the detention is pursuant to judicial order or in a detention facility." The Court of Appeals felt the language of R. C. 2921.34 ruled out a defense of necessity. Finding its judgment to be in conflict with a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Scioto County in State v. Procter (1977), 51 Ohio App. 2d 151, the Court of Appeals certified the record of the case to this court for review and final determination.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant escaped the jail where he was being held on arson charges, fled to Mexico, and turned himself in three weeks later. Defendant was convicted on an escape charge. The trial judge did not permit defendant to present evidence on the alleged inhumane jail conditions as a basis for the affirmative defense of "necessity" or "duress." The Court of Appeals (Ohio) affirmed the judgment and certified the case for review and final determination.


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued that the jury should have been instructed concerning the common-law defense of necessity and that the phrase "in the case of any other detention," found in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2921.34(B), was so vague, arbitrary and unreasonable as to be unconstitutional under the 14th Amendment. Reviewing defendant's allegations on the jail conditions, the court found no specific threat of death, forcible sexual attack, or substantial bodily impairment in the defendant's immediate future. At most, the evidence revealed that defendant had a common cold. The court held that undesirable prison conditions were not sufficient to justify an escape or make one necessary. The defendant made no complaints to the authorities about the conditions, that he had ample time and means to resort to the legal system, and that he had not immediately turned himself in after his escape. Because escape was not the only viable choice available to defendant, he was not entitled to present evidence on the defense of necessity. Section 2921.34 was sufficiently clear and unambiguous in defining the prohibited activity and not unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment, but for different reasons than those stated by the appellate court.

 

91 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Dayton Power & Light Co. v. Lindley


No. 78-1207


Supreme Court of Ohio


58 Ohio St. 2d 465; 391 N.E.2d 716; 1979 Ohio LEXIS 460; 12 Ohio Op. 3d 387



June 27, 1979, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

The Dayton Power & Light Company (D P & L) is an Ohio corporation with its general business offices located in Dayton. It is an investor-owned utility distributing electricity and gas in West Central Ohio and steam in downtown Dayton.

As an Ohio utility, the company is subject to the regulatory jurisdiction of the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio as well as the general regulatory jurisdiction of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission.

The company's service area consists of about 6,000 square miles encompassing approximately 1,300,000 residents. In order to operate its steam and electric generating plants the company consumes a considerable amount of coal from outside sources because it owns no coal mines itself. During the year 1977 the company purchased coal for its Ohio generating plants from Ohio, Kentucky, and West Virginia. The company received shipments of 7,335,640 tons of coal, of which 2,108,040 tons came from Ohio mines and 5,227,600 tons came from mines in Kentucky and West Virginia. During that same year the company burned over 6,494,553 tons of coal for which it paid in excess of $150,000,000.

The purchase [***2] of such vast quantities of coal for both immediate use and in order to maintain a normal 60-70 day stockpile at each of its generating stations, represents the company's most significant single category of operating expense.

D P & L owns two coal-fired electric generating stations known as the F. M. Tait and O. H. Hutchings Stations located in Montgomery County, as well as two coal-fired steam production plants situated in downtown Dayton. Due to strict federal environmental regulations the company has become increasingly aware of sulphur oxide emissions emanating from its coal-fired generating stations. The emissions are created by the oxidation of sulphur in the coal during the combustion process, and the higher the sulphur content, the greater the proscribed emission.

Because of these sulphur emission restrictions, the company has been forced to burn coal having a low sulphur content. Specifically, the coal burned at the company's Tait and Hutchings Stations cannot exceed 0.7 percent sulphur, based on 12,000 BTUs per pound. Likewise, the restriction of sulphur output imposed upon the Dayton Steam plant is 1.0 percent.

D P & L, pursuant to R. C. 5751.01 et seq., was [***3] assessed an Ohio Coal Use Tax of $70,672.65 on the coal consumed in generating electricity and producing steam between the dates of December 14 to December 31, 1977. On March 1, 1978, the Tax Commissioner denied the company's objections to the tax and an appeal was perfected to the Board of Tax Appeals.

On appeal to the board, D P & L challenged the constitutionality of the coal tax by asserting that it imposed a discriminatory tax on interstate commerce and impermissibly burdened such commerce in violation of Section 8, Clause 3, of Article I of the United States Constitution. No objection was raised concerning the actual calculations of the tax assessed.

The board affirmed the assessment and concluded that because it was merely an administrative agency, limited in its statutory authority, it lacked jurisdiction to determine the constitutional validity of the statutory scheme.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Decision reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant corporation challenged a decision by the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which found that appellee tax commissioner (commissioner) properly assessed coal use tax against the corporation pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5751.02.


OVERVIEW: The corporation was an Ohio utility company and was assessed a coal use tax by the commissioner. The corporation challenged the decision contending that the assessment of the tax violated the Commerce Clause. The court found that based on a review of the rate structure embodied in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5751.02, the economic reality of Ohio's coal industry, and the geographic location of low sulfur coal in that part of the country, a discriminatory effect was imposed upon interstate commerce by the application of the tax. The court found that those who bought the local product were rewarded in the form of a lower tax rate, while those who did not buy the local product had to suffer the burden of a higher tax rate. Therefore, the court found that the Ohio Coal Consumption Tax, as imposed by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5751.02, was in violation of the Commerce Clause of the United States Constitution.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's decision, which imposed a coal use tax upon the corporation.

 

92 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Columbus v. Public Utilities Com.


Nos. 78-1235, 78-1287


Supreme Court of Ohio


58 Ohio St. 2d 427; 390 N.E.2d 1201; 1979 Ohio LEXIS 454; 12 Ohio Op. 3d 361



June 20, 1979, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Public Utilities Commission.

The General Assembly in Section 1 of Am. Sub. H. B. No. 230 enacted R. C. 4905.70, effective October 9, 1977. That section required the Public Utilities Commission (commission) to promulgate a rule compelling each electric light company to offer "demand" or "load" metering to those residential customers whose homes are primarily heated by electricity and to provide rate tariffs reflecting the lower cost of service during off-peak periods.

The commission adopted Rule 4901:1-10-01, Ohio Adm. Code, which complied with the mandate of R. C. 4905.70. Subsequently, by entry of February 8, 1978, the commission ordered "municipally owned and operated electric light companies and not-for-profit electric light companies" to file tariffs in accordance with the rule, or show cause why they should be exempted from its requirements.

On March 6, 1978, appellant city of Columbus filed a response, asserting that the commission's assumption of jurisdiction over municipal electric light companies was proscribed by the Constitution of Ohio. On March 7, 1978, appellants Ohio Municipal Electric Association and members thereof * filed a similar [***2] response. Appellants' arguments were rejected by the commission on June 29, 1978, and their applications for rehearing were subsequently denied.


* Arcanum, Beach City, Bethel, Bryan, Carey, Cleveland, Cuyahoga Falls, Deshler, Greenwich, Hamilton, Jackson Center, Napoleon, New Bremen, Newton Falls, Oberlin, Orrville, Painesville, St. Marys, St. Clairsville, Versailles, Wellington, Westerville, and Woodville.

The causes are now before this court upon appeals as of right.



DISPOSITION: Order reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, City of Columbus, Ohio and the Ohio Municipal Electric Association challenged a decision of appellee Public Utilities Commission of Ohio, which rejected their claims that its assumption of jurisdiction over municipal electric light companies was proscribed by the Constitution of Ohio.


OVERVIEW: Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4905.70 (1977) required the Commission to promulgate a rule compelling electric light companies to offer "demand" or "load" metering to residential customers whose homes were primarily heated by electricity. The Commission adopted a rule, Ohio Admin. Code § 4901:1-10-01, which complied with the mandate of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4905.70. The City and Association claimed that § 4905.70 conflicted with Ohio Const. art. XVIII, § 4. The court held that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. 4905.70 contravened Ohio Const. art. XVIII, § 4 to the extent that it purported to apply to municipal electric light companies. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4905.70 and Ohio Admin. Code § 4901: 1-10-01 imposed a direct and substantial restriction upon the City and Association's operation of municipal electric light companies. By attempting to subject the rate structures of the companies to control of the Commission, the general assembly overstepped the line drawn by the Ohio Constitution. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4905.70 (1977) could not, in balancing the interests of the State and of local communities, be supported as an exercise of a valid state police power.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the Commission's order rejecting the City and Association's claims.

 

93 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Columbus v. Ohio Power Siting Com.


No. 78-1236


Supreme Court of Ohio


58 Ohio St. 2d 435; 390 N.E.2d 1208; 1979 Ohio LEXIS 455; 12 Ohio Op. 3d 365



June 20, 1979, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

The city of Columbus, appellee and cross-appellant herein, intends to construct a 90 megawatt refuse and coal fired electric generating plant, a "major utility facility" as that term is defined in R. C. 4906.01(B)(1).

The Ohio Power Siting Commission and its individual members, appellants and cross-appellees herein, upon learning of appellee's intentions, notified appellee's mayor by letter, dated December 30, 1975, that the commission possessed jurisdiction over the intended construction pursuant to R. C. Chapter 4906. The letter further stated that appellee must, by rule, 1 file a Letter of Intent with the commission at least two years prior to the anticipated commencement of construction, and at least one year before construction begins appellee must file an application for a certificate with the commission identifying the need for, and environmental impact of, the intended facility, pursuant to R. C. 4906.06.


1 Appellants' regulation PSC-5-01(A) requires those who must obtain a certificate of environmental compatibility and public need to file a Letter of Intent with the commission at least one year prior to the anticipated submission of an application for said certificate.

 [***2] Appellee filed neither a Letter of Intent nor the application for a certificate with the commission. Instead, appellee initiated a declaratory judgment action on May 12, 1976, in the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County, seeking to have R. C. 4906.01, 4906.03, 4906.04, 4906.06, 4906.10, 4906.13 and 4906.15 declared unconstitutional. Appellee essentially alleged in its complaint that these statutes unlawfully infringe upon a municipality's "home rule" powers, as provided for in Sections 3, 4, 6 and 7 of Article XVIII of the Ohio Constitution, by requiring municipalities to obtain commission approval for construction of a major utility facility.

Appellants denied the allegations of unconstitutionality in their answer and further sought by counterclaim, a writ of mandamus and, or, a mandatory injunction requiring appellee to comply with R. C. Chapter 4906. 

In answer to appellants' counterclaim, appellee admitted its failure to file a Letter of Intent and application for a certificate, but justified the failure on the basis that the municipality's home rule authority relieved appellants of these obligations.

The trial court held the statutes unconstitutional. On appeal,  [***3] the Court of Appeals for Franklin County found only those provisions in the statutes unconstitutional which entitled the commission to determine questions of necessity, public interest and convenience in deciding whether to issue a certificate. Those statutory provisions relevant to the environmental impact of proposed facilities were upheld, however, as an appropriate exercise of legislative regulatory power over matters of state-wide concern. The court also denied appellants' request for injunctive relief.

Appellants have appealed to this court from that portion of the judgment below which held in favor of appellee. Appellee has cross-appealed as to the other issues.

The cause is before this court pursuant to allowance of a motion and cross-motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant power siting commission sought review of a decision from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which found certain provisions of the relevant statutes unconstitutional. Appellee city had initiated this declaratory judgment action in the court of common pleas seeking to have Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 4906.01, 4906.03, 4906.04, 4906.06, 4906.10, 4906.13 and 4906.15 declared unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The power siting commission had requested that the court issue a writ of mandamus ordering the city to comply with Ohio Rev. Code Ann. ch. 4906. The issue in this cause involved the legislature's inherent constitutional authority to exercise the police power and the city's constitutional right to construct, own, and operate a public utility. The city argued that the home rule authority conferred by Ohio Const. art. XVIII, § 4 prevented the commission from reviewing the proposed construction with regard to the matters specified in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4906.10(A). The court held that to permit the power siting commission to determine the city's need for a utility, as well as the public service to be provided by, and convenience of, the facility constituted a direct and substantial interference with the city's home rule authority under Section 4 of Article XVIII. Accordingly, the court held that these portions of the questioned statutes were facially unconstitutional. However, the court would not issue a writ of mandamus because the state failed to establish that its environmental interests could not be adequately protected by the city's compliance with other state statutes.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals.

 

94 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Meyer v. Cuyahoga County Board of Revision


No. 78-1313


Supreme Court of Ohio


58 Ohio St. 2d 328; 390 N.E.2d 796; 1979 Ohio LEXIS 438; 12 Ohio Op. 3d 305



June 13, 1979, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

This appeal is from a judgment of the Court of Appeals, which affirmed an order of the Cuyahoga County Board of Revision revaluing appellants' property pursuant to R. C. 5715.19.

The basic facts herein are that on May 14, 1973, the appellants, William and Patricia Meyer, in an "arm's-length" transaction, purchased two parcels of residential real property located in Gates Mills, the purchase price being $ 120,000. The value of the property on the tax duplicate at the time of the sale was $ 43,410, such value having been established by the county auditor at the 1970 sexennial reappraisal.

On January 18, 1974, the Board of Education of the Mayfield City School District filed a complaint with the Cuyahoga County Board of Revision, pursuant to R. C. 5715.19, requesting that the assessed value of the Meyer property for the tax year 1973 be increased in accordance with the $ 120,000 purchase price for the property.

The board of revision, on June 11, 1974, issued its decision increasing the assessed value of the property to $ 120,000. Upon authority of R. C. 5717.05, the Meyers appealed to the Court of Common Pleas [***2] of Cuyahoga County, which court affirmed the increased valuation as established by the board of revision.

Upon appeal, the Court of Appeals, in a split decision, affirmed the judgment of the lower court.

The Court of Appeals finding its judgment in the instant cause to be in conflict with the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Clermont County in Poffenberger v.. Bd. of Revision (1977), 54 Ohio App. 2d 89, certified the record of the case to this court for review and final determination.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant property owners challenged the judgment of the Court of Appeals of Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's decision affirming the increased valuation of their property by appellee Cuyahoga County Board of Revision. At the request of appellee local school district, the Board increased the value of the property in accordance with its purchase price.


OVERVIEW: The property owners argued that it was basically unfair for the Board to adopt the purchase price method of evaluating their property for tax purposes while not requiring the auditor to revalue other surrounding properties on the same basis. On appeal, the court disagreed. The owners did not show that the common level of assessment in the county was not applied to their real property for tax purposes, and therefore, they failed to show a violation of the uniform rule of Ohio Const. art. XII, § 2. The Board of Tax Appeals' rules that were used to assess the prior value of their property and surrounding properties were a summary of considerations used to approximate an arm's-length sale where no such sale had taken place. Where there was an open market sale of the property, the purchase price was the best evidence of the value of the property and reasonably superseded any evidence based solely upon an appraisal by Board of Tax Appeals' rules. The record simply failed to establish either an intentional, systematic undervaluation of property in the county or a systematic or deliberate attempt by state officials to discriminate against the owners.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment upholding the increased valuation of the owners' property.

 

95 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Bd. of Educ. v. Walter


No. 78-1284


Supreme Court of Ohio


58 Ohio St. 2d 368; 390 N.E.2d 813; 1979 Ohio LEXIS 445; 12 Ohio Op. 3d 327



June 13, 1979, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

This cause was filed in the Court of Common Pleas of Hamilton County as a declaratory judgment action on April 5, 1976, seeking to have the Ohio system of financing public elementary and secondary education declared unconstitutional under the Ohio Constitution. The trial court decided that the cause was a proper class action, and the following constitute the parties plaintiff:

(A) The Board of Education of the City School District of the City of Cincinnati;

(B) Members of that board;

(C) The Superintendent of Schools for the City School District of the City of Cincinnati;

(D) The Clerk-Treasurer of the City School District of the City of Cincinnati;

(E) The named students who reside in the City School District of the City of Cincinnati and who attend the Cincinnati public schools;

(F) The named parents of children attending such schools who also are owners of real property located in the Cincinnati School District;

(G) All of the above in their representative capacities and as representative parties on behalf of all similarly situated school districts in Ohio, the members of the boards of education [***2] for such school districts, all administrators employed by such school districts, the students who reside therein and attend public elementary and secondary schools operated by such school districts, the parents of such students, and the owners of real property situated in such school districts.

The trial was commenced on December 6, 1976, and consisted of 78 days of testimony, including the testimony of approximately 77 witnesses and the introduction of approximately 2,400 exhibits. The record consists of 7,530 pages of transcript.

The trial court held for the plaintiffs and declared certain statutory provisions in Ohio's school finance system void and inoperative under both Section 2 of Article VI, the Thorough and Efficient Clause, and Section 2 of Article I, the Equal Protection and Benefit Clause of the Ohio Constitution. In so doing, the trial court adopted and filed approximately 400 pages of findings of fact and 35 conclusions of law submitted by plaintiffs.

The defendants appealed to the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County. On September 5, 1978, the court issued its judgment affirming in part, and reversing in part, the trial court's decision. The Court of Appeals [***3] affirmed the trial court's holding that the statutory plan for financing elementary and secondary education violates the Equal Protection Clause of the Ohio Constitution but reversed the trial court's holding that the system violates the Thorough and Efficient Clause of the Ohio Constitution.

The defendants appeal from that part of the Court of Appeals' judgment which held that the present system violates Ohio's Equal Protection Clause, while the plaintiffs cross-appeal from that part of the judgment which held that the system does not violate the Thorough and Efficient Clause.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion and cross-motion to certify the record.
Bd. of Educ. v. Walter, 1978 Ohio App. LEXIS 11208 (Ohio Ct. App., Hamilton County, 1978)



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed in part and affirmed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff Board of Education and Defendant Ohio General Assembly challenged the order of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which reversed the trial court's holding that the statutory plan for financing elementary and secondary education violated Ohio Const. art. I, § 2 and held that the system did violate Ohio Const. art. VI, § 2.


OVERVIEW: The Assembly and the board supported a statutory plan for financing elementary and secondary education. The trial court held that the statutory plan violated the Equal protection clause of the Ohio Constitution. The lower court reversed and held that the system statutory plan violated Ohio Const. art. I, the Thorough and Efficient Clause. The court affirmed the portion of the lower court order which found that the system did not violate the Equal Protection Clause and reversed the portion of the order of the lower court which found that the Assembly's funding system violated the Thorough and Efficient Clause. The court held that the Assembly's statutory plan was sufficient to assure that each school district had the means to comply with the State's minimum standards. Therefore, the school districts were being provided, in an equal manner, sufficient funds to properly educate and operate their programs. Further, the court held that the Assembly was under a statutory duty to provide efficient school systems throughout the State. Therefore, it was constitutional for the Assembly to use funds from one district to improve the school systems of another district.


OUTCOME: The court reversed in part and affirmed in part the order of the appellate court.

 

96 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Phipps


No. 78-554


Supreme Court of Ohio


58 Ohio St. 2d 271; 389 N.E.2d 1128; 1979 Ohio LEXIS 430; 12 Ohio Op. 3d 273



June 6, 1979, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

On November 22, 1976, Kenneth Phipps, the defendant-appellee herein, was convicted of the charge of importuning under R. C. 2907.07(B).

The evidence admitted at trial discloses that, on October 27, 1976, the defendant stopped his car at a downtown corner in Cincinnati and said to the only individual standing on a nearby sidewalk, a male adult, "Hop in, let's go have sex." The stranger looked into the back seat and Phipps retorted: "You look paranoid, come on in, I want to suck your dick." After the person got in the car, Phipps made the specific proposal again, along with some other conversation. At this point, the stranger identified himself as a police officer and arrested the defendant. At trial, the officer testified that he was offended by the defendant's remarks. Upon this evidence, Phipps was convicted by the Hamilton County Municipal Court.

Upon appeal, defendant's conviction was reversed. The Court of Appeals found R. C. 2907.07(B) to be in violation of the First Amendment to the United States Constitution, as an overbroad restriction on speech. The court held that Phipps' solicitation was protected speech,  [***2] and that the prosecution had not established a sufficiently compelling state interest to justify the regulation of this speech activity.

The Court of Appeals also held the importuning statute to be unconstitutionally vague, as denying the defendant the due process rights secured to him by the Fourteenth Amendment.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State of Ohio appealed the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), reversing defendant's conviction for importuning and finding that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2907.07(B) violated the First Amendment as an overbroad restriction on speech.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was arrested for importuning under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2907.07(B) after he solicited an undercover male police officer on a street corner for oral sex. The appellate court found that defendant's solicitation was protected speech, that the prosecution had not established a sufficiently compelling state interest to justify the regulation, and that § 2907.07(B) was unconstitutionally vague. The court disagreed and held that § 2907.07(B) was not void for vagueness. There were sufficient definitions in the statute to give a person of ordinary intelligence a reasonable opportunity to know what was prohibited. The court further found that § 2907.07(B) swept too broadly, and the state's interest in protecting unwilling hearers and a person's right to be "let alone" was not sufficiently compelling to warrant an infringement on otherwise protected speech. However, § 2907.07(B) could be narrowly construed to proscribe only the "fighting" words category of unprotected speech. Therefore, defendant could be punished under § 2907.07(B) if the solicitation inflicted injury, even if only emotional, or was likely to provoke the average person to an immediate breach of the peace.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's judgment and remanded for a new trial to determine whether defendant's speech violated the importuning statute under the appropriate narrowing construction.

 

97 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Atlas Crankshaft Corp. v. Lindley


No. 78-1182


Supreme Court of Ohio


58 Ohio St. 2d 299; 389 N.E.2d 1139; 1979 Ohio LEXIS 434; 12 Ohio Op. 3d 288



June 6, 1979, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

This is an appeal by Atlas Crankshaft Corporation, appellant, from a decision of the Board of Tax Appeals, appellee, affirming a final order of the Tax Commissioner, denying an application by appellant for a refund of corporate franchise taxes.

The Ohio corporate franchise tax law, R. C. Chapter 5733, was substantially revised by legislation (Am. Sub. H. B. No. 475) adopted effective December 20, 1971. Before this amendment, the 1972 franchise tax of a calendar year corporation would have been based on its net worth as of January 1, 1972. Under the new law, the net income earned by such a corporation during the 12-month period from January through December 1971, if resulting in more taxes than net worth at January 1, 1972, would be the basis for computing 1972 franchise tax liability.

The appellant is an Indiana corporation licensed to do business in Ohio. It is a major manufacturer of crankshafts and related items at its facilities in Fostoria, Ohio.

Appellant, a calendar year taxpayer, maintains its financial books and records in accord with generally accepted accounting principles. It computes its depreciation using the straight-line [***2] method for its general books of account, but depreciates these same assets on the double-declining balance method for federal income tax purposes. Appellant carried the difference between these two methods of depreciation on its books as surplus. This difference, as of December 31, 1970, was $ 1,564,113.

Appellant determined that its tax under the net income method was greater than under the net worth method and filed its 1972 franchise tax return using the former, pursuant to R. C. 5733.05. After having done so, appellant filed an amended return claiming that it should be allowed to deduct the surplus figure from net income and thereby qualify for a greater refund. Appellant's application was denied.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayer, a corporation, sought review of a decision of appellee Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio) denying an application by the corporation for a refund of corporate franchise taxes.


OVERVIEW: The corporation determined that its tax using the net income method was greater than its tax using the net worth method, and filed its 1972 franchise tax return using the former, pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5733.05. The corporation then filed an amended return claiming that it was entitled to deduct a surplus from net income and thereby qualify for a greater refund. The application was denied. The corporation claimed that the amendment of § 5733.05, effective December 20, 1971, insofar as it increased the franchise tax obligation of a corporation for that portion of an accounting year already passed, was void as a retroactive law in violation of Ohio Const. art. II, § 28. The court held that the amendment, by which the net income of a corporation was made an alternative basis for computing the corporate franchise tax, was not unconstitutional as a retroactive law, as applied to a corporate taxpayer whose accounting year was not yet closed at the time the amendment became effective. Since the tax year in question was not closed at the effective date of the statute, it was not unconstitutional to require the corporation to file its tax return pursuant to the amended § 5733.05.


OUTCOME: The judgment was affirmed.

 

98 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Dudukovich v. Lorain Metropolitan Housing Authority


No. 78-1071


Supreme Court of Ohio


58 Ohio St. 2d 202; 389 N.E.2d 1113; 1979 Ohio LEXIS 415; 12 Ohio Op. 3d 198



May 23, 1979, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lorain County.

Appellee, Marie Dudukovich, was employed by appellant, Lorain Metropolitan Housing Authority (LMHA), as an inspector of housing. On April 29, 1977, the board of directors of appellant, at a regular meeting, resolved to terminate the employment of appellee. Appellant listed five reasons for its dismissal of Dudukovich, which can be summarized as follows:

(1) Unsatisfactory performance of inspection;

(2) non-cooperation on eviction case bordering on insubordination;

(3) failure to show up for an inspection appointment with a tenant;

(4) miscalculation of rent owed by tenant; and

(5) errors in work performance.

Appellee appealed her dismissal to the board of directors of LMHA, and a hearing was held before that body on May 23, 1977, during which appellant was represented by counsel. The evidence presented at this hearing to support the charges against Dudukovich consisted of the unsworn testimony of the executive director of LMHA and a number of exhibits, all of which was offered without objection from appellee's counsel. At the conclusion of this hearing, appellant affirmed its dismissal of Dudukovich. 1 


1 Although the record contains no explicit affirmance by the board of its dismissal of appellee herein, it is undisputed that an affirmance resulted from the May 23, 1977, hearing.

 [***2] Appellee subsequently appealed the May 23 decision of the board to the Court of Common Pleas of Lorain County by filing a notice of appeal with that court on May 31, 1977, and by sending a copy of said notice to appellant by certified mail on May 28, 1977.

After reviewing the record compiled at the hearing, the Court of Common Pleas reversed the board's decision and ordered that appellee be reinstated in her position of inspector. The Court of Appeals thereafter affirmed the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas.

This cause is now before this court upon a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff employee appealed her dismissal from the employ of defendant municipal housing authority. The trial court reversed the housing authority's decision and ordered that the employee be reinstated to her position. The Court of Appeals for Lorain County (Ohio) affirmed and the housing authority appealed.


OVERVIEW: The housing authority challenged the trial court's assumption of jurisdiction and contended that the employee did not properly file a notice of appeal from an agency decision. The court considered the issue of whether the employee sufficiently complied with Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2505.04 by mailing a copy of her notice of appeal to the housing authority. The court found that since there was evidence in the record that the housing authority did eventually receive the mailed copy of the notice, the question remained whether it received the notice within the 10 day time limit prescribed by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2505.07(B). The court held that because a copy of the notice of appeal was sent by certified mail to a destination within the same city five days prior to the expiration of the statutory time limit and the housing authority presented no evidence of late delivery, a presumption of timely delivery controlled and the trial court correctly assumed jurisdiction. The court further held that the trial court acted within its scope of review in reversing the decision of the housing authority to dismiss the employee and did not abuse its discretion in finding as it did.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the lower courts' decision.

 

99 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Office of Consumers' Counsel v. Public Utilities Com.


No. 78-941


Supreme Court of Ohio


58 Ohio St. 2d 108; 388 N.E.2d 1370; 1979 Ohio LEXIS 399; 12 Ohio Op. 3d 115



May 9, 1979, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Public Utilities Commission.

This appeal by the Office of Consumers' Counsel arises from a March 31, 1978, opinion and order of the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio (commission) granting approximately $ 28.7 million in rate relief to the Columbus & Southern Ohio Electric Company (company). Both the company and the city of Columbus have also appealed from that order. C&SOE v.. Pub. Util. Comm. (1978), 58 Ohio St. 2d 120; Columbus v.. Pub. Util. Comm. (1978), 58 Ohio St. 2d 103.

Columbus & Southern Ohio Electric Company provides electric service to some 431,000 residential, commercial and industrial customers in all or parts of 25 central and southern Ohio counties.

On March 30, 1977, the company filed with the commission a notice of its intent to submit an application for permanent rate increases, pursuant to R. C. 4909.18.

On May 23, 1977, the Council of the city of Columbus enacted Ordinance No. 881-77, which would have extended the rates then being charged by the company for an additional two-year period. On June 23, 1977, the company rejected those rates established under Ordinance No. 881-77.

The company, on June 30, 1977, filed,  [***2] pursuant to R. C. 4909.34, a complaint and appeal from Ordinance No. 881-77, and submitted, concurrently, an application for an increase of $ 45,491,000 in rates for its jurisdictional customers outside Columbus.

Having previously set the test year as the 1977 calendar year, the commission, on August 24, 1977, found the application and complaint to be in conformance with its Standard Filing Requirements, set the date certain as June 30, 1977, and accepted the application for filing as of that date.

On November 30, 1977, a written report on the results of the commission's staff investigation of the matters set forth in the company's application and complaint was filed with the commission. Objections were timely filed to the staff report, including those of appellant, Office of Consumers' Counsel.

A public hearing was commenced on January 19, 1978, encompassing 24 hearing days and the testimony of over 30 expert witnesses.

The commission issued its opinion and order on March 31, 1978, granting $ 28,628,000 in rate increases to the company and substituting a new tariff schedule for Ordinance No. 881-77.

Office of Consumers' Counsel filed an application for rehearing on May [***3] 1, 1978, which was denied by the commission on May 30.

This cause is now before this court upon appeal as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed in part and reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant Office of Consumers' Counsel appealed an opinion and order of appellee Public Utilities Commission of Ohio granting rate increases to appellee Columbus & Southern Ohio Electric Company and substituting a new tariff schedule for appellee City of Columbus' ordinance, which would have extended the rates then being charged for two years. The city and the electric company also appealed.


OVERVIEW: The parties' main dispute was over the allowance of construction work in progress (CWIP) in the rate base under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4909.15(A)(1). On appeal, the court affirmed as to the inclusion of the CWIP in the rate base, but reversed as to the failure to offset working capital by customer deposits. The court held that the Commission's discretion under § 4909.15 to authorize a reasonable allowance for CWIP in a utility's rate base was a lawful delegation of the state's police power. But the Commission erred by failing to deduct customer deposits from the rate base under § 4909.05(I) and (J), or, alternatively, by failing to offset working capital with customer deposits. The rationale for an offset was to permit investors to earn a return only on that property for which they supplied funds, not on funds contributed by customers, and customer deposits were relatively constant and available for investment as working capital.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the Commission's order as to the formula used to determine the rate base and remanded to determine the amount of customer deposits to offset against working capital and a proper method to make such an adjustment, but otherwise affirmed.

 

100 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Riverside Methodist Hospital v. Gillie


No. 78-829


Supreme Court of Ohio


58 Ohio St. 2d 49; 387 N.E.2d 1378; 1979 Ohio LEXIS 388; 12 Ohio Op. 3d 50



April 25, 1979, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

This cause arises from an original action in mandamus, filed in the Court of Appeals for Franklin County, wherein Riverside Methodist Hospital, appellee herein, seeks to compel William T. Gillie, Judge of the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County, to submit a negligence action pending in that court between plaintiffs Earl and Mary LaValley and defendant Riverside to arbitration prior to trial pursuant to the mandates of R. C. 2711.21. * In response to a motion filed in that cause by plaintiffs to remove the matter from the arbitration provisions of the statute, Judge Gillie found that R. C. 2711.21 was unconstitutional. 


* R. C. 2711.21 provides, inter alia, that:

"(A) Upon a filing of any medical claim as defined in division (D) (3) of Section 2305.11 of the Revised Code, the controversy shall be submitted to an arbitration board * * *.

"* * *

"(C) If the decision of the arbitration board is not accepted by all parties thereto, the pleadings shall be amended to aver both the fact that the controversy was submitted to an arbitration board and the decision of the * * * board."

Riverside challenged [***2] Judge Gillie's determination by filing both a complaint in mandamus and a direct appeal in the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

On September 29, 1977, the Court of Appeals dismissed the appeal, concluding that the trial court's order was "interlocutory in nature."

By decision dated May 16, 1978, however, the Court of Appeals held that R. C. 2711.21 was constitutional and that the trial court had a clear legal duty to follow the arbitration provisions thereof. The writ of mandamus was allowed and the cause is now before this court upon an appeal as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.

 

101 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Wilson


No. 78-931


Supreme Court of Ohio


58 Ohio St. 2d 52; 388 N.E.2d 745; 1979 Ohio LEXIS 389; 12 Ohio Op. 3d 51



April 25, 1979, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

Ronald Wilson, appellant herein, was indicted by the grand jury on two counts of aggravated burglary under R. C. 2911.11(A)(3). He pleaded guilty to both counts. At his sentencing hearing, however, appellant requested that he be sentenced under the burglary statute, R. C. 2911.12, because of an alleged duplication between R. C. 2911.11(A)(3) and the basic proscription embodied in R. C. 2911.12. Appellant argued that, due to this duplication and the differing penalties imposed, the court was constitutionally required to sentence him pursuant to the lesser of the two penalties.

The trial court rejected appellant's request and sentenced him under the aggravated burglary statute. Appellant then appealed to the Court of Appeals, which, in a split decision, affirmed the conviction.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed a trial court judgment sentencing him under the aggravated burglary statute, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2911.11(A)(3) after his guilty plea to two counts of aggravated burglary.


OVERVIEW: After defendant pleaded guilty, he requested to be sentenced under the burglary statute, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2911.12, arguing that there was a duplication between §§ 2911.11(A)(3) and 2911.12. Defendant argued that, due to the duplication and the differing penalties imposed, the trial court was constitutionally required to sentence him pursuant to the lesser of the two penalties. The trial court rejected the request. The appeals court affirmed. Affirming, the court held that because the definitions of an "occupied structure" contained in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2909.01 were to be read disjunctively, no constitutional violation existed. The court found that the State was required to prove one of three aggravating circumstances under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2911.11(A)(3); therefore, § 2911.11(A)(3) did not violate the Equal Protection Clause.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appeals court's judgment.

 

102 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Burke International Research Corp. v. Lindley


No. 78-1165


Supreme Court of Ohio


58 Ohio St. 2d 27; 387 N.E.2d 1227; 1979 Ohio LEXIS 384; 12 Ohio Op. 3d 15



April 18, 1979, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

The Ohio corporate franchise tax law, R. C. Chapter 5733, was substantially revised by legislation (Am. Sub. II. B. No. 475) adopted effective December 20, 1971. Prior to this amendment, the franchise tax for a calendar year corporation was based on its net worth as of January 1 of each year. Under the new law, the net income earned by such a corporation during the calendar year became an alternative basis (whichever results in higher taxes) for computing franchise tax liability.

Burke International Research Corporation (hereinafter Burke) is an Ohio corporation subject to this tax. Pursuant to the revised law, it paid its 1972 franchise tax on the net income basis reflecting its operations for calendar year 1971, its annual accounting period.

Burke filed a claim for refund with the Tax Commissioner for the difference between the tax paid by it under the net income basis ($4,904) and the lesser amount payable under the net worth alternative ($2,683), the only measure of taxation prior to December 20, 1971. Burke's claim for refund was denied by the commissioner. Because Burke's taxable year ended after December 20, 1971, the commissioner [***2] concluded that this court's decision in Lakengren v. Kosydar (1975), 44 Ohio St. 2d 199, did not apply and that Burke was not otherwise entitled to the requested refund. The Board of Tax Appeals refrained from approaching the constitutional issues raised by Burke and affirmed the commissioner.

The cause is now before this court upon appeal as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant corporation sought review of a decision of the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which affirmed the decision of appellee Tax Commissioner denying the corporation a refund of part of the franchise taxes it paid for the year 1972 based on its net income for the calendar year 1971.


OVERVIEW: An amendment to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5733.05, which became effective as of December 20, 1991, permitted the "net income" of a corporation to be used as an alternative basis for calculating that corporation's annual franchise tax. Prior to this enactment, the method of calculation was a corporation's "net worth." The corporation in question had an accounting year which closed after the effective date of the amendment to § 5733.05. It argued that it was entitled to a refund of the difference between the franchise tax collected for 1972, which was based on its net income in 1971, and the lower amount that would have been collected under the net worth method. It contended that, as applied in the present case, § 5733.05 was a retroactive law violative of Ohio Const. art. II, § 28. On appeal, the court noted that when an accounting year was open for a taxpayer, it was also open for a taxing authority. Therefore, the court held that the amendment to § 5733.05 was not unconstitutional as a prohibited retroactive law as applied to a corporation whose fiscal year was not closed as of December 20, 1971.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the Board's decision, which affirmed the Tax Commissioner's denial of the corporation's request for a refund of part of its 1972 franchise taxes.

 

103 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Bernardini v. Board of Education


No. 78-619


Supreme Court of Ohio


58 Ohio St. 2d 1; 387 N.E.2d 1222; 1979 Ohio LEXIS 378; 12 Ohio Op. 3d 1



April 4, 1979, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Ashtabula County.

In 1965, plaintiff-appellee, Jay B. Bernardini, graduated from high school and entered Slippery Rock State College in Slippery Rock, Pennsylvania. During that same year he declared "Education" to be his major course of study and thereafter attended college continuously until January of 1967. In that same year he enlisted in the United States Marine Corps.

Appellee was honorably discharged on April 19, 1971, and returned to the pursuit of his college degree at Slippery Rock in September of 1971. He graduated in August of 1974 with a Bachelor's Degree in Education.

Shortly thereafter, he applied for and received a teaching certificate from the Ohio State Board of Education. In September of 1974 he was hired by the appellant, Board of Education for the Conneaut Area City School District, and commenced his duties as a teacher. When he was hired the appellant placed him at the first step (level "O") of its salary schedule.

On February 12, 1976, appellee filed a complaint in the Court of Common Pleas of Ashtabula County seeking a declaratory judgment that he was entitled to a category on the salary schedule which would [***2] credit him with his four years of military service. He later filed a motion for summary judgment contending that he was entitled to the military service credit pursuant to the statutory language found in R. C. 3317.13 and 3317.14. The appellant filed a cross-motion for summary judgment asserting that appellee was not entitled to the relief requested.

On July 6, 1977, the trial court granted appellant's cross-motion for summary judgment. In his opinion, the trial judge concluded that the military service credit, provided for in R. C. 3317.13, applied only to individuals who had both graduated from college and received their certification as teachers prior to entering the military.

On February 27, 1978, the Court of Appeals reversed the judgment of the trial court and rendered final judgment for appellee on his motion for summary judgment.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: With respect to appellee teacher's action seeking a declaratory judgment that he was entitled to a category on appellant education board's salary schedule, which would have credited him with his four years of military service, pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3317.13, the board challenged the judgment of the Court of Appeals (Ohio), which reversed the trial court's grant of summary judgment in favor of the board on the issue.


OVERVIEW: The teacher interrupted his college studies to serve in the military. Following his service, the teacher completed his education and got a teaching certificate. When the board hired the teacher, it placed him at the first step of its salary schedule.
