Upon appeal, the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County again held that from the record on the hearing for the purpose of determining the amount of bulk controlled substance possessed, the trial court should determine whether R. C. 2925.03(A)(4) or 2925.03(A)(6) were the substantial equivalent sections upon which modification was to depend and again remanded the cause to the trial court for that purpose.

The records of these cases are now before this court for review and final determination pursuant to the certifications by the Court of Appeals finding that its judgments are in conflict with that of the Court of Appeals for Lake County in State v.. Ruggerio (June 28, 1976), case No. 5-287.



DISPOSITION: Judgment accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Upon certification by the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), defendants sought review of the judgment of the appellate court, which remanded defendants' cases to the trial courts for resentencing. Defendants had each filed a motion with the respective trial courts under Am. Sub. H.B. 300 seeking vacation or modification of their sentences imposed under former Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 37.19.20(A).


OVERVIEW: Defendants were convicted of possession for sale of heroin, in violation of former § 3719.20(A), and were sentenced to imprisonment. Upon defendants' motions, the trial courts modified their sentences. On appeal, the appellate court remanded the cases for a determination of the quantity of drugs possessed for the purpose of finding which newly enacted statutes were the substantial equivalent for purposes of modification. While the court affirmed the appellate court's remand, the court noted that the legislative policy of § 3 of Am. Sub. H.B. 300 was to allow for the reduction of sentences that the general assembly considered too harsh. The court noted that the lower courts improperly attempted to fit each old conviction exactly into the altered scheme of criminal conduct, thereby imposing too great a burden on the lower courts. The court found that because the penalty under the old statute was greater than the penalty under the new law, § 3 of Am. Sub. H.B. 300 required that persons convicted and sentenced under the old law have that sentence reduced to a violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2925.03(A)(6), which was the next lower penalty for a trafficking-possession offense.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's orders remanding the applications to the respective trial courts for resentencing, but directed that the trial courts were to resentence under a specific statute.

 

120 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Roberts


No. 77-530


Supreme Court of Ohio


55 Ohio St. 2d 191; 378 N.E.2d 492; 1978 Ohio LEXIS 635; 9 Ohio Op. 3d 143



July 19, 1978, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lake County.

The Mentor police arrested the defendant, Herschel Roberts, on January 7, 1975, and charged him with forging a check in the name of Bernard Isaacs, and with receiving stolen property, namely, a number of credit cards belonging to Bernard Isaacs and his wife, Amy.

On January 10, the defendant came before the Mentor Municipal Court for preliminary hearing. At the hearing, the defendant offered the testimony of Anita Isaacs, the daughter of Bernard Isaacs. She testified that she had become friends with her classmate's younger sister, who was Roberts' girl friend, and that she had seen Roberts occasionally since June or July of 1974. On December 23, 1974, she had given the key of her apartment to Roberts' girl friend, and had told her it would be all right if she and Roberts used the apartment while she was away for the next few days. When she returned on December 30, Roberts said he was having trouble finding a place to stay, so she let Roberts go on using the apartment while she stayed at the home of a friend. She never spent any time in her apartment with Roberts.

Having thus described her acquaintance with Roberts,  [***2] the witness denied ever having given him her parents' credit cards, and she denied ever having talked to him about giving him the credit cards to help him pay for a television. Roberts' attorney did not ask to have the witness declared hostile, and he did not ask to examine her as on cross-examination.

The Municipal Court bound Roberts over to the grand jury which indicted him for receiving stolen property, R. C. 2913.51, and forgery, R. C. 2913.31. The grand jury also returned a secret indictment against Roberts for receiving stolen property, namely, silverware and appliances belonging to Mr. and Mrs. Isaacs, and for possession of heroin, R. C. 3719.09. The Court of Common Pleas of Lake County consolidated the proceedings on the two indictments and set the trial for July 17, 1975.

The case was continued six times, and the trial finally took place on March 4, 1976. Between November 1975, and February 1976, the trial court issued five subpoenas for four different trial dates to Anita Isaacs at her parents' address. It is undisputed that the last three subpoenas, showing returns on December 10, 1975, February 3, 1976, and February 25, 1976, respectively, all carried instructions [***3] to "please call before appearing." The witness never telephoned, nor did she appear at the trial.

At the trial, the prosecutor and the defense attorney both questioned Amy Isaacs on voir dire to determine whether Anita Isaacs was available to testify. Mrs. Isaacs testified that at the end of January 1975, Anita had left home for Tucson. She said that in April or May, she had received a form from a welfare office in San Francisco stating that Anita had applied for welfare. Mrs. Isaacs had used the address on the form to locate the social worker who was dealing with Anita. She had then talked to the social worker by telephone, and had spoken to Anita by telephone that same day. Later in the summer, Anita had called her parents and had indicated that she was traveling somewhere outside Ohio. From January 1975 to the date of the trial, neither Anita's parents nor any other relative had received any other communication from Anita. Mrs. Isaacs testified that she did not know what state Anita was in, and that she did not know how to contact Anita.

Citing R. C. 2945.49, 1 the prosecutor offered to introduce the transcript of the testimony which Anita had given at the preliminary [***4] hearing on the grounds that the witness was unavailable to testify in person. The court admitted the transcript over objection. The jury convicted the defendant on all counts, and the court entered judgment.


1 R. C. 2945.49. "Testimony taken at an examination or a preliminary hearing at which the defendant is present, or at a former trial of the cause, or taken by deposition at the instance of the defendant or the state, may be used whenever the witness giving such testimony dies, or cannot for any reason be produced at the trial, or whenever the witness has, since giving such testimony, become incapacitated to testify. If such former testimony is contained within a bill of exceptions, or authenticated transcript of such testimony, it shall be proven by the bill of exceptions, or transcript, otherwise by other testimony."

The Court of Appeals reversed. It held that by admitting the recorded testimony, the trial court had violated the defendant's right to confront adverse witnesses, as guaranteed by the Sixth Amendment to the United States Constitution.

The cause is before this court upon the allowance of the state's motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed [***5] .


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: After the common pleas court admitted the transcript of testimony which a witness had given at a preliminary hearing on the grounds that the witness was unavailable to testify in person, a jury convicted defendant on all counts. The Court of Appeals for Lake County (Ohio) reversed defendant's convictions, and the State's motion for leave to appeal was granted.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with forgery and receiving stolen property. At a preliminary hearing the victims' daughter testified against defendant. She was not cross-examined. She could not be found for trial, and a transcript of her preliminary hearing testimony was admitted pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.49. The court held that burden was on the State to show that the witness was unavailable by reason of her disappearance, and that the common pleas court erred in admitting the testimony. While the basic factual issues were the same at both proceedings, the ultimate factual issues were quite different. At trial, the ultimate issue was defendant's guilt beyond a reasonable doubt. At the preliminary hearing, in contrast, the ultimate issue was whether there was probable cause to believe that defendant had committed a crime. Since credibility was not the issue at a preliminary hearing as it was in trial, all the arts of cross-examination which were exerted to impair the credibility of a witness were useless in the preliminary hearing. Therefore, defendant's Sixth Amendment right to confrontation was violated by admission of the recorded testimony.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the court of appeals' judgment reversing defendant's conviction.

 

121 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Ackerman v. Tri-City Geriatric & Health Care, Inc.


No. 77-827


Supreme Court of Ohio


55 Ohio St. 2d 51; 378 N.E.2d 145; 1978 Ohio LEXIS 614; 9 Ohio Op. 3d 62



July 12, 1978, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Carroll County.

The events giving rise to the instant cause began some time before June 1974, when Mr. and Mrs. Woodrow Ring, officers of Tri-City Geriatric & Health Care Center, Inc. (appellee herein), decided, in part because of a dispute with their landlord as to rents and as to who should pay for improvements required by an adjudication order, to move their nursing home operation from quarters leased from the First Baptist Church of Massillon, to a building in Carroll County on which they had a purchase contract. Mrs. Ring called the office of the State Department of Health to inquire about applying for a license for the new home on June 15, and on June 30 she submitted a license application. At about that time she also discussed renovating the new facility with a representative of the Department of Industrial Relations. 1 A few weeks later Mrs. Ring moved nine patients into the unlicensed facility.


1 The procedure for licensing a nursing home is set forth in R.C. 3721.07 which provides:

"Every person desiring to operate a home as defined in section 3721.01 of the Revised Code shall apply for such a license to the director of health. The director shall issue a license for the home, if after investigation of the applicant and inspection of the home, the following requirements or conditions are satisfied or complied with:

"(A) The applicant has not been convicted of a felony or a crime involving moral turpitude;

"(B) The applicant is not violating any of the regulations made by the public health council or any order issued by the director of health;

"(C) The buildings in which the home is housed have been approved by the department of industrial relations, and the state fire marshal or a township, municipal, or other legally constituted fire department approved by the marshal. In the standards, and by the state fire marshal, and by section 3721.071 of the Revised Code[;]

"(D) The applicant, if it be an individual, or the principal participants, if it be an association or a corporation, is or are suitable financially and morally to operate a home defined in section 3721.01 of the Revised Code;

"(E) The applicant is equipped to furnish humane, kind, and adequate treatment and care;

"(F) The home does not maintain or contain:

"(1) Facilities for the performance of major surgical procedures;

"(2) Facilities for providing therapeutic radiation;

"(3) An emergency ward;

"(4) A clinical laboratory unless it is under the supervision of a clinical pathologist who is a licensed physician in this state;

"(5) Facilities for radiological examinations unless such examinations are performed only by a person licensed to practice medicine, surgery, or dentistry in this state.

"(G) The home does not accept or treat outpatients except upon the written orders of a physician licensed in this state, maternity cases, boarding children, and does not house transient guests housed for twenty-four hours or less.

"When the director issues a license, the license shall remain in effect until revoked by the director or voided at the request of the applicant; provided, there shall be an annual renewal fee payable during the month of January of each calendar year.

"Any applicant who is denied a license may appeal in accordance with sections 119.01 to 119.13 of the Revised Code."

 [***2] From July to November 1974, Mrs. Ring increased the number of patients in the new home, made some repairs on the building and began plans for, but not the actual work on, the installation of a $ 27,000 sprinkler system for the new facility. During that time, according to her testimony, Mrs. Ring was informed by a Mr. Donahue and a Mr. Sanders of the Department of Health that she was operating the home illegally. 2 She also received two letters informing her that she was not to operate a nursing home in the new facility. (On October 11, 1974, the Department of Industrial Relations sent a letter listing the improvements it would require "before the building can be reopened as a nursing home and approved by this department." Approximately two weeks later the Department of Health wrote Mrs. Ring stating her application was being processed and notifying her that "no more than two patients or residents may be admitted to your home until a license has been issued by the Director of Health.")


2 Mrs. Ring testified that Mr. Donahue and Mr. Hoyt Sanders "appeared on the scene and told me personally that I was operating illegally and that I should seek legal counsel and this is what I did." When asked by the court when this occurred, she testified that she didn't remember the exact date but that "I was in the hospital ten days and I just got out a while." Earlier, Mrs. Ring testified that she was in the hospital for ten days at roughly the same time that the welfare patients were moved from the Massillon facility and the patients who remained with her were moved to the new home.

 [***3] After November 1974, Mrs. Ring began to install the sprinkler system and to continue with other renovations. In February 1975, without having either granted or denied the home a license and, according to the testimony of one of the investigators, some time long after such licenses are usually acted upon, the Director of Health, appellant herein, filed a complaint in the Court of Common Pleas of Carroll County to enjoin, pursuant to R.C. 3721.08, the operation of the Tri-City home. (Approximately ten months later the Department of Industrial Relations issued a final adjudication order against the home which appellee has appealed pursuant to R.C. 3781.031.)

During the hearing on appellant's motion to enjoin the operation of the home, the parties stipulated that the Tri-City facility was unlicensed and that it was operated as a nursing home within the meaning of R.C. 3721.01. Ruling that the maxim that "he who seeks equity must do equity" applies to the instant cause, the trial court denied the injunction, directed appellee to make further changes in the home and ordered appellant to issue a license. The Court of Appeals for Carroll County ruled that "where a statute creates a [***4] new statutory right of action, equitable principles may not be applicable" but affirmed the trial court's denial of the injunction on the grounds that R.C. 3721.07 (the statute setting forth the requirement that nursing homes be licensed) was unconstitutionally applied in the instant cause. The appellate court also substituted the common pleas court's order with an order to appellant to either grant or deny appellee's license application within ten days.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to an allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant director of health sought review of an order from the Court of Appeals for Carroll County (Ohio), which denied the director's application for an injunction under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3721.08 that would have prevented appellee from operating its nursing home facility.


OVERVIEW: The nursing home moved its facility into a different building and applied for a license at the new address. Before any new license was issued the director notified the nursing home that it was operating illegally. The director applied for an injunction but the injunction was denied. On review the court found that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3721.08 granted a trial court jurisdiction to grant injunctive relief to enjoin the illegal or dangerous operation of a nursing home if the home is operated without a license or if there was a real and present danger to the health or safety of any occupants of the home. The court held that it was not necessary to show both a danger and unlicensed operation. The court found that it was established state law that when a statute granted a specific injunctive remedy to an individual or to the state, the party requesting the injunction did not need to aver and show that great or irreparable injury was about to be done for which he had no adequate remedy at law. The court noted that where an injunction was authorized by a statute and designed to provide a governmental agent with the means to enforce public policy, no balancing of equities was necessary.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals and held that the statute should have been granted because the statutory conditions existed.

 

122 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Ohio State Bar Asso. v. Mayer


J. D. No. 78-1


Supreme Court of Ohio


54 Ohio St. 2d 431; 377 N.E.2d 770; 1978 Ohio LEXIS 595; 8 Ohio Op. 3d 434



June 28, 1978, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from Commission of Judges.

Relator-appellee, Ohio State Bar Association, filed a complaint with the Board of Commissioners on Grievances and Discipline of the Supreme Court of Ohio pursuant to Rule VI of the Supreme Court Rules for the Government of the Bar of Ohio, seeking the retirement, removal or suspension from office of respondent-appellant, Judge James J. Mayer.

The first two paragraphs of the complaint state:

"1. Relator alleges that cause exists to remove Respondent from the office of Judge of the Court of Common Pleas of Richland County, Ohio for the reason Respondent engaged in * * * conduct * * * prejudicial to the administration of justice and for the reason that Respondent engaged in * * * conduct * * * which would bring the judicial office which he holds into disrepute.

"2. Relator alleges that cause exists to remove Respondent from the office of Judge of the Court of Common Pleas of Richland County, Ohio for the reason that Respondent is suffering from a physical disability and from a mental disability * * *."

After investigation in compliance with Gov. R. VI and R. C. 2701.11, the board reported to the Supreme Court its finding that [***2] "* * * there is substantial credible evidence in support of the misconduct allegations as set forth in paragraph one of the complaint * * *." Thereafter, the Supreme Court, pursuant to Gov. R. VI and R. C. 2701.11 appointed a five-judge commission to determine the question of retirement, removal or suspension of appellant.

The commission of judges conducted a hearing in the matter and ordered that appellant "* * * be retired for disability as a Judge of the Court of Common Pleas of Richland County, Ohio with the right to any emoluments, benefits and compensation allowed by law."

Appellant appealed the order of the commission to this court and moved for a stay of the order of the commission pending disposition of the appeal. The motion to stay was granted and the cause is now before the court for a determination of the question whether the order of the commission should be affirmed, reversed or modified.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent judge appealed the order of the Commission of Judges (Ohio), which ordered that the judge be retired for disability as a trial court judge in response to a complaint filed by relator Ohio State Bar Association with the Board of Commissioners on Grievances and Discipline of the Supreme Court of Ohio.


OVERVIEW: The State Bar alleged that cause existed to remove the judge from his office because the judge engaged in conduct prejudicial to the administration of justice and engaged in conduct which would bring the judicial office into disrepute. The State Bar further alleged that cause existed to remove the judge because the judge was suffering from a physical disability and from a mental disability. The Commission ordered that that the judge be retired for disability. The judge argued that the Commission's order was not supported because evidence showed that the judge did not suffer from any present disability which now prevents his performance of his job. In affirming the Commission's order, the court held that given the judge's physical condition, there was ever-present a latent possibility of recurrence of the mental conditions that precipitated his non-judicious conduct. The judge suffered from manic depressive disorder. Evidence showed that the judge engaged in conduct violative of the Code of Judicial Conduct when his lithium level was not properly maintained, which was an ever-present possibility due to the drug's complication of the judge's intestinal cancer.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the Commission's order.

 

123 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Ocasek v. Riley


Nos. 78-604, 78-605


Supreme Court of Ohio


54 Ohio St. 2d 488; 377 N.E.2d 792; 1978 Ohio LEXIS 605; 8 Ohio Op. 3d 466



June 28, 1978, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN PROHIBITION.

On December 5, 1977, respondent, Judge Paul E. Riley, sitting by assignment in the Court of Common Pleas of Hamilton County, rendered a judgment in Bd. of Education of the City School District of the City of Cincinnati, et al. v.. Franklin B. Walter, Supt. of Public Instruction, et al., case No. A7602725 (hereinafter Board v.. Walter). Respondent ruled that certain statutes concerning the distribution of "basic state aid" to public schools were unconstitutional and therefore void. Respondent provided that the effect of the order was to be suspended until July 1, 1978, at which time the statutes in question would become inoperative.

That judgment has been appealed and is pending in the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County. Oral argument has not yet been scheduled.

Relator herein, Franklin B. Walter, Superintendent of Public Instruction, is a defendant-appellant in the above cause. Following respondent's entry, on April 21, 1978, defendants-appellants in Board v.. Walter filed with the Court of Common Pleas an application for stay pending termination of appellate litigation. On May 1, 1978, plaintiffs in that case filed a motion [***2] to extend time and for an evidentiary hearing on the stay application. Respondent granted plaintiffs' motion and scheduled May 26, 1978, as the date for the evidentiary hearing.

Defendants-appellants then filed a motion for reconsideration, on which oral argument was heard on May 16, 1978. Respondent indicated his intention to proceed with the evidentiary hearing as scheduled. At the May 16 hearing, plaintiffs indicated their intention to depose relator Walter and three other non-party witnesses, who are also relators herein (Oliver Ocasek, President Pro Tempore of the Ohio Senate; Vernal G. Riffe, Jr., Speaker of the Ohio House of Representatives; and Richard Sheridan, Ohio Legislative Budget Officer). These depositions were scheduled for May 18, 19, 22 and 23, 1978, and respondent ordered that a convenient place was the office of plaintiffs' counsel in Cincinnati.

Relators filed with this court on May 17, 1978, complaints in prohibition and motions for alternative writs to prevent respondent from holding an evidentiary hearing on defendants-appellants' application for stay pending termination of appellate litigation in Board v.. Walter and further to prevent respondent [***3] from permitting any proceedings, including depositions of relators, which are ancillary thereto.

On May 17, 1978, this court, by separate entries, allowed the motions for alternative writs and further ordered respondent to show cause on or before June 15, 1978, why a permanent writ of prohibition should not issue.



DISPOSITION: Writs allowed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relators sought a writ of prohibition in the Supreme Court of Ohio against respondent judge to prevent the judge from holding an evidentiary hearing on appellant board's application for stay pending termination of appellate litigation and to prevent the judge from permitting any proceedings, including depositions of relators.


OVERVIEW: Appellants filed their application for stay pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 62. Pursuant to that rule, they were entitled to a stay of the judgment as a matter of right. The lone requirement of Fed. R. Civ. P. 62(B) was the giving of an adequate supersedeas bond. Fed. R. Civ. P. 62(C) made that requirement unnecessary in this case, and the judge had no discretion to deny the stay. Therefore, the evidentiary hearing on the stay and the related depositions were inappropriate proceedings.


OUTCOME: The writs of prohibition were allowed.

 

124 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Black


No. 77-1011


Supreme Court of Ohio


54 Ohio St. 2d 304; 376 N.E.2d 948; 1978 Ohio LEXIS 560; 8 Ohio Op. 3d 296



May 31, 1978, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

Lonnie Black (appellant) was arrested on July 25, 1975, and indicted on August 13, 1975, for the attempted aggravated murder and the aggravated robbery of Dr. Margaret Tucker (decedent). The original two-count indictment was nolled, and the appellant was indicted for aggravated robbery and for aggravated murder with the specification that the offense was committed while the offender was committing or attempting to commit aggravated robbery.

Between 12:30 and 1:00 a. m. on the morning of July 8, 1975, a security guard observed the decedent leaving the Veterans Administration Hospital, where she had been employed for the last ten years. The guard testified that he recalled that the decedent was carrying a shopping bag, but he did not know its contents nor did he observe a purse in the decedent's possession. Within approximately ten or fifteen minutes after he had observed the decedent leaving the hospital, apparently for her apartment in the vicinity, the security guard heard what he believed to be three gunshots in rapid succession.

At 1:38 a. m., on July 8, 1975, while patrolling the East Boulevard area, a Cleveland [***2] police officer discovered the decedent, with her head lying in a pool of blood, in front of the Western Reserve Historical Society. Subsequent searches of this area failed to reveal any of the decedent's personal effects, including the shopping bag. Meanwhile, the decedent was transported to Mt. Sinai Hospital, where an examination revealed two gunshot wounds. There was an entrance wound on the posterior part of the right shoulder and a corresponding exit wound on the anterior part of the right shoulder. The other bullet entered the decedent's chin, fractured the jaw, deflected downwards, fractured the hyoid bone, transected the spinal cord and lodged in the neck, leaving the decedent paralyzed. The decedent died on October 29, 1975, as a result of bronchopneumonia caused by the gunshot wound to the face.

According to testimony elicited at trial, the appellant had a conversation with Barbara Hickman, age 21, and her sister, Beverly, age 15. During this conversation, according to the testimony of the Hickman sisters, the appellant told them that he had to leave town because he had just shot a white woman in the face near the Veterans Administration Hospital when she refused [***3] to give up her purse.

The appellant's stepfather, Richard Harrison, testified that he took the appellant to the bus station on July 8, 1975, at 11:00 p. m., and that appellant bought a ticket to Tennessee. The appellant was eventually arrested in Springfield, Tennessee, and brought back to Cleveland.

The appellant testified on his own behalf at the trial. He stated that the trip to Tennessee had been planned for several weeks, and he went there with the expectation of seeking employment. Appellant admitted to having a conversation with the Hickman sisters but denied making any inculpatory statement and denied his involvement in the murder of the deceased. The defendant also relied upon the alibi that he was visiting with one Adolphus Cureton, a security guard at Parkgate Beverage, at the time of the murder.

At the conclusion of the trial, the jury returned verdicts of guilty of aggravated murder with the specification and of aggravated robbery.

Thereafter and in accordance with R. C. 2929.03, a sentencing hearing was held. The trial judge, failing to find any mitigating circumstances established by a preponderance of the evidence, imposed the required death penalty for [***4] the aggravated murder charge and a term of years on the aggravated robbery charge. Appellant then appealed to the Court of Appeals, which affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

The cause is presently before this court as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed his criminal convictions and sentence. Defendant was convicted of aggravated murder with specifications and aggravated robbery. The death penalty was imposed after the trial court failed to find any mitigating circumstances established by a preponderance of the evidence.


OVERVIEW: A murder victim was seen leaving work carrying a shopping bag. A security guard heard gun shots and the victim was found shot a short distance away, lying in a pool of blood, without any of her personal possessions. During his trial two witnesses testified that defendant had confessed that he had to leave town because he had shot a woman near the victim's place of employment. Defendant appealed and asserted that the State had failed to prove his intent to commit murder, that his confession should not have been admitted into evidence, and that the sentencing hearing was flawed. In affirming the convictions, the court held that the State had to independently prove the corpus delicti in order to admit defendant's extra judicial confession. The record contained evidence of both the criminal act and the criminal agency and defendant's confession was, therefore, properly admitted. The use of a gun was sufficient evidence of defendant's intent to kill. The court reversed the sentence imposed. Defendant did not have the burden of proving the existence of mitigating factors and it was error for the trial court to place that burden on him during the mitigation hearing.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's convictions, reversed the death penalty imposed, and remanded the cause for further proceedings.

 

125 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


American Modulars Corp. v. Lindley


No. 77-657


Supreme Court of Ohio


54 Ohio St. 2d 273; 376 N.E.2d 575; 1978 Ohio LEXIS 555; 8 Ohio Op. 3d 258



May 24, 1978, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

Between 1970 and 1973, appellant, American Modulars Corporation (now merged with United States Steel Corp.), purchased tangible personal property from out-of-state and Ohio vendors for use in two counties which levied, pursuant to R. C. 5739.021 and 5741.021, one-half percent sales and use taxes. The Ohio purchases were made in counties which did not levy those taxes. On July 17, 1974, the Tax Commissioner of Ohio assessed a one-half percent use tax on appellant's use of the property purchased out of state. Appellant was not assessed the one-half percent sales and use taxes on property purchased in the state. Appellant appealed the Tax Commissioner's assessment to the Board of Tax Appeals on Ohio and federal constitutional grounds. The board determined that it was without jurisdiction to address the constitutional argument and affirmed the order of the commissioner.

The cause is now before this court on an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Decision reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayer challenged the decision of the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which determined that it was without jurisdiction to address a constitutional argument and affirmed the order of appellee tax commissioner who assessed a one-half percent use tax on the taxpayer's use of property purchased out of state.


OVERVIEW: The issue was whether Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5741.021, as a permissive local use tax incorporating the exceptions of a mandatory state use tax, violated the Commerce Clause. The question was whether that tax burdened interstate commerce by discriminating against the acquisition of goods when those goods were acquired out of state. The court reversed. The court found that because goods used in taxing counties and purchased in non-taxing Ohio counties were not subject to a four and one-half percent tax even though identically used goods purchased out of state were so taxed, § 5741.021 provided a direct commercial advantage to local purchases which impeded the free flow of trade between the states. The court held that § 5741.021 was unconstitutional insofar as its application imposed a higher tax rate on property purchased out of state and used in a taxing county than on similarly used property purchased in the state.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision.

 

126 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Nabozny


No. 77-821


Supreme Court of Ohio


54 Ohio St. 2d 195; 375 N.E.2d 784; 1978 Ohio LEXIS 547; 8 Ohio Op. 3d 181



May 10, 1978, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Licking County.

William V. Nabozny (appellant) was arrested for the killing of James Jeffrey Crawford (decedent). The Licking County grand jury returned an indictment on January 30, 1976, charging the appellant with aggravated murder in violation of R. C. 2903.01 and the specification that the murder was committed while committing, attempting to commit, or fleeing immediately after committing or attempting to commit kidnapping in violation of R. C. 2929.04(A)(7).

The decedent was employed by the National Bank of Detroit as an assistant branch bank manager. On the morning of December 5, 1975, the decedent was abducted from the parking lot of the branch bank where he worked. According to the testimony of two eyewitnesses, two adult males apparently forced the decedent into a dark automobile (described by one witness as a Monte Carlo) and then drove away from the bank.

The principal state's witness was Chester Wysocki. Testifying under a grant of immunity from the state of Ohio, Wysocki revealed that he had participated with John Garside and William Nabozny (appellant) in an aborted attempt to kidnap the decedent on December [***2] 4, 1975. Wysocki also testified that, pursuant to a telephone call from Garside on December 5, 1975, he went to the Detroit suburban home of Joseph Byle, a mutual acquaintance. Upon his arrival at the Byle residence, Wysocki met the appellant and Garside and saw Crawford, who was bound and blindfolded in the basement. Garside, fearful that the Monte Carlo had been recognized during the commission of the crime, instructed Wysocki to rent another car. Enlisting the aid of David Finley, Wysocki rented an orange Firebird and returned to the Byle residence. Later in the afternoon, the appellant, Garside and the decedent left in the Firebird for Garside's rented house in Eden Township in Licking County, Ohio.

Wysocki remained in Michigan and undertook to extort $ 250,000 from the National Bank of Detroit through a series of telephone conversations with bank personnel. Failing to effectuate an exchange, and believing a news report that the ransom would not be delivered without proof that the decedent was still alive, Wysocki drove to the rented house in Ohio to tape record the decedent's voice. The recording having been made on the morning of December 8, Wysocki returned to Detroit,  [***3] leaving the appellant and Garside with the decedent at the rented house. This tape recording was discovered later that same day by the decedent's sister, acting upon instructions received by phone from Wysocki.

On December 9, 1975, Garside returned to Detroit in the orange Firebird to meet with Wysocki to devise a plan for receiving the $ 250,000. On that afternoon, Garside and Wysocki believed they were being followed and decided to meet later that day at the residence of Joseph Holmes. At approximately 5:45 p. m., Wysocki testified that, while they were at this house, Garside made a series of telephone calls, including at least one to Ohio, and that he heard Garside giving directions "[t]o clean up the house." Borrowing the station wagon owned by Holmes, Garside departed, while Wysocki remained in Michigan.

The decedent's time of death was placed at 10:30 p. m., on December 9, by the Licking County coroner. This was substantiated by a pathologist connected with the Hamilton County coroner's office. The pathologist testified that the decedent had lived for an hour or two after the stabbing because no major arteries were severed by any of the 30 stab and incised wounds.

 [***4] On the evening of December 9, Sharon Scheurell, apparently Garside's common-law wife, appeared at her sister's home in Columbus seeking lodging for herself and "Skip" (a nickname by which appellant is known). Being denied lodging, Scheurell went to the home of her mother, Mrs. Emma Evans. The identity of the person who accompanied her was not disclosed during the prosecution's case. Later, as indicated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) surveillance of the Evans' home, the station wagon owned by Joseph Holmes and driven by a male arrived at the house at 2:15 a. m. The automobile departed the Evans' house at 2:35 a. m. and arrived at Garside's rented house at 4:04 a. m. The appellant was identified as a passenger in the auto after it left the Evans' residence and Garside was identified with the automobile upon its arrival in Eden Township.

Later that morning, the appellant, Garside, Scheurell and her children left the house and met Homer Porter at a truck stop at the intersection of State Route 37 and Interstate 70, east of Columbus. They then returned to Columbus. Leaving her children in Columbus, Scheurell accompanied the appellant and Garside on a journey in [***5] the station wagon along Interstate 70 that terminated with the arrest of the appellant and Garside by the FBI outside Dayton, Ohio.

Thereafter, Scheurell was released and returned to Columbus. However, within a short time of her release Mrs. Evans contacted the FBI and they returned to her home. A search of the Eden Township area for the decedent's body subsequently ensued but was discontinued with the approach of night. The search was renewed the following morning, when the decedent's body was discovered.

The state was able to corroborate the testimony of Wysocki concerning the presence of Garside, the appellant, and the decedent at Byle's home by the testimony of Joseph Byle. Byle testified that Garside, the appellant and an unidentified male arrived at his house at approximately 9:00 a. m. on December 5. He then stated that he left his house to go hunting, and, upon his return, the house was vacant. Additionally, David Finley testified as to the assistance he rendered to Wysocki in obtaining the orange Firebird. Furthermore, a search of Garside's house in Eden Township revealed the fingerprints of the decedent, appellant, Garside and Scheurell.

The appellant testified [***6] on his own behalf at the trial. He admitted being in Columbus on December 9 and meeting Scheurell but alleged his purpose was to engage in illicit drug traffic. Appellant also admitted to being at the house in Eden Township on the 10th but stated he was there only to help clean the house.

The jury found the appellant guilty of aggravated murder with a specification.

Thereafter and in accordance with R.C. 2929.03, a sentencing hearing was held. The trial judge, not finding any mitigating circumstances, imposed the required death penalty. Appellant then appealed to the Court of Appeals, which affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

The cause is presently before this court as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged the decision of the Court of Appeals (Ohio), which affirmed a lower decision that convicted defendant of aggravated murder with a specification that the murder was committed while committing, attempting to commit, or fleeing immediately after committing or attempting to commit kidnapping in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2929.04(A)(7).


OVERVIEW: The trial court convicted defendant of aggravated murder in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2903.01 with the specification that the murder was committed while committing a kidnapping in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2929.04(A)(7). The trial judge, not finding any mitigating circumstances, imposed the death penalty. The court of appeals affirmed. On appeal, defendant claimed, among many items, that since the state failed to prove the identity of the actual person who purposely committed the killing, he could not be convicted. The court affirmed the conviction, noting, inter alia, that the threshold inquiry was not whether there was proof beyond a reasonable doubt as to the identity of the actual killer, but whether, once testimony of the conspiracy to kidnap was offered, was there proof beyond a reasonable doubt that one or more of the conspirators killed the victim during the kidnapping. There was sufficient evidence of such a conclusive and persuasive force for the jury to determine on the facts that there was no reasonable hypothesis other than guilty and accordingly to decide that either defendant or one of the co-conspirators purposely murdered the deceased.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for aggravated murder with a specification.

 

127 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Buckeye Ware, Inc. v. Arnold


No. 77-1086


Supreme Court of Ohio


54 Ohio St. 2d 164; 375 N.E.2d 420; 1978 Ohio LEXIS 540; 8 Ohio Op. 3d 158



May 3, 1978, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED BY the Court of Appeals for Wayne County.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, the Chief of the Ohio Division of Elevator Inspection, Department of Industrial Relations, sought review of the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Wayne County (Ohio), which granted appellee conveyor company's request for a declaratory judgment that the company's conveyors were not elevators under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4105.01(A).


OVERVIEW: The Division prohibited the use of the company's conveyor units, for which the company never secured an installation permit. The company's conveyors were lifting and lowering devices which rose at an angle of 70 degrees from the horizontal. The trial court determined that the Division lacked jurisdiction over the conveyors and permanently enjoined the Division from interfering with their use. The appellate court affirmed the trial court's judgment and certified the case to the court as the judgment was in conflict with another decision from a different appellate court. On appeal, the issues concerned the use of the words "vertically or substantially vertically," and whether they modified the phrase "other lifting or lowering apparatus permanently installed on or between rails or guides," as those terms appeared in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4105.01. The court held that "substantially vertically" referenced an angle of incline so closely approximating 90 degree from the horizontal as to be essentially and fundamentally vertical itself. The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment and held that the conveyors were not elevators under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4105.01(A).


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment.

 

128 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Curtis


No. 77-715


Supreme Court of Ohio


54 Ohio St. 2d 128; 375 N.E.2d 52; 1978 Ohio LEXIS 536; 8 Ohio Op. 3d 121



April 26, 1978, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

On the afternoon of May 11, 1975, Suzanne L. Candler's body was found in a wooded area at the Galbraith Road exit off Interstate 75 in Cincinnati. Her clothing was in disarray. There was evidence of recent sexual intercourse and there were .38 caliber gunshot wounds in her body. Her car, a Ford Maverick, was parked along the expressway. The evidence showed that Suzanne, age 19, had been enroute from Cincinnati to visit her family in Lima. It was Mother's Day and Suzanne left at about 5:30 a. m., as she planned to attend church that morning with her family.

Based on information derived from their investigation of the apparent homicide, on May 12, 1975, the Cincinnati police obtained a warrant to search the premises at the residence of the defendant, James T. Curtis. The search warrant included defendant's car as an item to be seized, together with a .38 caliber revolver, and certain personal effects of the deceased. At about 5:00 p. m. on that day, defendant was arrested as a suspect in the homicide. Pursuant to the warrant, the police searched defendant's home and found the victim's purse. They also recovered [***2] a .38 caliber revolver from the trunk of defendant's car, which was parked in the driveway at his residence. Ballistic tests revealed that defendant's gun fired the bullets which killed Suzanne Candler. At the police station, the victim's ring and watch, as well as four spent .38 caliber casings, were discovered when defendant emptied his pockets. All of these items were introduced in evidence at defendant's trial.

Testimony at trial established that between 3:30 to 3:45 a. m. on the morning of the homicide the defendant was observed by police officers in the area where the deceased's car was parked. Another witness, Miss Patricia G. Chitwood, testified that she was driving south on Interstate 75 in the area of the homicide at about 4:15 to 4:30 a. m. on that morning, and at that time was closely followed for about 10 miles by the defendant, who was driving a vehicle resembling a police cruiser but which had no emblem. She testified that defendant stopped her by means of a red flashing light and represented that he was a police officer. He took her driver's license and suggested that she accompany him to his car, which she did. After remaining in the car for some time, she [***3] apparently became suspicious, grabbed her license, returned to her car, and drove away. She promptly reported the incident to the police. On or about May 12, 1975, Miss Chitwood appeared at the police station where she identified defendant as the person who had stopped her vehicle on the morning of the murder. No motion to suppress her identification was made, nor was there any objection to the identification at trial.

The defendant filed a notice of alibi prior to trial and presented the testimony of an alibi witness, Glenn Sullivan, that he and the defendant had been drinking at various bars on the night in question; the witness stated that he was with the defendant until about 4:00 a.m. The defendant testified that he had been a private security officer. He denied any knowledge of the incident and claimed that he had the deceased's personal effects because the deceased and he were having an affair. He stated that she had given him the ring, that he had her watch to get it repaired and that he discovered that she had left her purse in his car. There was no corroboration of the latter's testimony.

The jury returned a verdict of guilty of aggravated murder with specifications,  [***4] finding that the murder was committed during the perpetration of an aggravated robbery and rape.

Thereafter, the trial court, at a mitigation hearing, found that no mitigating circumstances were established and sentenced the defendant to death.

The conviction of defendant was appealed to the Court of Appeals which affirmed the judgment of the trial court. An appeal as of right has been taken to this court.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Court of Appeals, Hamilton County (Ohio) affirmed a trial court's judgment convicting defendant of aggravated murder with specifications, finding that the murder was committed during the perpetration of an aggravated robbery and rape. The trial court, at a mitigation hearing, found that no mitigating circumstances were established and sentenced the defendant to death. Defendant appealed.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, defendant contended that the trial court erred in overruling his motion to suppress the evidence of a revolver found in the trunk of defendant's automobile. The court affirmed the court of appeals' decision. The court stated that the car was properly seized as an item of evidence pursuant to a valid search warrant. Thus, the car was lawfully in the custody of the police to be used as evidence in the subsequent trial. The court found, in response to defendant's contention that the Ohio scheme for imposing the death penalty was unconstitutional, that sufficient standards were provided to comply with constitutional mandates against cruel and unusual punishments. Defendant's final contention was that the trial court erred in that its finding of no mitigating circumstances was based on cursory psychiatric examinations. The court found that, although there was a conflict of medical opinion, there was ample evidence to find that defendant was not psychotic or mentally deficient so as to entitle the trial court to conclude that none of the mitigating circumstances had been established by a preponderance of the evidence.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the court of appeals' decision affirming defendant's conviction for aggravated murder with specifications and the trial court's sentencing of defendant to death.

 

129 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Cincinnati Gas & Electric Co. v. Pope


No. 77-695


Supreme Court of Ohio


54 Ohio St. 2d 12; 374 N.E.2d 406; 1978 Ohio LEXIS 526; 8 Ohio Op. 3d 7



April 5, 1978, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

In February 1975, Cincinnati Gas & Electric Company and The Dayton Power & Light Company (hereinafter appellees) filed petitions for appropriation, pursuant to R. C. 163.05, naming appellants, Earl and Dolores Pope, Edwin and Dolores O. Pope, and Edith Pope, as owners of three contiguous parcels of property located in western Hamilton County. By these complaints appellees sought to acquire an easement across appellants' properties, for the purpose of constructing a high-voltage electric transmission line. 1 


1 The three cases were consolidated for trial and have been consolidated for the purpose of appellate review by both the Court of Appeals and this court.

The cases were tried to the Court of Common Pleas of Hamilton County during several days in September 1976, and January 1977. On January 18, 1977, the trial court entered an oral opinion, finding that appellees were entitled to appropriate the easements which they sought. Subsequent to this ruling, but prior to an assessment of compensation by a jury, as provided for in R.C. 163.14, 2 appellants filed notices of appeal. Appellees filed a motion to [***2] dismiss the appeal, and on May 3, 1977, the Court of Appeals granted said motion.


2 R.C. 163.14, in pertinent part, provides as follows:

"In appropriation proceedings the jury shall be sworn to impartially assess the compensation and damages, if any, without deductions for general benefits as to the property of the owner.

"The jury, in its verdict, shall assess the compensation for the property appropriated and damages, if any, to the residue, to be paid to the owners. * * *

"The verdict shall be signed by at least three-fourths of the members of the jury.

"If a jury is discharged without rendering a verdict, another shall be impaneled at the earliest convenient time and shall make the inquiry and assessment."

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant landowners challenged the decision of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which, pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 163.09(B), dismissed their appeal from an adverse determination that appellee utility companies were entitled to appropriate three parcels of land to acquire an easement for the purpose of constructing a high-voltage electric transmission line.


OVERVIEW: The landowners' argued that the legislature could not limit the power or the right of appellate courts to review judgments of the courts of common pleas, and that any such legislative attempt was unconstitutional. On review, the court affirmed the decision. The court found that under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2505.03, every final order, judgment, or court decree could be reviewed, unless otherwise provided by law. The court found that the legislature had otherwise provided by law in stating that a trial court's order in favor of the appropriating agency on the preliminary questions was not immediately appealable. The statutory scheme contemplated that the landowners could obtain appellate review only after the preliminary issues were decided by the trial court, a jury assessed compensation, and a journal entry was made. Only after a judgment was entered were all the rights of the parties adjudicated. There was no inherent right of appeal from a judgment of a court, and such right could only be conferred by constitution or statute. Because the legislature had the constitutional authority to make such a decision, the landowners' argument was rejected.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals and remanded the cause to the trial court for an assessment of compensation.

 

130 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Coca-Cola Bottling Corp. v. Lindley


Nos. 77-580, 77-591, 77-595, 77-596


Supreme Court of Ohio


54 Ohio St. 2d 1; 374 N.E.2d 400; 1978 Ohio LEXIS 525; 8 Ohio Op. 3d 1



April 5, 1978, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Board of Tax Appeals.

During 1972, each of the appellants -- Scott & Fetzer Company; Cook United, Inc.; Heinen's, Inc.; and the Coca-Cola Bottling Corporation -- filed corporate franchise tax reports and paid franchise taxes on income earned in 1971. They used the net income method of calculating franchise tax liability provided for in R. C. 5733.05. On December 31, 1975, this court, in Lakengren v. Kosydar (1975), 44 Ohio St. 2d 199, held that the application of the net-income measure of franchise tax liability in R. C. 5733.05 to income earned during a fiscal year ending before December 20, 1971, was retroactive and unconstitutional. Within 90 days of the announcement of the Lakengren decision, each of the appellants filed for a refund of the difference between what it paid in franchise taxes in 1972 under the R. C. 5733.05 net income measure of liability and what it would have paid under the net worth measure of liability that had been in effect prior to the enactment of R. C. 5733.05. The Tax Commissioner dismissed the claims for the requested refunds on the grounds that, because appellants had not claimed them within three years after [***2] paying their corporate franchise tax, he did not have jurisdiction pursuant to R. C. 5733.12 to grant them. Appellants appealed to the Board of Tax Appeals.

In each case the board declined, on jurisdictional grounds, to decide the constitutional issues raised by appellants. It also held that R. C. 5733.12 clearly sets forth a statute of limitations of three years, and it affirmed the determination of the Tax Commissioner.

The causes are now before this court upon appeals as of right from the Board of Tax Appeals.



DISPOSITION: Decisions affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayers sought review of decisions of the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which affirmed appellee Tax Commissioner's determination to dismiss their claims under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5733.12 for a refund of franchise taxes on income earned in 1971 because they had not claimed the refund within three years after paying the taxes. The Board declined, on jurisdictional grounds, to decide the constitutional issues raised by the taxpayers.


OVERVIEW: On December 31, 1975, the Ohio Supreme Court held that the application of the net-income measure of franchise tax liability in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5733.05 to income earned during a fiscal year ending before December 20, 1971 was retroactive and unconstitutional. Each taxpayer then filed for a refund of the difference between what it paid in franchise taxes in 1972 under § 5733.05 and what it would have paid under the measure of liability that had been in effect prior to the enactment of § 5733.05. The Commissioner dismissed their refund claims and the Board affirmed. The court affirmed the Board. The language of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5733.12 was clear. The taxpayer had three years after payment, and 90 days after ascertainment that a payment was illegal, in which to request a refund. Further, the three-year deadline was absolute. Section 5733.12 was not retroactive as applied to the taxpayers because, while it decreased their refund filing period, it did not destroy an accrued right or change the legal significance of, or place new obligations upon, their past conduct. Finally, the application of § 5733.12 did not violate the taxpayers' equal protection and due process rights.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decisions of the Board of Tax Appeals.

 

131 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Columbus v. Teater


No. 77-540


Supreme Court of Ohio


53 Ohio St. 2d 253; 374 N.E.2d 154; 1978 Ohio LEXIS 524; 7 Ohio Op. 3d 410



March 29, 1978, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] This action was originally brought against the former Director of the Department of Natural Resources, William B. Nye.


PRIOR HISTORY: APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

The instant controversy originated in the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County. The following matters were agreed to before that court by the parties:

Appellant is the duly qualified and appointed Director of the Department of Natural Resources of the state of Ohio, and appellee is a chartered municipal corporation organized and existing under the Constitution and laws of this state;

Pursuant to R. C. Chapter 1501, appellant may designate any watercourse in this state to be a wild, scenic, or recreational river area, which in appellant's judgment possesses water conservation, scenic, fish, wildlife, historic, or outdoor recreational values which ought to be preserved. Appellant has determined that Big Darby Creek is to be designated a Scenic River Area from a point near a covered bridge on Old State Route 38 in Madison County, southward for approximately fifty-three and eight-tenths miles along said watercourse to its confluence with the Scioto River. The above-referenced portion of [***2] Big Darby Creek qualifies as a Scenic River Area pursuant to R. C. 1501.16. Appellant has manifested his intent to designate this portion of Big Darby Creek a Scenic River Area and has so notified appellee;

Appellee provides its inhabitants with water supply facilities and services, and in so doing operates a public utility. Appellee has instituted a program for the construction, operation and maintenance of a new water supply reservoir to be located on Big Darby Creek within the area proposed by appellant for designation as a Scenic River Area. Appellee has appropriated portions of the necessary funds for this water supply program and has expended certain of these funds in acquisition of land and in feasibility studies in furtherance of the program;

The construction of the water supply reservoir will cause a modification of the channel of Big Darby Creek and will result in the erection of structures on the Big Darby Creek within the proposed Scenic River Area.

In addition to the facts stipulated, it is undisputed that the instant controversy originally was instituted because appellant, on or about February 6, 1974, notified appellee's mayor of appellant's intent to journalize [***3] the determination that the Big Darby Creek meets the criteria for designation as a scenic river pursuant to the provisions of R. C. Chapter 1501. The area is outside appellee's present corporate boundaries.

The Court of Common Pleas declared R. C. 1501.17 violative of the Constitution of Ohio. Upon appeal by the Director to the Court of Appeals for Franklin County, the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas was affirmed.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of appellant's motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, the Director of the Department of Natural Resources of the State of Ohio, challenged the decision of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio) that affirmed a trial court decision that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1501.17 violated the Ohio Constitution, in an action challenging enforcement of the law brought by appellee city.


OVERVIEW: Under § 1501.17, the department declared a stream to be a Scenic River Area that was protected from development. At the same time, the city was attempting to build a water supply reservoir along the stream in an area outside its municipal boundaries. The trial court declared § 1501.17 violative of the Ohio Constitution. The appeals court affirmed. On further appeal, the court held that the authority enjoyed by municipalities under Ohio Const. art. XVIII could not be extinguished by the general assembly. Nevertheless, under appropriate facts, the power possessed by the general assembly under Ohio Const. art. II, § 36 could override the interest of a city in constructing water supply impoundments located outside its corporate limits. Courts were to determine the facts in such controversies, balance the rights of the state against those of the municipality, and endeavor to protect the respective interests of each. Whether the law was constitutional as applied would be determined by the facts and circumstances of the case. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1501.17 was not facially violative of Ohio Const. art. XVIII, § 3, 4, 5, 6, or 7.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appeals court's decision.

 

132 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Adams


No. 77-493


Supreme Court of Ohio


53 Ohio St. 2d 223; 374 N.E.2d 137; 1978 Ohio LEXIS 519; 7 Ohio Op. 3d 393



March 29, 1978, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

Eugene L. Adams, appellant herein, was indicted in Franklin County for aggravated robbery and aggravated murder in a two-count indictment. The first count of the indictment charged appellant and one Thomas D. Deal with violating R. C. 2911.01, in attempting or committing a theft offense as defined in R. C. 2913.01 while having a deadly weapon on or about their persons or under their control. The second count charged appellant and Deal with purposely causing the death of Marlyn J. Darst while committing, attempting to commit, fleeing immediately after committing or attempting to commit aggravated robbery, with a specification under R. C. 2929.04(A)(7), in compliance with R. C. 2941.14, that the offense was committed while the offenders were committing, attempting to commit or fleeing immediately after committing aggravated robbery.

At appellant's trial, the evidence established that Marlyn J. Darst, while working at a carry-out store, was shot twice and died as a result of those wounds. There was evidence that money had been taken from the cash register of the store.

Rena Darst, the ten-year old daughter of the deceased,  [***2] testified that on the night of the crime, having heard "something like a bang," she entered the store which her mother had been tending, and saw her mother lying on the floor kicking at a man with a gun, who was wearing a stocking pulled over his head. She saw him shoot her mother twice. Rena failed to identify the appellant at trial, but there was other testimony that the appellant had changed the style and color of his hair since the date of the crime. She did pick his photograph from a group of six pictures shown to her by a policeman a few days after the crime.

At the trial, she identified a certain jacket as the one worn by the man with the gun. Two other witnesses testified that that same jacket was the one the appellant was wearing on the night of the crime.

Three witnesses saw the assailant get into a waiting car, and all three descriptions of the car agree. David A. West testified that on the day before the crime he rode to Lake Erie in a car that matched the eyewitness descriptions, with his uncle Tommy Deal, with the appellant, and with Margaret Etter, who is now Deal's wife. (Deal is charged in the same indictment with the defendant, and the state maintains that [***3] he drove the get-away car.) Having spent the night at the lake, West and the others returned to Columbus in the evening of the next day. West testified that after they reached Columbus, the appellant "said something about hitting a place on High Street." The store where the deceased was killed is on South High Street in Columbus. Deal and the appellant then left West and Margaret Etter at the home of West's sister and departed again. West testified that the two men returned shortly, and that he heard the appellant admit that he had shot a woman three times. Margaret Etter testified that the appellant was pale and nervous when he returned to the house with Deal, and that when she asked, "Why did you shoot the woman," he answered that it was because she had kicked him. West's sister also testified that she heard the appellant admit to shooting a woman. Later the same night, Margaret Etter, West and Deal took the appellant to Cincinnati. Etter testified that during the ride she again asked why the appellant had shot the woman, and that he repeated that it was because the woman had kicked him, and that he had said there had been a child present at the time.

West testified that,  [***4] after leaving the appellant near Cincinnati, Etter, West and Deal returned to Lake Erie "to go get an alibi." Upon the group's return to Columbus, as soon as they stopped their car in front of West's home, the Columbus police arrested Deal, searched the car, and found a gun under the seat. The parties stipulated that the state's ballistics expert would testify that the fatal bullets removed from the body of the deceased were fired from that gun.

Appellant was tried to a jury, which returned a verdict of not guilty on the charge of aggravated robbery contained in count one of the indictment, and a verdict of guilty of the charge of aggravated murder contained in count two of the indictment. Appellant was subsequently sentenced to death.

Upon appeal, the Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas and the cause is now before this court upon appeal as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of an order from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which affirmed defendant's conviction for aggravated murder.


OVERVIEW: While robbing a carry-out store, defendant shot and killed the store's clerk. The clerk's child witnessed the robbery and murder. Defendant fled, and two friends took him to another city in an attempt to establish an alibi. During the ride, defendant admitted to his friends that he had shot the clerk. When the friends arrived at home, police arrested them and discovered the murder weapon in a search of the car. Defendant was arrested and charged with aggravated robbery and aggravated murder. The jury convicted defendant only on the murder charge, and the conviction was affirmed on appeal. Defendant sought review. The court found that the capital punishment statutes were not unconstitutional, that defendant lacked standing to seek suppression of the gun on the ground it was obtained without a warrant because defendant was not present when the gun was seized, that the conviction of just the murder charge was not an inconsistent verdict, that there was no error in the trial court's replacement of two jurors, and that it was harmless error for evidence of defendant's prior conviction to be admitted.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's decision.

 

133 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Wade


No. 77-716


Supreme Court of Ohio


53 Ohio St. 2d 182; 373 N.E.2d 1244; 1978 Ohio LEXIS 513; 7 Ohio Op. 3d 362



March 22, 1978, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Trumbull County.

On December 29, 1975, a robbery occurred at the Austin Beverage Store in the Austin Village Plaza in Trumbull County. During the occurrence, both of the employees then present, Dominic Chiarella and Frederick C. Piersol, were shot by one of the two robbers. Chiarella died of his bullet wounds, and Piersol was seriously wounded.

Later that evening, police officers, acting upon information concerning the robbery suspects received from a service station attendant, stopped an automobile bearing the license plate number furnished by the attendant. A search of the occupants, Pompie Junior Wade (appellant) and Moses Hurd, and the automobile revealed 13 or 14 .32 caliber bullets. a shotgun in plain view on the back seat, a .32 caliber revolver, a ski mask (all of which were identified at the trial as being similar to the items used in the robbery), and sundry food items of the brands carried by the Austin Beverage Store.

Thereafter, appellant was indicted by the Trumbull County grand jury for the crimes of aggravated murder with specifications, attempted aggravated murder and aggravated robbery.

On March 3, 1976, a suppression [***2] hearing was held and resulted in a finding by the trial court that appellant's admission to the robbery and shooting of the two employees of the Austin Beverage Store was voluntarily given and therefore admissible.

A jury trial was commenced, and, on March 17, 1976, the jury returned a verdict of guilty on all three counts charged in the indictment. The trial court, failing to find any mitigating circumstances, sentenced appellant to death on the aggravated murder conviction, in accordance with the statutory mandate, and to two consecutive sentences of from seven to twenty-five years on the other two convictions.

Appellant's motion for a new trial being overruled, he appealed to the Court of Appeals which affirmed his conviction.

The cause is now before this court as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged a decision from the Court of Appeals for Trumbull County (Ohio), which convicted him of aggravated murder with specifications, attempted aggravated murder, and aggravated robbery.


OVERVIEW: During a robbery, two convenience store clerks were shot. A short time later, a service station attendant spotted a suspicious vehicle. He called police and gave them a description. When the vehicle was stopped, several items used in the robbery were found in the car. Defendant later admitted to his role in the robbery. After his motion to suppress was denied, defendant was convicted. In affirming, the court determined that prospective jurors should not have been asked about their views on capital punishment on a questionnaire. However, defendant failed to make a timely challenge to the array, pursuant to Ohio. R. Crim. P. 24(E). In addition, certain remarks made by the prosecutor during closing argument were not inflammatory, nor did they prejudice defendant's rights. The court held that certain comments made by the judge were not prejudicial to defendant's rights. Further, defendant failed to make an objection during the trial. In the instances where defendant did object, he failed to show that there was any possibility of prejudice arising from those occasions. Finally, defendant failed to file his motion to suppress in the time mandated by Ohio R. Crim. P. 12(C).


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's convictions.

 

134 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Barker


No. 77-296


Supreme Court of Ohio


53 Ohio St. 2d 135; 372 N.E.2d 1324; 1978 Ohio LEXIS 505; 7 Ohio Op. 3d 213



February 22, 1978, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Greene County.

Karen Miller (decedent) was employed by a photographic processing company, called Foto Fair. On the evening of October 24, 1974, the decedent telephoned her mother and asked her to come to the Foto Fair booth to accompany her home. The decedent had been frightened by a dark-haired man who had been there that evening. Mrs. Miller went to the booth, and she and her daughter left for home at approximately 8:30 p. m. Upon their arrival, the decedent was hailed by a voice from the street. Inquiring as to the identity and receiving a reply ending in "y" or "ie," according to Mrs. Miller, the decedent proceeded to the street, and Mrs. Miller entered the house. Shortly thereafter, Mrs. Miller noticed a car in the street and signaled to the decedent to come in. Mrs. Miller next heard a door slam and, looking out again, saw the car was gone.

Neighbors of the Millers, walking home, heard the car door slam and then saw a car traveling in their direction at a high speed without its headlights turned on.

After unsuccessfully attempting to locate the decedent, Mrs. Miller reported to the police, at approximately 10:00 p. m.,  [***2] that her daughter was missing. Shortly thereafter, the decedent's body was found on a bridge on Kemp Road in Beavercreek Township, Greene County, with a bullet hole through the head and neck and exhibiting evidence suggestive of a sexual assault.

Subsequent to his confession to the Greene County sheriff's department, on January 3, 1975, the grand jury returned an indictment of aggravated murder with specifications, charging Kenneth Ray Barker (appellant) with purposely causing the death of Karen Miller "while committing kidnapping or rape or while fleeing immediately after committing kidnapping or rape."

Appellant, after the rejection of his motion for a change of venue and motion for suppression of evidence, was brought to trial by a jury on March 31, 1975. On May 8, 1975, the jury returned a verdict of guilty of aggravated murder with all three specifications.

Thereafter and in accordance with R. C. 2929.03, a sentencing hearing was held. The trial judge, not finding any mitigating circumstances, imposed the required death penalty.

Appellant's motion for a new trial was considered and overruled at a hearing held on August 7, 1975.

Appellant then appealed his conviction [***3] and sentence to the Court of Appeals, which affirmed on January 13, 1977.

This cause is presently before the court as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The jury convicted defendant of aggravated murder with specifications. The trial court, not finding any mitigating circumstances, imposed the required death penalty. Defendant's motion for a new trial was overruled. The Court of Appeals for Green County (Ohio) affirmed the conviction and sentence. Defendant appealed as a matter of right.


OVERVIEW: The court found that defendant's confession and its fruits were properly admitted in evidence because (1) the police advised him of his constitutional rights under Miranda; (2) he was legally arrested with probable cause; and (3) the totality of the circumstances supported the conclusion that the confession was not induced by duress or other improper influences and was voluntary and admissible. The court also held that (1) the record had no indication that the consent to the taking of a hair sample was involuntary; (2) the showing of only one photograph to the identifying witness was not impermissibly suggestive; (3) the reversal of one specification was not reversible error; (4) the doctor's testimony that bruises in the vaginal area of the victim indicated force was not erroneously admitted; (5) the testimony of the State's rebuttal witness was not improper; (6) the admission of an altered exhibit, the victim's brassiere, was not an abuse of discretion; (7) defendant's claim that due to drugs he was unable to form the purpose to murder was raised for the first time on appeal and was correctly disregarded; and (8) the death penalty did not constitute cruel and unusual punishment .


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for aggravated murder with specifications.

 

135 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Long


No. 77-174


Supreme Court of Ohio


53 Ohio St. 2d 91; 372 N.E.2d 804; 1978 Ohio LEXIS 499; 7 Ohio Op. 3d 178



February 15, 1978, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County.

A bill of indictment was filed against appellant, Donnie Long, charging him with aggravated murder. Appellant's trial to a jury commenced on February 24, 1976.

At trial, the evidence was that during or around the last two weeks of August, 1975, Terence C. Butler had been attacked by appellant and that in the course of their brawl appellant said to a bystander, "Give me a pistol because I'm going to kill this nigger." Butler testified that on the day that decedent, Jeffrie C. Boyd, was killed, Butler and Boyd went to a crap game at a pool hall and appellant was there.

Butler stated that when he saw appellant walk through a door, Butler and Boyd attempted to depart. Appellant pulled a gun from his pocket, aimed at Butler and began firing. Boyd and Butler dived through a doorway, at which point Boyd fell to the floor, blood pouring from his head. Appellant left the scene, having fired approximately six shots in a span of four seconds.

Butler admitted that at one juncture he had threatened appellant's life, owned numerous guns and at one time before Boyd's killing had stalked appellant with a shotgun. Appellant [***2] testified that the killing occurred while he was defending himself. His evidence of self-defense was his own testimony that he had not seen either Butler or Boyd in the pool hall on the day of the killing until the incident at issue. He testified that Butler and Boyd stepped to opposite sides of the room, the latter attempting to hide a bottle behind his back. According to appellant, Butler and Boyd then closed in upon him and Boyd raised the bottle when he was two feet away. Appellant stated that Butler reached for his pocket and that appellant then drew his own gun, intending to fire into the air. Appellant testified that when he fled the pool hall, he feared pursuit by Butler and Boyd.

At trial, testimony was taken from officer Ronald A. Perella, of the Akron Police Department.
