Officer Perella testified that he had arrived at the scene of the Boyd shooting to protect it, to prevent persons inside the pool hall from leaving and to keep persons outside the pool room from entering; he testified that he saw no loose bottles lying on the floor in the area where people had been about.

On March 3, 1976, appellant was found not guilty of aggravated murder, but guilty of the lesser [***3] included offense of murder. On March 16, he was sentenced to serve an indeterminate sentence of 15 years to life.

On December 22, 1976, the Court of Appeals for Summit County affirmed appellant's conviction, and the cause is now before us pursuant to our allowance of appellant's motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from the order of the Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio), which affirmed his conviction for murder.


OVERVIEW: The supreme court held the trial court erred in instructing the jury that defendant bore the burden of proving the affirmative defense of self-defense by a preponderance of the evidence, this being in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2901.05(A). However, pursuant to Ohio R. Crim. P. 30, a party could not assign as error the giving or the failure to give instructions unless he objected thereto before the jury retired to consider its verdict. Defendant conceded that he failed to object to the giving of the erroneous instruction. Further, a jury instruction violative of § 2901.05(A) did not constitute a plain error or defect under Ohio R. Crim. P. 52(B) unless, but for the error, the outcome of the trial clearly would have been otherwise. The record in the instant cause did not meet this criterion. The court held the trial court did not deny defendant his right to cross-examine a state witness concerning the witness's interest and bias. The record showed that defense counsel was afforded an aggressive cross-examination of this witness and was able to impeach his credibility despite the limitation on cross-examination. Thus, any such error was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt.


OUTCOME: The supreme court affirmed the appellate court's judgment.

 

136 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Welch


No. 77-320


Supreme Court of Ohio


53 Ohio St. 2d 47; 372 N.E.2d 346; 1978 Ohio LEXIS 490; 7 Ohio Op. 3d 128



February 1, 1978, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Athens County.

Defendant, Nina Welch, was charged in the Athens County Municipal Court with disorderly conduct, in violation of R. C. 2917.11, for recklessly causing "inconvenience, annoyance or alarm to another by making offensively coarse utterance, genture [sic] or display."

Following defendant's plea of not guilty on November 15, 1974, a hearing was held in Municipal Court on November 25, 1974, at the conclusion of which the case was continued without a judgment. The transcript of the proceeding shows that, subsequently, on March 25, 1975, "the defendant, having failed to appear," the court found defendant guilty and sentenced her.

On appeal, the Court of Appeals affirmed.

The allowance of defendant's motion to certify the record brings the cause to this court.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and cause remanded.

 

137 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Neer v. Industrial Com.


No. 77-622


Supreme Court of Ohio


53 Ohio St. 2d 22; 371 N.E.2d 842; 1978 Ohio LEXIS 483; 7 Ohio Op. 3d 64



January 18, 1978, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

The relator, Tressa Neer, sought a writ of mandamus in the Court of Appeals ordering the Industrial Commission to consider her appeal with respect to the denial of her claim for death benefits filed as a result of the death of her husband in 1971 by reason of silicosis. The Cleveland Regional Board of Review had found relator's claim to be barred by the time-limitation provisions contained in R. C. 4123.68(X). * 


* The provision for an eight-year limitation upon claims on account of silicosis is now contained in R. C. 4123.68(Y).

Relator contended in the Court of Appeals that the time-limitation provisions of R. C. 4123.68(X) were unconstitutional as being a denial of due process of law and equal protection of the laws.

The Court of Appeals, in sustaining a motion to dismiss filed by the respondent, stated, in part:

"From the complaint, it appears that the claim has not been determined by the respondent but is pending before it. Accordingly, relatrix primarily seeks a declaratory judgment as to the constitutionality of R. C. 4123.68(X). This court has no original jurisdiction in declaratory judgment.  [***2] It might be proper to join the claim for declaratory judgment with that for mandamus in the Common Pleas Court which has original jurisdiction in both declaratory judgment and mandamus. However, such joinder is not proper in this court which has no original jurisdiction to render a declaratory judgment."

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.

 

138 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Toth


No. 77-217


Supreme Court of Ohio


52 Ohio St. 2d 206; 371 N.E.2d 831; 1977 Ohio LEXIS 488; 6 Ohio Op. 3d 461



December 28, 1977, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Licking County.

On June 24, 1975, Donald Steven Toth, appellant herein, was indicted by the Licking County Grand Jury for the crime of aggravated murder, with the specification that he "* * * did unlawfully and purposely and with prior calculation and design, cause the death of Terri Singleton * * *," in violation of R. C. 2903.01(A).

Appellant plead not guilty and not guilty by reason of insanity to the charges in the indictment. Following a sanity hearing, the court found, on July 21, 1975, that Toth was sane and competent to be tried.

On the evening of June 4, 1975, Patricia J. Zinck, age 19, Terri L. Singleton, age 20, and Kathy Roseculp, age 20, decided to visit the Toy Box Bar, located in Union Township, Licking County, Ohio. They arrived there around 10:00 p. m. Upon entering the bar, Patricia left the group to go to the restroom, and upon rejoining her friends, saw the appellant sitting at the bar next to Terri. The girls left the bar around 10:30 p. m. because the appellant was bothering Terri.

The girls then set out by car to the Rock Palace, located about one mile away from the Toy Box Bar, only to again encounter the appellant.  [***2] While Kathy and Patricia were standing near the juke box, the defendant was seen approaching Terri, who continued to ignore him. The girls thereupon left the Rock Palace and returned to the Toy Box Bar. They arrived there around 1:00 a. m. on the morning of June 5, 1975.

Meanwhile, shortly before 1:00 a. m. that same morning, Orin G. Noyes saw the appellant trying to repair his car on the corner of the parking lot next to the Rock Palace and the main road. Noyes, in assisting the appellant, found that the car's headlights were connected to the wrong terminals, and repaired them. Noyes heard the appellant say that he would "waste" those responsible for "messing" with his headlights.

The appellant then returned to the Toy Box Bar and began to argue with the three girls concerning his headlights. Patricia denied that the girls did anything to his car, and asked that the appellant leave them alone.

Shortly thereafter, the appellant reached into his pants and pulled out a gun. The gun fell to the floor. The appellant picked up the gun, fired and missed. He then grabbed Patricia by the hair, held the gun to her jaw, and fired. Taking two more steps he shot Terri, and from two [***3] to four more steps shot Kathy.

Terri Singleton later died in a Columbus hospital on June 9, 1975. Doctor George A. Gressle, the coroner for Licking County, testified at the trial that Terri died of a pulmonary embolism directly caused by the gunshot wound.

Laura Jean Toth, one of the two witnesses for the defense, who was apparently the common-law wife of the appellant, testified on direct examination that she had been in the company of the defendant on the afternoon of June 4, 1975. She stated that, despite the fact that the appellant had drunk about a fifth of Bacardi rum (less two shots) that afternoon, he was not drunk when he left their trailer home around 10:00 p. m. that night. She stated, however, that upon his return home between the hours of 1:00 and 1:30 a. m. the next morning, the defendant was "* * * staggering all over the place, falling over furniture * * * mumbling and not making any sense * * *." She stated that when the appellant entered the trailer he told her not to ask any questions, that he did not want to hurt her, and that he wanted to park his car somewhere away from the trailer. He also had a gun and loaded it. According to Mrs. Toth, the appellant [***4] then undressed himself and went to bed.

Upon cross-examination of Mrs. Toth, it was learned that the Toth trailer was located about 8 or 9 miles from the Toy Box Bar (a one-way trip took 25 minutes to complete over five separate routes); that upon the defendant's returning home early on the morning of June 5, 1975, he stated to her that if anyone asked about him, she should reply that she had not seen him for two weeks; that, before retiring for the night, the defendant placed a gun under his pillow; and that, about a week and a half before the crime, the defendant had hit her on the face during an argument.

The following medical opinions were rendered concerning the issue of whether the appellant was insane at the time of the commission of the crime.

Doctor Allen Sherrow, a psychiatrist, called as a witness for the defense, testified in answer to a hypothetical question, that in his opinion, the appellant was temporarily insane at the time of the crime, which condition was induced by a combination of drugs and alcohol. He testified further in response to this question, that at the time of the crime, the appellant was severely impaired in terms of judgment, that he had major problems [***5] in terms of thinking, and in terms of being able to negotiate, that in his condition he was extremely paranoid and suspicious, that he was unconscious to the extent that his judgment would be severely clouded, and that he suffered a black out, in terms of remembering as opposed to functioning.

On the other hand, Doctor Dwight D. Palmer, the court-appointed psychiatrist, testified that at the time of the crime the appellant was sane, and testified further in answer to a similar hypothetical question as given to Doctor Sherrow, that in his opinion, at the time of the crime, the appellant was not blacked out, that he knew what he was doing, and that he suffered from a personality disorder of the anti-social type.

The following, additional evidence was provided the jury on the issue of whether the appellant was intoxicated at the time of the crime.

Orin G. Noyes testified that while assisting the appellant with his headlights minutes before the appellant returned to the Toy Box Bar, he noticed that the appellant was logical in his speech, and not staggering or "falling all over himself." Noyes noted that the appellant was angry about his headlights.

Steven H. Eichorn, the owner of [***6] the Toy Box Bar, testified that the appellant ordered a drink when he was in the bar around 4:30 p. m. on June 4, 1975, that he remained there about 45 minutes, and that upon his return to the bar early in the morning of June 5, 1975, he showed no signs of intoxication, such as a staggered walk.

Alfred C. Mazalic, who witnessed both the altercation between the girls and the appellant, and the ensuing shots of fire, observed that the appellant demonstrated no physical difficulties either in his speech or walk.

Sergeant Gerald Eddington testified that upon apprehending the appellant at home around 4:08 a. m. on June 5, 1975, he observed that there was no odor of alcohol whatsoever about the appellant's person, that his speech was clear, and that his ability to walk was very good. Sergeant John Swick also observed that at 5:00 a. m. the appellant spoke very plainly.

Trial before a twelve-member jury commenced on August 21, 1975. In its instructions to the jury, the court, in effect, directed that the appellant had the burden of proving the defense of insanity and of establishing his claim of disabling intoxication by a preponderance of the evidence. On August 27, 1975, the jury [***7] rendered a guilty verdict as to the charge and specification made in the indictment.

A mitgation hearing was conducted on November 17, 1975, whereupon the court found that the appellant failed to establish any of the mitigating factors set forth in R. C. 2929.04 by a preponderance of the evidence, and imposed the sentence of death upon the appellant.

The trial court granted appellant a hearing on his motion for new trial, and found that the jury verdict as rendered on August 27, 1975, was sustained by sufficient evidence and not contrary to law.

The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment of conviction and sentence.

The appeal is now before this court as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an appeal as a matter of right, defendant sought reversal of the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Licking County (Ohio), which affirmed both his conviction for aggravated murder in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2903.01(A) and the sentence of death.


OVERVIEW: Defendant suspected three young women of tampering with the headlights on his automobile. Stating that he would waste the person responsible for messing with his car, he entered a bar where he shot all three women, one of whom later died. On appeal of his death sentence he argued that the trial judge improperly instructed the jury on the defense of insanity, that the murder was not aggravated because it was not committed with prior calculation and design, and that he was improperly required to prove a statutory mitigating factor at sentencing in order to avoid the death penalty. In affirming the conviction, the court held that the error in instructing the jury on insanity was not prejudicial where all the witnesses who observed defendant before, during, or after the crime, except his common law wife, testified that he showed no signs of intoxication or drug influence. There was sufficient substantial evidence in the method of shooting the three women and the statement about wasting someone to prove that defendant acted with prior calculation. The sentence of death was reversed, however, because it was error to impose the burden of proving a mitigating factor on defendant.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the intermediate appellate court affirming defendant's conviction for aggravated murder. The sentence of death was reversed and the case was remanded to the trial court for further proceedings.

 

139 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Depas v. Highland Local School Dist.


No. 77-156


Supreme Court of Ohio


52 Ohio St. 2d 193; 370 N.E.2d 744; 1977 Ohio LEXIS 485; 6 Ohio Op. 3d 421



December 21, 1977, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Medina County.

The instant cause arises out of the nonrenewal of appellant Chris Depas' contract as principal for the Sharon Elementary School, Medina County, Ohio. In the spring of 1974, Depas signed a one-year limited contract with appellee, the Board of Education of the Highland Local School District, to serve as principal for the Sharon Elementary School. When Depas' contract came up for renewal in the spring of 1975, the board unanimously voted not to reemploy him as a principal. The board did, however, employ Depas as a classroom teacher for the 1975-1976 school year. Depas received written notice of the board's decision not to renew his limited contract as a principal prior to April 30, 1975.

Depas then filed a complaint in the Court of Common Pleas of Medina County challenging the board's decision. The board's subsequent motion for summary judgment and affidavits from both parties were referred by the trial court to a referee. The court accepted the referee's recommendation and granted the board's motion for summary judgment.

Depas appealed that decision to the Court of Appeals upon the following assignments of error:

"I. The [***2] trial court erred in accepting the referee's recommendation and in entering summary judgment for the appellee Board of Education.

"II. The trial court erred in concluding that appellee's nonrenewal of appellant's teaching contract without adhering to its duly adopted employment policies did not unconstitutionally deprive appellant of continued employment with the appellee board."

The Court of Appeals found that the assignments of error "overlapped," considered them together and affirmed the trial court's judgment.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of appellant's motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant employee sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Medina County (Ohio), which affirmed a trial court decision granting appellee school board's motion for summary judgment in the employment action.


OVERVIEW: The employee, a former school principal, brought an action against the school board after his contract was not renewed as a principal. The court of common pleas granted summary judgment in favor of the school board and the appellate court affirmed. The court affirmed. The court noted that the requirements of procedural due process applied only to the deprivation of interests encompassed by the Fourteenth Amendment's protection of liberty and property. While one of those property interests was an interest in continued employment, an employee must have had a legitimate claim of entitlement to continued employment. In the absence of statutory or contractual guarantees of continued employment, one claiming a protected property interest had to produce rules or mutually explicit understandings that supported his claim of entitlement to the benefit. The court found that the employee had not shown that he was entitled to continued employment by the school board.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court.

 

140 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Brown v. Galbraith


No. 77-113


Supreme Court of Ohio


52 Ohio St. 2d 158; 370 N.E.2d 477; 1977 Ohio LEXIS 480; 6 Ohio Op. 3d 374



December 14, 1977, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

This is an original action in which the Attorney General seeks to have this court order respondent Judge Harold H. Galbraith to enforce R. C. 2743.70. The cause is before this court upon an agreed statement of facts.

Relator alleges that respondent, as the Judge of the Vandalia Municipal Court, has a mandatory legal duty under R. C. 2743.70 to impose the sum of three dollars as costs (in addition to any other court costs he is required by law to impose) in all cases in which a person is convicted of or pleads guilty to any offense other than a traffic offense that is not a moving violation, but that respondent has refused to do so.

Relator also alleges that respondent Patricia Dresser, as the Clerk of the Vandalia Municipal Court, has a mandatory legal duty under R. C. 2743.70 to transmit these same costs to the Treasurer of State, but that she has refused to do so.

On September 29, 1976, Judge Galbraith declared R. C. 2743.70 to be unconstitutional in State of Ohio v. Marc F. Grilliott (unreported, case No. 27559A). The court's "entry" shows that case to have been a routine traffic offense, in which the court sustained an oral defense motion not to impose [***2] the three dollars in court costs for the reason that H. B. No. 82 (the Victims of Crime Act, effective September 29, 1976, which includes R. C. 2743.70) was unconstitutional, without specifying the reasons for such decision.

The parties agree that notice of the court's ruling in Grilliott was given to the Vandalia City Attorney, who did not appeal, but that relator and his staff did not have knowledge of the court's decision.

Since declaring R. C. 2743.70 to be unconstitutional, Judge Galbraith has not imposed the three dollars in court costs in any other case, and, consequently, respondent clerk has been unable to transmit these costs to the Treasurer of State.



DISPOSITION: Writ allowed.

 

141 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Malloy v. Westlake


No. 76-1361


Supreme Court of Ohio


52 Ohio St. 2d 103; 370 N.E.2d 457; 1977 Ohio LEXIS 472; 6 Ohio Op. 3d 329



December 7, 1977, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

Appellants are firemen employed by the city of Westlake, appellee herein. Prior to November 1, 1972, appellants accumulated one and one-fourth "days" (each day equalling 8 hours) per month of sick leave. If a fireman missed work for a "day" (which involved a 24 hour shift), he used only one "day" (8 hours) of sick leave. However, in 1972, the appellee converted all unused sick leave of the appellants from a daily basis to an hourly basis, to be retroactively applied from November 1, 1969. The appellee, in effect, reduced all unused sick leave earned by the appellants after November 1, 1969, by two-thirds. Furthermore, from and after November 1, 1969, appellants were charged with 24 hours of their accumulated sick leave if they were absent from a normal day's work due to illness.

The appellants filed a declaratory judgment action in the Court of Common Pleas of Cuyahoga County, claiming, inter alia, that the city acted without authority in reducing previously accumulated and unused sick leave earned by the firemen and in improperly interfering with appellants' vested rights.

Motions for summary judgment were subsequently [***2] filed by both parties. In their motion, appellants contended, in part, that the city deprived them of a vested right contrary to Section 28, Article II of the Ohio Constitution and that, under R. C. 124.38 and Section 34, Article II of the Ohio Constitution, the city had no authority to restrict the right of its employees to accumulate unused sick leave benefits. The appellants did not serve the Attorney General with a copy of their declaratory judgment action as required by R. C. 2721.12.

In ruling on the motions, the trial court held that although the appellants were entitled to reinstatement of their unused sick leave benefits as they existed prior to November 1, 1969, the appellee could constitutionally place a limit on the accumulation of those benefits.

Upon appeal by both parties, the Court of Appeals dismissed the appeals, holding that the trial court's judgment was void and of no effect, since the appellants failed to serve a copy of the declaratory judgment proceeding upon the Attorney General as required by R. C. 2721.12.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of appellants' motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant employees sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio) that dismissed their action against appellee city challenging the constitutionality of a city ordinance because appellants failed to serve a copy of the declaratory judgment proceeding upon the Attorney General as required by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2721.12.


OVERVIEW: The lower court dismissed a declaratory judgment action brought by appellant employees against appellee city challenging the constitutionality of a city ordinance, based on the fact that appellants failed to serve a copy of the declaratory judgment proceeding upon the Attorney General as required by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2721.12. Appellants sought review, alleging that Ohio R. Civ. P. R. 4, which did not require special service upon the Attorney General, superseded the special service requirement of § 2721.12. Upon review, the court affirmed. It noted that by employing the verb "shall" throughout § 2721.12, the General Assembly manifested a clear intent that the statute's provisions, including service upon the Attorney General, were mandatory. Accordingly, in such a declaratory judgment action challenging the constitutionality of an ordinance, declaratory relief was precluded where the Attorney General was not served a copy of the proceeding as required under the statute at issue.


OUTCOME: The dismissal of appellant employees' declaratory judgment action against appellee city challenging the constitutionality of a city ordinance was affirmed because appellants failed to effect service upon the Attorney General as required by statute.

 

142 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Downs


No. 77-75


Supreme Court of Ohio


51 Ohio St. 2d 47; 364 N.E.2d 1140; 1977 Ohio LEXIS 438; 5 Ohio Op. 3d 30



July 13, 1977, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Fairfield County.

On August 9, 1975, Steven R. Bailey, Connie S. Hodgman and her daughter Tracy L. Hodgman, were shot and killed in a remote area of southern Fairfield County. Each victim was shot three times with a sixteen gauge shotgun with at least one shot being at point blank range to the head. Connie Hodgman was also stabbed four times in the chest with a knife.

Although the prosecution presented 32 witnesses to prove the defendant's guilt, most of the evidence consisted of testimony by Virginia Browning, a girl friend of the defendant, and by Mr. Ronald Byers, a friend of the defendant. Their testimony established that the defendant, Charles Edward Downs, was well acquainted with the three victims. Bailey and Hodgman had rented a small house in a very remote area of southern Fairfield County. The defendant, Byers and Browning had often visited the Bailey residence. Apparently, Bailey and the defendant were dealers in marijuana.

Approximately two months prior to the date of the homicides, the defendant had given Bailey some money to buy marijuana. Bailey apparently cheated the defendant out of his money. Angry about the loss,  [***2] the defendant suspected Bailey of duplicity. He made several statements to other people that if "* * * he found out for sure Bailey had taken his money, he [would] kill him * * *."

On the date of the crime, August 9, 1975, the defendant was living in Lancaster, Ohio, with Virginia Browning. Ronald Byers visited the defendant on the morning of August 9, 1975, to borrow some money. The defendant indicated that he had no money to loan. He requested Byers to drive the defendant into the country to check on some marijuana patches.

At approximately 11:00 a. m. on August 9, Byers drove the defendant and Browning to a remote part in southern Fairfield County to check on the marijuana patches. The defendant discovered that someone had taken his marijuana plants. He was very angry. In the presence of Browning and Byers, he accused Bailey of taking the plants. He then said that he was going to kill Bailey, Bailey's girl friend and her child. The three then drove back to the defendant's apartment in Lancaster.

After having eaten lunch, the defendant removed a shotgun and a box of shotgun shells from his bedroom. Mr. Thomas O'Roarke, a friend visiting the defendant at this time,  [***3] saw the defendant, Byers and Browning, leave in Byers' car around noon on August 9, 1975. O'Roarke did not know what the defendant planned to do.

Browning testified that while driving to the Bailey residence, the defendant and Byers talked about various ways the defendant could stealthily approach the homestead. It was decided that they would go around by a back road which would allow the defendant to approach the Bailey home from the rear.

When the defendant got out of the automobile he removed all articles of personal possession from his pockets except his handkerchief, so that he would not drop any incriminating evidence. The defendant took a knife from the car. Defendant told Byers to pick him up in two hours. The defendant warned Browning not to tell anyone about his intentions or he would kill her.

Byers drove Browning back to the defendant's apartment. After picking up his wife and dropping her off at a friend's residence, he then returned to meet the defendant at the aforementioned rendezvous. Upon arriving at the car, the defendant had blood on his pants and shoes. The knife was also covered with blood. The defendant then told Byers that he had shot Bailey, Connie [***4] Hodgman and the little girl.

While driving back to the defendant's apartment, the defendant threw some spent shotgun shells out of the car window. Two of those shells were later found and matched with two other shells found at the scene of the crime. When the two men arrived at the residence, the defendant took the shotgun and shells into the apartment. Byers then left to pick up his wife.

When the defendant entered the apartment, Browning and O'Roarke were waiting. After O'Roarke left the apartment, the defendant told Browning that he had killed Bailey and Connie and Tracy Hodgman. The defendant indicated that he was going to get rid of the gun by burying it. Prior to leaving his apartment, he burned the shotgun shell box in the shower. The defendant then left with the gun. The gun was never found.

Later that same night, August 9, 1975, Browning, the defendant and Byers all went to another friend's apartment for a party. According to Byers' testimony, the defendant remarked that he had disposed of the gun, but had forgotten to get rid of the knife.

The next day, the defendant went to his sister's residence for a Sunday afternoon dinner. The defendant showed the knife [***5] to one of his brothers. Accompanied by his brother, the defendant then went to a cemetery behind his sister's residence. After wiping the knife with a handkerchief, he threw both the knife and the knife case into the cemetery. Only the knife case was later recovered. Byers identified the case as the one he had given to the defendant on the day of the killings.

On Monday afternoon, August 11, 1975, Browning's mother told the sheriff's office about the killings. The defendant was arrested and indicted on three counts of aggravated murder, with the specification in each count that the killings were a part of a course of conduct involving the purposeful killing of two or more persons. R. C. 2929.04(A) (5).

At the trial, ballistics experts matched the two shotgun shells which were found along the road at a place indicated by Byers with the shells which were found near the bodies of Bailey and Connie Hodgman.

The state introduced evidence to prove that the defendant had owned a 16 gauge shotgun and that the shotgun had been in the defendant's possession when he had left the apartment just prior to the commission of the three murders. The state also established that previous troubles [***6] had existed between Bailey and the defendant and that the defendant had threatened to kill Bailey, Connie and Tracy.

The defendant offered no defense.

The jury found the defendant guilty of all counts of the indictment. Following a mitigation hearing, the court sentenced the defendant to death. The Court of Appeals affirmed both the conviction and the sentence.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Fairfield County (Ohio), which affirmed his conviction for three counts of aggravated murder and his sentence of death.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was indicted on three counts of aggravated murder, with the specification that the killings were a part of a course of conduct involving the purposeful killing of two or more persons. Following a mitigation hearing, defendant was sentenced to death. Defendant claimed that the capital sentencing procedure violated constitutional due process because it required an offender to prove certain mitigating circumstances by a preponderance of the evidence in order to be sentenced to life imprisonment, rather than to death. The court held that although Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2929.03(E) placed the burden of the risk of non-persuasion during the mitigation hearing upon the offender, it did not impose an unconstitutional burden. The court also held that the trial court had properly appointed a psychiatrist to make a presentence report and was not constitutionally required to appoint an additional psychiatrist of defendant's choosing at state expense. The court further held that the police officer's failure to return the search warrant to the properly designated judge and to prepare an inventory did not render inadmissible the evidence seized pursuant to the warrant.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's judgment of conviction and the death sentence imposed thereon.

 

143 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Weind


No. 76-1128


Supreme Court of Ohio


50 Ohio St. 2d 224; 364 N.E.2d 224; 1977 Ohio LEXIS 408; 4 Ohio Op. 3d 413



June 22, 1977, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

This cause concerns the involvement of the defendant, James Kenneth Weind, in the abduction and murder of Hermalee Ross on December 15, 1974. * Weind was charged with the following counts: (1) kidnapping ( R. C. 2905.01); (2) aggravated murder ( R. C. 2903.01[A]), in that he purposely and with prior calculation and design, caused the death of Hermalee Ross; and (3) aggravated murder ( R. C. 2903.01[B]), in that he purposely caused the death of Hermalee Ross while committing, attempting to commit, fleeing immediately after committing, or attempting to commit, kidnapping. Included in counts two and three were the specifications that the murder was committed during a kidnapping ( R. C. 2929.04[A][7]) and for hire ( R. C. 2929.04[A][2]).


* This court has already affirmed the judgments and sentences of appellant's co-defendants, Mrs. Alberta Osborne, in State v. Osborne (1976), 49 Ohio St. 2d 135, and Carl Osborne, in State v. Osborne (1977), 50 Ohio St. 2d 211.

 [***2] Subsequent to the jury finding of Weind's guilt as to all the charges and specifications, a mitigation hearing was held on April 14, 1975. The court on June 20, 1975, having found none of the mitigating factors listed in R. C. 2929.04 to have been established by a preponderance of the evidence, imposed the sentence of death on the defendant with respect to count three and the sentence of from 7 to 25 years imprisonment on the defendant with respect to count one.

On July 16, 1975, an appeal was taken to the Franklin County Court of Appeals, which court affirmed the defendant's conviction and sentence.

The evidence adduced at trial implicating the defendant in this abduction and murder is set forth in the opinion which follows.

The cause is now before this court as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which convicted defendant of kidnapping and two counts of aggravated murder. Included were specifications that the murder was committed during a kidnapping and for hire. Finding no mitigating factors listed in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2929.04 to have been established by a preponderance of the evidence, the trial court's sentence included the death penalty.


OVERVIEW: Among other assertions, defendant challenged the constitutionality of Ohio's death penalty, the finding of insufficient mitigating factors, the failure to have defendant reexamined by psychiatrists to establish a mental deficiency or psychosis, the denial of a continuance, discovery misconduct, and the calling of a witness by the trial court. The court upheld the convictions and sentences. Ohio's scheme for establishing mitigating factors, including judicial sentencing, was approved in decisional law. Ohio R. Crim. P. 11(C)(3), which allowed a trial court to dismiss specifications if defendant pled guilty to a charge, was constitutional and did not have chilling effect on the right to plead not guilty. The record supported the trial court's determination that defendant was not acting under duress, coercion, or strong provocation. The possibility of a psychosis was not enough to support a finding of a mitigating circumstance. The denial of a continuance was unavailing in the absence of a showing of prejudice. There was no abuse of discretion shown in the trial court's handling of discovery irregularities. The practice of a trial court calling a witness was lawful.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

144 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Taft v. Campanella


No. 77-454


Supreme Court of Ohio


50 Ohio St. 2d 242; 364 N.E.2d 21; 1977 Ohio LEXIS 409; 4 Ohio Op. 3d 423



June 22, 1977, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

On November 22, 1976, the Board of County Commissioners of Cuyahoga County (board) adopted two resolutions, a "Purchase and Lease Resolution" and a "Bond Resolution." The Purchase and Lease Resolution provides that Cuyahoga County (county) will acquire the existing facilities of Deaconess Hospital of Cleveland (hospital). The resolution authorizes the improvement of the facilities and a leaseback of those facilities to the hospital.

The Bond Resolution authorizes the issuance of $ 26 million of Cuyahoga County hospital-improvement first-mortgage revenue bonds to finance the acquisition and improvement of the hospital facilities. This resolution provides for the pledge of, and a lien on the hospital receipts for payment of, the bonds, and authorizes an indenture of mortgage providing for the payment of the debt service charges on the bonds and for securing such payments. Upon retirement of the bonds, the hospital may purchase the facilities at a nominal cost.

The Purchase and Lease Resolution also provides that approximately $ 10.6 million of the proceeds from the sale of the bonds will be used to retire and release the [***2] existing first mortgage on the hospital property so that a new first mortgage can be placed on such property.

The board concluded in the Purchase and Lease Resolution that the acquisition and improvement of the hospital and the leasing of the facilities would better provide for the health and welfare of the residents of the county by enhancing the availability, efficiency and economy of hospital facilities. Thus, the objectives of the resolution would promote the public purposes stated in R. C. 140.02.

Upon receipt of the resolutions, the Cuyahoga County Auditor, appellant herein, advised the board by letter that, although he did not question that the county might properly issue hospital revenue bonds under R. C. Chapter 140 to provide approximately $ 16 million for the proposed construction and remodeling of existing facilities or that the county could use revenue bond proceeds to purchase existing hospital facilities, he did specifically question the use of the $ 10.6 million, to retire the existing debt of the hospital, as a proper public purpose. The auditor then refused to perform the duties specified in the resolutions, to draw drafts or warrants pursuant to R. C. 319.16,  [***3] 321.12 and 321.15, or to certify the availability of funds in accordance with R. C. 5705.41(D).

On December 21, 1976, the board and the hospital, appellees herein, initiated an action in mandamus in the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County, seeking to have the auditor directed to perform the necessary actions to permit the issuance of the hospital revenue bonds and apply the proceeds from the sale of such bonds.

Appellant in his answer to the complaint maintains that because the issuance of the bonds would not promote a public purpose, as required by R. C. 140.02, he has no duty to perform pursuant to the resolutions.

On March 28, 1977, the Court of Appeals allowed the writ of mandamus.

The cause is now before this court upon appeal by the auditor as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant county auditor sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which granted mandamus relief to appellees, a county board and a hospital, in their action pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 140.02. The board and the hospital sought to have the auditor directed to perform the necessary actions to permit the issuance of the hospital revenue bonds and apply the proceeds from the sale of such bonds.


OVERVIEW: The board adopted two resolutions, which provided for the purchase and lease of a hospital and its facilities. The board concluded that the acquisition and improvement would assist in promoting better health and welfare of the residents of the county by enhancing the availability, efficiency and economy of hospital facilities. Thus, the board contended the objectives of the resolution promoted the public purposes stated in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 140.02. The auditor specifically question the use of the money to retire the existing debt of the hospital, as a proper public purpose. The auditor then refused to perform the duties specified in the resolutions, to draw drafts or warrants, or to certify the availability of funds. The appellate court's grant of mandamus relief was affirmed. The court reasoned the determination of whether a use of bonds constituted a public purpose was primarily the function of the board, as the bond issuing authority, and was subject to being overruled only if manifestly arbitrary or unreasonable. The court concluded the board's findings were based on reliable and uncontroverted evidence and was not manifestly arbitrary or unreasonable.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court.

 

145 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Jackson


No. 77-147


Supreme Court of Ohio


50 Ohio St. 2d 253; 364 N.E.2d 236; 1977 Ohio LEXIS 411; 4 Ohio Op. 3d 429



June 22, 1977, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

According to a statement given by appellant to Cincinnati police (tape recorded and entered into evidence at trial below), appellant Jerry Jackson and Curtis Palmore, at approximately 7:45 p. m. on November 14, 1974, approached the service station where Charles Pomerantz was working. Appellant and Palmore intended to rob the attendant at the station. While appellant deliberately diverted the attention of Pomerantz from Palmore, to facilitate the robbery, Palmore shot Pomerantz. Palmore then removed Pomerantz's wallet from his pocket, and when the two left the scene they took the wallet and the service station money box with them.

Palmore's father testified that on November 18, 1974, he found a library card and a driver's license, both bearing the name of Charles Pomerantz, among his son's personal effects. He turned the items over to Cincinnati police officers, and testified at trial that on the evening of November 14, 1974, appellant and Palmore had conversed in the latter's house, and that the two had departed the house together before 8:00 p. m.

Cincinnati detective Frank Sefton testified that appellant's statement [***2] of November 19, 1974, was taken while appellant was in custody, and that Sefton already had told appellant that the police had two witnesses to the Pomerantz crime who could identify a suspect. Sefton testified that he already had played appellant a recording in which Curtis Palmore named appellant as Pomerantz's killer. Sefton also had told appellant that Curtis had named appellant as the party who had taken the service station cash box.

On December 6, 1974, the Hamilton County Grand Jury returned a two count indictment, with a specification as to the first count, jointly charging appellant and Palmore with aggravated murder and aggravated robbery. Appellant waived his right to trial by jury and a three judge panel found him guilty as charged. On September 11, 1975, the panel unanimously found that none of the mitigating circumstances in R. C. 2929.04(B) had been established by a preponderance of the evidence, and sentenced him to a term of from seven to twenty-five years for his aggravated robbery offense, and to death for his aggravated murder offense. On December 13, 1976, the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County affirmed appellant's conviction.

The cause is now before this [***3] court as a matter of right, pursuant to Section 2(B)2(a)(ii) of Article IV of the Constitution of Ohio.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was convicted of aggravated murder and aggravated robbery. The Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio) affirmed his conviction. Defendant appealed.


OVERVIEW: Defendant, along with a codefendant, was accused of robbing and killing a service station attendant. He argued that a statement he made while in custody should have been suppressed because officers played him a recording in which the codefendant had implicated him, informed him that two witnesses could identify him, and showed him evidence identifying him as a suspect, thereby making his statement involuntary. The court rejected the argument. It stated that defendant had been properly advised of his constitutional rights and that his confession was voluntarily initiated by defendant himself. Next, the court held that because there was evidence from which the trial court could have found defendant's confession to be voluntary, the fact that the State did not call as a witness each officer who participated in defendant's interrogation was not a basis for reversal under the "missing witness" rule. Finally, the court rejected defendant's argument that his death sentence was arbitrary because defendant's offer to plead guilty to the murder charge in exchange for the imposition of a life sentence was not accepted.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the court of appeals' decision.

 

146 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Hall v. Rosen


No. 76-971


Supreme Court of Ohio


50 Ohio St. 2d 135; 363 N.E.2d 725; 1977 Ohio LEXIS 390; 4 Ohio Op. 3d 336



June 8, 1977, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

In June 1973, Patricia Hall (appellee) filed a complaint on behalf of herself and Lisa Renee Ross, her minor child, alleging that John J. Rosen (appellant) is the father of Lisa Renee, and seeking future support and reimbursement for necessaries furnished the child in the past.

Appellee claims that she met appellant in 1968 and they began to associate almost daily. At this time, appellee was single, being previously divorced from Jerry G. Ross. Appellant contends further that she and appellant engaged in sexual relationships in Chicago during July of 1968, resulting in the conception of Lisa Renee.

On February 6, 1969, appellee married her former husband, Jerry G. Ross, who was fully aware of her obvious pregnancy. Lisa Renee was born on May 6, 1969. The birth certificate bears Ross' name as the father. Appellant does, however, admit to sending funds to cover the hospitalization cost, as well as sending intermittent payments for support, and to visiting appellee and her child.

Thereafter, Ross filed for a divorce. The decree granting the divorce was entered on May 20, 1970. The decree determined, inter alia, that [***2] the child born during the marriage was "not issue of the marriage."

The trial court granted appellant's motion for summary judgment, finding that there was no genuine issue of material fact and that, as a matter of law, appellant was entitled to the judgment. Appellee filed a motion for reconsideration. Relying on Miller v. Anderson (1885), 43 Ohio St. 473, the trial court overruled the motion.

On appeal, the Court of Appeals reversed the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas and remanded the cause for further proceedings not inconsistent with its opinion.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of appellant's motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant biological father challenged the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which reversed existing precedent and held that the father was liable to appellee mother for the support of the child born during the mother's marriage to another man. The issue before the court was whether the rule that the husband was solely responsible for the support of any child born during the marriage would continue to be the law.


OVERVIEW: The mother became pregnant by the biological father but before the birth re-married her ex-husband; all parties knew that the husband was not the father of the child. A year later the husband and the mother divorced and the divorce decree declared that the child was "not the issue of the marriage." When the mother sought support from the biological father, the trial court granted the father's motion for summary judgment on the grounds that binding precedent declared that when the husband married the mother knowing that she was pregnant by another, the husband became the only party liable for the child's future support even after a divorce. The intermediate appellate court reversed, holding that the historical precedent was out-of-date and needed to be set aside. The court on review rejected the appellate court's reasoning, reaffirmed the trial court's holding, and emphatically reinstated the established rule of law that decreed the husband in marrying the mother while pregnant with another man's child had "adopted" the child and by promissory estoppel, stare decisis, and for social policy reasons had become solely liable for the child's support.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the intermediate appellate court, reaffirmed the ruling of the trial court, and held that the mother of the child could not bring a child support action against the biological father of the child but could only proceed against her former husband for the child's support.

 

147 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Associated Adjusters of Ohio, Inc. v. Ohio Dep't of Ins.


No. 76-1086


Supreme Court of Ohio


50 Ohio St. 2d 144; 363 N.E.2d 730; 1977 Ohio LEXIS 391; 4 Ohio Op. 3d 341



June 8, 1977, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

On June 20, 1973, the Department of Insurance (appellee) rejected the applications of Earl Shipper, Gerald T. Phillips and Associated Adjusters of Ohio, Inc., to become certified public insurance adjusters in Ohio. Subsequently, the applicants filed with appellee their requests for adjudication hearings, as provided by R. C. 119.06 and 119.07.

A consolidated hearing of the three cases was held on August 13, 1973, at which time the hearing officer received briefs from the applicants and from appellee. Over the objection of the applicants, the hearing officer permitted five certified Ohio public insurance adjusters, Morris I. Atkin, John A. Donovan, Robert Sill, James Triplett and Arthur F. Westfall, to intervene and file a brief opposing the certification of the applicants.

On March 27, 1974, the hearing officer announced his findings of fact, conclusions of law, and recommendations. With regard to the individual applicants, the hearing officer found that neither Shipper nor Phillips was an Ohio resident. He therefore recommended that the individual applicants be denied certificates of authority to act as public insurance [***2] adjusters.

With regard to the corporate applicant (hereinafter Associated Adjusters), the hearing officer found that although Associated Adjusters was duly incorporated in Ohio, the individual applicants, Shipper and Phillips, were its only officers and directors, and that the corporate stock was owned entirely by nonresidents. The hearing officer therefore concluded that Associated Adjusters was not a resident of Ohio, and recommended that it be denied a certificate of authority to act as a public insurance adjuster.

After review of all the evidence, the Superintendent of Insurance concurred with the findings of fact and conclusions of law of the hearing officer. All three applicants then filed notices of appeal to the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County, pursuant to R. C. 119.12. The Court of Common Pleas consolidated the appeals, and on August 1, 1975, rendered a decision overruling all assignments of error proposed by the applicants.

On September 22, 1975, Associated Adjusters filed its notice of appeal to the Court of Appeals for Franklin County. No such notice of appeal was filed in the case of the individual applicants. The Court of Appeals, on July 29, 1976, rendered [***3] its decision, affirming the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas as to Associated Adjusters.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of Associated Adjusters' motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant corporate applicant challenged an order of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), affirming an order holding that appellant was not entitled to a certificate of authority to act as a public insurance adjuster, pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 3951.02 and 3951.06(D).


OVERVIEW: Appellee department of insurance rejected the applications of two individuals and appellant corporation to become certified public insurance adjusters in Ohio. A hearing officer concluded that the individual applicants were not Ohio residents and therefore were not entitled to certificates of authority, pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3951.06(D). He further concluded that while appellant was duly incorporated in Ohio, the individual applicants were its only officers and directors and that the corporate stock was owned entirely by nonresidents. He recommended that it be denied a certificate as well. The superintendent of insurance concurred. The applicants appealed, but the court overruled all proposed assignments of error. Appellant alone challenged the court's order, but the intermediate court affirmed. The appellate court also affirmed. It held that the individual applicants had attempted to circumvent the statutory residency requirement by incorporating their enterprise in Ohio and, therefore, the court disregarded appellant's fictitious corporate entity. The court also rejected appellant's challenge to the constitutionality of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3951.06(D).


OUTCOME: The appellate court affirmed the lower courts' order holding that appellant corporate applicant was not entitled to a certificate of authority to act as a public insurance adjuster where the court held that the corporate officers had attempted to circumvent the statutory residency requirement by incorporating their enterprise in Ohio, and therefore the court disregarded the fictitious corporate entity.

 

148 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Hawkins v. Ivy


No. 76-883


Supreme Court of Ohio


50 Ohio St. 2d 114; 363 N.E.2d 367; 1977 Ohio LEXIS 386; 4 Ohio Op. 3d 243



May 18, 1977, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

Appellant, Laura B. Hawkins, brought an action against appellee, Michael L. Ivy, in the Cuyahoga County Court of Common Pleas, seeking damages as the result of an automobile collision. At the close of appellant's case, the trial court granted appellee's motion for a directed verdict.

The Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County affirmed the judgment of the trial court and the cause is now before this court upon the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant driver sought review of an order from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed the judgment of the trial court granting appellee car owner's motion for a directed verdict. The driver brought an action against the car owner seeking damages as the result of an automobile collision.


OVERVIEW: The car owner left his stalled car in a lane of traffic on a dark, wet night and departed for a gas station. The driver collided with the rear of the car owner's car and was injured. On appeal, the court found that the car owner's conduct was more than simple negligence. The court determined that with full knowledge of the surrounding circumstances, his reckless and inexcusable disregard of the rights of other motorists would support a finding of wanton misconduct. The court held that should a jury determine that the car owner's behavior and the surrounding circumstances were as described at trial, a finding of wanton misconduct would be appropriate. The court concluded that where the driver of an automobile failed to exercise any care whatsoever toward those to whom he owed a duty of care and his failure occurred under circumstances in which there was great probability that harm would result, such failure constituted wanton misconduct. The court held that the driver's contributory negligence did not bar recovery where it was determined that the damages suffered as a proximate result of the car owner's wanton misconduct.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the appellate court granting the car owner's motion for a directed verdict.

 

149 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Cleveland Classified School Employees Civil Service Asso. v. Board of Education


No. 76-785


Supreme Court of Ohio


50 Ohio St. 2d 31; 361 N.E.2d 1342; 1977 Ohio LEXIS 368; 4 Ohio Op. 3d 85



April 20, 1977, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

On April 4, 1974, plaintiffs, an organization composed of non-teaching employees of the Board of Education of the Cleveland City School District, and a civil service employee, filed a complaint for declaratory judgment, injunction and equitable relief, and a motion for preliminary injunction, in the Court of Common Pleas. In their complaint, plaintiffs allege that R. C. 124.271, which allows provisional civil service employees in certain circumstances to become permanent employees without taking a competitive examination, is unconstitutional in that it is contrary to Section 10, Article XV of the Ohio Constitution. The board of education, the Cleveland Civil Service Commission, and individual members of those organizations, are named as defendants.

The case was submitted to the trial court on the pleadings, stipulations, briefs and oral argument, and the court entered judgment for defendants, upholding the constitutionality of R. C. 124.271. The Court of Appeals reversed and remanded.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, the Board of Education of the Cleveland City School District, the Cleveland Civil Service Commission, and individual Board and Commission members, appealed from a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio) reversing a decision that upheld the constitutionality of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 124.271 and remanding the declaratory judgment and equity action of plaintiffs, an organization and a civil service employee.


OVERVIEW: The organization was composed of non-teaching employees of the Board. The complaint sought a declaratory judgment along with equitable relief. A motion for a preliminary injunction was also filed. Section 124.271 allowed provisional civil service employees in certain circumstances to become permanent employees without taking a competitive examination. Section 124.271 allegedly violated Ohio Const. art. XV, § 10. On review, the court found that because school districts were not mentioned in § 10, its limitations on the power of the General Assembly to enact laws relating to a "appointment and promotions in the civil service" were not applicable to appointments and promotions in the civil service of the city school districts. The General Assembly had the power to enact civil service laws applicable to schools by reason of Ohio Const. art. I, § 7, to encourage schools and the means of instruction. Ohio Const. art. XV, § 10 did not apply to laws relating to civil service appointments and promotions in city school districts. Therefore, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 124.271, insofar as it applied to city school districts and to plaintiffs, was not affected by Ohio Const. art. XV, § 10.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals in favor of defendants.

 

150 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Lockett


No. 76-424


Supreme Court of Ohio


49 Ohio St. 2d 48; 358 N.E.2d 1062; 1976 Ohio LEXIS 772; 3 Ohio Op. 3d 27



December 30, 1976, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County.

On January 15, 1975, Sidney Cohen was shot and killed in his pawn shop, located in downtown Akron. On January 21, 1975, appellant, Sandra Lockett, was indicted by the Summit County grand jury in connection with the Cohen homicide. She was charged with aggravated murder (felony murder), including specifications, and with aggravated robbery.

Appellant, approximately two weeks prior to trial, was offered the negotiated plea of voluntary manslaughter and aggravated robbery if she would cooperate with the state. This plea was rejected.

Prior to commencement of trial, on March 28, 1975, after the state had prepared its case, appellant was offered the negotiated plea of aggravated murder. This, too, was rejected. The offer was renewed on April 1, 1975, the date of trial, and was again rejected by appellant. On April 3, 1975, appellant was subsequently found guilty by a jury, of aggravated murder, with two specifications, and of aggravated robbery. The trial court, upon completion of the statutory requirements, found no mitigating circumstances and sentenced appellant to death, and the Court of Appeals affirmed.

The [***2] cause is now before this court pursuant to an appeal as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was indicted in connection with a homicide. Defendant was convicted by a jury of aggravated murder (felony murder) and aggravated robbery. The trial court, upon completion of the statutory requirements, found no mitigating circumstances and sentenced defendant to death. The Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio) affirmed. Defendant appealed.


OVERVIEW: The victim was shot and killed in his pawn shop. Defendant was repeatedly offered a negotiated plea if she would have cooperated with the state. The court stated that an examination of the record of the voir dire did not reveal that the trial court erred in conducting an insufficient and cursory examination into the opinions and attitudes of prospective jurors on the issue of capital punishment. The court also stated that the evidence clearly established a common plan to use a deadly weapon in the commission of the robbery of the victim as all the participants were aware that an inherently dangerous instrumentality was to be employed to accomplish their felonious purpose. The record contained sufficient evidence upon which a jury could have found a purposeful intent to kill, and the court could not have altered that finding in the absence of evidence tending to rebut or mitigate the existence of that intent.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court, which affirmed defendant's conviction for aggravated murder and aggravated robbery.

 

151 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Lane


No. 76-838


Supreme Court of Ohio


49 Ohio St. 2d 77; 358 N.E.2d 1081; 1976 Ohio LEXIS 774; 3 Ohio Op. 3d 45



December 30, 1976, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County.

On February 28, 1975, Georgene Burse was found dead in her place of business, the Borocki & Burse Florist Shop, located at 1280 Lockwood Road, Coventry Township, Summit County. Mrs. Burse had been shot six times.

On that day defendant-appellant, Stacey Lane, informed several relatives that he planned to rob the florist shop. Earlier, Lane had questioned Richard L. Sturm, a half-brother who had formerly been employed at the florist shop, concerning how many people would be there and how much money would be available.

The appellant went to the shop twice. The first time he did not carry out his plan because other people were present. On the second occasion, just prior to 5:30 p. m., appellant and Sturm drove up to the florist shop. Lane announced his intention to perpetrate the robbery, and then proceeded into the shop. As Sturm got out of the car he heard Mrs. Burse scream. At this point Sturm apparently became frightened and began to flee the area. As he ran, he first heard one shot come from the florist shop; he then heard five more shots in succession.

Later that evening, appellant was observed counting money taken [***2] from the decedent and looking through several credit cards belonging to her. Another half-brother, Rudy P. Trivonovich, asked appellant what had happened. Lane disclosed that, after entering the florist shop and confronting the victim with a gun, she threatened to call the police and turned to walk away. Appellant spun her around and hit her, and then shot her four times in the head, once in the throat and once in the chest.

On May 9, 1975, appellant was indicted and arraigned on charges of aggravated robbery, aggravated murder, and two specifications thereto as follows: (1) The murder was committed to escape detection, apprehension, trial or punishment; and (2) the murder was committed while appellant was committing, attempting to commit, or fleeing immediately after the commission or attempted commission of, an aggravated robbery.

Trial was commenced before a jury on July 21, 1975. At that time the state presented its two key witnesses, Sturm and Trivonovich. The appellant did not present any evidence. On July 24, 1975, the jury rendered its verdict, finding appellant guilty of aggravated robbery, aggravated murder and both specifications thereto.

On September 10, 1975,  [***3] a mitigation hearing was held. The court, finding no mitigating circumstances present, sentenced Stacey Lane to death.

The Court of Appeals overruled all the appellant's assignments of error and affirmed the judgment of the trial court and the cause is now before this court as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment of the Court of Appeals (Ohio), which affirmed his convictions for aggravated robbery and aggravated murder along with his death sentence.


OVERVIEW: The trial court prohibited the questioning of veniremen on their views regarding capital punishment on voir dire because it felt that the charge would be that the jury would not take into consideration any question of punishment in reference to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2929.03(B). On appeal, defendant argued that by restricting voir dire examination on the question of capital punishment, the trial court prevented a venireman's possible partiality to emerge and be met by challenges for cause or peremptory challenges. He alleged that because there may have been members of the jury who were not opposed to the death penalty, those individuals may have been unable to fairly determine guilt. The court disagreed and held that the trial court delivered a preliminary instruction to the veniremen, to the effect that they would consider only the issue of guilt, and further informed them that they would not prescribe the sentence should a guilty verdict be returned. The court determined that no evidence was presented which supported defendant's contention that the possible presence on the jury of one not opposed to capital punishment prevented a fair and impartial determination of guilt.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment convicting defendant of aggravated robbery and aggravated murder, and sentencing him to death.

 

152 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Osborne


No. 76-791


Supreme Court of Ohio


49 Ohio St. 2d 135; 359 N.E.2d 78; 1976 Ohio LEXIS 776; 3 Ohio Op. 3d 79



December 30, 1976, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

On December 15, 1974, the deceased, Hermalee Ross, was abducted by two men from the parking lot of an Ontario food store in Franklin County, and was later found dead with bullet wounds to the back of her head and neck, and to her ear and hand, and with numerous other abrasions and contusions apparently caused by repeated strikings with a blunt instrument.

Robbery was ruled out as the motive since the victim was still wearing her watch and a ring when her body was discovered, and the victim's purse, containing a $ 100 bill, was recovered from two young girls who had found it on the Ontario parking lot. The victim's automobile was also recovered on the Ontario lot.

In the course of the police investigation, it was discovered that the victim's husband, Edgel Ross, and defendant-appellant, Alberta Osborne had been involved in an affair of long standing.

On December 30, 1974, Alberta L. Osborne was indicted on three counts by the Franklin County Grand Jury. The first count charged kidnapping in violation of R. C. 2905.01; the second count charged aggravated murder in violation of R. C. 2903.01(A), with two specifications of [***2] aggravating circumstances, that the homicide was for hire, pursuant to R. C. 2929.04(A)(2), and that the murder was in the course of a kidnapping, pursuant to R. C. 2929.04(A)(7); and the third count charged aggravated murder in violation of 2903.01(B), murder committed in the course of a kidnapping, with the same specifications as listed in the second count.

The state alleged that Carl Edward Osborne, Jr. (appellant's son), James Kenneth Weind, Carl's friend, and appellant, while acting in concert, kidnapped and murdered Hermalee Ross.

Appellant entered a plea of not guilty to all three counts of the indictment and was separately tried by a jury.

Appellant filed a pretrial motion asserting that exhaustive news media coverage of this homicide had attracted intense public interest and that detailed news reports of the results of the police investigation had saturated Franklin County and made it unlikely that a jury could be impaneled which would be able to fairly try the defendant free of the influence of that publicity.

Appellant asserts that such influence was aggravated by the fact that the subpoenas served upon prospective jurors in her case contained her name, and argues that [***3] one must assume that persons thus notified would avidly read all the pretrial newspaper accounts of the matter and thus be particularly aware of evidence and speculation contained therein.

The trial court reserved its ruling until after the voir dire was conducted and then overruled the motion.

At appellant's trial, Delaware County deputies testified that they received a call from Mrs. Dorothy Hale who lived about 150 yards from an abandoned schoolhouse in that jurisdiction. She reported that she had observed two males pull up to the school in a blue-green automobile; that they removed a female, and took her inside; and that a few moments later, the two men left the schoolhouse without the female. The deputies then proceeded to that location and found the deceased's body.

One Lois Berg, who was in a laundromat near the Ontario store at the time of the abduction, testified that she observed a tall, light-skinned black, wearing jeans and a patterned bandana around his head, in the Ontario lot that morning. She testified further that a "commotion" with another person took place, and that a blue-green car with two occupants left the lot.

Photos of appellant's family cars were [***4] shown to Lois Berg and to Mrs. Hale and to her son, who had partially observed the incident. All identified the photo of a blue-green 1969 Plymouth automobile as being the one they had previously seen. It was later shown that the identified automobile belonged to Kay L. Osborne, appellant's daughter.

The bullets retrieved from the victim's body and from the scene of the murder were determined to have been fired from a Raven .25 caliber automatic pistol. One Michael M. Goins, hoping to obtain leniency in an unrelated crime, assisted police in recovering a Raven .25 caliber automatic pistol from Alum Creek in Franklin County. There was expert testimony, based on a ballistics report, that such gun was the murder weapon.

Goins testified that in the early morning hours of December 15, 1974, James Weind, who was with Carl Osborne, Jr., in a car, had purchased a .380 automatic pistol from him. Goins testified further that Weind had thrown the Raven pistol into Alum Creek later on the same day in the presence of Goins and another man.

Kay Osborne testified that her brother Carl and Weind had borrowed her car about 6:00 a. m., on December 15, 1974, and returned it at about 10:00 a.  [***5] m., and that on those occasions Weind was wearing jeans and a dark blue and white bandana. Kay Osborne testified further that she saw her mother go out to Kay's car with a bucket of water. Kay was told to drive her mother's automobile to work because additional cleaning was needed on Kay's car since Weind had become ill in the car.

There was evidence that appellant had new carpeting installed in Kay's car within a few days and had replaced all the tires, as well as evidence that pretrial newspaper articles had reported that a tire print was lifted from the mud outside the schoolhouse where the body was found. The police testified that blood stains had been found on the back of the front seat of Kay's car and on Weind's shoes.

Kay Osborne's further and most incriminating testimony was that her mother had told her some time following the homicide that she was going to lose Edgel Ross because he was leaving her, and that appellant had told her daughter Kay that she had hired her son Carl and his friend Jimmy Weind to kill Mrs. Ross for the sum of $ 325.

Edgel Ross in court admitted to the existence of a five-year clandestine relationship between himself and appellant.

The jury [***6] found Alberta Osborne guilty of kidnapping and of two counts of aggravated murder, with the specification that the homicide was for hire on both counts. However, appellant was found not guilty of the specification that the homicide was done in the course of a kidnapping.

A mitigation hearing was held as required by R. C. 2929.02, 2929.03 and 2929.04. After hearing the testimony of two psychiatrists, appellant's brother, employees of the Columbus Women's Correctional Institution and a missionary who frequented that institution, the trial court found that none of the mitigating circumstances contained in R. C. 2929.04(B) had been established. The trial court then sentenced appellant to death, as required by law.

The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment of the trial court, and the cause is now before this court as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which affirmed her conviction for kidnapping in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2905.01, and two counts of aggravated murder in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2903.01(A), (B), with the specification that the murder was for hire on both counts pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2929.04(A)(2). Defendant was sentenced to death.


OVERVIEW: The jury found that defendant hired her son and his friend to kill the victim, whose husband had been involved in a long-standing affair with defendant. On appeal, the court rejected defendant's assertions of error. Defendant was not denied due process of law or a fair trial because an impartial jury was obtained despite pretrial publicity. Defendant waived her challenge regarding the poor technical quality of the electronic recording of the trial proceedings because she failed to correct and supplement the record. Moreover, the court found that defendant was not prejudiced. Defendant similarly waived her right to challenge the trial court's introduction of extrajudicial statements of an alleged co-conspirator because she failed to timely object. There also was sufficient evidence to establish all of the elements of the crimes, and the trial court complied with Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2941.25(A) because it sentenced defendant on only one of the counts of aggravated murder. The court also rejected defendant's contention that Ohio's mitigating circumstances under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2929.04(B) were unconstitutionally narrow.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction and sentence.

 

153 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Edwards


No. 76-38


Supreme Court of Ohio


49 Ohio St. 2d 31; 358 N.E.2d 1051; 1976 Ohio LEXIS 771; 3 Ohio Op. 3d 18



December 29, 1976, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County.

On December 28, 1974, Joseph Eshack, Jr., was shot and killed at his place of business located at 223 Wooster Avenue, Akron. He was found by the Akron police lying with his face down in the aisle of his storeroom. His business consisted of the sale and rental of used tools.

Prior to the police discovering Eshack, Floyd Edwards met with a friend named Standford Harris. Edwards told Harris that he was going to rob Joseph Eshack. Edwards asked Harris to participate and showed him a gun. Harris consented. Edwards and Harris entered the store and soon thereafter argued with Eshack over the price of various tools scattered over the floor. The last item discussed was a pair of wire cutters, and, as Eshack bent over to pick them up, Edwards pulled the gun from his pocket and demanded Eshack's money. Edwards grabbed Eshack's arm and a struggle ensued. Edwards fired a bullet into the back of Eshack's head. The shot was fatal.

After the shot was fired, Eshack's wallet was taken. It contained some credit cards, identification papers, other miscellaneous papers, and $ 65. The money was divided between Edwards and Harris. The [***2] wallet was later discarded in the basement of a nearby apartment house. Gary Hendon, a maintenance man at the Edgewood Home Apartments, found Eshack's wallet in the basement of one of the apartment buildings. Hendon knew Edwards, and remembered seeing him in that basement two or three days before finding the wallet.

At about 5:30 p. m., on January 9, 1975, Edwards was arrested by two detectives of the Akron police, Harold Craig and Grover Goodwell. Following the arrest, Edwards was taken to the police station to be interrogated. After receiving his Miranda warnings from detective sergeant Russell Cross, defendant made an oral, unrecorded incriminating statement. Also present in the room at the time of that statement were Craig and Goodwell.

At 8:20 p. m., later that day, Edwards, after receiving another explanation of his constitutional rights, gave a tape-recorded statement of his confession in the presence of assistant county prosecutor John Shoemaker, Cross and Goodwell. When the prosecutor flipped the cassette to side two, it did not properly engage. Approximately 75 feet of the tape was blank

At 10:25 p. m., another recorded statement was taken to fill in the blank [***3] 75 feet. Shoemaker again read Edwards his Miranda warnings. Edwards repeated his confession. Also present in the room were Craig, and one Haywood Manning.

Sometime during the interrogation of Edwards the location of the gun was ascertained. A search warrant was drawn and a search of 1125 Inman Court was made.
