Moreover, Flora remarked that, under present conditions, he could not, as a matter of conscience, enroll his children in public school, and that the Tabernacle Christian School is the only school within reasonable travelling distance in which he could, in conscience, enroll his children. Finally, Flora testified that he and his wife "are extremely well pleased with the academic progress of our children" in the Tabernacle Christian School, despite the fact that the school is not chartered by the state or in total compliance with its "minimum standards."

Mrs. Quinn testified that her children are enrolled in the Tabernacle Christian School because of the "moral breakdown in our public schools, and because I feel it is my duty as a parent to give my children the best education possible." In this regard, she stated that her obligations to her children are elucidated in Proverbs 22, verse 6: "Train up a child in the way he should go, and when he is old he will not depart from it." Mrs. Quinn testified further that the Tabernacle Christian School is the only educational institution within reasonable travelling distance of her [***15] home in which she could, consistent with her conscience, enroll her children.

The defense and the state then stipulated that the testimony of the other defendant-parents would be the same as that previously rendered by Rev. Whisner, Mr. Flora and Mrs. Quinn with regard to their view of the Tabernacle Christian School as a religious school, their religious reason for having their children in the school, their knowledge that the school is not one that complies with the minimum standards, and the fact that they feel they cannot enroll their children elsewhere.

Near the conclusion of the trial, the defense presented two expert witnesses, Mr. Ralph O'Neal West and Professor Donald A. Erickson, both of whom testified that they had read and were familiar with the publication, Minimum Standards for Ohio Elementary Schools.

West, the Director of Evaluation for the Commission on Independent Secondary Schools of the New England Association of Schools and Colleges, testified that since 1961 he has spent virtually all his time working on problems of evaluation of non-public schools. With regard to the Minimum Standards for Ohio Elementary Schools, West testified that "there is an apparent failure [***16] in the document to spell out clearly the procedures for a school seeking approval"; that the standards command that "a private school, a non-tax supported school is [be] effectively under the control of the local school board of education for all activities of the school"; "that for non-public schools, non-tax supported schools, there is a severe question on both education [sic] and other grounds for the necessity for certification as a qualification for hiring a person as a teacher in one of these schools"; that "there is an increasing concern over the validity of the selection by the state of text books for schools with diverse educational philosophical * * * goals and purposes"; and finally that, in his opinion, there is no compelling state interest in requiring a non-public school to conform to each of the minimum standards.

Erickson, a professor at the University of Chicago, testified that he has worked extensively in studying non-public education, including the question of what controls should be imposed upon non-public schools. Erickson stated that he is "of the firm position that the state has some farreaching fundamental educational responsibilities," but that "the [***17] state can fulfill all its fundamental responsibilities in education without prescribing how people must be educated; where they must be educated; what kind of buildings they must be educated in; what must be in the program; and what must be the nature of the individual who instructs them." With regard to Ohio's minimum standards, Erickson commented that "I am vastly confused by these standards, and I don't know how I would advise a school administrator to proceed on the basis of that document." He testified further that the standards "go a long way down the road toward obliterating any distinction between public and private education"; that the standards are not neutral in that a philosophy of "secular humanism" is espoused therein; that enforcement of the standards would "in effect take away from the school the right to run its [own] philosophy"; that the school day and curriculum content required by the standards are, educationally, "very close to nonsense"; that there is no apparent reason to impose teacher certification requirements upon non-public schools, although in public education these are "probably a necessary evil, because public education is a massive enterprise"; that [***18] Ohio's minimum standards "are about the weakest way I know of to try to accomplish what they are designed to accomplish, and that is to make schools better"; and that "I don't think the state has any compelling interest at all in requiring schools to live up to the minimum standards in this book as a whole."

Finally, the uncontradicted testimony of Rev. Whisner, Flora and Quinn revealed these appellants to be lawabiding and upright citizens in all respects.

At the conclusion of the trial, defendants moved in writing for acquittal of the charges on the basis that, as applied to them, the compulsory attendance law constitutes:

"First, a violation by the state of the right of the defendants and their children to the free exercise of



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and defendants discharged.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant parents were convicted of failing to send their children to school, as required by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3321.38, in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3321.03. The Court of Appeals for Darke County (Ohio) affirmed the convictions. The parents sought review of the appellate court's judgment.


OVERVIEW: The parents' children attended a nonpublic, religious elementary school. The State alleged that the parents violated § 3321.03 because the school did not conform to the minimum educational standards promulgated by the State's board of education. The parents challenged their convictions on the grounds that the standards infringed upon their right to freely exercise their religion, as guaranteed by U.S. Const. amend. I and XIV and Ohio Const. art. I, § 7. The court held (1) the appellate court erred in questioning whether the parents' beliefs were founded upon religious principles, (2) although the educational standards were facially neutral, they unduly burdened the parents' free exercise rights because they interfered with the school's ability to devote time to the teaching of religious subjects and they required "all activities" of a nonpublic school, including religious activities, to conform to the policies adopted by the board of education, and (3) the standards effectively eradicated the distinction between public and nonpublic education and thereby infringed on the parents' right under U.S Const. amend. XIV to direct the upbringing and education of their children.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the appellate court and ordered that the parents be discharged.

 

165 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Hunt


No. 75-951


Supreme Court of Ohio


47 Ohio St. 2d 170; 351 N.E.2d 106; 1976 Ohio LEXIS 685; 1 Ohio Op. 3d 99



July 21, 1976, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Ross County.

In March 1974, appellant, James Robert Hunt, was indicted by a grand jury for aggravated murder. Appellant is a deaf-mute and, although capable of communicating rudimentarily by universal sign and finger language, is functionally illiterate.

Appellant entered a plea of not guilty and was committed by the Court of Common Pleas to Lima State Hospital for a determination of his mental condition and competency to stand trial. Subsequently, appellant was transferred to Columbus State Hospital for a more thorough examination.

At the close of the competency hearing in August 1974, the court found that appellant was unable to stand trial and that he was not sane. Therefore, the court ordered that he be committed to Lima State Hospital until restored to reason or for a period of two years, whichever occurs first. Additionally, the order directed the authorities at Lima to transfer appellant to an institution or school where his communicative skills could be enlarged.

Appellant's appeal of the order was dismissed by the Court of Appeals on the basis that no final appealable order had been entered by the trial court.

The cause [***2] is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the order of the Court of Appeals for Ross County (Ohio), which dismissed his appeal of the trial court's order that he be committed to the state mental hospital until restored to reason or for a period of two years, whichever was less. The appellate court determined that the trial court order was not a final appealable order.


OVERVIEW: Defendant, a deaf-mute with limited communication skills, was indicted on a charge of aggravated murder. He entered a plea of not guilty, and the trial court committed him to the state mental hospital for evaluation. At the close of the competency hearing the trial court found he was incompetent to stand trial and ordered him committed for two years unless he returned to reason prior to the expiration of the two-year period. The appellate court dismissed his appeal because there was no final order. The court held that the trial court's commitment order was not a final order. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.381 provided the necessary safeguards for review of a commitment order. The trial court did not abuse its discretion in setting a two-year limit on the length of the commitment period. The trial court was under an obligation to prevent the violation of defendant's due process rights by avoiding an unconstitutional indefinite period of commitment, even though it was not statutorily empowered to place limits on the period of commitment. The court did not answer whether a trial court had the authority to set durational limits on confinement under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.38.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

166 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Robinson


No. 75-943


Supreme Court of Ohio


47 Ohio St. 2d 103; 351 N.E.2d 88; 1976 Ohio LEXIS 679; 1 Ohio Op. 3d 61



July 21, 1976, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

The defendant, George Robinson, Jr., was charged with aggravated murder in connection with the shooting death of his nephew, Ronald R. Robinson (hereinafter called "the deceased"), on June 29, 1974. The case was tried to a jury in the Court of Common Pleas on January 27, 1975. There were eight witnesses for the state, eight for the defendant, and three rebuttal witnesses.

The state's first witness, Dr. Emery Van Hamm, testified that the deceased died from a gunshot wound to the head; that the deceased was intoxicated at the time of his death; and that the alcohol's effects were increased by amphetamines. The doctor testified further that the deceased was a large, muscular man about six feet tall, who weighed an estimated 200 pounds. The state's next witness, Detective Dennis Canada, testified concerning his investigation at the scene of the incident, the defendant's home, 227 North Eureka Avenue, Columbus, Ohio. He described state exhibits consisting of pictures of a holster on an upstairs bed, the living room wherein the shooting occurred, and the position of the deceased's body as he found it. Mr. Hermann Motter and [***2] his son David were doing cement work on the porch of defendant's house when the shooting occurred. They testified that the deceased drove a Mustang automobile to the front of the house, parked his car, walked into the defendant's house with a beer bottle in his hand, and later came out and sat on the porch. Both workers stated that they did not pay much attention to the situation, as ordinarily they ignored people who were drinking. However, they testified that subsequently they heard someone say, "If you don't get out of here, I'll shoot you." Officer David Morris testified that the inventory of the deceased's pockets disclosed no weapons.

Officer Bruce Morgan described the scene as it appeared in his investigation. He volunteered the information that when he arrived the defendant was in the kitchen "brushing his teeth. I think the purpose of that was maybe to get the odor of alcohol from his breath." This comment precipitated a motion for a mistrial, which was overruled. The court admonished the officer to answer the questions as asked, and directed the jury to disregard the gratuitous testimony as being totally unresponsive. Officer Morgan then testified that the defendant [***3] said he had shot his nephew for fear of his life. Officer Donald Corbin also summarized his part in the investigation. Mrs. Elizabeth Robinson, the deceased's widow, said that her husband did not come home from his night shift at Buckeye Steel on June 29, 1974. She conceded that the deceased took "nerve pills" and drank alcohol. She also testified that she was aware defendant owned a gun. The state's final witness, Richard C. Fisher, criminologist for the city of Columbus, stated that the weapon used in the shooting would not discharge automatically.

Upon motion of counsel for defendant at the close of the state's case, the trial court reduced the charge against defendant from aggravated murder to murder.

The defendant's case included seven witnesses, in addition to his own testimony. There was evidence that defendant and the deceased had a disagreement some time prior to the shooting. Further, the record indicates the deceased had said he was going to "get him [the defendant] one way or another." Charles Siders, a neighbor, testified that just before the shooting he heard a car stop, with tires squealing and gravel flying; and that he saw a man with a beer bottle get out,  [***4] go to defendant's house, and enter. The defendant, his wife, and Vernon Burnett, stated that they were in the basement when they heard someone upstairs. Mrs. Robinson went up to see who it was. The deceased descended the stairs into the basement, and there was an altercation between him and the defendant. There is some conflict as to what actually happened, but the two men went upstairs. The defendant then went up to the second floor to get his gun and came down the stairs to the ground floor. It was there the shooting occurred. The defendant called the police. Carl Robinson, a cousin of the deceased, testified concerning a time when he and the deceased engaged in a fight and the deceased apparently used a knife on him. Don Vest, who worked for the defendant, testified concerning an incident when he, the defendant, and the deceased were out drinking together, at which time the deceased became angry and pushed him into a brick wall.

The state, as noted above, called three rebuttal witnesses. Two police officers indicated that the information given by Mrs. George Robinson and Mr. Burnett the day of the shooting was somewhat different from their trial testimony. Further, Mrs.  [***5] Ronald Robinson, the decedent's wife, gave a different version of an incident when she, the defendant, and his wife were allegedly threatened by the deceased with a butcher knife.

At the close of the evidence, the defendant moved for acquittal, and was overruled. Counsel for defendant objected to several parts of the court's charge. After the jury retired, it requested the court to repeat the charge. The court refused to repeat the entire charge, but charged upon voluntary manslaughter and self-defense. Counsel for defendant reiterated his previous objections. Subsequently, the jury returned a verdict of guilty of voluntary manslaughter, and judgment was entered upon the verdict.

Defendant perfected an appeal to the Court of Appeals, setting out four assignments of error. The Court of Appeals reversed, and sustained three of the assignments of error, which related to the trial court's instructions to the jury. The court overruled the fourth, which claimed error in the failure to grant a mistrial after the unresponsive answer of Officer Morgan.

The cause is before this court upon the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The court granted review of the State's challenge to a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which reversed defendant's conviction for voluntary manslaughter.


OVERVIEW: On appeal from defendant's conviction of voluntary manslaughter, the court of appeals reversed, and sustained three of the assignments of error, which related to the trial court's instructions to the jury. The State appealed and the court granted review. The first issue was whether the trial court committed prejudicial error by instructing the jury that defendant bore the burden of proving his affirmative defense of self-defense by a preponderance of the evidence. The court affirmed the reversal of defendant's conviction. Pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2901.05(A), the State had the burden of proof beyond a reasonable doubt through the trial, and the burden did not shift to defendant. The court agreed with the court of appeals that the charge to the jury was erroneous in imposing upon defendant the burden of proving self-defense by a preponderance of the evidence and that that error was prejudicial. Defendant admitted that he killed the deceased; the sole issues in the case were those of mitigation and justification.


OUTCOME: The judgment reversing defendant's voluntary manslaughter conviction was affirmed.

 

167 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Waller


No. 76-12


Supreme Court of Ohio


47 Ohio St. 2d 52; 351 N.E.2d 195; 1976 Ohio LEXIS 673; 1 Ohio Op. 3d 32



July 14, 1976, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

Appellee, Stanley Waller, was charged on October 12, 1974, in the Hamilton County Municipal Court with a misdemeanor offense of having a deadly weapon, to wit, a knife, concealed upon his person in violation of R. C. 2923.12. On December 3, 1974, the trial court granted a motion by appellee to suppress the knife as evidence. On December 9, 1974, the state of Ohio filed a notice of appeal in the trial court stating therein: "This appeal is taken pursuant to Rule 12(J), Ohio Rules of Criminal Procedure." The notice of appeal contained the requisite certifications required in the first paragraph of Rule 12(J). No proceedings were instituted by appellant pursuant to R. C. 2945.67 through 2945.70, or otherwise, to obtain leave to appeal. Thereafter, the record was transmitted to the Court of Appeals and briefs were filed.

On November 24, 1975, the Court of Appeals, sua sponte, dismissed the appeal for want of jurisdiction. On January 23, 1976, upon appellant's motion, the record of the case was certified to this court for review and final determination, as being in conflict with the unreported decision of the Court of [***2] Appeals for Lucas County in State v. Edgeworth, C. A. No. 7947, November 14, 1975.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals, Hamilton County (Ohio), which dismissed the State's appeal for want of jurisdiction. The State had sought review of a decision by the trial court to suppress evidence of a knife in a case in which defendant was charged with a misdemeanor offense of having a deadly weapon, to wit, a knife, concealed upon his person, a violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2923.12.


OVERVIEW: The issue before the court was the constitutionality of Ohio R. Crim. P. 12(J) upon which the State solely relied in perfecting its appeal to the court of appeals. The court held that the procedural steps provided for in Ohio R. App. P. 5(A), respecting leave to appeal and the time limitations in Ohio R. App. P. 4(A), which included the seven-day time limitation as to Ohio R. Crim. P. 12(J) appeals, were applicable in criminal appeals by the state. The court held that the requirements delineated in Ohio R. Crim. P. 12(J) of certification by the prosecuting attorney, the seven-day time limitation, diligent prosecution, and the recognizance provision were matters of procedure in implementation of the limited statutory right of appeal and properly promulgated under the constitutional grant of rule authority to the court. The court held that these were valid procedural requirements to which the prosecution was required to adhere. The court held that inasmuch as the State had perfected its appeal solely upon reliance on Ohio R. Crim. P. 12(J), and failed to obtain leave to appeal from the court of appeals, the judgment of the court of appeals, dismissing the appeal, was affirmed.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals.

 

168 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Cincinnati v. Kelley


No. 75-919


Supreme Court of Ohio


47 Ohio St. 2d 94; 351 N.E.2d 85; 1976 Ohio LEXIS 677; 1 Ohio Op. 3d 56



July 14, 1976, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

On the afternoon of June 15, 1974, patrolman Eugene Depue received a radio message that there was an intoxicated person in an automobile on Walnut Street in the city of Cincinnati, appellant herein. After locating the vehicle and asking the occupant, appellee Edward Kelley, to step out, Officer Depue observed that Mr. Kelley was in an intoxicated condition. Kelley was then arrested and charged with being in actual physical control of a vehicle while under the influence of alcohol, in violation of Section 506-1 of the Cincinnati Municipal Code.

Appellee entered a plea of not guilty and waived his right to a jury trial. At the trial, Officer Depue testified that when he arrived on the scene, the automobile was legally parked; that appellee was seated in the driver's seat with his hands on the steering wheel and the keys in the ignition; and that the engine was not running.

According to appellee, he had driven downtown early in the morning, while completely sober, and lawfully parked on Walnut Street. After drinking at a bar, he realized he was in no condition to drive and, sometime between 12:00 P. M. and 1:00 P. M., went [***2] back to his car and lay down on the front seat. He stated he did not leave the car until about 3:00 P. M., at which time he called his wife and requested her to come and get him. Kelley testified further that when he returned to the car he again lay down upon the front seat and that he was arrested shortly thereafter. Additionally, it was uncontroverted that the driver's seat belt, which had to have been in use in order for the engine to be started, was not fastened.

At trial, appellee was found guilty as charged. The Court of Appeals reversed the conviction, finding that the "actual physical control" aspect of the ordinance must relate to operation of a vehicle and, in the case before it, the factor of operation was absent.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city sought review of a decision of the Ohio Court of Appeals, which reversed a trial court's decision entering appellee driver's conviction for being in actual physical control of a vehicle while under the influence of alcohol, in violation of Cincinnati, Ohio, Mun. Code § 506-1. The cause was before the court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.


OVERVIEW: A police officer found the driver in an intoxicated state in the driver's seat of his car with his hands on the steering wheel and the keys in the ignition. However, the engine was not running and the driver's seat belt, which had to be in use in order for the engine to be started, was not fastened. The appellate court found that the "actual physical control" aspect of the ordinance related to the operation of a vehicle and the factor of operation was absent. Reversing the appellate court's decision, the court ruled that the driver was in "actual physical control" of his vehicle, within the meaning of the ordinance. The court reasoned that the term "actual physical control" was required to relate, in a reasonable manner, to the prevention of the operation of vehicles by intoxicated persons. The record supported a conclusion that the driver was under the influence of alcohol and was in actual physical control of the vehicle at the time of his arrest. The court rejected the driver's argument that the ordinance was unconstitutional, holding that no conflict existed between the ordinance and Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4511.19, which excluded physical control as a possible statutory offense.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the appellate court, which reversed a trial court's entry of the driver's conviction for being in actual physical control of a vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.

 

169 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Bruno


No. 75-1092


Supreme Court of Ohio


47 Ohio St. 2d 98; 351 N.E.2d 82; 1976 Ohio LEXIS 678; 1 Ohio Op. 3d 58



July 14, 1976, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lake County.

Marvin Bruno, appellee herein, was charged in a two-count indictment returned by the Lake County grand jury with the offenses of endangering children proscribed by R. C. 2919.22(A). On March 21, 1975, appellee moved to dismiss the indictment upon the ground the statute was unconstitutional by reason of facial vagueness. On April 25, 1975, the trial court sustained the motion. On May 8, 1975, appellant filed with the Court of Appeals a document characterized by that court as a "Petition for Permission to File Bill of Exception." The bill of exceptions, which had been previously filed with the trial court, was attached to the petition as an exhibit. On May 27, 1975, the Court of Appeals, by entry, granted permission to file the bill of exceptions. The bill of exceptions was thereafter filed, followed by briefs. On August 28, 1975, appellee moved to dismiss the appeal. The Court of Appeals, without passing upon the merits of the appeal and treating the petition as a motion for leave to appeal, dismissed the appeal for the reason that appellant had not filed a notice of appeal concurrently with its motion for leave to appeal,  [***2] citing as authority State v. Wallace (1975), 43 Ohio St. 2d 1. This cause is before this court upon the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged in a two-count indictment with the offenses of endangering children pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2919.22(A). The trial court dismissed the action. The Court of Appeals for Lake County (Ohio) granted the State permission to file a bill of exceptions. Defendant moved to dismiss the appeal. The State sought review of the decision from the court of appeals, which dismissed the appeal.


OVERVIEW: The pivotal issue in the appeal was whether the requirement in a recent case that appeals by the State shall be governed by the procedural requirements of Ohio R. App. P. 5 and the time requirement of Ohio R. App. P. 4(B), were retroactive or prospective in application. The court found that Ohio R. App. P. 4(B) and Ohio R. App. P. 5 governed appeals by the State from only those orders and judgments which become final after July 2, 1975. Since the judgment of dismissal by the court of appeals rested upon an application of such rules to an appeal from an order entered prior to July 2, 1975, and the appeal was otherwise properly perfected pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 2945.67 through 2945.70, the judgment was reversed and the cause remanded for further proceedings. Because the holding applied only prospectively, it was error to dismiss the appeal for failure to file a notice of appeal, as none was required.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals.

 

170 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Armour & Co. v. Kosydar


No. 75-601


Supreme Court of Ohio


46 Ohio St. 2d 450; 349 N.E.2d 301; 1976 Ohio LEXIS 659; 75 Ohio Op. 2d 502



June 23, 1976, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

Armour & Co. (hereinafter Armour) is a foreign corporation doing business in the state of Ohio. That business consists primarily of the manufacture and sale of food and dairy products.

After an audit of Armour's records, the Tax Commissioner of Ohio issued franchise tax arrearage certificates for the return years 1966-1968, and a franchise tax assessment for 1969, based upon his assignment of an Ohio situs to a portion of Armour's investments in subsidiary corporations, and his consequent increase in the "property" fraction of Armour's franchise tax formula. R. C. 5733.05.

During the audit period here in question, Armour owned shares in a number of other corporations, including all the shares of Baldwin-Lima-Hamilton, Armour Agricultural Chemical Co., and Armour Industrial Product Co.; and 81.6 percent of the shares of Armour-Dial Inc. A portion of the physical property of each of those corporations is located in Ohio.

Armour perfected a timely appeal to the Board of Tax Appeals, objecting to the Ohio situs assigned its investments, and contending that the Ohio situs was unconstitutional as applied to appellant. The board affirmed the [***2] order of the Tax Commissioner, and refused to pass upon appellant's constitutional claim.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayer sought review of an order of the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which affirmed a decision of appellee state tax commissioner regarding franchise taxes owed by the taxpayer under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5733.05, based on his assignment of an Ohio situs to a portion of the company's investments in subsidiaries, and a consequent increase in a property factor used in the company's franchise tax formula.


OVERVIEW: The numerator of the factor defined by § 5733.05 was determined by the value of property owned or used by the company in Ohio. The dispute concerned the situs of intangibles, consisting of shares of stock of the taxpayer's subsidiary corporations. On appeal, the court held that (1) the intangibles were to be valued in accordance with the value of physical property in and out of the state under § 5733.05, without regard to guidelines in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 5709.02 and .03; (2) the rule applied to the subsidiaries after a spin-off, just as it did before the spin-off; (3) cases cited by the taxpayer to support arguments of unconstitutionality were not applicable because the tax imposed by the commissioner was not a tax on intangibles, but upon a reasonable approximation of the value of the taxpayer's corporate franchise in Ohio, and it bore a real and reasonable relation to the privilege granted or to the protection of the state's interests; and (4) the equal protection clause was not violated because the allocation of the taxpayer's interest in the subsidiaries was based upon a true distinction, was not patently arbitrary, and was reasonably related to a legislative interest.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the Board.

 

171 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Dayton Newspapers, Inc. v. Phillips


No. 75-1036


Supreme Court of Ohio


46 Ohio St. 2d 457; 351 N.E.2d 127; 1976 Ohio LEXIS 661; 75 Ohio Op. 2d 511; 1 Media L. Rep. 1237



June 11, 1976, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN PROHIBITION.

This case involves charges of kidnapping, extortion and aggravated murder. Extensive publicity in the media followed the kidnapping of a prominent Dayton citizen, the announcement of the payment of a $ 400,000 ransom, the discovery of the murder and the arrest and indictment of the alleged perpetrators of the crime, including the defendant, Moore.

Moore moved for a change of venue.

Moore then filed motions to suppress evidence. In response to another motion by Moore, the trial court closed the courtroom, excluded the public and barred the press from publishing any news report about what is to transpire in the courtroom hearing to be held by the judge on the motions to suppress.

The cause before this court is an original action in prohibition, brought by relators, two Dayton daily newspapers, seeking to prohibit the enforcement of the court's order excluding the press from the judicial hearing on the motions to suppress and ordering the newspapers not to publish a news report of what transpires at such hearing. An alternative writ of prohibition was allowed.



DISPOSITION: Writ allowed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator daily newspapers filed an action in prohibition seeking to prohibit the enforcement of respondent court's order excluding the newspapers from a judicial hearing and ordering them not to publish a news report of what transpired at the hearing.


OVERVIEW: Relator daily newspapers filed an action in prohibition seeking to prohibit the enforcement of respondent trial court's order excluding the press from a judicial hearing on a criminal defendant's motions to suppress and ordering the newspapers not to publish a news report of what transpired at the hearing. The court determined that an action in prohibition was the appropriate remedy for the relief sought and that the newspapers had standing to maintain the action. The court held that a change of venue was the proper alternative for the trial court to use to avoid a denial of defendant's right to a fair trial by reason of prejudicial publicity. The court found that the trial court's order abridged the freedom of the press and that such abridgment was prohibited by U.S. Const. amend, I and Ohio Const. art. I, § 11. The court determined that Ohio Rev. Code Ann § 2901.12(I) gave the trial judge adequate power to protect the defendant's constitutional right to an impartial jury, and, at the same time, to preserve the constitutional right of freedom of the press for the benefit of the public.


OUTCOME: The court granted a writ of prohibition to prohibit the enforcement of respondent court's order excluding relator daily newspapers from a judicial hearing and ordering them not to publish a news report. The court found that the trial court's order abridged the freedom of the press and that such abridgment was prohibited by the First Amendment.

 

172 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Sorin v. Board of Education


No. 75-606


Supreme Court of Ohio


46 Ohio St. 2d 177; 347 N.E.2d 527; 1976 Ohio LEXIS 613; 75 Ohio Op. 2d 224



May 12, 1976, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

Appellee, Morris Sorin, was hired by appellant, Board of Education of Warrensville Heights School District, by resolution adopted May 20, 1968, to serve as superintendent of the Warrensville Heights School District. The parties entered into a three-year contract to effectuate the purpose of the aforesaid resolution, which by its terms commenced August 1, 1968, and was to expire July 31, 1971.

However, sometime during the second year of this contractual period the parties began to experience certain differences of opinion. These difficulties resulted in three members of the appellant, board of education, on March 9, 1970, asking appellee to tender his resignation. On March 16, 1970, appellee complied with this request, but due to the parties' failure to agree upon the effective date of said resignation, appellee subsequently withdrew his tender of resignation.

Whereupon, the appellant drafted numerous charges against appellee, and suspended him effective March 23, 1970, pending final determination of the aforesaid charges. Pursuant to the provisions of R. C. 3319.16, as it existed at that time, appellee demanded [***2] a public hearing before the board of education.

On April 23, 1970, the hearing commenced, and continued almost daily for five months. On September 28, 1970, upon consideration of the record consisting of over 11,000 pages of testimony and 367 physical exhibits, the board of education, by a vote of three to two, terminated appellee's contract retroactive to March 23, 1970.

On September 29, 1970, appellee filed a petition of appeal to the Court of Common Pleas of Cuyahoga County pursuant to R. C. 3319.16. On March 13, 1974, the Court of Common Pleas issued a memorandum of opinion reversing the decision of the board of education. In its opinion, the court held that appellee had been denied due process of law in the proceedings before the board of education because the members of the board of education comprising the tribunal before whom the charges were heard were biased and prejudiced, and because the charges filed against appellee were "vague, general, not specific and therefore not in compliance with the statute." Accordingly, the court entered judgment for the appellee "for the full salary and contract benefits for the period of suspension less any funds earned by him during [***3] said period in the like or similar capacity in the educational field and costs." The court also held that appellee should recover his attorney fees "as proper costs of these proceedings based upon a hearing to be held in which appropriate evidence is to be submitted for reasonable fees by plaintiff's [appellee's] counsel."

On April 4, 1974, the court held an evidentiary hearing for the purpose of determining the reasonable value of the services rendered by appellee's counsel.

On April 19, 1974, the Court of Common Pleas entered its judgment, in which appellee was awarded the sum of $ 17,279.83, representing salary and contract benefits less deductible earnings for the period of suspension, and the sum of $ 62,867.13, representing "reasonable attorney fees and costs."

Upon appeal to the Court of Appeals, the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas was affirmed in its entirety.

On June 6, 1975, appellant filed its notice of appeal to this court in the Court of Appeals. In its notice of appeal, appellant sought to appeal only that part of the decisions below awarding attorney fees to appellee. On September 18, 1975, this court granted appellant's motion to certify as so limited.

 [***4] The cause is now before the court for decision upon the merits.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant board of education (board) challenged the order of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's reversal of the board's decision to terminate appellee superintendent's contract. The board appealed only that portion of the lower court's opinion affirming the award of attorney fees to the superintendent.


OVERVIEW: After the superintendent refused to tender his resignation at the board's request, the board drafted numerous charges against the superintendent which ultimately resulted in the termination of his contract. The trial court reversed the board's decision and awarded the superintendent compensatory damages and attorney fees, and the lower appellate court affirmed the judgment in its entirety. On appeal, the court held that the American rule did not permit the superintendent, as the prevailing party, to recover attorney fees in the absence of statutory authorization. The court held that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3319.16 did not provide statutory authorization for the recovery of attorney fees in the superintendent's case. The bad faith, vexatious, wanton, obdurate, or oppressive conduct exception to the American rule did not apply in the case.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the portion of the lower court's order affirming the award of attorney fees to the superintendent.

 

173 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Wilson v. Cincinnati


No. 75-622


Supreme Court of Ohio


46 Ohio St. 2d 138; 346 N.E.2d 666; 1976 Ohio LEXIS 607; 75 Ohio Op. 2d 190



May 5, 1976, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

In December 1973, the city of Cincinnati enacted two ordinances modifying and amending its building code.

Ordinance No. 556-1973, Section CC-3-47.03, provided, in pertinent part:

"Whereas, the city of Cincinnati desires to preserve quality in its housing inventory; and

"Whereas, in most of the city, existing housing is only inspected on a complaint basis; and

"Whereas, the city of Cincinnati desires to protect its citizens from housing which is a threat to their health and safety; and

"Whereas, the city of Cincinnati desires to provide more effective information to prospective housing purchasers * * *.

"Sec. CC-3-47.03. Certificate of Housing Inspection.

"(A) Every owner of improved real property intended for use as residential housing, prior to entering into a contract for the sale of that property, shall tender to the prospective buyer and obtain from the prospective buyer his signed acknowledgment of the receipt of a copy of a Certificate of Housing Inspection, issued by the Director of Buildings and Inspections on the subject property within 180 days of the entering into the contract for sale.

"* * *

"(C)  [***2] The Director of Buildings and Inspections shall issue a Certificate of Housing Inspections within fourteen (14) days after gaining access to all structures upon the realty and when:

"(1) The owner or his authorized agent applies in writing to the director, agrees to a time during the working hours of the Department of Building and Inspections during which the subject property will be available for inspection, and pays to the City Treasurer the following fees: * * *.

"* * *

"(D) In every sale of realty to which this section applies, the seller shall warrant that the structure is in substantial compliance with Chapter CC-77 of the Cincinnati-Ohio Building Code and the provisions of the Cincinnati Zoning Code pertaining to use and occupancy at the time of the contract for sale, except where the seller has obtained and presented to the buyer a Certificate of Housing Inspection or where the buyer has actual knowledge of the deficiencies in the structure at the time of the contract for sale. The buyer shall be presumed not to have knowledge of any deficiencies unless:

"(1) The buyer signs a written statement which specifically notes each deficiency, or

"(2) The buyer derives a substantial [***3] portion of his income from the business of real estate operations or is otherwise actively engaged in the business of real estate operations.

"Any action to enforce the provisions of the warranty imposed by this section shall be brought within two years of the time of the entering into the contract for sale.

"* * *

"(F) Any person, being the owner or agent of improved realty subject to the provisions of this section, who fails to tender a Certificate of Housing Inspection to a prospective buyer in accordance with the provisions of this section shall be subject to penalty as provided in Section CC-3-64 COBC. The absence of deficiencies in the subject property or the buyer's actual knowledge of any deficiencies shall not be a defense to the failure to tender a Certificate of Housing Inspection."

Ordinance No. 557-1973, stated, in part:

"* * * any person who violates any of the provisions of Section CC-3-47.03(F) shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be subject to a penalty of a fine of not less than $ 5.00 nor more than $ 500.00."

Subsequently, the Cincinnati Board of Realtors, Inc., and Chester J. Wilson filed an action for declaratory judgment in [***4] the Court of Common Pleas, asserting that the ordinances were unconstitutional and invalid, and seeking an injunction against their enforcement. Appellant and cross-appellee herein, Vivian E. Wilson, was then added as a plaintiff by an amended complaint.

After dismissing the Cincinnati Board of Realtors and Chester Wilson for lack of standing, the court held that the ordinances were unconstitutional and enjoined the city from acting under their provisions.

The Court of Appeals found that Ordinance No. 556-1973 was a valid exercise of the city's police power in that it bore an adequate relationship to the public health, safety and general welfare. However, the court determined that subsection (F) and Ordinance No. 557-1973 in its entirety were contrary to the Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution; that the presumption within subsection (D), and the two exceptions thereto, were arbitrary and unreasonable; and, that the two year limitation of action established by subsection (D) was in conflict with state law and was invalid.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant claimant sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which found that a certain ordinance was a valid exercise of appellee city's police power in that it bore an adequate relationship to the public health, safety, and general welfare. Appellee sought review of a determination that the ordinance was contrary to the Fourth Amendment.


OVERVIEW: Appellant claimant filed an action for a declaratory judgment in a trial court, asserting that appellee city's ordinances were unconstitutional and invalid, and seeking an injunction against their enforcement. A lower court found that Hamilton County, Ohio, Ordinance No. 556-1973 was a valid exercise of appellee's police power, but determined that Hamilton County, Ohio, Ordinance No. 557-1973 was contrary to the Fourth Amendment. Both parties sought review pursuant to a motion to certify the record. The court affirmed the lower court's judgment, finding that the enactment of the ordinance was not an exercise of the powers of local self-government. The court determined that the coercion represented by the sole alternative of possible criminal prosecution negated any consent, which could have been inferred from the allowance of a building inspection, and therefore the validity of such searches upon the basis of consent was not sustainable. The court found that the provisions of 557-1973(F) could not be constitutionally enforced. The court agreed with the lower court that the presumption in 556-1973(D), and the exceptions thereto, had to be declared to be arbitrary and invalid.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed a lower court's finding that appellee city's ordinance was a valid exercise of police power and that a subsection of the ordinance was contrary to the Fourth Amendment because the enactment of the ordinance was not an exercise of local self-government powers, coercion by possible criminal prosecution could not be the basis of consent, and two subsections of the ordinance could not be constitutionally enforced and were invalid.

 

174 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Boyer v. Boyer


No. 75-1029


Supreme Court of Ohio


46 Ohio St. 2d 83; 346 N.E.2d 286; 1976 Ohio LEXIS 599; 75 Ohio Op. 2d 156



April 28, 1976, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Licking County.

The subject of this cause is a custody dispute over George Bryan Boyer, Jr., who turned eight years old in March 1976.

Prior to going on the road with a carnival in 1968, George's parents, Sandra L. Boyer, appellant herein, and George Bryan Boyer, Sr., appellee herein, left George with his paternal grandparents when he was a few months old. George has continually resided with his grandparents since that time.

On September 17, 1973, after his mother had made several demands for his return, the grandparents filed a petition in the Probate Court of Fairfield County to adopt George. That petition was dismissed by operation of R. C. 3107.06(B), which requires the consent of each parent who has not wilfully failed to properly support and maintain the child. The Court of Appeals affirmed that judgment on November 8, 1974. The court determined that the grandparents had voluntarily assumed the obligation to support George, that the mother was not guilty of wilful failure to support George, and that, therefore, the petition would be dismissed.

During the pendency of the adoption proceeding, the Court of Common Pleas of Licking [***2] County on July 16, 1974, granted an uncontested divorce to appellant, and reserved the matter of George's custody.

The custody hearing commenced on December 13, 1974. Appellee urged that custody be granted to the grandparents, and appellant requested that she be granted custody. Appellant testified that she was not employed, that she had not sought employment, that she was receiving aid to dependent children payments, and would support George on an increase in such payments.

Fifteen witnesses and over 200 pages of transcript provided a thorough inquiry into the life-styles and home environments of the proposed custodians.

The court issued an oral order, which reads:

"I find it in the best interest of the child * * * to award the custody to neither of the parents, but to award the custody of this child to Esther Boyer [the grandmother], with reasonable visitation to Sandra L. Boyer.

"I am not making a finding that either party is unfit to have the custody of this child, I am saying that it is for the best interest of this child to make this order."

Subsequently, the court issued findings of fact and conclusions of law, pursuant to Civ. R. 52, which found, inter alia: (1) that [***3] "neither parent [is] unfit," (2) "that the child has resided with his paternal grandparents since infancy, and they are suitable and willing to care for the grandchild," (3) "that it would be for the best interest of said child to be awarded to the paternal grandmother, Esther C. Boyer," (4) "that the child's interactions and interrelationship with the paternal grandparents has been excellent and to the child's best interest," (5) that "the child's adjustment to the paternal grandparents home and community has been excellent," and (6) that "the child's mental and physical health and the paternal grandparents mental and physical health is excellent."

The court concluded that under R. C. 3109.04, as amended September 30, 1974, an award of custody to a nonparent could be made in the absence of finding both parents unfit, and that it was in the best interest of George for custody to be awarded to his grandmother.

The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment, and this court allowed a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a custody action, appellant mother challenged a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Licking County (Ohio) granting custody of her son to the child's paternal grandparents pursuant to Ohio R. Civ. P. 75(P). The mother contended that Ohio R. Civ. P. 75(P) conflicted with Ohio Rev. Code § 3109.04.


OVERVIEW: The mother and father left the child with his paternal grandparents when he was a few months old, and the child continually resided with his grandparents after that time. The lower court concluded that the parents were not unfit but that it was in the child's best interest for the grandparents to have custody of the child. The court affirmed the order. The court held that that the conflicting portions of Ohio R. Civ. P. 75(P) and Ohio Rev. Code § 3109.04 dealt with matters of substantive law and that the statute controlled. The court also held that the lower court properly applied the provisions of Ohio Rev. Code § 3109.04. The court stated that where the rights of the mother conflicted with the interests of the child, the best interests of the child controlled.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order granting the paternal grandparents custody of the minor child.

 

175 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Bailey v. Martins Ferry


No. 75-639


Supreme Court of Ohio


46 Ohio St. 2d 95; 346 N.E.2d 317; 1976 Ohio LEXIS 602; 75 Ohio Op. 2d 162



April 28, 1976, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Belmont County.

In November 1972, the city of Martins Ferry enacted Ordinance No. 6234, which stated, in part:

"All vehicles using alleys, streets and highways of the city of Martins Ferry shall, when hauling dirt, coal, ashes, fly ash, gravel, sand, rubbish, garbage, or anything else of an unsightly or unsanitary nature, which can fall or be blown from said vehicle on to the alleys, streets, highways, sidewalks and property adjacent thereto in the city of Martins Ferry, must cover said vehicle with a tarpaulin or other cover which shall prevent any dust, dirt, coal, ashes, fly ash, gravel, sand, rubbish, garbage, or anything else of an unsightly or unsanitary nature, or any material from being dropped or being blown from said vehicle."

Appellees are primarily engaged in the business of transporting coal. Subsequent to the passage of the ordinance, a number of drivers of trucks owned or operated by appellees were arrested for failing to comply with its provisions.

Consequently, appellees filed a complaint in the Court of Common Pleas of Belmont County, seeking a declaratory judgment that the ordinance was unconstitutional and requesting [***2] a permanent injunction against its further enforcement.

The court upheld the validity of the ordinance and found it to be neither in conflict with the general laws of the state nor discriminatory.

The Court of Appeals reversed, holding that the ordinance was in conflict with R. C. 4511.06 and 4513.31.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city sought review of an order of the Court of Appeals for Belmont County (Ohio), which reversed a trial court's ruling that upheld the validity of Martins Ferry, Ohio, Ordinance No. 6234, which required trucks hauling certain materials to use a tarpaulin. The court of appeals held that the ordinance was in conflict with Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 4511.06, 4513.31.


OVERVIEW: Appellee truckers brought the underlying suit to test the validity of the ordinance, claiming that it was in conflict with statutory law, and was therefore contrary to Ohio Const. art. XVIII, § 3. Municipalities had the authority to exercise all powers of local self-government and to adopt and enforce within their limits such local police, sanitary, and other similar regulations, as were not in conflict with general laws. On review the court held that the trucker's argument could not be sustained. The court held that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4511.06 was not part of the general laws and did not provide a basis upon which a conflict could be asserted. The court noted that in determining whether an ordinance was in conflict with general laws, the test was whether the ordinance permitted or licensed that which the statute forbade and prohibited, and vice versa. The primary purpose of the legislation was to keep public roads and adjacent areas free from debris. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4513.31 did so my mandating that each vehicle be properly constructed so as to prevent spillage. Although the means might differ slightly, the ordinance did not prohibit that which the statute permitted.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals and affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

 

176 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Dvorak v. Municipal Civil Service Com.


No. 75-879


Supreme Court of Ohio


46 Ohio St. 2d 99; 346 N.E.2d 157; 1976 Ohio LEXIS 603; 75 Ohio Op. 2d 165



April 28, 1976, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Athens County.

Allan Dvorak, appellant, was appointed to the position of fireman in the Athens Fire Department by letter dated March 29, 1973, posted by the mayor of that city. The letter opened with the language:

"In accordance with certification from the Athens Civil Service Commission * * * and Section 143.20 of the Ohio Revised Code * * *.

"The appointment to this position is effective April 1, 1973 for a probationary period of one year. * * *"

Mr. Dvorak accepted the appointment and worked as a fireman until he received a latter dated April 2, 1974, from the same mayor advising him that he had been denied permanent employment and confirming verbal notification of termination given him by the mayor the previous day. The letter further advised him of his right to appeal "as provided in the civil service laws of the state of Ohio." Defendant's counsel attempted to appeal the removal issued by the appointing authority to the civil service commission of the city of Athens. A motion to dismiss the appeal for the reason that appellant had no right to an appeal was granted by the commission, said order being received by appellant on May [***2] 9, 1974. On May 15, 1974, appellant's counsel filed a notice of appeal to the Court of Common Pleas of Athens County "[p]ursuant to Ohio Revised Code Section 124.34 and Ohio Revised Code Section 2506.01 et seq. * * * on questions of law and fact * * *."

An affidavit requesting a trial de novo pursuant to R. C. 2506.03 was filed by appellant's counsel on July 3, 1974. Counsel for the Municipal Civil Service Commission of the city of Athens filed a motion for summary judgment on July 8, 1974, "because there is no genuine issue as to any material fact." The motion was supported by an affidavit signed by the mayor. A memorandum contra the motion for summary judgment was filed on July 12, 1974.

However, on October 21, 1974, the Court of Common Pleas, by judgment entry, granted appellee's motion for summary judgment. A notice of appeal was duly filed in the Court of Appeals for Athens County, which affirmed the decision of the lower court. On November 17, 1975, the Court of Appeals was directed to certify its record to this court.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant public employee challenged the decision from the Court of Appeals for Athens County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's grant a motion for summary judgment in favor of appellee Municipal Civil Service Commission's of the City of Athens, in the employee's action for judicial review of the termination of his employment.


OVERVIEW: After certification by the Commission, the employee was appointed as a fireman for a one year probationary period. One year and one day after his appointment, he was denied permanent employment and notified of his termination. He appealed to the Commission. His appeal was dismissed on the grounds that he had no right to an appeal. The employee sought judicial review, pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 124.34, 2506.1 et seq. The appellate court affirmed the trial court's grant of the Commission's motion summary judgment. The employee appealed. On appeal, the court reversed and held that a motion for summary judgment could not lie on the basis of the record because the record did not contain evidence that a hearing was conducted before the employee was terminated. The court noted that, under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2506.04, the trial court was required to exercise an appellate function limited to determining whether the decision of the Commission was unconstitutional, illegal, arbitrary, capricious, unreasonable, or unsupported by the preponderance of substantial, reliable, and probative evidence on the whole record.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's decision, which had affirmed the trial court's grant of the Commission's motion for summary judgment in the employee's action for judicial review of his denial of permanent employment and termination.

 

177 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Maloney v. Rhodes


No. 75-1049


Supreme Court of Ohio


45 Ohio St. 2d 319; 345 N.E.2d 407; 1976 Ohio LEXIS 582; 74 Ohio Op. 2d 499



March 19, 1976, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

This is an action filed in the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County seeking a declaratory judgment and injunctive relief. It was filed by Michael J. Maloney, plaintiff, as a citizen and taxpayer, against defendants, Governor James A. Rhodes, Secretary of State Ted W. Brown, Clerk of the Ohio Senate William Chavanne, Speaker of the House Vernal Riffe, and all the duly elected and qualified members of the Senate, except the plaintiff.

Six bills were passed by each house of the General Assembly by the required majority vote and signed by the Speaker of the House and by Governor Gilligan. The Lieutenant Governor, who, under the Ohio Constitution, Section 16, Article III, is the President of the Senate, did not sign any of the bills. The Clerk of the Senate did not present the bills to the presiding officer of the Senate, who was available, for his signature, but instead presented the bills directly to the Governor for his signature. Governor Gilligan signed each bill and had the signed laws delivered to the Secretary of State to be filed. The Secretary of State refused to file them and instead delivered them to Governor [***2] Rhodes, the successor to Governor Gilligan in the office of Governor. Governor Rhodes did not file them with the Secretary of State, but retained possession of them.

The plaintiff seeks a declaratory judgment declaring Amended House Bills Nos. 18 and 44, Substitute House Bill No. 43, and Amended Senate Bills Nos. 3, 4 and 5 null and void, and also prays for a permanent injunction prohibiting the defendants from implementing or purporting to act under the six bills.

The trial court entered a judgment issuing an injunction prohibiting the Secretary of State from accepting and filing the laws, and prohibiting Governor Rhodes from signing and/or filing the laws with the Secretary of State.

The Court of Appeals affirmed that judgment.

The cause is before this court upon the allowance of a motion to certify the record and an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, the Governor, Secretary of State, Clerk of the Ohio Senate, Speaker of the House, and members of the Ohio Senate (state officials), challenged the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which affirmed the judgment that issued an injunction prohibiting the Secretary of State from accepting and filing certain laws and prohibiting the Governor from signing and filing those laws with the Secretary of State.


OVERVIEW: Each house of the General Assembly passed six bills, but the President of the Senate did not sign any of the bills. Instead, the Governor signed the bills, but the Secretary of State refused to file them. Appellee taxpayer filed an action for injunctive relief and for a judgment declaring those bills null and void. The trial court issued an injunction prohibiting the Secretary of State from filing the laws and prohibiting the Governor from signing and filing the laws with the Secretary of State. The court of appeals affirmed the judgment, but the court reversed and ordered the Governor to deliver the laws to the Secretary of State, who was ordered to file them. Under the Ohio Constitution, the Governor, having signed the bills, was required to file them, and the Secretary of State had no authority to decline to file them. The validity of the laws was a judicial decision. However, the court declared each law constitutionally invalid on the ground that the constitutionally mandatory signature-certification of the President of the Senate did not appear on any of the bills to certify that the procedural requirements had been met, as required by Ohio Const. art. II, § 15(E).


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment that affirmed the issuance of an injunction against the state officials. The Governor was ordered to deliver to the Secretary of State the laws in question, and the Secretary of State was ordered to file such laws. The court declared those laws constitutionally invalid.

 

178 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Sun Finance & Loan Co. v. Kosydar


No. 75-105


Supreme Court of Ohio


45 Ohio St. 2d 283; 344 N.E.2d 330; 1976 Ohio LEXIS 574; 74 Ohio Op. 2d 434



March 17, 1976, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

Appellee, Sun Finance & Loan Company (hereinafter referred to as Sun), is an Ohio corporation primarily engaged in the sales and consumer finance business in Ohio. Sun operates its finance business through hundreds of offices located in approximately ten states, including Ohio.

Sun is the parent corporation, with numerous subsidiary corporations wholly owned by it, and operated as separate corporate divisions.

For each of the tax years pertinent to this appeal (1967-1971), a number of Sun's subsidiaries were either incorporated in, or qualified to do business in, Ohio, while others were not.

Based upon business done during the calendar years 1966 through 1970, inclusive, Sun filed consolidated dealer-in-intangibles returns in the taxable years 1967 through 1971, inclusive. In computing the tax base applicable to such consolidated returns, Sun totaled the net worth of all its Ohio subsidiaries and the net worth of all out-of-state subsidiaries controlled by it, regardless of whether such out-of-state subsidiaries operated offices within Ohio or were incorporated.

Upon audit, the Tax Commissioner recomputed certain assessments, and [***2] arrived at total corrected net worth figures for the years involved herein, which corrected figures were accepted by Sun.

On May 22, 1972, Sun filed an application for a refund based upon the March 28, 1972, decision of the Board of Tax Appeals in Midland Guardian Company v. Kosydar, B. T. A. No. 71-01-0224. This refund application pertained to the tax years 1967 to 1970, inclusive. Subsequently, Sun filed a second refund application pertaining to tax year 1971.

The Tax Commissioner denied both refund applications, whereupon Sun filed notices of appeal to the Board of Tax Appeals on June 26, 1974.

The causes were consolidated for hearing before the Board of Tax Appeals. On January 7, 1975, the board upheld Sun's claim for refund of a portion of the dealer-in-intangbles tax paid by Sun during the tax years 1967 to 1971, inclusive.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Decision reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant Ohio Tax Commissioner sought review of the decision by the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which upheld appellee taxpayer's application for a refund of a portion of the dealer-in-intangibles tax paid by it for four tax years. The Commissioner alleged that the taxpayer's business done by its out-of-state finance subsidiaries that did not operate in Ohio should not be included in the Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5725.15 apportionment formula.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer was a Ohio corporation engaged in the sale of consumer financing. It operated its business in 10 states, including Ohio. The taxpayer was the parent corporation, with numerous subsidiary corporations wholly owned by it under it. The subsidiaries were operated as separate corporate divisions. Some of the subsidiaries were qualified to do business in Ohio, while others were not. When calculating its net worth for all its subsidiaries for dealer-in-intangibles tax returns, the taxpayer included the net worth of all its Ohio subsidiaries and all the out-of-state subsidiaries controlled by it. It then applied for a refund for the inclusion of the out-of-state income. The tax appeals court granted the application. The court reversed that decision and held that the out-of-state subsidiaries should not be included in the apportionment formula in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5725.15 because in order to qualify as a dealer in intangibles, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5725.01(B) required that the taxpayer's subsidiaries have an office or other place of business within Ohio. Because the taxpayer chose to operate its business in this manner, its out-of-state subsidiaries were not "dealers."


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision of the tax appeals court granting the taxpayer a refund on a portion of the dealer-in-intangibles taxes paid by it for four years and denying the Commission's claim for payment of taxes by the taxpayer.

 

179 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Heimann v. George


No. 75-1153


Supreme Court of Ohio


45 Ohio St. 2d 231; 344 N.E.2d 130; 1976 Ohio LEXIS 563; 74 Ohio Op. 2d 376



March 10, 1976, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

On July 16, 1975, relator, Elaine A. Heimann, filed an action in prohibition in the Court of Appeals, seeking to restrain respondent, Paul J. George, Judge of the Court of Common Pleas of Hamilton County, Division of Domestic Relations, from proceeding in a divorce action pending before him, "known as Edward A. Heimann v. Elaine A. Heimann, case No. A755163," which was filed on June 25, 1975. Relator alleges that her husband has set forth as grounds for divorce, R. C. 3105.01(K), effective May 7, 1974, and commonly known as "the two-year separation statute." The Court of Common Pleas had, on December 3, 1974, previously entered a "decree for alimony, support and custody of children" in an earlier divorce action filed by Mr. Heimann in July of 1973.

The Court of Appeals granted respondent's motion to dismiss, for the reasons that the court lacked jurisdiction over the subject matter of the complaint and that the complaint failed to state a claim upon which relief could be granted.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to an appeal as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.

 

180 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Washington Court House v. McStowe


No. 75-614


Supreme Court of Ohio


45 Ohio St. 2d 228; 343 N.E.2d 109; 1976 Ohio LEXIS 562; 74 Ohio Op. 2d 333



March 3, 1976, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Fayette County.

At approximately 1:00 a. m. on September 1, 1973, Washington Court House police officers executed a search warrant at the apartment of Robert M. George, 418 South Fayette Street. The officers seized an undetermined quantity of marijuana and other related paraphernalia, placed each of those individuals present, including appellant, Deborah M. McStowe, under arrest, and transported them to the police station. Appellant was charged with violating ordinance No. 45-72, which provides in relevant part:

"* * * [I]t shall be unlawful for any suspicious person to be in the city. The following shall be deemed suspicious persons:

"* * *

"(B) Any person who keeps, frequents, operates, lives in, loiters in or around, is found in, or around, or is employed in any home, place, room or establishment where narcotic drugs, hallucinogen, or similar drugs are sold or used, in violation of any ordinance or state or federal law. * * *"

Subsequently, appellant was tried and convicted in the Municipal Court. Upon appeal, her conviction was affirmed.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION:  [***2] Judgment reversed.

 

181 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


In re Proposed Annexation by Columbus City School Dist.


No. 75-230


Supreme Court of Ohio


45 Ohio St. 2d 117; 341 N.E.2d 589; 1976 Ohio LEXIS 545; 74 Ohio Op. 2d 215



February 11, 1976, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

This consolidated appeal challenges the validity of the transfers of 15 parcels of land to the Columbus and Upper Arlington school districts pursuant to R. C. 3311.06. Each parcel transferred to these school districts had been annexed to the respective cities for municipal purposes prior to the requests for transfer for school purposes.

Upon receiving the transfer requests, the State Board of Education referred the matter to a referee for hearings. On April 12, 1971, the State Board of Education considered the referee's report and voted to approve all the transfers. The execution of the transfer resolutions has been stayed during this litigation.

The transfer resolutions were appealed to the Court of Common Pleas, and the appeals consolidated for purposes of review. That court, after admitting additional testimony and evidence, rendered its decision finding that each of the transfer resolutions was based upon reliable, probative and substantial evidence.

The Court of Appeals, in separate judgment entries, affirmed the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas.

The cause is presently before this court pursuant to the allowance [***2] of a motion to certify the record. Appellants present to this court the single claim, which was preserved in the assignments of error below, that R. C. 3311.06 is unconstitutional.



DISPOSITION: Judgments affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant local board of education challenged the validity of judgments from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's judgments that affirmed the state board of education's transfer of 15 parcels of land to two local school districts pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3311.06.


OVERVIEW: The trial court affirmed the state board's transfer of all 15 parcels of land to two local school districts under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3311.06. The appellate court consolidated two appeals and affirmed the trial court's judgment. On appeal, the local board contended that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3311.06 was unconstitutional in that it gave the state board no standards or guides to follow in determining whether territory should be transferred to the school district following a partial annexation for municipal purposes. The appellate court's judgments were affirmed. The court held that Ohio Const. art. II, § 26 expressly sanctioned both the delegation of legislative authority by the general assembly in § 3311.06 and the exercise of that authority by the state board.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgments affirming the trial court's judgment affirming the state board's approval of all the transfers.

 

182 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Niemeyer v. Collins


No. 75-685


Supreme Court of Ohio


45 Ohio St. 2d 63; 341 N.E.2d 847; 1976 Ohio LEXIS 533; 74 Ohio Op. 2d 117



January 28, 1976, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

On December 4, 1974, the Tax Commissioner issued a cigarette tax jeopardy assessment against appellant pursuant to the provisions of R. C. 5743.082.

On December 31, 1974, appellant filed a petition for reassessment with the Tax Commissioner, which was dismissed. Appellant then filed a notice of appeal with the Board of Tax Appeals.

The board, finding that "[w]ithin the five days after appellant received notice of the jeopardy assessment she neither furnished evidence satisfactory to the Tax Commissioner regarding payment, return, or collection of the tax, nor did she post a bond with the Tax Commissioner," dismissed the appeal for the reason that it had no jurisdiction to hear the matter since appellant failed to comply with the provisions of R. C. 5743.082.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayer challenged a decision of the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which dismissed the taxpayer's challenge to a cigarette tax jeopardy assessment made by appellee Ohio Tax Commissioner.


OVERVIEW: The Tax Commissioner issued a cigarette tax jeopardy assessment against the taxpayer pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5743.082. The taxpayer did not pay the tax, but filed a petition for reassessment with the Commissioner, which was dismissed. The taxpayer then filed a notice of appeal with the Board of Tax Appeals. The Board dismissed the appeal for the reason that it had no jurisdiction to hear the matter because the taxpayer failed to comply with the provisions of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5743.082. The taxpayer sought judicial review, and the court affirmed the Board's decision. The taxpayer claimed that application of § 5743.082 was unconstitutional. The court held that the requirement of payment of the tax as a condition precedent to testing its correctness and validity did not violate the Due Process provision. The court held that the Board's decision was neither unreasonable nor unlawful.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the Board's decision dismissing the taxpayer's appeal of the assessment.

 

183 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Howland Realty Co. v. Wolcott


No. 3077


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh Appellate District, Trumbull County


8 Ohio App. 3d 424; 457 N.E.2d 883; 1982 Ohio App. LEXIS 11291; 8 Ohio B. Rep. 548



December 30, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant residents sought review of an order from the trial court for Trumbull County (Ohio), which held in favor of appellee realty company in its declaratory action and found that an amended zoning regulation sought by the residents and passed by township trustees was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The realty company replatted its undeveloped lots and planned to build duplexes on them. The residents, who owned single-family homes near the undeveloped lots, applied for a zoning change to restrict construction of the undeveloped lots to single-family homes. The trustees amended the area's zoning and prohibited duplexes. The realty company filed a declaratory action seeking to have the new zoning amendment declared unconstitutional. The trial court held in favor of the realty company. The residents sought review and argued that under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 519.12, the realty company failed to exhaust their administrative remedies regarding the zoning by failing to seek a referendum to change the new zoning change, and that it was erroneous to declare the zoning amendment unconstitutional. The court found that § 519.12 provided for the trustees' decision to become law unless it was challenged in court, that there was no duty imposed on the realty company to seek a referendum, that duplexes had been permitted for over 20 years in that area, and that the realty company's lots were the only lots where duplexes were prohibited.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's decision.

 

184 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State -vs- Stidham


NO. 9-109


COURT OF APPEALS, ELEVENTH APPELLATE DISTRICT, LAKE COUNTY, OHIO


1982 Ohio App. LEXIS 12062



December 30, 1982 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged a decision from the trial court (Ohio), which convicted him of murder. Defendant claimed that the trial court erred in instructing the jury that defendant was required to establish self-defense by a preponderance of the evidence thus impermissibly shifting the burden of proof, in giving partial and confusing instructions in response to jury questions, and in allowing the State to withhold a witness's out-of-court statements.


OVERVIEW: The common law husband of defendant's sister arrived at defendant's home to persuade the sister to move back to their apartment. Upon his arrival a disturbance began and defendant's mother called the police. The victim left soon after the police arrived but returned later in the day and threatened to stab himself and defendant's sister. Defendant picked up a shotgun and fired two shots into the victim. At the time defendant entered the room, his sister had disarmed the victim. Defendant was convicted of murder. Defendant contended he acted in defense of another person.
