In affirming the conviction on appeal, the court held that: (1) defendant's position that he acted in defense of another did not negate the "purposely" element of Ohio Rev. Code § 2903.02(A), and thus the imposition upon defendant of the burden of going forward with the evidence of the defense was proper; (2) defendant failed properly to preserve his objection to the trial court's response to a jury question; and (3) because the sister, who was scheduled as a prosecution witness, was not a co-defendant, the trial court did not err in refusing to compel discovery of her prior statements and grand jury testimony.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for murder.

 

185 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Pauley


No. 44886


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth Appellate District, Cuyahoga County


8 Ohio App. 3d 354; 457 N.E.2d 864; 1982 Ohio App. LEXIS 11280; 8 Ohio B. Rep. 466



December 23, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of the decision from the trial court (Ohio), which convicted defendant of having a weapon while under disability in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2923.13. Defendant had also been indicted for carrying a concealed weapon in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2923.12, and carrying a concealed weapon in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2923.12. The trial court overruled the pretrial motions to suppress.


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued that the trial court erred in overruling defendant's motion to suppress because the police did not have reasonable articulable suspicion to conduct an investigative stop and frisk of defendant. The court determined that the officers had probable cause to believe a crime was in progress, and their belief was a justifiable inference from their observations and their experiences. There was no constitutional right to carry concealed weapons. The legislative classification under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2923.13(A)(2) prohibiting a person under indictment for any felony of violence from knowingly carrying a firearm did not violate the Fourteenth Amendment's Due Process Clause. The statute did not infringe upon defendant's fundamental right to bear arms as guaranteed by the Ohio Constitution and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment from the trial court.

 

186 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Cleveland -vs- Constantine


NO. 44751


COURT OF APPEALS, EIGHTH APPELLATE DISTRICT, CUYAHOGA COUNTY, OHIO


1982 Ohio App. LEXIS 12157



December 23, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM CLEVELAND MUNICIPAL COURT, No. 81-CRB-25034


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The City appealed a decision by the Cleveland Municipal Court (Ohio), which suspended a 10-day mandatory sentence that was imposed upon defendant after she was convicted of solicitation in violation of Cleveland, Ohio, Municipal Code § 619.09.


OVERVIEW: The municipal court suspended defendant's mandatory 10-day prison sentence after finding that Cleveland, Ohio, Municipal Ordinance § 619.09(B) violated the separation of powers doctrine, the right to trial by jury, and the right to due process, and imposed cruel and unusual punishment. The court reversed, upholding the ordinance's constitutionality against all defendant's challenges. The ordinance did not violate the separation of powers doctrine because it was the role of the legislature, and not the judicial branch, to determine sentence lengths. Thus, the city council had the power to establish mandatory sentencing for solicitation. Defendant's right to a jury trial was not violated by a prosecutor's alleged practice of allowing defendants to choose to plead guilty to a violation of the ordinance instead of the state statute. Defendant's due process rights were not violated because the ordinance bore a rational relationship to the legitimate city interest of promoting safety and public health. Finally, the sentence imposed was not cruel and unusual. The cause was remanded for resentencing.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision of the trial court suspending defendant's mandatorily imposed sentence and remanded the cause for further sentencing.

 

187 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Shady Acres Nursing Home, Inc. v. Rhodes


No. 82AP-352


COURT OF APPEALS, TENTH APPELLATE DISTRICT, FRANKLIN COUNTY, OHIO


1982 Ohio App. LEXIS 12537



December 23, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL from the Franklin County Common Pleas Court.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator nursing home filed a complaint for a writ of mandamus to compel respondents, a state governor and a director of the Ohio Department of Public Welfare (ODPW), to audit the nursing home's records and to adjust its Medicaid payments. The nursing home dismissed and then reopened the complaint, and when the Franklin County Common Pleas Court (Ohio) adopted a referee's recommendation to deny the writ, the nursing home sought review.


OVERVIEW: The nursing home provided skilled nursing services to Medicaid patients and sought to compel the director to adjust its payments for the years 1974 through 1976. On review, the court sustained the nursing home's seven assignments of error, finding that ODPW at the time was without statutory authority to impose an additional requirement that construction costs for various categories were to exceed specified terms because Am. Sub. H.B. 221, Gen. Assem. (Ohio) was not yet effective. Similarly, ODPW was without authority to impose ceilings on several line items of the cost reports because Ohio Admin. Code § 5101:3-3-20 was not yet in effect. Ohio Admin. Code § 5101:3-3-22 was unreasonable because the nursing home would be required to pay increased payroll taxes in the report year but would not be reimbursed on the prospective rate until 1978. Even if ODPW's prospective rate method of reimbursement was a reasonable interpretation, such interpretation was not established as a rule pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 119.03 and 119.04. Because no statutory authority existed and no rules were lawfully promulgated, ODPW could not lawfully initiate a prospective system of payments.


OUTCOME: The court reversed and remanded for further proceedings for a determination of what was due to the nursing home.

 

188 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State vs. Bentz


NO. C-810908


COURT OF APPEALS OF OHIO, FIRST APPELLATE DISTRICT, HAMILTON COUNTY


1982 Ohio App. LEXIS 11859



December 22, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM THE COURT OF COMMON PLEAS HAMILTON COUNTY, OHIO


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed the decision of the Court of Common Pleas of Hamilton County (Ohio), which convicted them of pandering obscenity in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2907.32.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were indicted by a grand jury of pandering obscenity and were found guilty of the charged offenses. The trial judge had allowed the prosecution to admit new evidence, which was part of its case in chief, at the close of trial, but denied defendants of the opportunity to reopen their defense to rebut the evidence. Following their convictions, defendants appealed. The court held that, because the evidence was offered by the prosecution as part of their case in chief, rather than as rebuttal evidence, defendants were entitled to defend against the new evidence. The court found that the trial court's refusal to allow defendants to respond to the new evidence, despite the timing of its introduction, was reversible error and that defendants were entitled to a new trial as a result of the error.


OUTCOME: The court, finding that defendants were denied a fair trial, reversed defendants' convictions for pandering obscenity and remanded the matter for a new trial.

 

189 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Carolyn Louise Blankenship v. Ulm


NO. 10710


COURT OF APPEALS, NINTH APPELLATE DISTRICT, SUMMIT COUNTY, OHIO


1982 Ohio App. LEXIS 12294



December 15, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM JUDGMENT ENTERED IN THE COMMON PLEAS COURT PROBATE DIVISION COUNTY OF SUMMIT, OHIO, CASE NO. C 82 2 54


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant mother sought review of the judgment from the Probation Division of the Common Pleas Court of Summit County (Ohio), which dismissed her case for legitimization of her child. The trial court agreed with appellee father that pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2105.18, only he could institute an application for legitimization. The mother claimed that the trial court's ruling violated the equal protection clause of U.S. Const. amend. XIV.


OVERVIEW: The mother, who was not married to the father, filed an application for legitimization of her child. The trial court dismissed the action, finding that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2105.18 allowed only the natural father of a child to institute the proceeding. On appeal, the court found that the appeal did not center on the constitutionality of the concept of legitimacy; rather, the question was whether or not the legislature intended to abolish illegitimacy by enacting § 2105.18. The court concluded that the intent of the legislature in enacting § 2105.18 was to permit, not command, fathers to legitimize their illegitimate children. The court reasoned that § 2105.18 stated that the natural father of a child could file an application for legitimacy, and concluded that the legislature obviously did not intend to involuntarily commit someone to the legal relationship of father-child; hence the wording "may" in the statute. The court added that had the legislature intended otherwise, it would have made the process mandatory by including the word "shall" in the statute.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

190 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Bosworth


Nos. 82AP-392 and 82AP-393


COURT OF APPEALS, TENTH APPELLATE DISTRICT, FRANKLIN COUNTY, OHIO


1982 Ohio App. LEXIS 12390



December 14, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL from the Franklin County Municipal Court.



DISPOSITION: Judgments affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged the judgment of the Franklin County Municipal Court (Ohio), which convicted him of operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol and changing lanes without caution. Defendant moved to suppress the evidence of alcohol test results and testimony concerning the tests. The trial court overruled the motion.


OVERVIEW: The arresting officer obtained a urine sample from defendant. Defendant alleged that the trial court erred in admitting the urinalysis test. On appeal, the court held that a presumption existed that the urinalysis was valid, and that the trial court did not err in admitting the test result. The court noted that defendant did not object to the trial court's instructions concerning such presumption. The court stated that since the trial court admitted all other evidence except the use of the term "usual individual," defendant's assignment of error was otherwise moot. Further, the court ruled that the fact that the officer did not refrigerate the urine sample went to the weight of the test result as evidence and not the result's admissibility. The court indicated that there was no sign that the assistant prosecutor acted with any intent to influence the jury when he moved to the lectern. The court concluded that the trial court's instruction on "under the influence of alcohol" was correct, and that the trial court did not err by refusing to allow defense counsel to use the word "intoxicated" in connection with the charge against defendant pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4511.19.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's convictions.

 

191 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


C. E. Angles, Inc. v. Evans


NO. 82AP-635


COURT OF APPEALS, TENTH APPELLATE DISTRICT, FRANKLIN COUNTY, OHIO


1982 Ohio App. LEXIS 13125



December 14, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL from the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed; Case remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, a building contractor, its owner, and an association of builders and contractors, appealed an order of the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County (Ohio), which, in plaintiffs' action against defendant Director of the Ohio Department of Industrial Relations challenging the constitutionality of a state prevailing wage law, granted the Director's motion for summary judgment on the ground of plaintiffs' lack of standing.


OVERVIEW: The contractor was a member of the association and a non-union employer that paid its workers based on a wage scale lower than that set forth in the state prevailing wage law. The contractor was required under such law to utilize a higher wage scale in computing its bid for a public project, which was then awarded to a lower bidder. Plaintiffs brought an action against the Director for a declaration that the law was unconstitutional. The trial court granted the Director's motion to dismiss for lack of standing, and plaintiffs appealed. The court found that because the association and the contractor sought to enjoin performance of the public contract, they were entitled to seek additional relief under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2721.09, including an injunction to prevent the contract's execution; thus, if the wage law was held unconstitutional, plaintiffs might be entitled to such relief. The court thus held that the association and the contractor had standing. Because the owner believed that the contract was in contravention of constitutional law, he had standing as a taxpayer under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 309.12, 309.13 and was not required to meet the common law tests for standing.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order dismissing plaintiff's action and remanded for further proceedings.

 

192 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State vs. Holt


NO. CA-2074


COURT OF APPEALS, FIFTH APPELLATE DISTRICT, RICHLAND COUNTY, OHIO


1982 Ohio App. LEXIS 13718



December 14, 1982 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Common Pleas Court of Richland County, Ohio, convicted and sentenced defendant, upon defendant's plea of no contest, for carrying a concealed weapon, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2923.12(A), and complicity to commit attempted felonious assault, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2923.02(A). Defendant appealed.


OVERVIEW: Defendant met with another person twice and stated that he would be willing to pay someone to beat up a third party. At the time of the second meeting, the other person was working in conjunction with the sheriff's department. Defendant provided the other person with photographs of the third party and other relevant information, and defendant made a partial payment. After the other person confirmed that defendant was armed during that second meeting, a deputy sheriff stopped defendant's vehicle and took him into custody. Defendant confirmed that he was armed and indicated where the weapon was located. On appeal, defendant claimed the trial court erred in overruling his motion to suppress evidence because his arrest was unlawful and unconstitutional. Defendant also argued that the trial court erred in overruling his motion to dismiss the count of the indictment that charged him with attempted felonious assault or complicity in an attempted felonious assault. The appellate court held (1) that defendant's arrest was not unlawful, and (2) that defendant's conduct went beyond mere acts of preparation and included acts that were a substantial step towards the commission of the offense.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment that convicted and sentenced defendant for carrying a concealed weapon and complicity to commit attempted felonious assault.

 

193 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Mollenkopf


No. 1259


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh Appellate District, Portage County


8 Ohio App. 3d 210; 456 N.E.2d 1269; 1982 Ohio App. LEXIS 11252; 8 Ohio B. Rep. 281



December 10, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the decision of the Portage County Municipal Court (Ohio) convicting him of telephone harassment, in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2917.21(A)(5).


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2917.21(A)(5), which made it a crime for a person to call a premises, having been previously told by anyone at that premises not to call, was impermissibly vague in its application and, therefore, unconstitutional. The court held that § 2917.21(A)(5) gave defendant sufficient notice that he was prohibited from calling the complainant's residence after having been told not to call there. Accordingly, the court affirmed defendant's conviction.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for telephone harassment.

 

194 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Lyman Steel Co. -VS- Lindley Comm.


NO. 44531


COURT OF APPEALS , EIGHTH APPELLATE DISTRICT CUYAHOGA COUNTY, OHIO


1982 Ohio App. LEXIS 11314



December 9, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] 
APPEAL FROM BOARD OF TAX APPEALS COURT No. 80-D-39



DISPOSITION: Both branches of taxpayer's assignment of error are overruled and the judgment of the Board of Tax Appeals is affirmed


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayer sought review of a decision of the Ohio Board of Tax Appeals, which affirmed appellee state tax commissioner's determination that the taxpayer owed personal property tax on allegedly exempt imported inventory listed on its tax return.


OVERVIEW: On appeal the taxpayer argued that the additional assessment resulted from an unconstitutional retroactive application of a tax auditor's bulletin. The taxpayer manufactured and fabricated steel products. A tax auditor bulletin was issued and the taxpayer was assessed a deficiency on its tax return. The court held that the Ohio Supreme Court had previously approved retroactive application of federal decisions for pre-1976 imports. The court further held that the application of the bulletin to the taxpayer's return was constitutional. There was no application of a statutory amendment or new enactment. The bulletin was merely an instructional or informational notice of the impact of an Ohio Supreme Court case on personal property taxation under already existing Ohio statutes. The taxpayer's sole disadvantage from retroactive application was the loss of a special tax immunity but the court noted that the loss of a special preference was not a sufficient hardship to prevent retroactive application. Finally, the court concluded that the bulletin was not an invalid regulation.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

195 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State v. Nelson


NO. 10745


COURT OF APPEALS, NINTH JUDICIAL DISTRICT, SUMMIT COUNTY, OHIO


1982 Ohio App. LEXIS 14498



December 8, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM JUDGMENT ENTERED IN THE CUYAHOGA FALLS MUNICIPAL COURT COUNTY OF SUMMIT, OHIO, CASE NOS. 82 CRB 335, 82 CRB 336


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment from the Cuyahoga Falls Municipal Court, County of Summit (Ohio), which convicted him of two counts of pandering obscenity, pursuant to Ohio. Rev. Code Ann. § 2907.32(A)(5).


OVERVIEW: On two occasions, a police officer entered an adult bookstore and purchased obscene books and magazines from defendant. Defendant, who indicated that he was a salesperson at the store, also answered the officer's questions concerning the availability of other titles and videotapes. On appeal, the court held that defendant's motion for acquittal under Ohio R. Crim. P. was properly overruled. The testimony demonstrated that defendant worked in the store and did sell the material to the officer. Defendant also testified that he was aware of the nature of the material in which the store traded. In addition, the trial court did not have to permit evidence of contemporary community standards. The only instance related to such standards was defendant's knowledge of the availability of cable television service in the area of the bookstore. Such information was not probative of the community standards. Defendant's testimony was also inadmissible on such standards because there was no indication that he was an expert in the filed or that his testimony would clarify the issue of the triers of fact.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

196 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Cleveland -vs- Kasarda


NO. 44398


COURT OF APPEALS OF OHIO, EIGHTH APPELLATE DISTRICT, CUYAHOGA COUNTY


1982 Ohio App. LEXIS 12161



December 6, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM CLEVELAND MUNICIPAL COURT, No. 81-CRB-23211


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a decision of the Cleveland Municipal Court (Ohio), which convicted defendant of disorderly conduct, Cleveland, Ohio, Codified Ordinance § 605.03.


OVERVIEW: Because there were questions regarding his age, defendant's friend was not allowed in a dance club. An exchange ensued between the club's security guard and defendant, which resulted in defendant's arrest. Defendant contended that the trial court erred in denying his motion for acquittal and motion to dismiss. Defendant also argued that jury instructions were improper. In affirming, the court held that the charging instrument was sufficient. According to the court, the complaint clearly advised defendant of the charges against him. The court also determined that § 605.03 was neither vague nor overbroad. Furthermore, the court noted that defendant's arrest and conviction under § 605.03(a)(1) did not violate any constitutionally protected right. The court found that the State established proof of each element of the crime charged. Finally, the court held that the instructions properly informed the jury of the charges against defendant and of possible dispositions that it could make.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the trial court.

 

197 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Davis -vs- East Liverpool


NO. 82-C-6


COURT OF APPEALS, SEVENTH APPELLATE DISTRICT, COLUMBIA COUNTY, OHIO


1982 Ohio App. LEXIS 13345



December 6, 1982 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellee property owners brought an action against appellee city asking the trial court (Ohio) to declare East Liverpool, Ohio, Codified Ordinance § 1133.01 unconstitutional. Appellant intervenors filed a motion for intervention. The trial court denied the motion and declared § 1133.01 unconstitutional. The intervenors sought review of the denial of their motion.


OVERVIEW: A declaratory judgment action having to do with zoning was filed in the trial court. On the day of trial, the intervenors filed their motion. Their attorney explained that she had intended to file the motion for over 20 days and requested a continuance so that she could prepare her case. The trial court denied the motion and proceeded with the trial. On appeal, the court held that Ohio R. Civ. P. 24(A) and (B), which dealt with the process of intervention, both opened with the phrase "upon timely application." The court determined that the original parties and the trial judge were in the courtroom prepared for trial. It was an act of discretion on the part of the trial court to determine that the application was not timely filed. The court concluded that an application to intervene accompanied with a request for continuance filed on the day of trial could not be considered timely. The court found no abuse of discretion. Finally, the court agreed with the trial court that East Liverpool, Ohio, Codified Ordinance § 1133.01 was unconstitutional because it conflicted with Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 713.15, a general law setting forth a rule of conduct for citizens.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

198 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State vs. McIntosh


NO. L-82-232


COURT OF APPEALS, SIXTH APPELLATE DISTRICT, LUCAS COUNTY, OHIO


1982 Ohio App. LEXIS 14421



December 3, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM LUCAS COUNTY COMMON PLEAS COURT NO. CR 81-7033


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged his conviction and sentence from the Lucas County Court of Common Pleas (Ohio) for aggravated trafficking of a controlled substance.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of aggravated trafficking for selling lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2925.03(A)(7). On appeal, the court affirmed the conviction and sentence, concluding that the mandatory sentencing range provided in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2925.03(C)(6) did not constitute cruel and unusual punishment under the Eighth Amendment of the United States Constitution or Ohio Const. art. I, § 9. The Eighth Amendment prohibited punishment that was grossly disproportionate to the severity of the crime. There was a reasonable basis for the legislature to segregate drug trafficking from other third degree felonies and the comparative gravity of criminal offenses and their injurious consequences were matters for the state to determine. Testimony presented by the State that defendant offered to sell 100 "hits" of LSD to an undercover police officer and accepted payment that was later found in his possession was sufficient to sustain the jury's guilty verdict. A person could offer to sell a controlled substance in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2925.03(A)(1) without transferring the drugs to the buyer.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's judgment of conviction and sentence.

 

199 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. - vs - City Council of the City of Youngstown


NO. 82 C.A. 9


COURT OF APPEALS, SEVENTH APPELLATE DISTRICT, MAHONING COUNTY, OHIO


1982 Ohio App. LEXIS 11440



December 1, 1982.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator clerk of courts sought a writ of mandamus compelling respondent city council to reinstate the reductions effected by them in her 1982 budget.


OVERVIEW: The clerk alleged that she had requested, by way of an estimated budget, reasonable and necessary monies for the operation of her office during 1982. The city council, by passage of an ordinance, enacted a quarterly budget rather than an annual or half-year budget. By way of said ordinance, the council reduced the clerk's estimated budget. The clerk requested that the court issue a writ of mandamus directing the council to reinstate the reductions effected by them in the budget of 1982. The court found that the financial shortage that existed was not of such proportion as to justify cuts in the clerk's budget so that the city could operate. If the council had granted the clerk's request, the operation of the city departments would not be impeded. The court further found that the council arbitrarily reduced the clerk's budget. The court held that the clerk was entitled to receive the salaries that she had requested. However, the court held that, as to equipment and supplies, the clerk was not entitled to an unquestioned appropriation of all money requested.


OUTCOME: The court granted the clerk relief in part by ordering the council to appropriate the money for the salaries that the clerk had requested in her budget. The remainder of the clerk's prayer for mandamus was denied.

 

200 of 1535 DOCUMENTS


Village Of Hudson v. Albrecht, Inc.


NO. 10684


COURT OF APPEALS, NINTH APPELLATE DISTRICT, SUMMIT COUNTY, OHIO


1982 Ohio App. LEXIS 11524



December 1, 1982 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM JUDGMENT ENTERED IN THE COMMON PLEAS COURT COUNTY OF SUMMIT, OHIO CASE NO. CV 81 3 0687


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, a general contractor and a business, challenged a judgment of the Common Pleas Court, County of Summit (Ohio), which ordered the general contractor and the business to submit window plans for a grocery store to appellee village in accordance with a local ordinance.


OVERVIEW: Hudson, OH, Ordinance § 1428.01 provided that no person could construct or alter any building or structure in the municipality, when the cost exceeded $ 50 or where the effect of the construction or alteration was to enlarge or affect the bearing walls of any building without having first secured a permit. The general contractor of a store changed the glass windows to windows made of solid materials without receiving the approval of the building inspector. The village filed a complaint against the business and the general contractor to restrain the business from occupying the building until the village issued a necessary building permit and certificate of occupancy. The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court. The court held that: (1) the trial court did not err in finding that the installation of stone aggregate panels had to be approved by the village's architectural and historic board of review; (2) the board of review could approve the plans without a hearing; and (3) the village's ordinances were constitutional.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court.
